text: Season 2, Episode 15: “Spellcaster”

headline: Chris Christie Shows Fondness for Luxury Benefits When Others Pay the Bill
text: As Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey waited to depart on a trade mission to Israel in 2012, his entourage was delayed by a late arrival: Mr. Christie’s father, who had accidentally headed to the wrong airport.

headline: In 2nd Year, Mayor de Blasio Will Focus on Making Housing Denser and More Affordable
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Tuesday is set to declare housing as the focal point of his second year in office, unveiling a vision for an even denser yet more affordable New York City that will transform neighborhoods from East Harlem in Manhattan to Staten Island’s North Shore.

headline: Rangers Put a Damper on the Panthers’ Postseason Hopes
text: Flush with young talent, and with a smattering of accomplished veterans, the Florida Panthers are the leading team among the Eastern Conference’s also-rans, perhaps the only squad outside the top eight that still has a chance at a playoff spot.

headline: Lindsey Vonn, Healthy, Will Have Momentum on Her Hometown Slopes
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Nearly two years after injuring her right knee in a horrific crash, Lindsey Vonn was primed to compete in Tuesday’s super-G, the opening race of the 2015 Alpine World Championships here.

headline: In Williamsburg Warehouse Fire, Lingering Risks of New York’s Analog Age
text: The fire that engulfed a Brooklyn warehouse over the weekend revealed how dependent government agencies and hospitals are on paper records, even in the age of digital media.

headline: Facts About the Measles Outbreak
text: A map of counties where cases have been reported so far this year, and a chart showing how the number of cases compares to previous years.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 3, 2015
text: “I watched him walk one block away. I turned around to go back upstairs, and that was the last time I saw him.”

headline: Drug Makers’ Data on Side Effects Is Called Lacking in a Report
text: The main system for keeping track of the dangerous side effects of prescription drugs is deeply flawed, primarily because drug makers are submitting incomplete information about the problems to the Food and Drug Administration, according to a new study by a nonprofit group that tracks drug safety issues.

headline: Super Bowl Was a Stunner, and That’s Just the Size of the TV Audience
text: The other day I suggested that even a lousy game can yield sensational Super Bowl viewership, which happened last year. But a game that is incredible, surprising, tightly played and has everything but an elf on the sideline deflating balls?

headline: Inside Mercado Roma, Mexico City’s Newest Foodie Destination
text: Tomorrow, more than 120 galleries from 22 countries will descend upon Mexico City for the 12th edition of the Zona Maco International Contemporary Art Fair. And this year, the art set has a new culinary destination to hit up between booth visits: Mercado Roma. Situated in the hipster neighborhood of La Roma, the bustling food market, which opened last summer, takes its cues from sleek stateside food halls like Manhattan’s Chelsea Market. There are communal tables set against a vertical garden out back, where guests can enjoy prepared foods and artisanal treats from approximately 60 vendors, most of whom produce local, farm-to-table dishes and desserts.

headline: New York Attorney General Targets Supplements at Major Retailers
text: The New York State attorney general’s office accused four major retailers on Monday of selling fraudulent and potentially dangerous herbal supplements and demanded that they remove the products from their shelves.

headline: What’s in Those Supplements?
text: The New York State attorney general’s office accused four national retailers on Monday of selling dietary supplements that were fraudulent and in many cases contaminated with unlisted ingredients.

headline: President Tweaks the Rules on Data Collection
text: WASHINGTON — A year after President Obama ordered modest changes in how the nation’s intelligence agencies collect and hold data on Americans and foreigners, the administration will announce new rules requiring intelligence analysts to delete private information they may incidentally collect about Americans that has no intelligence purpose, and to delete similar information about foreigners within five years.

headline: Retailers Are Warned Over Herbal Supplements
text: These cease-and-desist letters were sent to GNC, Target, Walgreens and Walmart by the New York State attorney general, who demanded that the retailers explain how they verify the ingredients in their herbal supplements.

text: viscous •\ˈvis-kəs\• adjective

headline: Obamacare, Back at the Supreme Court: Frequently Asked Questions
text: A list of frequently asked questions about the King v. Burwell Supreme Court case and its implications for Obamacare.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 2:30 P.M. (Sundance) THE KING’S SPEECH (2010) Colin Firth, in the role that won him an Oscar for best actor, portrays Albert Frederick Arthur George, or Bertie, as his family called him, the shy second son of George V of Britain (Michael Gambon) in this film from Tom Hooper. Geoffrey Rush is Lionel Logue, the speech therapist who helps Bertie conquer a debilitating stutter. And Helena Bonham Carter is Elizabeth, Albert’s wife and staunch support system, who can’t quite stomach Wallis Simpson (Eve Best), the American divorcée who leads Bertie’s older brother, David (Guy Pearce), to abdicate as Edward VIII. “It isn’t exactly ‘Pygmalion,’ not least because Mr. Hooper has no intention of satirizing the caste system that is one of this movie’s biggest draws,” Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, said of the film, which received 12 Oscar nominations and also won for best director, best picture and original screenplay. “Like many entertainments of this pop-historical type,” she added, “ ‘The King’s Speech’ wears history lightly no matter how heavy the crown.”

headline: Corrections: February 3, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Alibaba and Lending Club to Form Financing Partnership
text: The companies behind two of the hottest stock market debuts of 2014, Lending Club and the Alibaba Group, are teaming up — to help American companies buy parts from Chinese manufacturers.

headline: China Considers Whether to Allow Baijiu With Bling
text: Among the casualties in China’s continuing crackdown on corruption have been the spirits makers who sell to the country’s monied elite. With ostentatious imbibing now highly frowned upon, the makers of liquor like baijiu have seen serious hits to sales growth over the past two years.

headline: Central Banks in India and Australia Take Steps to Lift Growth
text: HONG KONG — Two more central banks have joined the growing international trend toward monetary stimulus as an antidote for weak global demand, as India on Tuesday reduced the reserves that commercial banks must hold while Australia cut its benchmark interest rate to a low.

headline: ‘Coming Out’ as Anxious
text: When I was 10, I was diagnosed with a collection of anxiety disorders. For the next three and a half decades, I hid my condition from those around me. I concocted elaborate explanations for the absences caused by my therapy appointments. I kept my medications out of sight. I generally did everything I could to project an aura of competence and confidence that was often at odds with the vulnerability, and sometimes the terror, that I felt.

headline: In New York State, a Chance for Major Reform
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Supreme Court’s Secret Decisions
text: CHICAGO — A CONVICTED murderer, Charles F. Warner, was executed in Oklahoma last month after the United States Supreme Court denied his request for a last-minute stay. Mr. Warner and other death-row inmates had challenged the state’s lethal injection procedures as unconstitutional. In a strange twist, the court agreed to hear his claims — a week after Mr. Warner had been executed.

headline: Support for Gay Marriage: What Our History Shows
text: To the Editor:

headline: Government Handouts at Wireless Auctions
text: Large telecommunications companies have repeatedly taken advantage of rules meant to help small, rural, female- and minority-owned businesses buy licenses for airwaves for wireless phone and data transmission, including in a recent auction that raised nearly $45 billion for the government. Congress and the Federal Communications Commission should crack down on such abuse.

headline: To Stop Violence, Start at Home
text: THE pattern is striking. Men who are eventually arrested for violent acts often began with attacks against their girlfriends and wives. In many cases, the charges of domestic violence were not taken seriously or were dismissed.

headline: Building Better Secularists
text: Over the past few years, there has been a sharp rise in the number of people who are atheist, agnostic or without religious affiliation. A fifth of all adults and a third of the youngest adults fit into this category.

headline: Arcapita Gets More Than $1 Billion in Sale of Pods
text: LONDON – The Bahrain private-equity firm Arcapita said on Tuesday that it had sold Pods, a moving and storage container company, to the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan in a deal worth more than $1 billion.

headline: Measles and the Vaccine Opponents
Reckless Rejection of the Measles Vaccine
text: It is bad enough that many misguided parents are endangering their own children by refusing to let them be vaccinated against measles and other contagious diseases. But it is shockingly irresponsible of them to put other children and adults at risk of catching measles from their unvaccinated children.

headline: Inside Syria’s Jails
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In the spring of 2011, hundreds of thousands of Syrians rose up in protest to demand democracy and freedom and an end to the dictatorship of President Bashar al-Assad. The response of the regime was to escalate the methods of repression that had been tried and tested against political opponents since the 1970s: arbitrary detention, disappearance and torture.

headline: Melody
text: In this short documentary, students in a youth orchestra program in Chile pursue their love of music to escape poverty.

headline: ‘Melody’
text: For more than two decades, my home country of Chile has had a stable democracy, as well as a thriving economy. At the same time, Chile has one of the largest wealth disparities in the world, reinforced by high tuition rates for secondary and college education.

headline: Banco Santander Profit Rises 69 Percent as Loan Provisions Decline
text: LONDON – Banco Santander of Spain reported on Tuesday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 69 percent as it continued to benefit from a decline in provisions for bad loans.

headline: South Korean Who Killed 5 Fellow Soldiers Is Sentenced to Die
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean Army sergeant was sentenced to death on Tuesday for killing five of his fellow conscripts and wounding seven others in a shooting rampage in June.

headline: BP Posts Net Loss of $4.4 Billion in Fourth Quarter
text: LONDON — BP on Tuesday reported a net loss of $4.4 billion in the fourth quarter of 2014, attributed mainly to write-offs of about $5.5 billion on the value of assets in the North Sea and Angola because of lower estimates of reserves and falling oil prices.

headline: What Would It Mean to 'Fix' No Child Left Behind?
text: The Elementary and Secondary Education Act is up for reauthorization. What is and isn't working?

text: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 1 review, “Super Bowl Commercials Go for Heart, Not Just Funny Bone and Jugular.”

text: In “A Boy Praises the Principal of His Brooklyn School, and a Fund-Raising Campaign Takes Off,” Winnie Hu and Jonah Bromwich write about a remarkable social media campaign that has raised money for a New York City public middle school.

text: Raul Roa has been a general-assignment photographer in Los Angeles for 20 years. He covers everything. The overturned tractor-trailer on I-5. The water polo meet at Glendale High. The protests in downtown Los Angeles after Ferguson. He does it all.

text: HONG KONG — Fiji will replace its national flag this year to remove symbols of British colonialism, Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama announced Tuesday.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing

headline: The Tough Path Facing Chris Christie and Marco Rubio
text: The end of Mitt Romney’s candidacy has brought the so-called invisible primary — the behind-the-scenes competition for the resources and credibility needed to win the nomination — into a new phase, with new players. Marco Rubio and Chris Christie, in particular, seem as if they might benefit. The two are racing against Jeb Bush to earn the support of Mr. Romney’s former supporters, according to my colleague Nicholas Confessore.

headline: China Proposal on NGOs Raises Transparency Concerns at U.N.
text: A proposal by China that would have withheld the names of countries that criticize nongovernmental organizations at the United Nations has drawn condemnation from diplomats and rights groups, citing concerns about transparency.

text: Good morning on this fiercely cold Tuesday.

headline: Daily Report: In Net Neutrality Plan, F.C.C. Chief Aims to Govern Web Like a Utility
text: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission this week is widely expected to propose regulating Internet service like a public utility, a move certain to unleash another round of intense debate and lobbying about how to ensure so-called net neutrality, or an open Internet, Steve Lohr reports.

headline: E.U. Focuses on Belgium in Tax Avoidance Inquiry
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union authorities on Tuesday broadened their drive against tax avoidance by multinational companies, opening an investigation into the way Belgium appeared to grant unfair state aid.

headline: Eddie Huang Against the World
text: On a cold, dark street in Tijuana, Mexico, I asked Eddie Huang a question that many people were sure to ask him in the months to come. “What did you expect?”

headline: Art for Money’s Sake
text: You could be forgiven for thinking the boxy structure that opened last November in Long Island City, Queens, with gray-and-white stripes flanking a blue frontispiece, was a bold new art museum. The modern-looking facility, built from the ground up at a cost of $70 million, is set to span 280,000 square feet when an adjacent building opens this spring. The complex will be packed with thousands of works of art, from old masters to contemporary rising stars. But unlike at a museum, few will ever see the works that live inside it.

headline: A Republican Joins Obama in Seeking Ties to Cuba
text: WASHINGTON — Two days before President Obama  ended a half-century of diplomatic estrangement with Cuba, his national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, asked Senator Jeff Flake of Arizona to be the only Republican on a secret flight to Havana to bring home a jailed American, Alan P. Gross — and to tell no one.

headline: Morning Agenda: The Road to S.&P.’s Settlement
text: THE ROAD TO S.&P.’S SETTLEMENT | An overflow crowd of government regulators, including attorneys general from states across the country, spent a day in January ticking off their demands before eventually negotiating a $1.37 billion settlement with the giant ratings agency Standard & Poor’s, Ben Protess reports in DealBook. The settlement, expected to be announced on Tuesday, was the culmination of a heated, two-year fight between S.&P. and the Justice Department, according to an account assembled through interviews.

headline: A Plan Is Slow to Take Shape
text: There were 60 million good reasons for Phil Jackson to accept the formidable challenge of rebuilding the Knicks along with one intangible benefit that could not be banked. Some might think the one he chose, however, borders on obsession: to resurrect his beloved triangle and prove to the world that it is an offense for the ages.

headline: London Theater Journal: A Harrowing Descent Into War
text: LONDON — The boys with the rifles separated us according to sex, the men forced into one group and the women into the other. Most of us complied, a startled and sheeplike herd.

headline: Tough Fedding
text: The monetary-policy gap between insiders and outsiders — between economists at the Fed and other policy institutions, who still seem eager to raise rates, and those of us on the outside, who think this is a really, really bad idea — continues to widen. This morning Tim Duy — one of the outsiders who, commenting from his perch at Mark Thoma’s invaluable blog, has seemed most sympathetic to the urge to hike rates — joins the what-are-they-thinking chorus. Core inflation is drifting downward, not upward, and is now well below the Fed’s target. So why hike?

headline: Comedy Material Woven From Real Life
text: Having worked together on and off for more than 40 years, Catherine O’Hara and Eugene Levy can withstand almost anything one says about the other, unless it is complimentary.

headline: Cisco Makes Its Annual Predictions on Mobile Data Traffic
text: If everybody has a smartphone, maybe we’ll soon just start calling them phones.

headline: When Spell-Check Can’t Help
text: Last week, we looked at near-miss word choices. This week, a roundup of homophone problems, many of them familiar by now. Put them on your list — and look them up every time if you need to.

headline: For Transgender Students, Business Schools Are a Transition
text: It was 2 a.m. when Danielle Piergallini composed an email to classmates at Vanderbilt University’s Owen Graduate School of Management announcing she was transgender. She had spent her first semester in the M.B.A. program presenting as male and worried what kind of response she would get after she clicked “send.”

headline: A University Recognizes a Third Gender: Neutral
text: Rocko Gieselman looked like any other undergraduate at the University of Vermont but perhaps a little prettier, with pale freckles dancing across porcelain skin and bright blue eyes amplifying a broad smile. Black bra straps poked out from a faded black tank top emblazoned with the logo of the indie band Rubblebucket; a silver necklace with an anchor dangled over ample décolletage.

headline: In Performance: Ryan Kasprzak and Joel Jeske of ‘Everybody Gets Cake!’
text: This week’s video features the performers Ryan Kasprzak and Joel Jeske in an excerpt from “Everybody Gets Cake!,” a new show from the comedy troupe Parallel Exit. The scene takes place at an unusually taxing taping of a public service announcement about Novocain abuse. In his review, Neil Genzlinger called the skit “pretty hilarious.” The show, directed by Mark Lonergan, continues through Feb. 8 at 59E59 Theaters.

headline: Viktor & Rolf Hop Off the Ready-to-Wear Treadmill
text: Well, this is a turn of the fashion wheel I did not see coming: A season after Jean Paul Gaultier announced he was closing his ready-to-wear line to concentrate on couture, the Dutch designers Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren, otherwise known as Viktor & Rolf, have followed suit.

headline: Grid Sensors Could Ease Disruptions of Power
text: For decades, utility companies have relied on customers telling them when their lights have gone off as a sign that there may be a broader power disruption. The utilities then send workers to drive along mile after mile of power lines, looking for tiny devices — little red circular tabs — that have popped up, signaling the source of the problem in the network.

headline: A Solo Traveler’s Guide to Meeting People
text: When you are traveling solo, it’s not always a breeze to strike up a conversation with a stranger.

headline: In London, an Olympic Park Anchors a Resurgence
text: Before London snagged the 2012 Olympic Games, Stratford — due east of Hackney, on the banks of the Lea River — was among the poorest areas of the capital, renowned mostly for its industrial pylons and its “fridge mountain,” an imposing fortress of discarded appliances, along its waterfront. More than nine years and £9 billion (about $13 billion) later, the industrial wetlands have been transformed into a gleaming sports and shopping hub.

headline: New York Times Co. Profit Falls Despite Strides in Digital Ads
text: The New York Times Company said on Tuesday that its annual operating profit declined in 2014 because of investments in digital journalism and severance costs from a round of job reductions. Revenue was flat as growth in digital advertising and circulation offset declines in its print business.

headline: CCTV Appoints Hosts for Lunar New Year Gala, With Some Surprises
text: Lunar New Year celebrations in China are typically marked by travel back home, dumplings with family members and, on New Year’s Eve, the Spring Festival Gala on China Central Television.

headline: S.&P.’s $1.37 Billion Reckoning Over Crisis-Era Misdeeds
text: Nearly a decade after credit ratings agencies became a symbol of a financial crisis they helped create, one of the industry’s biggest players faces a costly reckoning.

headline: Daily Clip Report
text: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Strange Interlude in the Subway
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Baccarat’s Crystal Palace
text: Not surprisingly, the new Baccarat Hotel, a grand mansion opening next month in midtown Manhattan, is a shiny affair. The French designers Patrick Gilles and Dorothée Boissier have adorned lamps, walls, arches and even armchairs with the company’s gleaming crystal. Thousands of backlit Harcourt tumblers — Baccarat’s most iconic design — flank the entrance, and tiered chandeliers hung from slack hemp-covered chains intensify deep red walls in the bar. The sumptuous guest rooms, bathed in crisp whites and grays, mix elegance with informality — which, says Boissier, “is so not French.”

headline: Saudi Oil Is Seen as Lever to Pry Russian Support From Syria’s Assad
text: WASHINGTON — Saudi Arabia has been trying to pressure President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to abandon his support for President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, using its dominance of the global oil markets at a time when the Russian government is reeling from the effects of plummeting oil prices.

headline: Obama Unveils 2016 FIscal Year Budget
text: The president discussed his budget for the next fiscal year at the Department of Homeland Security headquarters.

headline: A Gender-Neutral Glossary
text: SEX Classification as male or female or, rarely, intersex (not exclusively male or female). Sex is usually assigned based on external anatomy but is determined by characteristics like chromosomes, hormones and reproductive organs.

headline: Is Book Reviewing a Public Service or an Art?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Anna Holmes debate whether book reviewing should be considered a public service or an art.

headline: Richard Linklater and Ellar Coltrane on ‘Nerding Up’
text: Richard Linklater’s crowning cinematic achievement, “Boyhood,” seems locked neck-and-neck with Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s “Birdman” in the race for best picture. Yet way back in the early aughts, when Mr. Linklater decided to move ahead with his idea of filming a fictional family over a dozen years, he wasn’t sure if such a movie could even work. The idea hinged on finding the right boy, which Mr. Linklater did in Ellar Coltrane, who was cast when he was 6.

headline: Verbatim: Boehner on Vaccinations
text: — Speaker John A. Boehner, adding his opinion to the vaccination debate.

headline: Staples Said to Be in Talks to Buy Office Depot
text: Eighteen years after regulators shot down a merger between Staples and Office Depot, the two big office supply retailers may try to join forces once again.

headline: Fidel Castro Appears Animated and Alert in New Photos
text: MEXICO CITY — Photographs of Fidel Castro taken 10 days ago appeared on an official website late Monday, the first to be published since rumors about Mr. Castro’s death swirled through Havana and Miami in December.

headline: Should ‘Slut’ Be Retired?
text: The word “slut,” says Leora Tanenbaum, has changed.

headline: French Soldiers Guarding Jewish Site Are Attacked
text: PARIS — The French police on Tuesday arrested a man believed to have attacked and wounded three soldiers who were guarding a Jewish community center in the southern city of Nice, prosecutors said, heightening anxieties just weeks after terrorist attacks in Paris shook the country.

headline: Healing Touch
text: Arizona’s “cactus doctor,” Rilée Leblanc, tends to the region’s ailing desert plants.

headline: For the Prickliest Patients, a Desert Doctor Makes House Calls
text: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz. — The aging patient, prickly and stiff, loomed over the doctor, showing a number of troubling signs. The doctor noted poor posture, callused skin, limbs pocked with deep scars. He feared survival would hinge on drastic action, maybe even an amputation.

headline: 1940: Rationing May Be Started
text: Paris newspapers yesterday [Feb. 3]  published articles intimating that ration  cards for at least a few food products  may be introduced in the capital, if not in  all of France. Thus far in the war, France  alone of the belligerents has not introduced the ration system. Several newspapers also announced the fact that the  Seine Department General Council on  December 30 passed a resolution asking  that ration cards for sugar, coffee, oil,  macaroni and spaghetti be issued within  the department. At the same time, it was  revealed that ration cards were printed  by the government in 1937 and distributed to town halls throughout the nation. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 4, 1940

headline: Marriage Equality in Alabama
text: A television ad now airing across Alabama delivers a well-timed message about the human costs of denying gay couples the right to marry.

headline: Harper Lee, Author of ‘To Kill a Mockingbird,’ Is to Publish a Second Novel
text: For more than half a century, “To Kill a Mockingbird” has stood apart as a singular American literary masterpiece, a perennial best seller that has provoked countless classroom discussions about racial and social injustice. It brought instant and overwhelming fame to its enigmatic author, Harper Lee, who soon retreated from the spotlight to her native Monroeville, Ala. She never published another book, leaving her millions of fans yearning for more.

headline: Ron Lieber: By the Book
text: The Book Review editor, Pamela Paul, talks books with Ron Lieber, the “Your Money” columnist.

headline: Spring’s Points of Interest

headline: State of City Address: Full of Ambition, but Light on Details

headline: Time to Leave the N.I.C.U. Behind

headline: Apparent Discount Mars $41 Billion Spectrum Sale
text: The United States government has made a windfall. Some $41 billion of bids in its latest radio spectrum sale added up to about twice as much as expected. But the small print is making the auction look flawed. By bidding through entities it doesn’t fully control, the $33 billion Dish Network seems to have secured a 25 percent price discount aimed at small businesses.

headline: Track Fire Disrupts Subway Service on N, Q and R Lines
text: A small track fire in a subway tunnel on Tuesday morning disrupted service on three lines, the N, Q and R, a spokesman for the Fire Department said.

headline: Brokerage Firms Worry About Breaches by Hackers, Not Terrorists
text: The online attack on Sony Pictures Entertainment in the fall that federal authorities linked to the North Korean government raised alarm bells about the hacking threat posed by foreign governments. But brokerage firms based in the United States remain most concerned about an attack carried out by a loose band of hackers or employees with a grudge.

headline: Croatia and Serbia Cleared of Genocide by Hague Court

headline: Jordanian Pilot’s Death, Shown in ISIS Video, Spurs Jordan to Execute Prisoners
text: AMMAN, Jordan — When relatives learned Tuesday night that the Islamic State had released a video showing the death of a Jordanian fighter pilot, First Lt. Moaz al-Kasasbeh, they tried to keep it from his mother, Issaf, and his wife, Anwar. They switched off the television and tried to wrest a smartphone out of his wife’s hand, but she had already seen a mobile news bulletin.

headline: Croatia and Serbia Absolved of Genocide
text: The president of the International Court of Justice ruled on Tuesday that Serbia and Croatia did not commit genocide against each other during the breakup of Yugoslavia.

headline: Denied Prime Targets, Rubio Still Unloads at Cuba Hearing

headline: Proposal for a Theme Park Draws From Crimea’s Distant Past
text: LES EPESSES, France — Philippe and Nicolas de Villiers, father and son, run one of France’s most popular theme parks, a grand and gaudy take on the country’s past. So naturally, they are planning to expand. To Crimea.

text: Puy du Fou, a historical theme park in Les Epesses, France, may become a model for a park planned for Crimea.

headline: Auto Sales Stayed Strong in January, Bucking Trend for Month
text: Coming off the best sales year in nearly a decade, the auto industry showed little sign of slowing down in January.

headline: Christie Goes Silent as He Wraps Up His Trip to Britain
text: LONDON — On the final day of his trade mission to Britain, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey met with titans of London finance, visited a drug rehabilitation center, dined with the chancellor of the Exchequer and took in a rehearsal of “Henry V” at Shakespeare’s Globe.

headline: The Right Way to Pay Ransoms to Terrorists
text: DURHAM, N.C. — IT all began in 2003, when a German official flew into the wilds of northern Mali with three suitcases full of cash to secure the release of 14 European hostages. That first big ransom breathed life into the militant group known as Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, and laid the groundwork for a kidnap economy that now finances Islamist extremist groups around the globe.

headline: Fall in Fortunes for Pennsylvania Attorney General
text: HARRISBURG, Pa. — The question before Pennsylvanians is this: Is Kathleen G. Kane, the first woman to be elected as the state’s attorney general, the victim of angry men who targeted her after she exposed their pornography habits?

headline: Rand Paul Shushes Interviewer, and Some Women See Sexism
text: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky appeared to stumble on Monday night when he stepped into a controversy over vaccine mandates, but his bigger problem may be a backlash from women.

headline: Pope Francis Honors Óscar Romero, Salvadoran Archbishop, as Martyr
text: ROME — Pope Francis has formally ratified the martyrdom of the Salvadoran archbishop Óscar Romero, who was shot to death at the altar as he was saying Mass in 1980 in an act of “hatred for the faith,” the Vatican said on Tuesday.

headline: Secondhand Smoke Exposure Drops, C.D.C. Reports
text: Americans’ exposure to secondhand smoke has declined by half since 2000, federal health authorities reported Tuesday, as states and municipalities banned smoking in bars, restaurants and offices, and fewer Americans smoked inside their homes.

headline: Danny Meyer’s Porchlight Bar to Open
text: Danny Meyer has opened many restaurants over the years that offer sophisticated cocktails. But he never felt tempted to open a stand-alone bar.

headline: Suge Knight Pleads Not Guilty to Murder Charge in Hit-and-Run Case
text: Marion Knight, the former Death Row Records chief executive known as Suge, was rushed directly from a Los Angeles courtroom to the hospital on Tuesday morning after pleading not guilty to murder charges stemming from a hit-and-run last week, the Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department said.

headline: LVMH, the Luxury Goods Giant, Posts a 64% Gain in Annual Profit
text: Paris — LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the world’s largest luxury goods group, said on Tuesday that its profit jumped by 64 percent last year, bolstered by stronger demand in the United States and Europe, despite an overall softening of global demand for high-end goods.

Obama’s Budget Seeks International Minimum Tax for Corporations

headline: Macroeconomic Cronyism
text: My old teacher Rudi Dornbusch — whose presence is sorely missed in this world gone mad — once wrote an influential analysis, with Sebastian Edwards, of what they called macroeconomic populism. This is the historical tendency of some (not all) populist governments to engage in wishful thinking, to believe that they can repeal the usual rules — that they can indefinitely contain inflation in an overheated economy with price controls, that they can ignore limits on capacity, etc..

headline: Fiat Chrysler Profit in U.S. Declined 56% in 2014 on Charges From Merger
text: DETROIT — Fiat Chrysler reported that profit for its American division fell 56 percent in 2014, mostly because of charges related to the merger of the Italian automaker Fiat and the former Chrysler.

text: The poet Langston Hughes was a courtly man with a slow fuse. “Violent anger,” he wrote in his memoir “The Big Sea” (1940), “makes me physically ill.”

headline: Local Politics Are Fracturing European Unity
text: The euro had been enshrined in a treaty but not yet come to life in the autumn of 1997, when Martin Feldstein, the influential president of the National Bureau of Economic Research, published an essay arguing that European leaders’ hopes that a monetary union would foster greater harmony and peace in a Continent repeatedly ravaged by wars were misplaced.

text: The Rosa Parks Collection at the Library of Congress is set to open to researchers on Wednesday, coinciding with what would have been Ms. Parks’s 102nd birthday.

headline: Thom Tillis on Burdensome Regulations, Like Hand-Washing at Restaurants
text: It is often hard to tell whether Republican legislators are joking, because so many of the things they say are unintentionally funny. So I don’t know whether Senator Thom Tillis, Republican of North Carolina, was trying to be a latter day Jonathan Swift or was perfectly serious when he said restaurants are over-regulated and should not be required to tell employees to wash their hands after using the toilet.

headline: Draft of Arrest Request for Argentine President Found at Dead Prosecutor’s Home
text: BUENOS AIRES — Alberto Nisman, the prosecutor whose mysterious death has gripped Argentina, had drafted a request for the arrest of President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, accusing her of trying to shield Iranian officials from responsibility in the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center here, the lead investigator into his death said Tuesday.

headline: Coming to Mourn Tahrir Square’s Dead, and Joining Them Instead
text: CAIRO — Her friends wanted to lay a wreath in Tahrir Square as a memorial, but Shaimaa el-Sabbagh urged them to reconsider. She feared that the police might attack, mistaking them for supporters of the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood, said a cousin, Sami Mohamed Ibrahim.

headline: ‘Fifty Shades’ of a Stay
text: Raunchy isn’t usually the best way to describe most Valentine’s Day packages, but two Kimpton hotels in New York City are going a little racy this year with a “Fifty Shades of Grey” promotion.

headline: ‘American Sniper’ Pulled From Iraq Theater
text: One group that seemed destined to take offense at “American Sniper” is Iraqis, and, according to The Washington Post and a GlobalPost article that ran in USA Today, the film was yanked from a cinema in Baghdad days after opening there.

headline: Wilmington Seeks a Youthful Energy Downtown
text: WILMINGTON, Del. — In a downtown district previously characterized by pawnshops and check-cashing stores, hundreds of apartments are being built here for a new generation of young professionals who want to live and play in the communities where they work.

text: Videos captured the final moments of the Egyptian activist Shaimaa al-Sabbagh’s life before and after she was shot by the police during a peaceful protest in Cairo on Jan. 24.

text: After almost 200 years in New York City, American Bible Society is moving its national headquarters to Philadelphia.

headline: Intrigue Deepens at Republican Committee in Virgin Islands
text: The strange case of the Virgin Islands political action committee took another strange twist.

headline: Columbia Hires Peter Pilling as Athletic Director
text: Columbia has hired Peter Pilling, a vice president at IMG College, the sports marketing firm, to be its next athletic director, the university said Tuesday.

headline: A Cultish French Shoe Brand From an Alumna of Louboutin and Pierre Hardy
text: “The ideal men’s footwear symbolizes power, taste and singularity,” the French shoe designer Alexia Aubert says. “Those are the qualities I’m attuned to in a man.” Aubert, who started her career assisting Christian Louboutin, went on to run the studio at Pierre Hardy and to transform the footwear division at Oscar de la Renta from a collection of licensing agreements into a proper design collection. Since then, she’s been consulting for various brands (including Mulberry and Balmain) and, last year, launched her own line of footwear, initially intended for men. She deems Solovière — named after her maternal grandfather — “a laboratory for new classics.” And her latest experiment came at the request of the Parisian boutique Colette: to offer additional sizes, effectively making some of her designs unisex.

headline: New York Philharmonic to Celebrate 50 Years of Concerts in the Parks
text: The New York Philharmonic will mark the 50th anniversary of its free parks concerts this June with Alan Gilbert leading the orchestra in a program of American music on Central Park’s Great Lawn featuring the violinist Joshua Bell performing a suite from “West Side Story.”

headline: Senate Democrats Block Republicans’ Homeland Security Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats on Tuesday blocked a Republican bill that would finance the Department of Homeland Security, objecting to a measure that would have gutted President Obama’s recent executive actions on immigration. The vote set up an urgent confrontation over the department, which will see its funding run out at the end of the month.

headline: 1965: Connoisseurs Steal Paintings
text: PARIS — A sophisticated gang of thieves carted off four paintings and silverware worth $400,000 from a château east of Paris, it was learned today [Feb. 3]. The theft was the latest in a series of about 60 committed in châteaus, mainly in the Paris region in recent years. In most of the cases, the ‘‘gang des châteaux’’ carefully selected only a few of many valuable items readily available for the taking. The style of the operation has been so consistent that police investigating the latest theft reportedly are working on the theory that the burglars are ‘‘replying to the orders’’ of a private collector. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 4, 1965

headline: Leon Silverman, 93, Dies; Lawyer Led Inquiry of Labor Secretary
text: Leon Silverman, a tenacious litigator best known outside the legal profession as the federal investigator who found insufficient evidence to prosecute Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan in 1982 on charges that he had ties to organized crime, died on Thursday at his home in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 93.

headline: Some See Risk in de Blasio’s Bid to Add Housing
text: Every month, city planners come to East New York to explain how the city wants to help this corner of Brooklyn, scarred by decades of poverty and violent crime, grow. They will invite developers to build up local streets in exchange for more units of affordable housing. They will invest in new trees and sidewalks. Better services and shops will follow, they say.

headline: Lindsey Vonn Slips to Third but Sees a Silver Lining
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — As Lindsey Vonn crossed the finish line and took the lead in the super-G at the Alpine World Ski Championships here on Tuesday, her boyfriend, Tiger Woods, shouted and pumped his right fist repeatedly as he watched nearby.

headline: Palestinian Newspaper Accused of Running Muhammad Cartoon

headline: U.N. Concerned About Reports That Food Aid to Syria Is in ISIS Hands
text: GENEVA — The United Nations food relief agency said it was “extremely concerned” about the possible manipulation of its aid to Syria after images posted on jihadist websites and social media appeared to show Islamic State supporters distributing the agency’s relief supplies rebranded with the militant group’s logo.

headline: Preventing Suicides Among Veterans Is at Center of Bill Passed by Senate
text: As a Marine serving in Iraq, Clay Hunt barely missed being killed by a sniper, yet he faced what proved to be more powerful foes after leaving the corps: depression and post-traumatic stress disorder. Mr. Hunt killed himself four years ago, even as he worked to help other struggling veterans.

headline: Holder on S.&P.’s Settlement
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced that the agency will pay $1.37 billion to settle an array of government lawsuits that accused S.&P. of inflating subprime mortgage investment ratings.

headline: Gender Bias Case Against Sterling Jewelers Can Proceed

text: After an outbreak of measles at Disneyland in California, doctors emphasize the importance of immunization.

headline: In Black and White, Illustration Sparks Reader Concerns

The piece was powerful, making the point that “men who are eventually arrested for violent acts often began with attacks against their girlfriends and wives.” But for some readers, dismay at the illustration overwhelmed their reaction to the article itself.

headline: Photographing a Filipino View of the Streets

headline: Cracking Codes Through the Centuries
text: WASHINGTON — The Sigaba encryption machine squats in the Folger Shakespeare Library here like a thuggish interloper. Used by the American military in the 1940s and 1950s to send coded messages, it looks like an oversize, boxy typewriter with rotors rising above the lid like a mechanical brain. No object could seem less Elizabethan, yet appearances deceive.

headline: A Two-Bedroom House on a Hillside in St. Barts

headline: Donating Embryos, Not ‘Giving Up Babies’

Katherine, a mother who thought her family was complete after a successful IVF procedure and the birth of her twins, described her and her husband’s decision to donate their three remaining frozen embryos in the comments. I wanted to know more. I wrote her, asking if she would be willing to share her story.

headline: An Orchestral Group Effort, With a Star Turn for Banjo

headline: Elgar and Haydn, Found Warming in a Hidden Space
text: Two dozen hardy souls made it through snow and ice to the Kosciuszko Foundation on Monday night. Small numbers make for acute listening, though, and often for rewarding experiences in chamber music. That was true of this brief, absorbing concert from the Manhattan String Quartet, presented by a venerable club for musicians and the musically inclined, the Bohemians.

text: Performer and chef, writer and provocateur, Eddie Huang tries to take his brand of Asian-American anarchism to the mainstream.

The company, which is based in Austin, Tex., serves 21 markets, including Austin, Dallas, San Francisco, Boston and Los Angeles, and plans to expand into New York.

text: GENEVA — The United Nations Human Rights Council on Tuesday picked an American judge serving on an inquiry into possible war crimes in Gaza to lead its work to completion a day after the inquiry’s chairman resigned after Israel accused him of a “blatant conflict of interest.”

headline: ISIS Video Presents Grim Choice for News Media
text: The images spread rapidly online Tuesday, some more graphic than others: A caged Jordanian pilot, captured by the militants of the Islamic State late last year, was shown apparently being burned alive.

headline: Video Shows Obama’s 2008 Comments on Vaccines Were Misreported
text: As reporters press potential 2016 presidential candidates on the question of whether parents should be compelled to vaccinate their children, new attention has been focused on how the issue was handled in the 2008 campaign, particularly by President Obama.

headline: Alternate-Side Parking Suspended Through Saturday
text: Because of snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City through Saturday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Metro-North Train Hits S.U.V. in Railroad’s Deadliest Accident
text: A crowded Metro-North Railroad train passing through Westchester County at the height of the evening rush on Tuesday slammed into a sport-utility vehicle on the tracks at a crossing, creating a fiery crash and explosion that killed seven people, injured a dozen and forced the evacuation of hundreds. It was the deadliest crash in the railroad’s history.

headline: Ex-Contractor Charged in Navy Bribery Case
text: Paul Simpkins, a former senior contracting officer for the Navy, was arrested Tuesday and charged with conspiracy to commit bribery in a scandal involving ship-supply contracts in the Pacific. Federal prosecutors said Mr. Simpkins, 60, accepted several hundred thousand dollars in cash, trips and the services of prostitutes from Leonard Francis, a Malaysian businessman who recently pleaded guilty to bribing Navy officials for help in overbilling the services by at least $35 million. Prosecutors said Mr. Simpkins, who pleaded not guilty, overruled a subordinate who wanted to drop a contract with Mr. Leonard in Thailand that included “many exceedingly high cost” items.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Moves to Expand Ferry Service in New York City
text: It has become a modern political axiom in New York, as bipartisan as it is expensive, according to transportation advocates: Elected officials love ferries.

headline: A City and Sea Hotel Pairing in Thailand
text: Travelers to Thailand who want to experience bustling Bangkok as well as pristine beaches can get a dose of both with the new customizable “Island and City Break” offer from the Point Yamu by Como hotel in Phuket.

headline: Our Curse
text: In this Oscar-nominated documentary, a young couple struggles to overcome every new parent’s worst nightmare: a child born with a life-threatening illness.

headline: ‘Nasza klątwa’
text: Cztery lata temu, u mojego nowonarodzonego syna Leo zdiagnozowano bardzo rzadką i nieuleczalną chorobę, tak zwaną Klątwę Ondyny. Znana jest również jako zespół wrodzonej ośrodkowej hipowentylacji.

headline: ‘Our Curse’
text: Four years ago, my newborn son, Leo, was given a diagnosis of a very rare and incurable disorder known as Ondine’s Curse. Also called  Congenital Central Hypoventilation Syndrome (C.C.H.S.), the disorder prevents the thousand or so people known to have been born with it from breathing while asleep, and sometimes also while awake. Though the disorder is manageable when treated, our son is likely to need a ventilator for the rest of his life.

headline: Low Energy Prices Offer Opening for Subsidy Cuts
text: In Saudi Arabia, drivers pay roughly 45 cents a gallon to fill up their cars, and in Venezuela even less. Energy is so inexpensive in Kuwait and Qatar that residents chill their enormous swimming pools in the summer and typically leave their air-conditioners on at full blast while they are away on vacation.

headline: U.S. Official Says Cuba’s Political Detentions Declined
text: WASHINGTON — Cuba temporarily detained 178 political prisoners in January, Tom Malinowski, the State Department’s senior human rights official, said Tuesday.

headline: On Tour, Greek Leaders Wear No Ties and Aim for Looser Belts
text: ROME — Less than two weeks after taking power in national elections, Greece’s leftist-led government is now taking Europe. Fashion critics in London are debating whether the Greek finance minister is an arbiter of cool chic or looks like a nightclub bouncer. Politicians in Brussels and Berlin are mulling whether the new Greek prime minister is a radical looking to bring down the eurozone or a canny operator looking for a deal.

headline: In a Sale Gone Awry, a Lesson for Other Deal Makers
text: The prolonged takeover battle for the GFI Group, a New York brokerage firm and clearinghouse, has been littered with missteps by Michael Gooch, its founder and executive chairman, raising the question of why supposedly intelligent leaders time and again do dumb things when they sell their companies.

headline: House G.O.P. Again Votes to Repeal Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON — The House passed a bill on Tuesday to repeal the Affordable Care Act for the first time in the new Congress, but Democrats appeared to show more zeal in defending the law than Republicans did in trying to get rid of it.

headline: N.H.L. Trailblazer Finds Forgiveness in the Tip of a Pen
text: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario — A little more than a year ago, the former N.H.L. player Val James handed his wife, Ina, the first draft of his autobiography and asked her to read it.

headline: S.&P. Settlement Leaves Future Unclear for Ratings
text: It cost $1.37 billion, but Standard & Poor’s has finally appeared to close the darkest chapter in its 150-year history as a rating agency.

headline: Moussaoui Calls Saudi Princes Patrons of Al Qaeda
text: WASHINGTON — In highly unusual testimony inside the federal supermax prison, a former operative for Al Qaeda has described prominent members of Saudi Arabia’s royal family as major donors to the terrorist network in the late 1990s and claimed that he discussed a plan to shoot down Air Force One with a Stinger missile with a staff member at the Saudi Embassy in Washington.

headline: New Speaker in Albany: A Skilled Operator, Embracing Change
text: ALBANY — After his election on Tuesday as speaker of the New York State Assembly, Carl E. Heastie echoed calls to reform the opaque and almost czarlike system in which the legislative chamber is ruled by its speaker, one of the “three men in a room” who dominate state government.

headline: Lincoln’s Failed Peace Process
text: On Feb. 3, 1865, a lovely false spring day, the president of the United States traveled south by train and steamboat to a spot near the front lines of the Civil War for a peaceful talk with the enemy. Such high-level negotiations in the middle of a shooting war had never happened before, and have never happened since. After nearly four years of battering, the Confederacy was all but broken – and Lincoln was eager to stop the killing and begin to heal the country with a peaceful reconciliation instead of a military conquest. That’s why, that afternoon, Abraham Lincoln welcomed three Confederate leaders to the presidential steamboat River Queen, the Air Force One of her day, and exposed himself to political attack for the mortal sin of compromise.

headline: Lawsuit Seeks to Legalize Doctor-Assisted Suicide for Terminally Ill Patients in New York
text: A group of doctors and terminally ill patients are asking New York courts to declare that doctor-assisted suicide is legal and not covered by the state’s prohibition on helping people take their own lives.

headline: A Crashing End to a Work of Ice a City Had Warmed Up To
text: SUPERIOR, Wis. — The ingredients needed to build the world’s tallest ice sculpture — bountiful water and extremely cold weather — exist in abundance in this small city hard on the state’s northwesternmost tip. A perfect place, in other words, for a self-taught engineer named Roger Hanson to surpass that record.

headline: Regulators Cite a New Danger in the Skies: Selfies
text: WATKINS, Colo. — In an age of digital distractions, the lethal risks of driving — or just crossing the street — while looking at a cellphone have been well-documented.

headline: With One’s Head in the Clouds
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE —The idiom “Your mileage may vary” comes up a lot on this blog, particularly when it comes to how a puzzle might make you feel. That’s an unusual stance to begin with, because many people believe that a puzzle can’t really affect your feelings one way or another. I understand that, and I respectfully disagree. We can agree to disagree, right?

headline: A Crumbling Tower of Ice
text: Roger Hanson calls himself the iceman. The 66 foot-high ice sculpture he’s been working on in Superior, Wis., since November came tumbling down Tuesday morning.

headline: What You Get for ... $750,000
text: This week’s properties include a log house in Kentucky, a contemporary in Arkansas and a houseboat in Seattle.

headline: High-Tech Fashion Redefines Meaning of Revealing Clothing
text: New to the city last year, Billie Whitehouse was struck by the inevitability of small-scale disaster on the streets of New York. Everywhere, it seemed, people walked with noses pointed into their smartphones. Like herself, these pilgrims were seeking directions. But they were liable to step blindly off sidewalks, to walk up the backs of people ahead of them, or to not notice that shop doors swing open.

headline: Evasive on Stand, Prosecution Witness Is Declared Hostile at Patz Trial
text: The trial of a man accused of killing 6-year-old Etan Patz in 1979 took an unexpected twist on Tuesday, after a prosecution witness — an employee at the bodega where prosecutors say the boy was murdered — was declared a hostile witness because he became evasive on the stand.

headline: The 10 Most Painful Losses in Super Bowl History
text: The Seattle Seahawks were a yard from history. Trailing by 4 points in the final minute of Sunday’s Super Bowl, Seattle had the ball, on second down, at the Patriots’ 1-yard line. According to the website Advanced Football Analytics, that gave the Seahawks an 88 percent chance of winning the Super Bowl.

headline: A Matchmaker and a Festival Keep an Irish Tradition Alive
text: LISDOONVARNA, Ireland — After 50-odd years in the business of romance, Willie Daly has a lot of stories to tell.

headline: United Arab Emirates, Key U.S. Ally in ISIS Effort, Disengaged in December
text: WASHINGTON — The United Arab Emirates, a crucial Arab ally in the American-led coalition against the Islamic State, suspended airstrikes against the Sunni extremist group in December, citing fears for its pilots’ safety after a Jordanian pilot was captured and who the extremists said had been burned to death, United States officials said Tuesday.

headline: Purchase by Mexican President Is Under Scrutiny
text: MEXICO CITY — President Enrique Peña Nieto announced Tuesday that a new federal comptroller would lead an investigation into the purchase by the president and his wife of two houses from government contractors.

headline: In Closing Arguments, Conflicting Accounts of Man’s Role in Silk Road
text: A prosecutor asked a Manhattan jury on Tuesday to convict a California man, Ross W. Ulbricht, of narcotics trafficking conspiracy and other charges in a trial involving Silk Road, the black-market website for drugs and other illicit goods.

headline: Knicks Fall to Celtics in a Matchup of Duds
text: The sad drumbeat continued on Tuesday for the Knicks, who lost to the Boston Celtics, 108-97, in a mostly listless affair at Madison Square Garden between two rebuilding franchises.

headline: Syria: Chemical Weapons Plant Razed
text: Seven months after Syria exported the last of its known stockpile of chemical weapons ingredients, the first of its 12 production facilities has been destroyed, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons reported Tuesday. Ahmet Uzumcu, director general of the organization, which polices the chemical weapons treaty that Syria signed in late 2013, said the destruction of the first facility had been completed Jan. 31 after a delay he attributed to “technical reasons.” He gave no timetable for the rest. Western countries have accused President Bashar al-Assad of Syria of procrastination in complying with the terms of the treaty, which he agreed to sign after a chemical weapons attack in a Damascus suburb for which government forces and insurgents blamed each other.

headline: Accuser in Strauss-Kahn Case Builds Restaurant and a Refuge
text: As the news media again turns its attention to Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former leader of the International Monetary Fund who is on  trial in France on accusations that he participated in a prostitution ring, the woman who accused him of sexual assault in New York City in 2011 has quietly resumed her life, this time behind the counter of a West African restaurant in the Bronx.

headline: Islanders Struggling to Adjust Without Injured Kyle Okposo
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Life without Kyle Okposo presents many challenges for the Islanders, who are clinging to first place in the Metropolitan Division with a sputtering offense.

text: Season 6, Episode 3, “Noblesse Oblige”

headline: Walker’s Wisconsin Budget Has a National Message
text: Gov. Scott Walker, a possible contender for the Republican presidential nomination, on Tuesday proposed a new spending plan for Wisconsin that relies on borrowing and spending cuts, including deep reductions to state universities, and steers clear of tax increases.

headline: New York City Schools Chancellor Objects to Cuomo’s Plan for Grading Teachers
text: The New York City schools chancellor, Carmen Fariña, spoke out forcefully against some of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s  education proposals on Tuesday, making clear the de Blasio administration’s opposition to a core part of the governor’s 2015 agenda.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: I was a first-time writer, so I did as I was told.

headline: Excerpts From Carl Heastie’s Speech
text: In a speech lasting almost eight minutes, the new Assembly speaker, Carl E. Heastie, spoke of restoring integrity to the Legislature through fiscal transparency and other measures.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 3, 2015
New York City Councilman Arrested on Corruption Charges
text: A New York City councilman was arrested on corruption charges on Tuesday for the second time in less than nine months.

headline: Aksel Lund Svindal Set to Compete at Alpine Championships
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — After three months away from the slopes because of injury, Aksel Lund Svindal of Norway, the three-time Olympic medalist and defending downhill world champion, confirmed that he would race in Wednesday’s super-G and Saturday’s downhill at the Alpine World Ski Championships here.

headline: Sherry Arden, Publisher With a Passion for Best Sellers, Dies at 91
text: Sherry Arden, whose exuberance as a promoter and perspicacity as a publisher helped invigorate the book industry with a raft of celebrity tell-all memoirs like Christina Crawford’s “Mommie Dearest” and pop psychology primers like Gail Sheehy’s “Pathfinders,” died on Jan. 27 at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 91.

headline: Sandy Socolow, CBS Newsman During Heady Days, Dies at 86
text: Sandy Socolow, a longtime executive at CBS News who worked closely with Walter Cronkite and helped shape television coverage of the Vietnam War and the Watergate scandal, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Monty Oum, Web-Series Animator, Dies at 33
text: Monty Oum, the creator of the animated web series “RWBY” and director of animation for Rooster Teeth Productions, a company best known for repurposing the bloodthirsty avatars in the Halo video games into angst-ridden slackers in the popular web series “Red vs. Blue,” died on Sunday near his home in Austin, Tex. He was 33.

headline: Aldo Ciccolini Dies at 89; Pianist Interpreted Satie
text: Aldo Ciccolini, an Italian-born pianist who specialized in the music of French composers and was known in particular as a champion of Erik Satie, has died at his home outside Paris. He was 89.

headline: Meh Head
text: The hairstyle of choice this season seems like no hairstyle at all. Unremarkable in color and length, and replete with flyaway bits, the look is effortless, but of course, it isn’t.

headline: The Softer Side of Spring Manicures
text: Last fall, at shows from Thakoon to DKNY, light and neutral nails marked the departure of dark manicures for spring 2015. And the season’s crop of nail polish offerings, an array of delicate colors that just hit the market this month, pair as seamlessly with snow gear now as they will with ready-to-wear when the weather warms up. Consider some of Dolce & Gabbana’s romantic new hues (aptly named Innocence, Bella and Rosebud) and Nails Inc.’s garden party varieties (soft shades and confetti-like top coats that mimic May flowers).

headline: The Rise of Japanese Chefs in Paris
text: For years, aspiring culinary stars from Japan have been decamping to Paris to learn new techniques, but recently they’ve been leaving behind the Michelin-starred dining temples that trained them — from Astrance to Taillevent — to headline their own spots. At Restaurant ES in the Seventh Arrondissement, the chef Takayuki Honjo improvises with simple, market-driven dishes, such as roast pigeon in cocoa sauce, which are as delicate in flavor as they are graphic in presentation. At Neige d’Été in the 15th, Hideki Nishi dabbles in modern French cuisine including salmon with a Gorgonzola millefeuille. Over in the 11th, at 6036 — a 14-seat izakaya named for the distance, in miles, between Paris and Tokyo — the chef Haruka Casters plays up seasonal small plates (sake-steamed clams with cabbage, teriyaki burgers). “Paris is a cosmopolitan city with many opportunities to improve one’s cooking,” says Casters. “But it’s also much easier to be seen here than in a megalopolis like Tokyo.”

headline: Anywhere, U.S.A.
text: Athletic sportswear has come a long way from the track and the field. High fashion sounds a call to action with all-American lettered jerseys, motocross stripes and high-tech mesh.

headline: Word of the Day | thermal
text: thermal • \ˈthər-məl\• adjective and noun

headline: Ford Raises Pay for 500 Workers as Demand Grows for F-150 Pickup
text: DETROIT — Growing demand for Ford Motor’s new pickup truck will prompt a transition to higher wages for up to 500 of the company’s entry-level union workers.

headline: Corporate Tax Reform: Focusing on Where the Money Is, Not Where the Jobs Are
text: Discussions of corporate tax policy involve a lot of rhetoric about whether it encourages companies to move overseas.

headline: Taiwan: Plane Crashes in Taipei
text: A small passenger airplane crashed into a river in Taipei after clipping a bridge on Wednesday morning, Taiwan’s Central News Agency reported, citing a local government official. The TransAsia Airways twin turboprop crashed shortly after takeoff from Taipei Songshan Airport on a flight bound for the Kinmen islands, near the Chinese province of Fujian. About a dozen people were rescued from the plane, an ATR-72, while 10 were still trapped, the news agency reported, citing local television reports. Local television showed the plane’s fuselage resting in the Keelung River near the southeast side of Taipei, the Taiwanese capital. The crash is the second for the airline in just over six months, following an ATR-72 crash on July 23 that killed 48 people. The cause of that crash is still under investigation.

headline: Plane Clips Road and Crashes in Taiwan, Killing at Least 31
text: HONG KONG — A passenger plane crashed into a river in Taiwan’s capital, Taipei, shortly after takeoff on Wednesday morning, killing at least 31 people, officials said. Rescue operations were underway to pull survivors from the water.

headline: After the Metro-North Crash
text: A train accident in Valhalla, N.Y., in Westchester County, was deadliest in the railroad’s history.

headline: Area of the Crash
text: The commuter train struck a vehicle on the tracks in Valhalla, N.Y.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (WE) MATCH MADE IN HEAVEN Shawn Bullard, a real estate developer and former college football player, receives guidance from Ken Johnson, chaplain and spiritual adviser to the Indianapolis Colts, who is charged with discerning the authenticity and godliness of 24 women hoping to make a love connection with Mr. Bullard. But it may be Mr. Bullard’s opinionated mother, who, after moving into the house with the contestants, has the final say on her prospective daughter-in-law. And forget about roses: The women will each be given a white cellphone at the start of the show to which Mr. Bullard will text messages as to the outcome of their romantic encounters.

headline: When Sports and Academics Compete
Europe’s Expanding ‘Right to Be Forgotten’
text: European officials are pushing an idea that will encourage autocrats everywhere to demand greater censorship on the Internet. They want companies like Google and Microsoft to abide by the European Union’s recently recognized legal principle of a “right to be forgotten” not just in the 28 countries of the union but everywhere.

headline: A Bad Mistake
text: The decision by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and House Speaker John Boehner to cook up an address to Congress by Netanyahu on why the U.S. should get tougher on Iran is churlish, reckless and, for the future of Israeli-American relations, quite dangerous.

headline: It Is Time to End Subminimum Wages
text: In New York, restaurants are allowed to pay servers a minimum wage of $5 an hour, as long as that hourly wage plus tips equals at least $8.75, the state minimum for nontipped workers (rising to $9 by 2016). That subminimum “tipped” wage is a vestige of the early days of modern labor law, when minimum-wage mandates were riddled with industry-specific exemptions, long since ended. It survives for tipped workers because of the strength of the restaurant lobby.

headline: ISIS Is Losing in Iraq. But What Happens Next?

headline: The Problem With Middle-Class Populism
text: In his State of the Union address last month, and in four subsequent addresses to the public, President Obama used the phrase “middle class” (approvingly) a total of 49 times, and the term “superrich” (in an accusatory sense) eight times. It sounded like this:

headline: 150 Years of Working on the Railroad
text: SAN FRANCISCO — IN 1864, my great-grandfather arrived here, a teenager from Ireland with few prospects. He’d left County Galway with a coat and shoes and crossed the Atlantic, caught a steamer to Panama, then another one to San Francisco. The journey took three months, an eternity for a young man hungry to work.

headline: Philosophy’s Lost Body and Soul
text: This is the sixth in a series of interviews with philosophers on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This week’s conversation is with Linda Martín Alcoff, a professor of philosophy at Hunter College and the CUNY Graduate Center. She was the president of the American Philosophical Association, Eastern Division, for 2012-13. She is the author of “Visible Identities: Race, Gender, and the Self.” — George Yancy

text: HONG KONG — After a rough few months, Sony got some relief on Wednesday as net profit almost doubled analysts’ expectations and the company reduced its loss projections for the year.

text: In “Harper Lee, Author of ‘To Kill a Mockingbird,’ Is to Publish a Second Novel,” Alexandra Alter reports on the discovery of a long-lost manuscript.

headline: New Leaders at Paris Opera Unveil an Ambitious Future
text: PARIS — In a major coup, the Paris Opera Ballet has secured one of the dance world’s biggest names, William Forsythe, as the company’s associate choreographer.

headline: Uber Tries to Ease Concerns in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The ride-hailing service Uber said on Wednesday that it was asking the South Korean government to register its drivers so that it could overcome legal challenges and continue to operate here.

headline: Photographing a Filipino View of the Streets
text: When Rick Rocamora left his career selling pharmaceuticals to become a photographer in 1990, he was guided by the advice and encouragement of everyone from Eli Reed and Ed Kashi to Gordon Parks. He has been paying it forward ever since, serving as a mentor to a new generation of Filipino photographers, both in Manila and among his native country’s far-flung diaspora.

headline: Do You Have an Idea for a Business or App?

headline: When to Take the SAT
text: During morning announcements, loudspeakers blare out SAT words and definitions at all elementary and middle schools in the Malverne, N.Y., school district. Kindergartners keep a “word of the week” journal — recently, “incentive” and “consequence” — in which they draw the word’s meaning or, if able, write a sentence using it. Students and teachers at all grade levels weave the new words into conversation; the district sends home definitions for parents.

headline: The Wardrobe Politics of Greece’s New Prime Minister
text: Last week, as the Twitterati and the talking heads tied themselves in knots over the nonstory of Michelle Obama doing like her peers Hillary Rodham Clinton and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and eschewing a head scarf on a visit to Saudi Arabia, an actual political sartorial revolution was, in fact, taking place elsewhere.

headline: Slow Runners Come Out Ahead
text: The ideal amount of running for someone who wants to live a long and healthy life is less than most of us might expect, according to a new study, which also suggests that people can overdo strenuous exercise and potentially shorten their lives.

headline: Age 6 and Applying to College
text: College awareness starts early for the first graders at Johnsonville Elementary School in Harnett County, N.C.

headline: Is Your First Grader College Ready?
text: What is college? To Madison Comer, a confident 6-year-old, it is a very big place. “It’s tall,” she explained, outlining the head of Tuffy, the North Carolina State mascot, with a gray crayon. “It’s like high school but it’s higher.”

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Defense Nominee Says He Would Consider More U.S. Military Aid to Ukraine
text: WASHINGTON — Ashton B. Carter, President Obama’s nominee for secretary of defense, told senators on Wednesday that he would consider increased American military assistance to Ukraine, including the sale of lethal arms, as part of the country’s effort to fight Russian-backed separatists in the east.

headline: Toyota Profit Gets Lift From U.S. Market and Favorable Exchange Rates
text: TOKYO — Buoyed by a growing American car market and the most favorable exchange rates in decades, Toyota Motor is closing in on its most profitable year ever, the automaker’s latest earnings report suggested on Wednesday.

headline: China Moves to Free Up Money in Its Economy
text: HONG KONG — China signaled fresh concerns about its slowing economy as the country’s central bank moved on Wednesday to stimulate growth by freeing up more money for banks to lend.

headline: 1915: Novelist Dies at Richmond
text: LONDON ­— Miss Braddon, the novelist, whose real name was Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Maxwell, died at her home, Lichfield House, Richmond-on-Thames, Surrey, this morning at the age of seventy-eight. Miss Braddon’s health only began to fail about a fortnight ago, just after she had completed her last novel. Miss Braddon was devoted to literary work from the age of twenty and published her first novel, ‘‘The Trail of the Serpent,’’ in serial form so long ago as 1860. She secured her first big success with ‘‘Lady Audley’s Secret,’’ a sensational novel which enjoyed a great vogue. From that time onward Miss Braddon was an indefatigable producer of novels. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 5, 1915

headline: The Shame of America’s Family Detention Camps
text: Christina Brown pulled into the refugee camp after an eight-hour drive across the desert. It was late July of last year, and Brown was a 30-year-old immigration lawyer. She had spent a few years after college working on political campaigns, but her law degree was barely a year old, and she had only two clients in her private practice in Denver. When other lawyers told her that the federal government was opening a massive detention center for immigrants in southeastern New Mexico, where hundreds of women and children would be housed in metal trailers surrounded by barbed wire, Brown decided to volunteer legal services to the detainees. She wasn’t sure exactly what rights they might have, but she wanted to make sure they got them. She packed enough clothes to last a week, stopped by Target to pick up coloring books and toys and started driving south.

headline: Tim O’Reilly Explains the Internet of Things
text: Tim O’Reilly has been at the cutting edge of the Internet since it went commercial. In fact, he helped take it there: In August 1993 he released the Global Network Navigator, a web page containing information, catalogs and a marketplace, which may have been the first site with advertising.

headline: Morning Agenda: What S.&P.’s Settlement Means
text: WHAT S.&P.’S SETTLEMENT MEANS | Standard & Poor’s $1.37 billion settlement with prosecutors, announced on Tuesday, will settle an array of government lawsuits against the giant rating agency. But it does not represent closure for the broader ratings business, DealBook’s Ben Protess and Nathaniel Popper report. An uncertain future still lies ahead for S.&P., as well as its main rivals, Moody’s and Fitch.

headline: Staples and Office Depot Say a Merger Will Keep Them Competitive

headline: A Boost From the State Capitol Helped Penn State Escape N.C.A.A. Penalties
text: HARRISBURG, Pa. — Like his father before him, State Senator Jake Corman represents the district that includes Penn State, his alma mater, in the Pennsylvania General Assembly. In his office as Senate majority leader, he keeps a box of Wheaties autographed by Joe Paterno, a model of Beaver Stadium and a small statue of the university’s Nittany Lions mascot.

headline: Without a Message, Christie Is Blown Off Course in Britain
text: LONDON – Candidates for the American presidency have been lifted and diminished here in Europe.

headline: Despite Recalls, G.M. Pays Workers a Big Bonus

headline: ‘Mourning Lincoln’ and ‘Lincoln’s Body’
text: Abraham Lincoln died on April 15, 1865, of a gunshot wound to the head. He was 56 years old and 6 feet 4 inches tall: a giant, felled. He was the 16th president of the United States and the first one killed in office. (A madman once tried to shoot Andrew Jackson, but both of his pistols misfired.) An assassination is treason by way of murder. Lincoln’s assassination was more — an act of war. Lee surrendered to Grant on April 9. Lincoln was the last of the Union dead. His death had another meaning, too. It founded a civic religion, dedicated to the memory of Lincoln’s sacrifice and to the proposition that emancipation is redemption.

headline: A Laugh for Every Season
text: There’s a very particular allure to a picture book that teeters on the verge of becoming a chapter book — that divides into three or more micro-stories featuring the same characters, with a title page for each vignette. James Marshall’s classic “George and Martha” books from the 1970s, with their hilariously bickering pair of hippos, are probably the gold standard, but there are many good examples from recent years, like Laura Vaccaro Seeger’s “Dog and Bear” books and Grace Lin’s “Ling and Ting” series.

headline: A Documentary Collaboration That Didn’t Start Out Promisingly

But the two men met for the first time only about six years ago, and initially there was no talk of the collaboration that led to the making of “The Salt of the Earth,” one of five nominees for the Oscar for best feature documentary.

headline: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center to Spotlight String Quartet Works

headline: ‘The Test,’ by Anya Kamenetz
text: Teachers and their unions have resisted standardized testing since the early 20th century. Their critics have claimed they do so because they fear being held accountable for how much children learn. But over the past few years, on both the right and the left, in scattered suburbs and in urban neighborhoods, a small yet growing group of parents have begun to join teachers in denouncing standardized testing. They complain about the narrowing of the school curriculum to the questions asked on high-stakes exams, the many hours and days — sometimes up to a quarter of the school year — spent testing and prepping for tests, and the stress that testing imposes on children. Some parents even have their children opt out of standardized testing altogether.

headline: ‘It’s What I Do,’ by Lynsey Addario
text: The modern battlefield can induce a peculiar strain of skewed logic among those sent to chronicle it. Upon a landscape where it is often mortally dangerous simply to stand in one place, how much worse can it be to venture a little farther, to get a bit closer? And having assumed the added risk of getting closer, how then to leave before you’ve taken the perfect image, conducted one last interview? What makes such calculations especially tricky is that most modern battlefields have no recognizable boundaries or rules of conduct; they bear less resemblance to any traditional war movie than, say, to “Mad Max.”

What grew up around them was a propane-fueled paradise: tacos, huaraches and elotes, tamales tonged out of pots wheeled around in shopping carts. People and flavors from Mexico, Guatemala, Ecuador, Honduras, Colombia, all just blocks away from where Americans fired cannonballs at a British frigate during the Revolutionary War, desperately trying to keep intruders out.

headline: 36 Hours in Anguilla
text: Anguilla has no right to be fabulous. The Caribbean island, a British overseas territory about seven miles north of St. Maarten/St. Martin, is a blip on the radar — a mere 35 square miles with just six traffic lights. It’s dry and flat, and its tourism scene took off only some 20 years ago; until the 1960s, after all, much of the island lacked electricity and telephone service. Yet fabulous Anguilla is home to some of the region’s toniest resorts, epicurean eateries and breathtaking beaches. It has architecturally striking villas like those at Altamer, named for exotic gemstones. And it is a magnet for celebrities like Kevin Bacon and Jimmy Buffett, a kind of British St. Bart’s. Without the pretension, though — Anguillan style is a perfect paradox: unfussy chic, barefoot elegance. There are no cruise ships, casinos or high-rise hotels, but there is a thriving local music scene, headed by notable up-and-coming singer-songwriters like Omari Banks and Ruel Richardson, and showcased at Moonsplash, the island’s annual reggae festival. And the fabulous factor grows with every season: luxe hotel unveilings include Malliouhana, reopened late last year after a three-year overhaul, along with coming debuts of Zemi Beach Resort and Spa, an opulent 115-room resort, and the Reef by CuisinArt, a boutique hotel powered by a four-acre solar field.
