text: These modern talismans give a hint of hippie magic.

headline: Ball Corporation in Merger Talks With British Aluminum Can Maker Rexam
text: LONDON – Rexam, the British aluminum can maker, said on Thursday that it was in talks to potentially be acquired by Ball Corporation in a deal that would value it at 4.29 billion pounds, or about $6.5 billion.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Love (III)’
text: This Poetry Pairing features George Herbert’s poem “Love (III)” and the Vows column “Their Chart-Toppers Are Each Other” by Lois Smith Brady.

headline: China Holds a Canadian It Says Stole State Secrets
text: BEIJING — A Canadian man with ties to a Christian group that provides humanitarian aid to North Koreans has been formally detained by China on suspicion of stealing state secrets, while his wife, also Canadian, was released on bail after they were held for six months without charge, China’s Foreign Ministry said Thursday.

headline: New York Finally Gets Its Own Men’s Wear Week — But Will Anybody Come?
text: A week before the autumn-winter 2015 women’s wear collections are due to kick off in New York, the Council of Fashion Designers of America finally confirmed the rumors that have been floating around and announced that it is creating a standalone men’s wear week, to take place from July 13 to 16.

headline: The Secret World of a Well-Paid ‘Donor Adviser’ in Politics
text: A constellation of left-leaning nonprofits and “super PACs” are raising tens of millions of dollars to pave the way for Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign — and nearly all of them have paid Mary Pat Bonner a cut.

headline: Decade-Long Night Curfew to Be Lifted in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — Seeking to normalize life in the embattled capital, Iraq’s prime minister said on Thursday that the authorities would lift a nighttime curfew in Baghdad that has been in force, with some interruptions, for over a decade.

headline: Greek Debt Diplomacy Doesn’t Sell Well in Germany
text: BERLIN — An attempt by Greece to shift the country’s debt narrative away from austerity ran into a wall of inflexibility during a two-day trip to Germany.

headline: Rapping a Revolution
text: “If Hamilton were on Twitter, he would have been a worse oversharer than me,” said the composer-performer Lin-Manuel Miranda recently over lunch at Fraunces Tavern in Lower Manhattan. Mr. Miranda, who won a Tony for the score of “In the Heights,” was holding forth on Alexander Hamilton, the nation’s first treasury secretary, who is the unlikely subject of his new musical, “Hamilton,” now in previews at the Public Theater. In contrast to such relatively taciturn rivals as Thomas Jefferson and Aaron Burr, Mr. Miranda said, “Everything we know about Hamilton, we knew when he was alive, because he told us.”

headline: In Delicate Dance With Gravity, Downhill Racers Are Soothed by Cacophony
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — In an Alpine downhill race, there is no more lonely and solitary position than standing over a pair of skis hurtling down the mountain at 80 miles an hour.

headline: Menendez’s Views on Cuba and Iran Show Rifts With Obama
text: WASHINGTON — When Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey said last week that he would give President Obama two months before defying a veto threat and voting for new sanctions on Iran, he made it clear that the delay was not out of loyalty to his fellow Democrat in the Oval Office.

headline: F.D.A. Commissioner Leaving After Six Years of Breakneck Changes
text: Dr. Margaret Hamburg, the commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, who led the agency for nearly six years through a period of rapid change in medical science, announced Thursday that she was stepping down.

headline: First Draft Focus: At First Light
text: Morning lights in the residence at The White House.

headline: Lazard Reports Higher Profit on Surge in M.&A.
text: The boom in mergers and acquisitions last year helped Lazard, the boutique investment bank, report a fourth-quarter profit that exceeded analysts’ expectations.

headline: Interpublic Adds New Directors, Settling Fight With Elliott
text: The Interpublic Group, the home of advertising agencies like McCann and FCB, said on Thursday that it would shake up its board, part of a settlement with the $25 billion activist hedge fund Elliott Management.

headline: 1915: Germans Threaten Shipping
text: LONDON — Amplifying its programme of attempting to torpedo hospital ships and sink merchantmen without warning and without giving a chance to their non- combatants aboard to escape, Germany has now issued the following amazing proclamation, which is in effect a declaration of war on the neutral commerce, and therefore on the neutral nations of the world: ‘‘The seas surrounding Great Britain and Ireland, including the whole of the English Channel, are hereby declared to be a military zone. On and after February 18, the merchant shipping of the belligerent nations navigating these waters will be destroyed, even when it may not be possible to preserve the crews and passengers from danger.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 6, 1915

headline: Sam Smith Rises in a Crowded Field for 2015 Grammys
text: Before Sam Smith can be crowned pop music’s new prince, he will have to make it past the queen.

headline: The Asian Heritage Network Talks ‘Fresh Off the Boat’
text: The Times has a number of affinity groups that bring colleagues with similar interests together. Pradnya Joshi is news editor for the DealBook section and is co-chairwoman of one such group: the Asian Heritage Network. The Times’s chairman and publisher, Arthur O. Sulzberger Jr., is the network’s executive sponsor this year.

headline: Checkpoints and Cash: Reporting From Ukraine
text: This week, Rick Lyman’s report from Horlivka, in eastern Ukraine, portrayed a slice of life of pro-Russian rebel fighters. But what of life as a reporter on the ground? Here he describes a reporting experience that includes pockets lined with cash, body armor and a Russian steam room.

headline: The Sounds of the Downhill
text: Start-house beeps, chattering skis, wind in their ears and the eerie silence of a fall; some of the top ski racers in the world describe the sounds of a World Cup downhill.

headline: Guns, Drugs and Money
text: Marijuana is legal in Colorado, but federal law makes banking nearly impossible for the cannabis industry. The result is a dangerous, all-cash operation that requires armed guards and layers of security.

headline: Hannibal Buress on His Favorite Comedians, Colors and Coffeehouse
text: For an “underground” comedian, Hannibal Buress is fairly omnipresent these days. On television, he is a co-star on both “Broad City” and “The Eric Andre Show.” On stage, he is currently touring the country and will appear at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Sunday, Feb 8. And lately in the media, he has gained (somewhat reluctant) recognition for bringing the allegations against Bill Cosby into the public dialogue.

headline: Voicing a Robot — and Schlepping It Around, Too
text: As anyone who has seen “Interstellar” can attest, it’s not difficult to get attached to TARS, the semi-snarky, heroic robot who rarely strays from Matthew McConaughey’s side — even when they get sucked into a black hole! And even after that!

headline: Well Book Club:  Raising an Unspoiled Child
text: Welcome to the Well Book Club, a place where readers can explore new or overlooked books about family, food, fitness and personal health. Every month, we will meet the author of the selected title, who will join us for weekly discussions online as we all read the book together.

headline: The First Bank of Bud
text: It was zero degrees in Denver on a late December morning, and the ice-covered streets were mostly empty. Mark Mason, wearing a full-length black coat, green wool hat and sunglasses, sat in a white Buick LaCrosse, eyeing the squat building across the street. It was the local branch of the Federal Reserve Bank.

headline: Netrebko to Replace Garanca at Carnegie
text: Don’t think of it as losing an Elina. Think of it as gaining an Anna.

headline: Patina
text: West African cuisine in the Bronx

headline: The Earth and Heat of Nigeria
text: “You don’t eat, we fight,” said the woman who had brought out the heaping platter, hands on hips. Then she leaned forward and gently folded up the ends of my sweater sleeves, which were drooping dangerously close to the food. “So they don’t get dirty,” she said, before disappearing into the kitchen.

headline: DuPont to Add 2 New Directors, but None From Peltz’s Slate
text: DuPont plans to change the lineup of its board members — but won’t draw from the nominees proposed by the activist investor Nelson Peltz.

headline: Global Debt Has Risen by $57 Trillion Since the Financial Crisis
text: Here are two things we know about how debt affects the economy.

headline: W.R. Grace to Split in Two
text: One year after emerging from the longest bankruptcy in United States history, W.R. Grace, the chemicals company marred by its legacy of products tainted by asbestos, is splitting in two.

headline: Pope, in a First, Will Address Congress in September
text: Pope Francis will address a joint meeting of Congress on Sept. 24, becoming the first pontiff to do so.

headline: Pierre Boulez Tribute Set in Lucerne
text: The 90th birthday of Pierre Boulez is being marked around the world this year with concerts, festivals, and the release of boxed sets of his recordings.

headline: Subprime Borrowers Often Lured by High-Fee Credit Cards
text: UNSOLICITED credit card offers can sound especially appealing to people with blemished credit, or a sparse borrowing history, since they lack alternatives.

headline: First Draft Focus: Dalai Lama and Golden Rule
text: — President Obama, speaking at the National Prayer Breakfast this morning.

headline: A Ride for the Trees in Florida
text: Registration is open for the annual bicycling fund-raiser for the Tree Fund, a nonprofit that sponsors a weeklong ride in a different North American location each year. This year’s ride is being held in Florida.

headline: Business Books Reveal a Billionaire Obsession
text: Who wants to be a billionaire? Everyone it seems, and not always to good effect.

headline: Applied Art
text: As fashion continues to demand ever more output and speed, many designers are finding freedom in the artisanal.

headline: Lorne Michaels Looks Back on ‘Saturday Night Live’
text: The ninth-floor office of Lorne Michaels at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, overlooking the storied Studio 8H where “Saturday Night Live” is performed, is furnished with framed photographs of the current “S.N.L.” cast and ready supplies of popcorn and Tootsie Rolls and Pops. But it is also a war room where, on a recent Friday night, Mr. Michaels, the creator and longtime executive producer of the show, was simultaneously planning a new broadcast of this NBC sketch-comedy institution and a 40th anniversary special, to be shown Feb. 15, that will bring alumni including Bill Murray, Tina Fey, Eddie Murphy and Will Ferrell back to the studio. NBC will also re-air the 1975 debut episode of “S.N.L.” on Feb. 14.

headline: Kerry and Poroshenko Meet in Ukraine
text: Secretary of State John Kerry and President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine held talks on what they said was continuing Russian aggression in the east of the country.

headline: George Takei to Star in Broadway Musical About Interned Japanese-Americans
text: “Allegiance,” a musical about Japanese-Americans in United States internment camps during World War II, will begin performances on Broadway in October at a Shubert theater to be announced later, the show’s producers said Thursday. The musical, which will cost a relatively hefty $13 million to mount, will star George Takei, who is best known as Mr. Sulu in the original “Star Trek” television series, and whose personal experiences in internment camps in Arkansas and California inspired “Allegiance.”

headline: Critics Seize On Obama’s ISIS Remarks at Prayer Breakfast
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama may have thought he was giving a straightforward history lesson at the National Prayer Breakfast on Thursday when he compared the atrocities of the Islamic State to the bloodshed committed in the name of Christianity in centuries past.

headline: Damage to Records in Brooklyn Warehouse Fire Is Less Than Feared, Officials Say
text: New York City has reassessed the extent of the damage to public records caused by a seven-alarm warehouse fire in Brooklyn over the weekend and expects it to be less than initially feared, city officials said Thursday.

headline: Amy Pascal Lands in Sony’s Outbox
text: LOS ANGELES — Amy Pascal, an old-style studio chief who was undercut by new Hollywood economics and bruised by the airing of private emails in a devastating cyberattack, said on Thursday that she would resign her post as the top film executive at Sony Pictures Entertainment.

headline: Drone Strike in Yemen Said to Kill Senior Qaeda Figure
text: SANA, Yemen — A senior member of Al Qaeda who had issued a statement saying the group had encouraged the terrorist attacks in Paris last month was killed in a drone strike on Saturday, the militant group said on Thursday.

headline: Wine and Chocolate Pairings for Valentine’s Day
text: With the arrival of February comes a question as inevitable as long-stem roses, come-hither lingerie and ridiculously bad Valentine’s Day restaurant deals: What wine goes best with chocolate?

headline: Standard & Poor’s Was Let Off Easy
text: In its self-described vigorous pursuit of wrongdoing in the financial crisis, the Justice Department has announced with fanfare the settlement of one case after another, proudly extolling the seemingly large penalties it has extracted.

headline: Checking Your Own References
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: ‘Falsettos’ to Return to Broadway in 2016
text: “Falsettos,” the Tony Award-winning musical about a man who leaves his wife and son to be with another man in the early years of the AIDS crisis, will be revived on Broadway in the spring of 2016, the show’s producer, Jordan Roth, announced on Thursday.

headline: Disney’s Head of Parks Is Named to No. 2 Spot
text: LOS ANGELES — Succession at Disney became clearer on Thursday, as Thomas O. Staggs beat out a rival to become the company’s No. 2 executive, a post that makes him the favorite to replace Robert A. Iger as chief executive in 2018.

headline: Iowa Republicans See Renewed National Clout
text: DES MOINES — In the early jockeying among presidential candidates, Iowa’s Republican leaders see signs that their state, which once seemed on the brink of political irrelevance, is back in the game.

headline: ‘Marijuana Can Be Helpful,’ Admits Surgeon General
text: Although the Justice Department under President Obama has given states some breathing room on marijuana—whether it’s used for medical or recreational purposes—the administration has held the line where federal law is concerned. In public, administration officials continue to say they think the drug should be illegal, and that they won’t consider rescheduling it even though it’s in the same category as heroin. The nominee for attorney general, Loretta Lynch, suggested at her confirmation hearing that marijuana was more dangerous than alcohol, an opinion that goes against available evidence.

headline: Singer Gary Glitter Convicted of Sexual Abuse in Britain
text: LONDON — The former glam rocker Gary Glitter was found guilty on Thursday of sexually abusing three young girls decades ago, and he could spend the rest of his life in prison.

headline: Venezuela Files Charges Accusing Pharmacy Executives of Economic Sabotage
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Amid a government campaign to blame Venezuela’s capitalist enemies for deep economic problems, the authorities have filed charges against two executives of the country’s largest pharmacy chain, accusing them of seeking to destabilize the economy by allowing a long line to form outside a store.

headline: MoMA Cuts Out Closing Hours for Last Look at Matisse Show
text: The immersive dose of color that is the Museum of Modern Art’s show on Matisse’s cutouts has been a potent antidote to these gray days of winter, and now museum-goers can get their fix any time during the coming weekend. The exhibition will be open to the public 24 hours a day from 10:30 a.m. Friday through 5:30 p.m. on Sunday. It closes for good on Tuesday.

headline: Jordanians Step Up Bombing Raids on ISIS
text: WASHINGTON — Jordan sharply increased airstrikes against the Islamic State in Syria on Thursday in retaliation for the immolation of one of its pilots, as the United States sent additional Black Hawk helicopters to Erbil in northern Iraq to increase the number of aircraft and personnel on call to rescue downed pilots.

headline: Obama at National Prayer Event
text: The president stressed the importance of religious speech at the National Prayer Breakfast in Washington on Tuesday.

headline: 301 Prompts for Argumentative Writing
text: For our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest, in which teenagers are invited to write on an issue they care about, we have gathered a list of 301 writing prompts that may help — an update to last year’s popular list of 200.

headline: Ex-Spymaster Is Called to Testify in Investigation of Argentine Prosecutor’s Death
text: BUENOS AIRES — The lead investigator in the mysterious death of Alberto Nisman, the prosecutor who accused Argentina’s president of trying to shield Iranians from responsibility over the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center here, summoned an ousted spy chief to testify in the case on Thursday.

headline: In Bedbugs, Scientists See a Model of Evolution
text: In the closing sentence of “The Origin of Species,” Charles Darwin marvels at the process of evolution, observing how “from so simple a beginning endless forms most beautiful and most wonderful have been, and are being, evolved.”

headline: Paying With ‘Lovin’’: A McDonald’s Mistake?
text: Between now and Valentine’s Day, some customers at McDonald’s will get the opportunity to pay for their food not with money but with “lovin’” — that is, by performing one of a variety of interpersonal acts including dancing, fist-bumping an employee, or calling their mothers. McDonald’s laid out some of the possibilities in an ad during Sunday’s Super Bowl:

headline: 1940: War Council Meeting in Paris
text: The fifth and most important Allied Supreme War Council met yesterday at the War Ministry in Paris to study the military and political aspects of the war, as well as to survey the European situation generally in view of possible early developments with the end of the winter. The question of supplies was given special emphasis, and the communiqué issued at the end of the day’s meetings stated that there was complete agreement on all questions taken up. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 6, 1940

headline: London Stock Exchange Looks to Sell Russell Asset Management Business
text: LONDON – The London Stock Exchange said on Thursday that it planned to put the investment management arm of Russell Investments up for sale, a move that was widely anticipated after it bought the owner of the Russell 2000 stock market index last year.

headline: A Deal That Could Reverse Pfizer’s History of Value-Destroying Acquisitions
text: Pfizer has made more than its share of value-destroying acquisitions. The pharmaceutical giant’s $15.2 billion purchase of Hospira could reverse that history. The injectable-drug maker’s strength in non-branded medications should bolster Pfizer’s own generics unit – and open the way for spinning it off.

headline: Pfizer Deal and Other Mergers Show a Case of the Mondays, on a Thursday
text: Wall Street has a late-in-the-week case of the Mondays.

headline: Promise of Europe Lures Syrians and Smugglers
text: SIDE, Turkey — He left his home in Syria over a year ago and set out more than a dozen times, he said, on perilous and ill-fated seaborne journeys to the promised lands of Western Europe. He never made it. In his last attempt, the fishing boat he was on capsized, killing 44 people, including one of his best friends.

headline: Lawmakers Aim to Protect Farm Animals in U.S. Research
text: Farm animals used in federal experiments to help the meat industry would receive new protections against mistreatment and neglect under legislation introduced on Thursday by a bipartisan group of lawmakers from both houses of Congress.

headline: ‘Boys Who Tricked Me,’ at the Musical Theater Factory
text: Everyone has a story when it comes to love. Ben Bonnema has enough tales to write an entire musical, but he still needs your help.

headline: Haunting Portraits of Abandoned Places
text: The photographer Aurélien Villette explores spaces that have been left behind, from the sacred to the industrial.

headline: A Love for Vintage Dolls That Never Grows Old
text: Deborah J. Neff, a toy collector in suburban Connecticut, has acquired hundreds of antique cloth dolls depicting African-Americans. They were handmade from the 1850s to the 1930s, but little information has survived about their seamstresses and original owners. About 125 of Ms. Neff’s dolls, as well as vintage photos of white and black children holding the playthings, go on view Saturday at Mingei International Museum in San Diego.

headline: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
text: 55 YEARS AGO

headline: Gauguin Painting Is Said to Fetch $300 Million
text: LONDON — A sensuous Paul Gauguin painting of two Tahitian girls has been sold from a Swiss private collection for close to $300 million, one of the highest prices believed to have been paid for an artwork, according to European and American art world insiders with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Modern Love College Essay Contest
text: We invited college students nationwide to open their hearts and laptops and write an essay that tells the truth about what love is like for them today.

headline: The Moral Appeal of P.C.
text: By way of a parting thought on the political correctness debate, I’m going to quote from a 2011 argument from Brendan O’Neill, the editor of the British magazine Spiked, in which he talks both about the essential appeal of the strident moralism inherent in a lot of what gets labeled as P.C., and about why it can exert so much effective pressure on institutions that seem like they should be better equipped to resist. Here’s O’Neill:

headline: MoMA PS1 Names Winner of Summer Architecture Competition
text: The transformation of MoMA PS1’s outdoor courtyard in Long Island City by an emerging architect has become one of the art world’s rites of summer. The popularity of these temporary installations has made its architectural competition increasingly stiff. In this, the 16th year of the Young Architects Program, the lucky winner is Andrés Jaque/Office for Political Innovation.

headline: Shared Custody: So Even on Paper, So Hard on the First Night
text: The first night I spent away from my son, I was certain I would never sleep. He had left with his father only a few hours before and was less than a mile away, but still my own crying was keeping me awake.

headline: How We Write About Love
text: A few months ago, I read several articles touting the health benefits of writing in a deeply personal way. Studies had shown that writing introspectively on a regular basis can lead to lowered blood pressure, improved liver function and even the accelerated healing of postoperative wounds. The study’s subjects had been told to write for short periods each day about turbulent emotional experiences.

headline: Contraceptive Coverage for Women in the Military
text: “We owe female service members the same access to contraception and family planning services as the women they fight to protect,” said Representative Jackie Speier of California, summing up the principle behind a bill she and another Democrat, Senator Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire, introduced on Wednesday.

headline: Board Strife Compounds Failed Deal for GFI
text: Open warfare appears to be breaking out on the board of the GFI Group, according to a filing on Thursday in a Delaware court.

headline: Doctor, Have You Had Your DNA Tested?
text: Several people have recently asked me if they should get their DNA sequenced. “Have you had yours tested?” they ask.

headline: Boehner Expects House G.O.P. to Accept Gay Marriage Ruling
text: Speaker John A. Boehner said on Thursday that he expected House Republicans to accept the decision on same-sex marriage that the Supreme Court is scheduled to issue later this year.

headline: Corcoran Gallery Art Transforms National Gallery
text: WASHINGTON — In the six months since a court allowed the Corcoran Gallery of Art here to dissolve, a victim of financial struggles, about 17,000 works in the museum’s overall collection — by masters like Degas, Sargent, Albert Bierstadt and Cy Twombly — have been in a highly unusual institutional limbo. Their fate is being adjudicated by a group of veteran curators from the National Gallery of Art, which agreed last February to bring as many Corcoran pieces under the museum’s own roof as appropriate and to help find homes for others in Washington-area public collections.

headline: Mike Nelson: ‘Gang of Seven’
text: The British artist and two-time Turner Prize nominee Mike Nelson has filled the spacious 303 Gallery with a lively crowd of lyrical sculptural assemblages made of flotsam and jetsam collected from the coastal waters of British Columbia. (The exhibition’s title, “Gang of Seven,” refers to a collective of early-20th-century Canadian landscape painters known as the Group of Seven.) They’re made of bottles, driftwood, chunks of plastic foam, lengths of frayed rope, bald tires, pieces of rusted iron, animal skulls and many other sorts of detritus.

headline: T’s Newest Pinterest Board: Full of Love, Courtesy of Aerin Lauder
text: In honor of Valentine’s Day, Aerin Lauder donned her rosiest lenses to curate a Pinterest board exclusively for T. It’s filled with inspired objects, delectable eats and swoonworthy fashion — all things pink, red, heart-shaped and sweet. Lauder, T’s first guest pinner — whose own eponymous lifestyle label just released a new rose-scented parfum in time for the holiday — shows that from the runway to the kitchen, love really is all around us.

headline: James Benning and Peter Hutton: ‘Nature Is a Discipline’
text: In the 1990s and 2000s, when celluloid film was being eclipsed by digital technology, there was an efflorescence of 16-millimeter film installations, with loud projectors and richly colored images, and a revival of interest in deceased pioneers like Paul Sharits and Hollis Frampton. One thing curiously absent — at least in galleries — was work by living artists revealing how they had (or hadn’t) made the switch from film to video.

headline: Michael Kors Earnings Exceed Analysts’ 3rd-Quarter Estimates
text: The logo-emblazoned handbags of Michael Kors are seemingly everywhere these days — and that is a growing cause of concern for the affordable luxury brand.

headline: ‘On Kawara — Silence’
text: A look at the new retrospective on the Japanese artist at the Guggenheim Museum.

headline: Madcap Stratagems of Songful Siblings
text: Sporting a sleek fire-engine red suit, Tommy Tune appears suddenly, like an exotic bird just flown in from the tropics to brighten our frigid winter, in “Lady, Be Good!,” the George and Ira Gershwin musical that’s the first production of the City Center Encores! season.

headline: Aide to Representative Schock Resigns Over Facebook Posts
text: Benjamin Cole, a senior adviser to Representative Aaron Schock, resigned Thursday after racially charged posts were discovered on his Facebook page.

headline: Bode Miller Crashes in Return, Putting His Career in Doubt
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Hurtling down the super-G course at the Alpine world ski championships at 60 miles an hour on Thursday, Bode Miller was putting down the kind of daring, electric run for which he was famous. Then came a terrifying crash that severed his right hamstring tendon and most likely ended his brilliant career.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Ballet 422’
text: The director Jody Lee Lipes narrates a sequence from his documentary “Ballet 422,” about the choreographer Justin Peck staging a new dance for New York City Ballet.

headline: Devin Troy Strother: ‘Space Jam’
text: Originality takes a holiday in Devin Troy Strother’s latest solo gallery show in New York. Apparently after an impressive debut at the Monya Rowe Gallery in 2011 and an even better sophomore follow-up at Marlborough Broome Street in 2013, this young, talented artist just wants to have fun. He does, but he also stoops to entertain, mostly abandoning his quirky little tableaus and painted cutout figures for a more generic approach to appropriation and art-about-art-about-black-popular-culture.

headline: Boko Haram, and Massacres Ruled by Whim
text: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — They came in the dead of night, their faces covered, riding on motorcycles and in pickup trucks, shouting “Allahu akbar” and firing their weapons.

headline: Jess Fuller: ‘Planet Without a Body’
text: In this terrific show, Jess Fuller exuberantly meets the challenge of inventing her own way to make paintings. Combining a parodic masculinity with intimations of women’s work, these big, squarish canvases boast a generous internal scale. They initially look simple and ham-handed but then reveal many subtle details.

headline: ‘Zero Tolerance’ at MoMA P.S. 1
text: ‘ZERO TOLERANCE’

headline: Lincoln Center to Open Great Performers Series With Schubert
text: Lincoln Center announced Thursday that it would open the 50th season of its Great Performers series in October with the acclaimed tenor Mark Padmore and pianist Paul Lewis performing the three Schubert song cycles: “Die schöne Müllerin,” “Schwanengesang” and “Winterreise.”

headline: Janice Guy: ‘Janice With Camera’
text: On the one hand, Janice Guy’s photographs from the late 1970s, on view at Cleopatra’s, are similar to what other artists, particularly women, were doing at the time. Like Francesca Woodman, Ana Mendieta, Adrian Piper, Hannah Wilke, Urs Lüthi or Cindy Sherman, Ms. Guy turned the camera on herself. And like many of these artists, she photographed herself nude, assuming the position of both author and subject of the work.

headline: Paris Calls a Halt to Outdoor Filming of Some Action Scenes
text: PARIS – Authorities have imposed new restrictions on filming movies or television shows in the city of Paris nearly a month after shootings that killed 17 people in and around the French capital. Outdoor scenes of actors in police or military uniforms and the use of fake weapons or explosives have been banned, underlining the heightened level of security after the attacks.

headline: Jody Lee Lipes Narrates a Scene From ‘Ballet 422’
text: In the documentary “Ballet 422,” the director Jody Lee Lipes chronicles the staging of a new dance by the choreographer Justin Peck, of New York City Ballet. This scene looks at a moment in the rehearsal process. Mr. Lipes discusses how the sequence was shot and what intrigues him about capturing the process of art creation.

headline: Dusting Off Gems From the Attic
text: WASHINGTON — With the closing of the Corcoran Gallery of Art here, we’ve lost a venerable museum but gained access to an eclectic, in odd corners brilliant, time capsule of a collection. Long housed in a block-filling chunk of Beaux-Arts granite that also held an art school, the museum had limited exhibition space and could show only a fraction of its holdings of 17,000 works. Now nearly half of them are being absorbed into the National Gallery of Art. And maybe just as important, the remainder will be parceled out to other Washington-area museums, raising the chances that, with a little schlepping, we’ll eventually be able to see more of the Corcoran than we could when it was intact.

headline: Twitter’s Revenue Grows Despite User Stagnation
text: Twitter just can’t seem to catch a break.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: running speed, supplements and depression. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Who Rosa Parks Was, Not Just What She Meant
text: WASHINGTON — Newly released papers offer a look at the feisty spirit of the seemingly mild Rosa Parks, who helped set off one of the seminal events of the civil rights movement, the Montgomery bus boycott.

headline: A Winding Road to the Yankees
text: Images of Rob Refsnyder, a top Yankees prospect, who was born in Seoul, South Korea, and whose adoption story has made him an inspiration to some adopted children and their parents.

headline: 1950 | A Times Casualty in a Railroad Nightmare
text: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: After Sony Hacking, the M.P.A.A. Considers Major Changes
text: LOS ANGELES — Fissures revealed by the hacking at Sony Pictures Entertainment have raised the prospect of profound change at one of Hollywood’s oldest institutions: the Motion Picture Association of America.

headline: Meth King’s Lawyer: The Early Years
text: Nobody wanted it to end, so the creators of “Breaking Bad” came up with a new beginning.

headline: Family Sues Pop Warner Over Suicide of Player Who Had Brain Disease
text: The family of a football player who committed suicide and was later found to have chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a degenerative brain disease, has sued the youth league Pop Warner, claiming that it failed to warn players about, and protect them from, the dangers of head trauma.

headline: Which Movies and Television Shows Get Veterans Right? Or Wrong?
text: Whenever movies about the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan come up when I’m interviewing veterans, talk inevitably turns to “The Hurt Locker.” Almost everyone who has deployed tells me they found the portrayals of life on an Explosive Ordnance Disposal team in Iraq laughably over the top: Since when do bomb techs ride out into the desert solo in full sniper gear?

headline: ‘Surround Audience’
text: The New Museum’s 2015 triennial is digital and beyond.

headline: As the World Embraces Diesels, Americans Still Play Hard to Get
text: LOOKING to increase his fuel economy, Roderick Smith of Woonsocket, R.I., who works in information technology, bought a new Volkswagen Golf at the beginning of the year. Unlike most Americans, Mr. Smith opted for a model equipped with a diesel, rather than a gasoline, engine.

headline: ‘American Masterworks From the Corcoran’
text: Works in the new show at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

headline: Where Virtual Equals Real
text: It is early 2009. Hope and change are in the air. President Obama stands before the camera delivering his Inaugural Address, but within seconds something seems off. The speech is not the pragmatic one he gave on that cold January day but a fiery message in which he excoriates “peddlers of hate whose stock-in-trade is xenophobia, homophobia, racism, sexism and isolationism, and who define America by our differences rather than our common bonds.”

headline: The Righteous Ranter, Howling at Left and Right
text: Andrew Napier’s “Mad as Hell” takes its title from Howard Beale’s famous rant in “Network” exhorting viewers to vent their anger. But the reference sets the stakes a little high: Will this documentary about the political pundit Cenk Uygur have as much to say about the media as Sidney Lumet’s 1976 classic, “Network,” did?

headline: No, More Running Probably Isn’t Bad for You
text: Don’t run less hard. Don’t run less often. Don’t run less distance. And don’t be persuaded by underpowered medical studies — a habit that really could harm your health.

headline: A Life Captivated by the Wonder of Time
text: The seemingly dry, narrow-gauge art of the Conceptual giant On Kawara is profound — profoundly simple, human and deep. And, as proved by that artist’s first full-dress retrospective, “On Kawara — Silence” at the Guggenheim Museum, its quality is most apparent when it is seen in quantity.

headline: With an Apology, Brian Williams Digs Himself Deeper in Copter Tale
text: For years, Brian Williams had been telling a story that wasn’t true. On Wednesday night, he took to his anchor chair on “NBC Nightly News” to apologize for misleading the public.

headline: An Internet-Age Music Collective Beloved by Telfar and Hood by Air
text: Everything about the R&B group Future Brown’s self-titled debut album, out Feb. 24 on Warp Records, comes across as perfectly calculated. The group strikes a balance between male and female vocals, between futuristic, icy beats and incisive lyrics and even between coasts: It consists of the Los Angeles producers Asma Maroof and Daniel Pineda (who also perform together as Nguzunguzu) and their New York counterparts, Fatima Al Qadiri and J-Cush. But in fact, according to Al Qadiri, the group’s modus operandi is less deliberate than it seems. “It’s all on accident,” as Al Qadiri says, backstage at a show at Los Angeles’ Catch One disco. “The thing that unites Future Brown is that there’s very little agenda.” The four D.J.s, who sit at the intersection of music, art and fashion, are linked through their ties to DIS Magazine, a tongue-in-cheek lifestyle webzine that Al Qadiri describes as an incubator for artists working in different mediums. “We’re indebted to curators that want to bring fresh air into the art world,” Al Qadiri says.

headline: Adrift in a Disaster Zone
text: If the point of “Call for Help” is to glorify a handful of off-the-grid heroes, it fails. If the point is to follow some young people who took their aimless wanderlust to a trouble spot and perhaps created more problems than they solved, it succeeds.

headline: On Deck for the Yankees, From South Korea, Rob Refsnyder
text: TAMPA, Fla. — At the end of all those baseball showcases in Orange County, Calif., the format would often be the same. Few of the coaches and children who had come together for the day knew one another. The director would stand in front of the players and call out the names of those who had excelled that day: the best fielder, the best arm, the best hitter.

headline: Meditative to Clamorous, but Always in Control
text: There’s a set of qualities in Ravi Coltrane’s sound on tenor saxophone — dark, dry and cool — that extends to the character of his bands. That’s bands, plural, despite his decade-long run with one quartet in particular, which ended a few years ago. Mr. Coltrane has experimented with other lineups since, bringing in new partners who can acclimate quickly to the limber, even-tempered shadow dance of his style.

headline: Tappan Zee Bridge Graces Cover of the Federal Budget
text: To much surprise and with little fanfare, the Tappan Zee Bridge assumed a place in national politics this week, a new ironclad symbol of President Obama’s federal budget for the 2016 fiscal year, of all things.

headline: Governor of Florida Turns Aside Accusations
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Facing a lawsuit, an ethics complaint and repeated demands for an investigation into the ouster of a top law enforcement official, Gov. Rick Scott admitted on Thursday that he could have handled the official’s resignation better but called accusations of impropriety “ridiculous and untrue.”

headline: Before the First Bell, a Nearly 10-Mile Walk
text: The documentary “On the Way to School” declares its importance from its opening title card. “Too often we forget how lucky we are to go to school,” it says. To illustrate this point, the movie trails children from three continents on what, in most cases, are their daily journeys “toward knowledge.” As they set off, we are given the distance and the duration of their travels.

headline: Rituals: Reader Submissions
text: Share a photo of your campus ritual. View submissions. Submit yours.

headline: It’s Tradition
text: What would college be without its crazy customs?

headline: Texas Museum to Build Ellsworth Kelly Design
text: In 1986, the painter and sculptor Ellsworth Kelly conceived his first free-standing building for a private collector, but it was never realized. Now, as Mr. Kelly prepares to turn 92 in May, the Blanton Museum of Art will acquire and construct his design for a 2,715-square-foot stone building, which will rise on the museum’s grounds at the University of Texas, Austin.

headline: A Family on a Mission, Zipping Through Space
text: Every generation, it seems, has its animated space adventure series, and today’s pint-size set gets an enjoyable one beginning Friday morning when “Miles From Tomorrowland” has its debut on Disney Junior.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Terrorist Detainees Should ‘Rot in Hell’
text: Senator Tom Cotton, Republican of Arkansas, insisted at a hearing on Thursday that the Guantanamo Bay detention facility should stay open and that, if anything, it was too good for terrorist suspects.

headline: His Own Threatening Soundtrack
text: The psychiatric thriller “Enter the Dangerous Mind” (originally titled “Snap”) tries to plumb the extremities of mental illness and childhood trauma for nerve-scraping frights. But despite a novel pursuit for its troubled protagonist — he’s a part-time composer of electronic dance music — the filmmakers, Youssef Delara and Victor Teran, fall back on some familiar beats.

headline: Jordan, Unabashed, Announces Latest Bombing Raid on ISIS Targets
text: AMMAN, Jordan — Jordanian warplanes bombed Islamic State targets on Thursday, the Jordanian military said, after King Abdullah II promised a “harsh” response to the militant group’s brutal killing of a captured Jordanian pilot.

headline: He’s Smitten, and That’s the Problem
text: With the reek of straight-to-video wafting from every frame, “Lovesick” astonishes most by its appearance in an actual theater. But it’s February, and pickings are slim, so this soulless, sterile romantic comedy has slipped under the wire to give audiences a headache and Matt LeBlanc’s reputation a relapse.

headline: The Art Fair Scene Heads South of the Border
text: On the heels of Los Angeles’s expanding art week, sun-chasing aesthetes push south to Mexico City’s Distrito Federal for Zona Maco and all the festivities organized around the city’s most established art fair. The main event was inaugurated last night at the Centro Banamex, an imposing conference complex on the outskirts of the posh northern regions of the city. Now on view to the public until Sunday, the fair counts David Zwirner, Zurich’s Mai 36, Bogotá’s Casas Riegner and local heavyweights like Kurimanzutto, Labor and OMR among its exhibitors. With sections siloed for new galleries, the southern hemisphere, modern art and design, Maco models itself after the department-store variety of mega-events like Art Basel and Frieze, where all of the visitors’ shopping needs are met under the roof of one neighborhood-sized building.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Syria and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Feb. 5, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Syria, Germany, Switzerland and Spain.

headline: Did He at Least Say Thank You?
text: My boyfriend of one year broke up with me a week after I paid $700 for his birthday dinner. I can’t afford luxuries, so I will be paying it off for months. He ended our relationship because he was “not at my commitment level.” I’m glad he was honest, but I can’t shake the feeling that he deliberately waited to enjoy the dinner before breaking up. (It was long planned.) I think the decent thing would be for him to split the cost with me. May I ask?

headline: Verbatim: President Ernst? She’s Honored
text: – Senator Joni Ernst, Republican of Iowa, responding to a new poll that said many Republican caucusgoers at home think she has what it takes to be president.

headline: Mandy Grunwald to Join Clinton Team
text: Mandy Grunwald, an adviser to the Clintons for over two decades and a top strategist to Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, is expected to serve as a senior adviser for communications to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s all-but-certain presidential bid.

headline: RadioShack Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy After a Deal With Sprint
text: For years, RadioShack — the retailer that helped bring personal computers to the masses — outlasted untold predictions that it would buckle in the face of bigger rivals and online competitors.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: The Spreading Rage at ISIS
text: Terrorism has long had a gruesome role in conflicts, often among revolutionary groups so fanatically certain of their ends that they readily justify the most barbaric of means. But it can also turn with a vengeance against those who inflict it, as the Islamic State is learning with its most recently publicized atrocity — murdering a Jordanian air force pilot by burning him alive. The video of the killing was meant to dissuade Arabs from participating in the Western coalition against the group; instead, it has succeeded in fostering rage and revulsion against the jihadists throughout the Arab world.

headline: East and West Meet, Checking Norms at the Door
text: After a leave of absence in 2003, the Thai artist Araya Rasdjarmrearnsook returned to Chiang Mai University, where she teaches, apparently pregnant. Her friends and co-workers reacted joyfully to this surprising turn of events. Then, nine days later, she announced that she wasn’t with child at all, and that her fake pregnancy was a work of performance art called “The Nine-Day Pregnancy of a Single Middle-Aged Associate Professor.” She documented it in a fragmentary five-minute video, in which viewers hear her thoughts on pregnancy and about her colleagues’ disappointed and angry reactions to her deception.

headline: Theater Listings for Feb. 6-12
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Comedy Listings for Feb. 6-12
text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Listings for Feb. 6-12
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: ‘Tell It Like It Is’
text: Images from films in the survey of black independent film of New York from 1968 to 1986, playing at the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

headline: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for Feb. 6-12
text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Suit Against Pop Warner
text: The family of a football player who committed suicide in 2012 at age 25 has filed a wrongful death lawsuit in federal court in Wisconsin against Pop Warner.

headline: Jazz Listings for Feb. 6-12
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Peeling Back the Layers of Black Indie Film
text: To watch Kathleen Collins’s “Losing Ground” — a 1982 film making its long-awaited theatrical debut at Lincoln Center on Friday as part of “Tell It Like It Is,” a sprawling survey of black independent film of New York from 1968 to 1986 — is to experience a curious blend of nostalgia and novelty. The clothes the characters wear, how they talk and what they talk about, the grainy texture of the images and the weariness of the world they capture — all of these emerge from a time capsule devoted to an era that doesn’t quite have a name. But partly because those images have remained unseen for so long, and partly because Ms. Collins, who died in 1988, was such a bold and idiosyncratic filmmaker, “Losing Ground” also feels like news, like a bulletin from a vital and as-yet-unexplored dimension of reality.

headline: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Feb. 6-12
text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Profit at Moelis & Co. Falls Short of Expectations
text: The boutique investment bank Moelis & Company on Thursday reported a higher fourth-quarter profit, though its results fell short of Wall Street’s expectations.

headline: Pond Hockey: They’re Naturals
text: Images from the United States Pond Hockey Championships in Minneapolis. The sport has grown from a curiosity into one of hockey’s most popular genres.

headline: Philip Johnson’s Homes
text: The legendary architect and his companion, the curator David Whitney, spent their weekends in the world’s most famous transparent box. Or did they?

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Feb. 6-12
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Dance Listings for Feb. 6-12
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: After a Decade Building Trust, an Anchor Starts a Firestorm With One Wrong Move
text: It is a “thing that you build slowly, over time,” according to grandiloquent promos last fall that extolled Brian Williams’s 10th anniversary as anchor of “NBC Nightly News.” Over shots of Mr. Williams talking to soldiers and small children in war zones and disaster areas, the narrator, Michael Douglas, adds, “And what you build, if you work hard enough, if you respect it, is a powerful thing called trust.”

headline: Spare Times Listings for Feb. 6-12
text: Museums and Sites

headline: With Back Problems, Tiger Woods Withdraws After 11 Holes
text: SAN DIEGO — Tiger Woods’s latest comeback suffered another setback Thursday when he quit after 11 holes of his opening round at the Farmers Insurance Open, citing a stiff back.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Feb. 6-12
text: BAMkids Film Festival

headline: A Visit to McDonald’s, Celebrity Chef in Tow
text: With all the recent excitement over Shake Shack — its share price more than doubled the day it went public last week — and Habit Burger, whose share price also more than doubled when it went public in November, you’d think America was entering a new golden age of the burger.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Feb. 6, 2015
text: The New York Times film critics review “Jupiter Ascending,” “The Voices” and “Ballet 422.”

headline: A Student and a Principal Pay a Visit to the White House
text: The online photography project “Humans of New York” aims to tell the story of the people of the city, one photo at a time. While each picture is shared and liked thousands of times across social media, one recent string of photos, featuring a young student and a principal from Brooklyn, made it all the way to the White House.

headline: Investigators Ask Why So Many Died on Train in Metro-North Crash
text: TARRYTOWN, N.Y. — Two days after the deadliest train crash in the history of the Metro-North Railroad, investigators on Thursday sought to shed light on a central mystery of the crash: how a train-on-car crash spread its devastation to the interior of the train.

headline: Designing a World of His Own
text: The man who once billed himself as the “world’s greatest photographer” has a new exhibit that shows lesser-known work with a quiet, classical bent.

headline: A Fly on the Wall, Watching a Troupe Work Toward Seamless Grace
text: Works of art are made from the inside out, as the passions, ideas and instincts of artists blossom into objective forms. Most movies about the making of art tend to proceed in the opposite direction, inviting us, as we observe the labor of creation, to infer what we can about the inspiration behind it.

headline: 9 Recent Cyberattacks Against Big Businesses
text: Cyberattacks have become an ever-increasing threat, and the F.B.I. now ranks cybercrime as one of its top law enforcement activities. Here are some of the major attacks on United States businesses in recent years.

headline: A World Premiere of Pure Dance to a Familiar Score
text: Three years ago, Justin Peck had choreographed no professional ballet. Today his works (new commissions and existing pieces) are in demand across America, and he has been resident choreographer at New York City Ballet since July. Not everything he has made, however, has succeeded. It seems fair to ask this season if he will prove one of those rare artists who, having begun with several important successes, can grow further.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses 4 in Silicon Valley of Insider Trading
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As an in-house financial specialist at two Silicon Valley technology companies, Christian B. Keller was privy to confidential information he agreed not to share.

headline: Obama Budget’s Call for Increased Funding for N.H.T.S.A. Faces Uncertainty
text: After a year of a record number of recalls in the auto industry, the Obama administration is aiming in its proposed budget to nearly triple the funding for defect investigations at the government’s auto safety agency and increase its overall budget by 20 percent annually over six years.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Ballet 422’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Ballet 422.”

headline: Patricia Arquette Grows Into ‘Boyhood’
text: After 25 years in show business, Patricia Arquette has reached a high point in her career with “Boyhood,” in which she allowed herself to age naturally onscreen.

headline: In a Setting Well Suited to Humility
text: The bright-toned, openhearted tenor Matthew Polenzani, who returned to his native New York in recital at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday, rose through the ranks at the Metropolitan Opera the old-fashioned way. He started in the late 1990s in truly tiny roles — remind me, who’s Khrushchov in Mussorgsky’s “Boris Godunov”? — then gradually moved into minor but noticeable parts, the likes of Arturo in Donizetti’s “Lucia di Lammermoor” and Jaquino in Beethoven’s “Fidelio.”

headline: A Difficult, Technical Subject (Personal Meta)
text: In his incredible essay “The Great Slump of 1930” – an essay that reads remarkably well to this day, as an analysis of our crisis as well as his – Keynes briefly vents a bit of frustration. “For — though no one will believe it—economics is a technical and difficult subject.”

headline: Old Tradition of Secularism Clashes With France’s New Reality
text: ROSNY-SOUS-BOIS, France — Laïcité, the concept of state secularism, is a defining principle of the French republic, right up there with the national motto of liberty, equality and fraternity. Developed in the French Revolution, which targeted the Roman Catholic Church as much as the monarchy, laïcité governs the public life of a nation that sharply delineates the realms of Caesar and God.

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Voices’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Voices.”

headline: The Cat Made Him Do It
text: Is Jerry, who works in the shipping department of a small-town bathtub factory and who is played by Ryan Reynolds, a quirky misfit or something more dangerous? This question hovers for a little while over “The Voices” but resolves itself even before Jerry starts filling his refrigerator with severed heads of women.

headline: In Statement, Harper Lee Backs New Novel
text: Harper Lee has issued a new statement expressing her happiness with the publication of her second novel, “Go Set a Watchman,” amid growing speculation that the fiercely private novelist may have been pressured into signing over publication rights for the book.

headline: Protecting Yourself From the Consequences of Anthem’s Data Breach
text: Given the steady beat of security breaches, consumers may assume that a cybercriminal already has at least some of their personal information. But in the latest intrusion, at the health insurer Anthem, hackers got their hands on an especially valuable collection of sensitive information on millions of people.

headline: What Oscar Nominees Do to Pass the Time
text: Every year, in between the big heave known as the fall awards season and that folly we call the Academy Awards, the major movie companies turn into a cinematic slag heap of the bad, the risible and the inexplicable. Even on paper, the latest February throwaway, “Seventh Son,” sounds like a bad idea, even if it does feature the wasted talent of the veteran production designer Dante Ferretti and was directed by Sergei Bodrov, who has a few fine credits to his name. As it turns out, there are those, including this reviewer, who can be seduced into seeing just about anything if it comes with name actors like Jeff Bridges and Julianne Moore, a herd of digital dragons and the cute guy who plays that incurably know-nothing Jon Snow in the HBO show “Game of Thrones.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Jupiter Ascending’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Jupiter Ascending.”

headline: Security Strategy Recognizes U.S. Limits
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to release his second, and final, national security strategy on Friday, laying out a blueprint for robust American leadership for his remaining time in office while recognizing limits on how much the United States can shape world events.

headline: Cleaning Lady Has No Idea of Her Crucial Role in the Cosmos
text: “Jupiter Ascending,” the latest from Lana and Andy Wachowski, is a big, woozy, spacey fairy tale with a science-fiction exoskeleton and a core of pure mush. With its nods to the original “Star Trek” and David Lynch’s proto-steampunk hallucination “Dune,” it seduces the eye with filigreed flourishes even as the mind reels from some of the mildewy storytelling. Mila Kunis plays Jupiter Jones, an earthling who turns out to be the reconstituted queen of the universe or some such, which apparently means that she needs to be repeatedly rescued. An uncomfortable-looking Channing Tatum plays her hybrid honey, Caine Wise, a man-wolf with pointy ears and, my, what big, bulging muscles.

headline: Jordan: Jihadist Cleric Freed From Jail
text: Jordan released Abu Muhammad al-Maqdisi, a leading jihadist cleric, from prison on Thursday, according to the official Petra news agency. Mr. Maqdisi, who was arrested in October, was accused of “using the Internet to promote and incite views of jihadist terrorist organizations.” It is unclear why he was released. Considered a spiritual mentor to Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the leader of Al Qaeda in Iraq until his death in 2006, Mr. Maqdisi later renounced the killing of civilians and has spoken out against the Islamic State group, calling it “deviant.”

headline: New Middle East Envoy Is Appointed
text: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said on Thursday that he had appointed Nickolay E. Mladenov, a former foreign minister of Bulgaria who has been his special representative in Iraq, as his new Middle East peace envoy. Mr. Mladenov succeeds Robert H. Serry, a Dutch diplomat who has been in that post for more than seven years. A statement on the appointment, posted on the United Nations website, said Mr. Ban thanked Mr. Serry for “his dedicated service and excellent leadership” but gave no indication about Mr. Serry’s future, precisely when the change would take effect or who would replace Mr. Mladenov in Iraq.

headline: An Heir Finds Trouble on His Way to the Throne
text: The main thing to be learned from “Outcast,”  Nicholas Powell’s loony directing debut about two former Crusaders hanging out in medieval China, is that Hayden Christensen’s portrayal of opium addiction is not appreciably different from his take on clean and sober.

headline: All Hail the Lordling Dolphin!
text: Explaining the appeal of SpongeBob SquarePants is a fool’s errand, but then that’s also a pretty good description of the adventures had by this irrepressible, highly absorbent hero. “The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water” is the show’s second feature-length installment, and while less fluid and fresh than its 2004 predecessor, the new film displays enough nutty writing and sheer brio to confirm the stamina of its enduring and skillfully voiced characters.

headline: Fewer Top Graduates Want to Join Teach for America
text: Teach for America, the education powerhouse that has sent thousands of handpicked college graduates to teach in some of the nation’s most troubled schools, is suddenly having recruitment problems.

headline: U.S. Business Group Urges Resistance to Chinese Policy
text: United States trade groups gave the Chinese government an earful last week about new policies that could hamper the ability of major technology multinationals to do business in China. Now, in a letter addressed to key United States officials, including Secretary of State John Kerry, 17 trade groups headlined by the United States Chamber of Commerce urged the government to resist the Chinese policies, according to a copy of the letter viewed Thursday by The New York Times. The letter called for the United States government to take “immediate action to work with Chinese officials to reverse an alarming number of troubling, new Chinese government policies impacting the information and communications technology sector.”

headline: A Top Aide Who Helped Mold de Blasio’s Public Image Is Leaving
text: The powerful steward of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s public image is leaving the administration, the most significant shake-up yet at a close-knit City Hall.

headline: Small Rise in New Cases Shows Ebola Hanging On
text: Officials from the United Nations and the World Health Organization expressed concern on Thursday over data showing the first weekly rise in new Ebola cases this year, countering the downward trend in the disease that has ravaged three West African nations.

headline: A Leader’s Legacy Outside the Shadow of Mandela
text: “There are not that many examples in history of leaders who negotiate the end of their own system,” an interviewee says in “The Other Man: F. W. de Klerk and the End of Apartheid.” But the man who presided over South Africa’s historic transition from white minority rule to fully participative democracy — and effectively ended his own presidency — remains little known, even among his countrymen.

headline: Shifting the Spotlight Back to the Man They Knew
text: A tender reconstruction of personal loss, “Matt Shepard Is a Friend of Mine” retraces the life of the University of Wyoming student whose 1998 murder put a national spotlight on hate crimes against gay people. Variably effective, this debut feature documentary from Michele Josue seeks to restore the Matt Shepard of his friends’ and family’s memories, and in so doing return a human symbol to a state of ordinary but beloved individuality.

headline: New Harvard Policy Bans Teacher-Student Relations
text: Harvard University has adopted a ban on professors’ having sexual or romantic relationships with undergraduate students, joining a small but growing number of universities prohibiting such relationships. The move comes as the Obama administration investigates the handling of accusations of sexual assault at dozens of colleges, including Harvard.

headline: Anthem Hacking Points to Security Vulnerability of Health Care Industry
text: The cyberattack on Anthem, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, points to the vulnerability of health care companies, which security specialists say are behind other industries in protecting sensitive personal information.

headline: Review: ‘Boy Meets Girl,’ Directed by Eric Schaeffer
text: “Boy Meets Girl,” or — as the subtitle should say, “Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Being Transgender” — is a romantic comedy that’s so progressive it hurts. Placing sex and gender identity at the center of almost every conversation, the writer and director, Eric Schaeffer, is so keen to demythologize that the film’s potentially most affecting moments are too often smothered by the hackneyed characters and setups that surround them.

headline: Ally Financial Seeks Brisker Profit Under New Leadership
text: Auto sales are booming. Low gas prices are enticing more people to buy higher-priced sport utility vehicles. All this means it could be another stellar year for banks that make auto loans.

headline: Harassment Suit Against Former Assemblyman Vito Lopez and Sheldon Silver Is Settled
text: ALBANY — The two former legislative aides at the heart of a sexual harassment scandal in the New York State Assembly settled their legal claims on Thursday against the disgraced former Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez and the recently deposed speaker, Sheldon Silver.

headline: Malcolm Smith, Ex-New York Senate Chief, Is Convicted of Corruption
text: Malcolm A. Smith, the former majority leader of the New York State Senate, was convicted on Thursday of federal corruption charges including bribery, wire fraud and extortion.

headline: Best Friends, but Wanting More
text: Whether the material is “Much Ado About Nothing” or “When Harry Met Sally,” if your story requires keeping true loves apart, it is often polite to pass the time with a steady flow of comedy.

headline: Democrats Exercise ‘No’ Power in Senate to G.O.P.’s Dismay
text: WASHINGTON — You could see the mischievous delight in John A. Boehner’s face as soon as he heard the question Thursday.

headline: Stolen Documents That Cast a Spotlight on Surveillance
text: In the age of encryption, computer hacking, WikiLeaks and Edward J. Snowden, the theft of typewritten government documents from an unlocked file cabinet 44 years ago by ordinary citizens may seem quaint.

headline: Bode Miller’s Crash
text: Bode Miller had a spectacular crash in the super-G at the Alpine world ski championships on Thursday.

headline: Among New York Subway’s Millions of Riders, a Study Finds Many Mystery Microbes
text: Have you ever been on the subway and seen something that you did not quite recognize, something mysteriously unidentifiable?

headline: White House Accelerates Drive to Improve Data Privacy
text: WASHINGTON — The White House accelerated its efforts on Thursday to bolster data privacy laws and announced a bid to scrutinize discriminatory pricing on the Internet, pressing to exert control on the use of data in Americans’ lives.

headline: Where Metro-North Railroad Fuels Life, and Takes It
text: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y. — In a hamlet that can seem sprung from a Currier & Ives lithograph, residents are drawn by many things: top-rated schools, safety, a picturesque setting — and the convenience of a train station.

headline: The Lives of 3 Crash Victims Who Shared a Metro-North Routine
text: The routine was the same, Monday through Friday. A man who, like generations of suburban commuters before him, had built his working life around the Metro-North timetables left the JPMorgan Chase tower on Park Avenue. He boarded his Harlem line train at Grand Central Terminal. He texted his wife: I’m on my way home.

headline: A Rocky Romance
text: There are many gargoyles jazzing up the exterior of the Cathedral of Notre-Dame. But only Pierre, stony and lonesome, is hopelessly in love with a pigeon.

headline: ‘Tis the Voice of the Lobster
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Some puzzles are “chattier” than others. There are those you hear nary a peep out of, and those that you simply can’t shut up.

headline: Human Behavior and Physics Hamper Rail Safety Systems
text: Engineers and transportation safety experts around the world are working to reduce the dangers of grade-level rail crossings like the one in Valhalla, N.Y., that was the scene of a deadly accident Tuesday evening. But human behavior and the laws of physics can defeat even the safest system, researchers say.

headline: Events in New Jersey for Feb. 8-14, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island for Feb. 8-14, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Martin Gilbert, Churchill Biographer With a Populist Bent, Is Dead at 78
text: Martin Gilbert, the official biographer of Winston Churchill, who also wrote histories of many of the signal events of the 20th century, including both world wars, the Holocaust and the Middle East conflict, died on Tuesday in London. He was 78.

headline: Ike Schambelan, Director Who Brought Disabled Artists to the Stage, Dies at 75
text: Ike Schambelan, a theater director who for more than three decades was the guiding force behind a professional Off Broadway company that featured blind and otherwise disabled actors in prominent roles, died on Tuesday in the Bronx. He was 75.

headline: Effects of Ancient Custom Present New Challenge to U.S. Doctors
text: DENVER — One immigrant woman told of visiting five gynecologists in recent months, each of whom gasped audibly at her anatomy.

headline: In Patz Trial, Witness Says Defendant Confessed to Him
text: Some months after 6-year-old Etan Patz disappeared in 1979, the man now accused of his murder told another man attending a religious retreat that he had killed a little boy in the basement of a grocery store, the second man testified on Thursday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Events in Connecticut for Feb. 8-14, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Sayreville Football Coach Is Ousted After Scandal
text: The embattled head football coach of Sayreville War Memorial High School has been ousted from his job in the wake of a hazing and sexual abuse scandal that drew national scrutiny, led to charges against seven players and upended a quiet New Jersey town that has long revered its top-flight program.

headline: Events in Westchester for Feb. 8-14, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Overruns Are Focus at Public Meeting on Boston Olympic Bid
text: BOSTON — In response to skeptical questions, Mayor Martin J. Walsh pledged Thursday night that Boston taxpayers would not pay a dime in cost overruns if the city ended up hosting the 2024 Summer Olympics.

headline: On Coney Island, Taking In the Sand and the Snow
text: Tunga Takavarasha, left, of Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, and his father, Bernard Takavarasha, visiting from Zimbabwe, took a walk on the Coney Island beach Thursday.

headline: On Atonement
text: For T’s ongoing series, the artist Tatiana Trouvé finds a metaphor for the poet Fady Joudah’s musing on the thin line between desire and disaster.

headline: In the Flesh
text: Embrace the tonal subtlety of a rose gold timepiece with a nude band against bare skin.

headline: Notes on a Scandale
text: For years, France’s leaders have been caught up in a sex farce of their own making, proving that bedfellows make for very strange politics.

headline: An Addictive, Momofuku Milk Bar-Approved Snack for the Grammys
text: With her last cookbook, “Momofuku Milk Bar,” the pastry chef Christina Tosi let her fans into her bakery, sharing the secrets behind her addictive Crack Pie, polarizing Cereal Milk ice cream and everything-but-the-kitchen-sink Compost Cookies. Three and a half years later, the founder and owner of Milk Bar will unveil her next treasure trove of recipes, “Milk Bar Life,” ($35, April 2015) which brings us instead into her home kitchen. And in honor of this Sunday’s Grammy Awards, Tosi shares a simple recipe from the book, one which has already become a T favorite and can easily be doubled or tripled for larger viewing parties (she quadruples the recipe for her Milk Bar team).

headline: Word of the Day | brawn
text: brawn • \ˈbrȯn\ • noun

headline: Investigation Finds Problems With Work on New York City 911 System
text: New York City employees were pressured by supervisors to “ ‘sanitize,’ ‘soften’ or ‘spin’ ” failures surrounding the long-delayed, $2 billion upgrade of the city’s 911 system by tampering with color-coded ratings, a new investigation has found.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
text: 9 P.M. (13) SHAKESPEARE UNCOVERED Morgan Freeman, who played Petruchio in “The Taming of the Shrew” in the Public Theater’s 1990 Shakespeare in the Park production, looks at some famous Petruchios (Richard Burton, John Cleese and Raul Julia) and Kates (Elizabeth Taylor, Fiona Shaw, Sinead Cusack and Meryl Streep) and reunites with his own sparring partner, Tracey Ullman (above with Mr. Freeman). Julia Stiles reflects on her role in the 1999 teenage comedy adaptation of the work, “10 Things I Hate About You.” And the Royal Shakespeare Company takes the play to a school near where Shakespeare grew up to find out what children make of the adult shenanigans. At 10, David Harewood, the first black actor to star in the title role of “Othello” at the National Theater in London, looks at the history behind the play; talks to Adrian Lester, the National Theater’s latest Othello, about the reaction to the 1825 performance of Ira Aldridge, the first black man to play the role in Britain; and ponders Laurence Olivier’s use of blackface in his acclaimed film portrayal in 1965.

headline: Carl J. Rubino, Lawyer in Quiz-Show Scandal, Dies at 100
text: In October 1959, a tormented 33-year-old named Charles Van Doren returned to his Greenwich Village apartment after driving around New England for days to escape the paparazzi camped on his doorstep. A letter from a complete stranger suggested a self-evident solution to his crisis of conscience: Just tell the truth.

headline: Tony Abbott, Australian Premier, Vows to Fight Leadership Challenge
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia’s embattled prime minister, Tony Abbott, said Friday that he would fight an attempt to contest his leadership next week, after a junior politician from his conservative Liberal Party called for the vote.

headline: East Timor’s Prime Minister, Xanana Gusmão, Resigns
text: HONG KONG — East Timor’s prime minister, Xanana Gusmão, submitted his resignation Friday as the government began a political restructuring meant to ease the young country’s often-fraught politics.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Saudis and 9/11
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ted Cruz’s Heritage
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Ending Slavery, the Abolitionists Came First
