headline: Missouri: Prosecutor Seeks Dismissal of Grand Juror’s Lawsuit
text: The St. Louis County prosecutor, with the backing of Missouri’s attorney general, asked a federal judge on Monday to dismiss a lawsuit from a grand juror who wants to speak publicly about the case of Darren Wilson, the Ferguson police officer who fatally shot an unarmed black man last summer and was not indicted. Missouri law prevents grand jurors from discussing their work in most instances, and the 12-member panel that decided not to indict Mr. Wilson for killing Michael Brown, 18, has remained anonymous. One juror sued last month seeking protection from the restrictions, naming the prosecutor, Robert P. McCulloch, as the defendant. That lawsuit, which said that the public’s understanding of the grand jury was “not entirely accurate,” indicated a willingness to discuss what happened during the hearings and “advocate for legislative change to the way grand juries are conducted.” In the lawsuit, the grand juror, who is represented by the American Civil Liberties Union of Missouri, indicated a fear of being prosecuted if he or she spoke publicly.

headline: Decrees Governing France’s Bakeries Prompt a Wider Debate on Work Rules
text: PARIS — Stéphane Cazenave, a baker in Saint-Paul-lès-Dax in southwestern France, was awarded a prize last year for best traditional baguette, in a contest organized by the confederation of French bakers. Back home, business was good, and Mr. Cazenave kept his bakery open seven days a week.

headline: Greek Prime Minister Tsipras Wins Confidence Vote Before Talks With Creditors
text: ATHENS — With Greece preparing for tough talks with creditors in Brussels, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's government easily won a confidence vote in Parliament early Wednesday with assurances that it would reverse an economic program that has slashed living standards.

headline: Midcentury Modernism Arrives in the California Desert
text: In the coming days, design and art lovers will descend on the desert east of Los Angeles for the 10th edition of Palm Springs Modernism Week. Among the lectures, house tours, exhibitions and fairs this year, one unofficial event stands out — and even offers the chance for the snowbound to get in on the action. The auction site Paddle8 has partnered with the design firm Homepolish to create “Desert Living: Icons of Modern Design,” a pop-up series of interiors vignettes at the Ace Hotel and Swim Club’s 4,000-square-foot clubhouse space. The four installations, says Jason Stein, Paddle8’s senior design specialist, reflect “what our favorite homes in Palm Springs would be; a setting we’d want to live in.” And though midcentury art and design are, as expected, well represented, the collectibles on offer extend far beyond the “Mad Men”-era nostalgia typically associated with the region. One California-themed tableau includes Frank Gehry’s cardboard chair, Bill Curry’s “Cattail” lamp, John Baldessari prints and an Ed Ruscha painting; another explores the notion of opulence through such pieces as a chrome 1970s Gucci wine cooler and a Helmut Newton nude photograph. And a future-themed area features Gerald McCabe’s seven-stemmed “Daisy” table and artwork by Kenny Scharf, Sam Francis and David Hockney. The environments will be accessible to visitors this weekend and are, Stein promises, “really layered”; for those stuck in less salubrious climes, everything is up for auction starting Wednesday on the Paddle8 site.

headline: The Perfect Pint (of Ice Cream)
text: It may seem unlikely given the time of year, but a handful of indie ice cream makers across the country introduced new, handcrafted flavors this month. And the small-batch pints, created in collaboration with other American purveyors of artisanal goods and available to be shipped anywhere in the U.S., are a welcome relief from the traditional Valentine’s Day sweets this time of year.

headline: The ‘Damien Hirst of New Delhi’ Brings a Personal Exhibition to New York
text: Many of the objects in Subodh Gupta’s career-spanning new exhibition, “Seven Billion Light Years,” are ordinary: The works on display include kitchen utensils piled together as part of a sculpture, a window buried in the ground and a broken stove attached to a painting. But Gupta thinks of them as more than discards; these are also someone else’s memories on display. Because he transforms certain objects into larger-than-life, sometimes shocking sculptures, Gupta has been called the “Damien Hirst of New Delhi”; alternately, his methods of appropriating and displaying other people’s objects could be described as Duchampian. The truth is, Gupta is a sentimentalist at heart. His objects, whether gilded or left as-is, are intimately bound up with Indian culture — agriculture and cooking traditions that are fading away from modern society.

headline: A Lesson in Natural Makeup From the Masterful Pat McGrath
text: The makeup artist Pat McGrath is a master of creating bold, hashtag-worthy looks with her whimsical use of sequins, glitter and Crayola-like color, but her most impressive trompe l’oeil might be when her handiwork is completely invisible to the eye. When she’s not pushing the avant-garde with wild materials, McGrath’s makeup can be so subtle that it appears as if the models aren’t wearing any at all. As it turns out, achieving this no-makeup makeup effect (seen on many a runway — and surely many more in the weeks to come during the fall/winter 2015 fashion shows), requires the right mix of products (11 to be exact) and ample blending. Here, McGrath reveals the secrets behind her stealth technique that results in casual perfection.

headline: The Human Touch
text: As fashion continues to demand ever more output and speed, many designers are finding freedom in the artisanal. Welcome to a season of exposed topstitching, frayed edges, crinkled linen, drawstring burlap and other disciplines of applied art.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New Starring Helena Bonham Carter and Kim Gordon
text: The Oscar-nominated actress and the noise-rock pioneer chew on duck-fat caramels, jazzy rap and the anti-Barbie.

headline: Judge Orders Saints’ Owner to Take Psychiatric Examination
text: As part of a fight over the future ownership of the Saints, a district court judge in New Orleans has ordered the team’s owner, Tom Benson, to take an examination to determine if he is mentally fit. Benson said last month that his third wife, Gayle, would inherit the Saints and the New Orleans Pelicans when he dies. Benson’s daughter and two grandchildren sued, claiming Gayle Benson had taken advantage of her husband’s infirmities to wrest control of the teams.

text: Jails across the country have become vast warehouses made up primarily of people too poor to post bail or too ill with mental health or drug problems to adequately care for themselves, according to a report issued Wednesday.

headline: Obama Administration Plans to Open Center to Fight Cyberattacks
text: President Obama’s homeland security adviser said Tuesday that the administration was planning to open a new center that would quickly assess and deter cyberattacks on the United States.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
text: 7 P.M. (Reelz) INVICTUS (2009) This rousing drama from Clint Eastwood, based on the book “Playing the Enemy” by John Carlin, was inspired by a true story of reconciliation and athletic triumph. Morgan Freeman portrays Nelson Mandela, newly elected as South Africa’s first black president, and Matt Damon is François Pienaar, the captain of the Springbok rugby team, a source of Afrikaner pride despised by many blacks. Mandela views the team as a vehicle to bring the country’s races together, especially if it can win the Rugby World Cup tournament in 1995, which South Africa is to host. “ ‘Invictus’ has implications beyond its immediate time and place that are hard to miss,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It’s an exciting sports movie, an inspiring tale of prejudice overcome and, above all, a fascinating study of political leadership.” In “Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom” (2013), Justin Chadwick’s biopic, at 6:35 on Showtime, Idris Elba portrays Mandela and Naomie Harris is his wife, Winnie. “Mr. Elba’s towering performance lends ‘Long Walk to Freedom’ a Shakespearean breadth,” Stephen Holden wrote in The Times. “His Mandela is an intensely emotional man whose body quakes in moments of sorrow and whose face is stricken with a bone-deep anguish. The carefully chosen words in his eloquent declarations of principle, spoken with gravity and deliberation, are deeply stirring.”

headline: What Is the Purpose of Society?
text: The world of food and agriculture symbolizes most of what’s gone wrong in the United States. But because food is plentiful for most people, and the damage that conventional agriculture does isn’t readily evident to everyone, it’s important that we look deeper, beyond food, to the structure that underlies most decisions: the political economy.

headline: A Quiet Fight to Marry
text: COKER, Ala. — MONDAY morning began like any other morning on our little farm in Alabama, where we have lived together for more than three decades. We already knew that Roy S. Moore, the chief justice of the State Supreme Court, had commanded the state’s probate judges to refuse to grant marriage licenses to same-sex couples. But turning on the radio, we learned that the judge in our county, Tuscaloosa, home to the state’s flagship university, had decided to go along with him.

headline: Lynching as Racial Terrorism
text: It is important to remember that the hangings, burnings and dismemberments of black American men, women and children that were relatively common in this country between the Civil War and World War II were often public events. They were sometimes advertised in newspapers and drew hundreds and even thousands of white spectators, including elected officials and leading citizens who were so swept up in the carnivals of death that they posed with their children for keepsake photographs within arm’s length of mutilated black corpses.

headline: Concealed Carry’s Body Count
text: In America’s endless debate about gun rights versus public safety, there should be no disputing the hard facts in a new report on gunshot fatalities showing that at least 722 nonself-defense deaths since 2007 were attributable to individuals with legal permits to carry concealed weapons. Concealed carry by citizens has been a soaring phenomenon as states liberalize laws in the name of lowering crime that allow more permits and easier gun access in public places, even schools, churches and restaurants.

headline: French Muslims, Never Fully at Home

Many demanded that they condemn the violence, which most Muslim organizations and public figures did. But far right-wing commentators in France and beyond attacked Islam itself, insisting that the religion was inherently violent.

headline: Better Fitness Through Your Phone
text: Many of us have invested in the wristbands or other wearable devices that tell us how many steps we’ve taken, calories we’ve burned and other information. But an interesting new study that compared activity monitors found that while some are accurate when measuring step counts, others are way off. And few are more accurate than the convenient and inexpensive apps you can find on your cellphone.

headline: Many Pilots Fail Safety Test at TransAsia
text: HONG KONG — Ten of 49 TransAsia Airways pilots failed emergency proficiency tests ordered by the Civil Aeronautics Administration of Taiwan after a deadly plane crash in the capital, Taipei, last week, the aviation regulator announced on Wednesday.

headline: The Stanford Undergraduate and the Mentor
text: On a weekend in March almost three years ago, Ellie Clougherty flew from London to Rome with Joe Lonsdale. She was a 21-year-old junior at Stanford University, and it was her first trip to Italy. Lonsdale, then 29, was a Silicon Valley entrepreneur, and he booked a room for them for two nights in a luxury hotel — a converted Renaissance mansion in the shadow of the Pantheon — and arranged a special excursion, with a friend of his who is an architect, to an archaeological site amid the ruins of the Golden House on Palatine Hill, overlooking the Colosseum. Under a light gray sky, they stood on plexiglass bridges and looked down at the uncovered remains of what is thought to be a fabled rotating dining room that the Emperor Nero built for extravagant banquets. Lonsdale is a Roman-history buff, and he told Clougherty about the emperors, praising their civilization and engineering feats.

headline: Morning Agenda: Private Equity’s Recruiting Race
text: PRIVATE EQUITY’S RECRUITING RACE | Some young bankers on Wall Street are the most sought-after financiers around, with lucrative pay packages dangling before them, DealBook’s William Alden and Sydney Ember write. Junior investment bankers, many of whom graduated from college only last year, are being madly courted by private equity firms like Apollo Global Management, the Blackstone Group, Bain Capital and the Carlyle Group in a scramble that kicked off last weekend. After back-to-back interviews, many are now fielding offers for jobs that won’t start until the summer of 2016.

headline: World Leaders Meet in Belarus to Negotiate Cease-Fire in Ukraine
text: MINSK, Belarus — The leaders of Russia, Ukraine, France and Germany negotiated through Wednesday night and into Thursday morning, locked in a tough effort to defuse the escalating conflict in eastern Ukraine, though there was little indication that whatever peace deal emerged from these talks would last any longer than a previous truce in September.

headline: An Unblemished Record Is New for Kentucky’s John Calipari
text: BATON ROUGE, La. — Louisiana State fans began lining up at Pete Maravich Assembly Center nearly two hours before game time on Tuesday, fully expecting that their Tigers, so tough at home, would end Kentucky’s 23-game winning streak.

headline: Shares of Aena and Elis Climb in Strong Demand for European I.P.O.s
text: LONDON – Aena, the Spanish airport operator, and Elis, the French provider of rental uniforms and linens, surged in their stock market debuts on Wednesday as investor appetite for initial public offerings remained strong in Europe.

headline: In Chapel Hill Shooting of 3 Muslims, a Question of Motive
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — It was a little after 5 p.m., a quiet time in a quiet neighborhood, before many people had returned home from work on Tuesday, when two women called 911 to report multiple gunshots and screams echoing through a condominium complex here near the University of North Carolina.

headline: Rite Aid to Buy Pharmacy Benefit Manager EnvisionRx

headline: ‘Fifty Shades of Grey,’ the Movie, as a Fairy Tale
text: If ever a novel could be described as review-proof, it is “Fifty Shades of Grey,” which, with its two sequels, has sold more than 100 million copies worldwide despite being ridiculed by virtually every critic who has read it. (Salman Rushdie, for one, said that it “made ‘Twilight’ look like ‘War and Peace.’ ”)

headline: The Times and Transgender Issues (Part 1 of 2): On Pronouns
text: In August 2013, soon after Chelsea Manning announced that she identified as a woman and no longer wanted to be known as Bradley Manning, The Times made a quick – and I thought appropriate – adjustment. Articles began referring to Private Manning with the feminine pronoun and the use of the name Chelsea. It caused a bit of a scramble at the time, because editors were concerned about clarity for readers when referring to the high-profile soldier who had just been sentenced to prison for leaking classified information. But in the end, a ruling principle – the preference of the individual – held sway.

headline: Cloud Software Start-Up AppDirect Raises $50 Million
text: AppDirect, a start-up focused on helping customers sell software online, said on Wednesday that it had raised $50 million in new financing to help it expand its staff worldwide.

headline: Workout Test: Fitness Apps vs. Trainer

headline: Malaysian Police Use Twitter in Crackdown on Dissent

headline: A New Orleans Neighborhood Takes Off
text: The Freret Corridor barely existed a decade ago. There was only Freret Street, run-down and with a single restaurant. In recent years, though, the Uptown neighborhood has taken off. The New Freret (pronounced fur-RET), as it’s sometimes called, combs the space of about six blocks. What makes it particularly valuable is the variety of the new spots, more than 20 of them, including a comedy club, a cocktail bar, a pet grooming shop, a boxing gym, and a garden center. And that is to say nothing of the eateries where New Orleans po’ boys are readily found, just in time for Mardi Gras.

headline: A Midwinter Playground in the Hudson Valley
text: Historic inns, a family ski center and a renowned art museum can be found amid rolling countryside an hour from New York City.

headline: Close Friend of Russian Leader Takes Role as a Negotiator for Ukraine

Putin of Russia get to go, like the V.I.P. section at a Formula One championship in Sochi, Russia, in October. He sat just a few feet from Mr. Putin, next to the actor Steven Seagal, another pal of the Kremlin leader’s.

headline: The Community College/‘Real College’ Divide

She followed her summary with these words to her audience of parents and incoming freshmen: “So that’s the minimum requirement. But here’s what you should take if you want to go to real college — you know, not community college.”

headline: Head of Belgian Group Said to Recruit Fighters for Syria Gets 12-Year Term

headline: In the Fall of Saigon, Lessons for Today
text: As the war in Vietnam recedes deeper into history, replaced in the American consciousness by more recent conflicts in places like Iraq and Afghanistan, its lessons also seem to fade. That amnesia is what the film director and producer Rory Kennedy is trying to counteract in “Last Days in Vietnam,” one of five nominees for the Oscar for best feature-length documentary.

headline: Nora Roberts: By the Book

text: What happened to American music? That often asked question is perhaps more valid now than ever.

headline: Amiri Baraka’s ‘S O S’
text: Amiri Baraka eulogized James Baldwin on Dec. 8, 1987, by saying: “He was all the way live, all the way conscious, turned all the way up, receiving and broadcasting. . . . He always made us know we were dangerously intelligent and as courageous as the will to be free.”

headline: Robert L. Grenier’s ‘88 Days to Kandahar’
text: As America’s longest war draws to a close, journalists and diplomats, spooks and soldiers keep turning out books attempting to explain what was lost and won over the last 14 years in Afghanistan. While none so far have synthesized the disparate worlds of American civilian policy, military action and Afghan realities, the latest entry, “88 Days to Kandahar: A CIA Diary,” by Robert L. Grenier, adds another on-the-ground view of how the early events actually unfolded. Grenier, who retired in 2006 after 27 years with the C.I.A., was the station chief in Islamabad, Pakistan, from 1999 to 2002, with practical responsibility for Taliban-dominated ­areas of southern and eastern Afghanistan during the crucial early months of the war. The book’s title refers to the period between Sept. 11 and Dec. 7, when an anti-Taliban tribal leader named Hamid Karzai made a perilous return to Afghanistan to rally Pashtun opposition to the Taliban, which culminated in their surrender.

headline: Obama Administration Plans to Aggressively Target Wildlife Trafficking
text: WASHINGTON — Hoping to stem illegal wildlife trafficking, the Obama administration on Wednesday introduced an aggressive plan for taking on traffickers that will include using American intelligence agencies to track and target those who benefit from the estimated $20-billion-a-year market.

headline: 1965: Resignations Over Madras Riot
text: NEW DELHI — Two cabinet ministers resigned today [Feb. 11] as rioting continued in Madras state against the adoption of Hindi as the official language of India. Five rioters were shot and killed after a mob of 4,000 stormed the railway station at Kumarapalam, a suburb of Madras city, and halted the speeding Indo-Ceylon Express. This brought to 39 the known death toll of the riots. The mob burned six coaches of the train before special armed police arrived and the shooting broke out. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 12, 1965

headline: Jackie Robinson West, a Team That Won Hearts, Loses Its Little League Title
text: Rarely had the Little League World Series gained such widespread attention, especially for African-American players.

headline: UniCredit of Italy Reports Profit Amid Cost-Cutting

headline: John Malone Takes a Stake and a Board Seat at Lionsgate

headline: Review: In ‘Fifty Shades of Grey’ Movie, Sex Is a Knotty Business
text: At the end of a recent New York sneak preview of “Fifty Shades of Grey” — in the blackout between the final lines of dialogue (“Anastasia!” “Christian!”) and the first breathy notes of the last Beyoncé song — a lot of the audience burst out laughing. The source of that laughter continues to puzzle and intrigue me, perhaps more than the actual movie did. Was it delight? Derision? Embarrassment? Surprise? All of the above?

headline: Chile’s Pablo Larraín Presents Film on Catholic Priests at Berlin Festival
text: BERLIN — The Chilean director Pablo Larraín has a penchant for the dark side. His “Tony Manero” (2009) was about a serial killer, and “Post Mortem” (2012) and the Oscar-nominated “No” (2013) explored the complexities of Pinochet’s Chile. In “The Club,” which debuted at the Berlin Film Festival this week to strong reviews, the director has mined another troubling theme: errant Roman Catholic priests and the system that has helped cover up their misdeeds.

headline: Dutchess County to Pay Brooklyn Native $7.5 Million for Wrongful Murder Conviction
text: The prize for this fight will be $7.5 million, but Dewey Bozella did not win it in a boxing ring.

headline: A Measured Approach to Cooking
text: There is a hoary reference to a bad cook, almost always a woman, who “couldn’t even boil water.” This apocryphal figure reminds me of another I used to consider similarly fictitious.

headline: In Politics of Rebuilding Ground Zero, a Lone Critical Voice

headline: Jewelry Designer Irene Neuwirth Goes to the Gem Show
text: In 2001, Irene Neuwirth took her first trip to the Tucson Gem, Mineral & Fossil Showcase, a massive exhibition held every winter that spans various venues across the city. At the time, the native Angeleno was teaching horseback riding and picking up beads at her local hippie haunt that she would later turn into jewelry for fun. “I drove there, stayed at the airport Hilton, and had $300,” she says. “I spent $500 and thought I would be in debt for the rest of my life.” Upon returning to L.A., Neuwirth made 10 necklaces, and sent them to Barneys with a note written in Magic Marker that read, “I hope you love them.” Today, her namesake line is one the department store’s best sellers and she has a fanciful Melrose Place flagship store to call her own.

headline: Hostage’s Hometown Is Well Acquainted With Loss
text: PRESCOTT, Ariz. — As if in a snow-globe village adjusted for the warmth of an Arizona winter, the gathering place at the heart of this city is a square with a western-wear boutique, a yogurt shop and, on the green lawn of the old courthouse, a scene playing out that is sadly familiar to many people here.

headline: Survey of Foreign Companies in China Finds Pollution a Growing Problem
text: BEIJING — Foreign companies in China are struggling with growing issues, including a perception that their businesses are less welcome than before.

headline: Babies Who Eat to Live, Instead of the Other Way Around
text: As a parent of a newborn, I was as naïve as they come. I had flowery illusions of bringing my swaddled daughter home, placing her in her monkey-shaped bouncy seat and watching her coo for hours until it was time to tuck her into her crib, lovey in hand.

headline: Composing ‘The Theory of Everything’
text: It begins with a piano riff and builds into a triumphant orchestral sweep. The piece, “Cambridge, 1963,” introduces audiences to a young, vibrant, bike-riding Stephen Hawking in “The Theory of Everything,” the film about the theoretical physicist’s first marriage, to Jane Hawking. The piece was composed by Johann Johannsson of Iceland, who won the Golden Globe for his now Oscar-nominated score. This piece is the composer’s favorite from the film.

headline: ‘Karate’ Means Empty Hand, but a Handheld Device Is Needed
text: LEARNING a martial art is a true challenge, both mentally and physically, because there is so much to master and remember. Turning to an app for help might not seem like an obvious course, but many apps do provide worthwhile support.

Mr. Stewart had plenty of confrontations, hard talks and other memorable moments, both comedic and poignant, in his 16 years at the helm. Here are a few highlights.

headline: Frigid New York Draws the Frozen and the Eclectic
text: If you think it’s chilly in New York City, it’s even colder in Toronto. So it is perhaps not surprising that several theater companies from Ontario are headed south to participate in Frigid New York. Frigid, entering its ninth year, is actually affiliated with the Canadian Association of Fringe Festivals and is modeled on its principles of first-come, first-served access for artists and a 100 percent return of box-office proceeds to those artists.

headline: ‘American Sniper’ Case Opens
text: Alan Nash, a district attorney in Texas, and Tim Moore, the defense lawyer, gave different portraits of Eddie Routh, who is accused of killing Chris Kyle, the protagonist in the “American Sniper” film.

headline: The World of Pat McGrath
text: In the beauty universe, you could say the world spins around Pat McGrath. Over the course of her three-decade career, the prolific, self-taught makeup artist has worked with in-demand models (Naomi, Gisele, Cara, Kendall), major fashion houses (Christian Dior, Versace, Prada) and the top photographers (Steven Meisel counts her among his closest collaborators). A backstage fixture, McGrath can set trends with a wave of her hands — she famously prefers to work with her fingers instead of with brushes — and is nothing if not extremely versatile: dewy, no-makeup skin, custom-made Swarovski crystal face masks and feather-adorned eyelids and brows are all in her wheelhouse. In 2004, she was made global creative design director for Procter & Gamble Beauty, and last spring, Queen Elizabeth II named her a Member of the Order of the British Empire for services to the fashion and beauty industries. (To celebrate, McGrath snapped her first selfie.) Here, a closer look at all things in McGrath’s orbit.

headline: The Case for Buying a Powerball Ticket
text: This article was published last February when the Powerball lottery hit $500 million. The point remains the same with the even larger jackpot this week.

headline: Jerry Tarkanian, 84, N.C.A.A. Foe and College Basketball Force, Dies
text: Jerry Tarkanian, who built Nevada-Las Vegas into a national powerhouse in college basketball with an insatiable will to win, created the persona of Tark the Shark and ignited a long-running feud with the N.C.A.A. over accusations that he ran outlaw programs at three universities, died on Wednesday in Las Vegas. He was 84.

headline: The Power of Saving: Exploring the Mathematics of Compound Interest
text: Overview | How do savings accounts grow? How can small, regular contributions add up to sizable retirement accounts? In this lesson students explore the basic mathematics of savings and interest using a simple model inspired by a recently proposed automatic retirement savings plan. By manipulating the parameters of the model and analyzing the consequences, students can build intuition about long-term investment strategies and evaluate the proposed policy from a quantitative perspective.

headline: Would an Emoticon Have Taken Eight Years?
text: Maia Leppo didn’t think that she and her boyfriend, Alex Kobzik, had a problem until they were vacationing with his family on Cape Cod, Mass., last summer, eight years into their relationship, and his mother asked them when they had first said “I love you.”

headline: Obama Seeks an Expansive War Authorization to Combat ISIS

headline: For Valentine’s Day, Adore Me Takes On Victoria’s Secret and Other Bigger Lingerie Rivals
text: In the weeks leading up to Valentine’s Day, the headquarters of Adore Me, a lingerie start-up, are frantic with activity, for good reason: Its daily sales in this period are more than 20 times the typical volume and nearly double those of Black Friday or Cyber Monday.

headline: Marcel Hirscher, a New Kind of Austrian Ski Star, Is Set to Add to His Title Collection
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — After winning the world title in the Alpine combined on Sunday, and delivering on the high expectations of his ski-crazed country, Marcel Hirscher of Austria was able to relax. So he celebrated his victory the best way he knew how: with steins of beer and plates of Wiener schnitzel at the Austria House, a temporary outpost of his homeland here in the Vail Valley complete with apple strudel, oompah bands and women wearing dirndls.

headline: Reducing Blood Pressure Lowers Risk of Diabetes Complications
text: Lowering blood pressure can significantly reduce the risk for many of the complications of Type 2 diabetes, a review of data from 40 trials involving more than 100,000 people with diabetes has found.

text: Premature delivery is tied to increased heart risks in the mother, a review of studies has found.

headline: On the Strauss-Kahn Trial Beat: Reporter’s Notebook
text: Covering the trial of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former I.M.F chief accused of being part of a freewheeling global sex ring, presented a challenge. How should one cover the case in a manner that would not be too prurient or inappropriate for a family newspaper?

headline: Love and Politics Collide as Scandals Plague Oregon’s Fourth-Term Governor
text: SALEM, Ore. — The allegations swirling around Gov. John Kitzhaber and his live-in fiancée did not seem to bother Oregonians much when they re-elected him last fall to an unprecedented fourth term. But now, with hints of scandal tumbling out almost by the day — about the business dealings of the fiancée, her previous marriage and her role in state government — the reaction has descended into a mix of tittering gossip, outrage and dismay, threatening to tarnish the last years of one of the state’s most enduring politicians.

headline: Director of  Gardner Museum to Step Down
text: Anne Hawley, who has led the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston for 25 years and oversaw an expansion that opened in 2012, more than doubling the museum’s footprint and increasing attendance, announced Wednesday that she planned to step down at the end of the year.

headline: Scott Walker, Traveling Abroad, Avoids Foreign Policy
text: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin visited London on Wednesday on a trade mission that some saw as an opportunity to bolster his foreign policy bona fides as he looks toward a presidential run in 2016.

headline: First 911 Call
text: The first of two 911 calls, made at 5:11 p.m. on Tuesday, reporting a shooting in Chapel Hill, N.C. The caller describes hearing “multiple, between five and 10” gunshots and “kids screaming.”

headline: Steps to Protect Your Tax Data as Refund Fraud Spreads
text: Last week’s suspension of some electronic state tax filings because of a sudden increase in fraudulent returns highlights the need for consumers to track potential misuse of their personal information, especially at tax time.

headline: One Great Unknown Steps Into Another
text: LOS ANGELES — On a sunny January afternoon, James Corden stood on the roof of CBS Television City, the boxy building where he will take over as host of the network’s “Late Late Show,” and surveyed his new domain.

headline: ‘My Name Is Rachel Corrie’ to Be Staged Off Broadway in April
text: “My Name Is Rachel Corrie,” a one-woman drama about a pro-Palestinian activist, will be staged Off Broadway this spring for the first time since an earlier production nine years ago caused an uproar in some corners of the New York theater world. A spokesman for the show announced on Wednesday that the play would run April 2-12 at the Culture Project’s Lynn Redgrave Theater in the East Village.

headline: Kyle Bass Wields New Weapon in Challenging Drug Makers
text: Drug makers make unlikely candidates for the next big short. Kyle Bass, a hedge fund manager who bet successfully on a housing market crash in the United States, is aiming at pharmaceutical companies worth a combined $450 billion in market capitalization.

headline: Congress, Don’t Be Fooled; Obama Still Believes in Unlimited War
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA is going before Congress to request authorization for the limited use of military force in a battle of up to three years against the Islamic State. On the surface, this looks like a welcome recognition of Congress’s ultimate authority in matters of war and peace. But unless the resolution put forward by the White House is amended, it will have the opposite effect. Congressional support will amount to the ringing endorsement of unlimited presidential war making.

headline: Captain of Ship That Capsized Off Italy in ’12 Is Convicted
text: ROME — An Italian court on Wednesday convicted the captain of a cruise liner that capsized in 2012, killing 32 people, of manslaughter and sentenced him to just over 16 years in prison for his role in one of the worst maritime disasters in modern Italian history.

headline: Facebook Takes Its Hardware Designs to a Giant Scale
text: Not content with connecting 1 billion-plus people, Facebook wants to connect millions of computer servers, too. The idea is to create technologies to handle data loads that are tens, even hundreds of times greater than what most companies have to handle today.

headline: Officer Charged in Akai Gurley Case Debated Reporting Gunshot, Officials Say
text: For four minutes, a New York City police officer who had just fired his gun into a darkened housing project stairwell argued with his partner over whether to tell their superiors about the shot.

headline: Another Week at No. 1 for Taylor Swift
text: In a slow season for new albums, no one can beat Taylor Swift.

headline: Unauthorized Immigrants’ Access to Driver’s Licenses Is at Risk
text: DENVER — His driver’s license is an economic lifeline, said Felipe Castro, an unauthorized immigrant from Mexico who commutes 40 miles each morning to his construction job in Northern Colorado. Or it was, until it expired last week.

headline: Student Filmmakers Focus on Coral Reef Revival in Curacao
text: It’s hard for me to believe, but this is my fifth year working with Pace University graduate and undergraduate communication students on films with environmental themes.

headline: First Draft Focus: Obama Between Speeches
text: — President Obama, at the White House, making the case for Congressional authorization to use force against the Islamic State.

headline: Withdrawing Troops, Obama Calls for Vigilance on Ebola
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced on Wednesday that the United States was withdrawing almost all of its troops from the fight against Ebola in West Africa, but he said the world needed to remain vigilant as it sought to eradicate the deadly disease.

headline: Microsoft Continues Mobile Push With Sunrise Acquisition
text: Microsoft has again turned outside the company to bolster its mobile app offerings.

headline: Vienna, City of Dreams
text: Known as “The City of Dreams,” Vienna, Austria, is one of Europe’s crown jewels. But modern Vienna is more than just a place for history buffs looking to explore extravagant attractions (though Schloss Belvedere and the Lipizzan ballet at the Imperial Palace certainly fit that description). It’s a host to a burgeoning community of designers and artists. Furthermore, the home city of Sigmund Freud also offers an array of indoor cultural experiences, making it an ideal wintertime destination. Here, in honor of the city’s festive ball season, is a guide to the places worth visiting.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Fingers Crossed Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.

headline: Doris Salcedo, Whose Art Honors Lives Lost, Gets a Retrospective in Chicago
text: CHICAGO — When the elevators at the Museum of Contemporary Art here stop on the fourth floor, they usually open on a large, airy lobby with a view of Michigan Avenue. These days, they open onto a vast art installation by the Colombian sculptor Doris Salcedo that evokes a mass grave.

headline: Indictment of Officer Peter Liang in the Death of Akai Gurley
text: The six-count indictment of Officer Peter Liang in the fatal shooting of Akai Gurley includes several felony charges, including second-degree manslaughter.

headline: Lincoln Center Will Bring Concerts to the South Bronx
text: Lincoln Center is going to the South Bronx this spring, announcing Wednesday that it will offer a series of free events there for families and children by groups including the New York Philharmonic, Jazz at Lincoln Center, New York City Ballet and the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Dressing ‘Inherent Vice’
text: Mark Bridges dressed the women of “Inherent Vice” in one “sexy number after the other” because he wanted to give life to the vivid, psychedelic world created by the book’s author, Thomas Pynchon.

headline: Reid Offended by Boehner’s Language
text: Speaker John A. Boehner went to great lengths on Wednesday to get his message across on funding the Department of Homeland Security, urging Senate Democrats to “get off their ass and do something.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Ukraine and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: New York Fashion Week: Fingers Crossed Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.

headline: Feb. 11, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Yemen, Greece, Ukraine and Egypt.

headline: Obama Says U.S. Work on Ebola Isn’t Done
text: President Obama said that although all but 100 of the American troops deployed to West Africa to help manage the Ebola outbreak will be coming home by April 30, the civilian response will be expanded.

headline: Where to Caffeinate, Juice Up and Wind Down During New York Fashion Week
text: Fashion Week starts tomorrow. And with the dizzying number of shows scattered throughout the city this season, attendees will have even less time than usual to settle in for leisurely breaks and repasts in between presentations. With a focus on what’s mostly new and talked-about this season, we’ve compiled a list of the best spots to drop by for beverages, whether it’s a hot coffee, a healthful juice or smoothie, or a day’s-end cocktail — in other words, the trifecta of Fashion Week drinking.

headline: Review: BalletNext Takes Risks in ‘Baroque’d’
text: Despite its live music and the admirable skills of most of its dancers, “Baroque’d,” BalletNext’s program at New York Live Arts, is always less than good. It varies from the blandly vague (the first two items) to the amateurishly pseudo-experimental (the last). That last dance, “Something Sampled,” is sufficiently irksome to be considerably more memorable than the first two.

headline: Review: Janine Jansen and Itamar Golan Balance Power and Nuance at Zankel Hall
text: New York fans of the Dutch violinist Janine Jansen have had it rough in recent years. Illness caused her to bow out of high-profile concerts with the Budapest Festival Orchestra in 2013 and the New York Philharmonic last year. On Tuesday, she was back, in radiant form, with a recital at Zankel Hall alongside the Israeli pianist Itamar Golan, which proved that she is an artist worth the wait.

headline: Classical Playlist: J. S. Bach, Mendelssohn, Wu Man and More
text: ‘J. S. BACH: CONCERTOS FOR OBOE AND OBOE D’AMORE’Gonzalo X. Ruiz, oboist; Portland Baroque Orchestra, Monica Huggett, violinist(Avie AV2324) The mellow, soulful sound of the Baroque oboe and oboe d’amore is the star attraction of this quietly compelling album of arrangements of Bach keyboard concertos featuring one of the pre-eminent artists on those instruments. The Baroque violinist Monica Huggett, at the helm of the Portland Baroque Orchestra, offers sensitive, stylish support. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

headline: Data Security Gaps in an Industry Student Privacy Pledge
text: On the eve of a congressional hearing to explore the use of new technology in classrooms nationwide, a software engineer has found significant gaps in an industry effort to bolster student data security and privacy.

headline: On Set | Floral, Military Spring Fashion
text: T’s senior fashion editor Jason Rider reveals the inspirations behind styling a floral and military trend fashion spread for the magazine’s spring fashion issue.

headline: At Yale, Trading a Playbook for a Songbook
text: Approaching 10 p.m. on the eve of a recent blizzard, the Rockwood Music Hall, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, was running low on breathing room, packed so tightly that each whoosh of cold air from the opening of the rear door brought sharp-eyed looks from those inside — no more, please. Even the stage was jammed: four musicians (drummer, keyboardist, two guitarists) and four singers, one of whom, stashed in the corner, slapping a tambourine against his hip, stood 6 feet 6 inches.

headline: Smoking’s Toll on Health Is Even Worse Than Previously Thought, a Study Finds
text: However bad you thought smoking was, it’s even worse.

headline: Review: Sara Gazarek Exudes Confidence and Cheer
text: The West Coast jazz singer Sara Gazarek, who appeared at Birdland on Tuesday evening, has many of the right moves. Rhythmically adept, she is an accomplished scat improviser who exudes an engaging blend of confidence and cheer. Her singing, at its most inventive, recalls Jane Monheit’s flights of fancy but without Ms. Monheit’s vocal lushness. She is at ease with tricky samba rhythms that break up phrases into staccato exclamations, and her far-reaching taste in songs encompasses both standards and original collaborations that take her in a pop direction.

headline: On JetBlue, Passengers Can Use Apple Pay
text: If you’re a frequent flier, JetBlue has just given you one more excuse to upgrade to an iPhone 6. This week the airline announced that it would become the first to allow its customers to use Apple Pay to make in-flight purchases.

headline: Beautiful Unrest: Roughed-Up Florals for Spring
text: Vivid botanical prints lose their ladylike sweetness when paired with utilitarian staples.

headline: Obama on His Islamic State Resolution
text: President Obama described the resolution he submitted to Congress for authorization to use military force against ISIS. He said it did not authorize a ground war like those in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Review: ‘Single, Carefree, Mellow,’ Except for That Illicit Affair
text: The young woman in the first story in Katherine Heiny’s debut collection, “Single, Carefree, Mellow,” has never lived in an apartment with air-conditioning. But that’s about as close to hardship as Ms. Heiny’s heroines get. Most are urban American semi-strivers, worrying a little about work, a little about happiness and a lot about the illicit affairs they’re carrying on. When it comes to these liaisons, Ms. Heiny has a fine way of keeping her women sharply perceptive about details yet too delusional to see the big picture.

headline: They’ll Just Hate to See Jon Stewart Go (So They Say)
text: WASHINGTON — He has all but called them losers and fools, but when Jon Stewart announced on Tuesday that he would leave “The Daily Show” sometime this year, many politicians and news media personalities had something of an unusual reaction: grief.

headline: ‘Deutschland 83’ and ‘Shkufim’ Are Among Exciting International Series
text: BERLIN — Sometimes there are limits to the imagination. Luckily, reality is much more boundless.

headline: A Credit to the Game Leaves a Legacy
text: One of the true gentlemen of bridge, Ernesto d’Orsi, died on Jan. 9 in his hometown, São Paulo, Brazil. He was 78.

headline: Wife Says Gunman Believed in Equality
text: Karen Hicks, the wife of Craig Stephen Hicks, who is accused of murdering three Muslim students, said he championed individuals’ rights on his Facebook page and believed everyone was equal.

headline: New York City Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Are Suspended on Thursday
text: Because of Lincoln’s Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Shopping With Paige Novick
text: Some jewelry boxes look like jewels themselves. Others are strictly for storage.

headline: Review: In ‘Iphigénie en Aulide,’ a Daughter’s Ultimate Sacrifice
text: The opera world often seems consumed with arguments over productions. A high-concept modern staging is at once condemned and cheered by various factions; a traditional production will be seen as either appropriately respectful or hopelessly timid.

headline: Walker Steps Back From Evolution ‘Punt’
text: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, in London on a trade trip, was forced to elaborate Wednesday on his views about evolution after his decision to “punt” on the question turned into a trans-Atlantic stumble.

headline: Whole Foods Market Reports a Rise in Sales
text: Sales at Whole Foods Market stores rose 10 percent to $4.7 billion in the most recent quarter as the upscale grocery chain drew more customer traffic, the company announced on Wednesday.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: The Green Goddess Club
text: The fashion color of the moment is deep green.

headline: For New York Fashion Week, Look-at-Me Style Statements
text: As Fashion Week comes to town on Thursday, the streets will fill with look-at-me style statements. But fewer of those, we suspect, will be ratcheted to the heavens on sky-high heels. It’s all about sneakers now. So which will be the most popular of the season? We’re betting on these styles, some of which, like the pastel Stan Smiths reinterpreted by Raf Simons, were previewed by attendees at last month’s fashion shows in Paris. Safer passage across New York’s patches of ice is but a bonus.

headline: Reading The Times With Andrew Solomon
text: Andrew Solomon is the National Book Critics Circle Award-winning author of “Far From the Tree” and “The Noonday Demon.”

headline: By Their Emails Ye Shall Know Them
text: The art of legislative power is being in the know before anyone else – which is why rank-and-file Kansas lawmakers are asking why they were kept in the dark for weeks even as Gov. Sam Brownback’s office was sharing his pending state budget with a couple of heavyweight statehouse lobbyists. The sneak preview was allowed for a select few state officials plus David Kensinger, who resigned three years ago as the governor’s chief of staff to become lobbyist for the powerfully conservative Club for Growth, and Mark Dugan, another ranking lobbyist who previously served as Mr. Brownback’s campaign manager.

headline: A Topsy-Turvy Day in TV Land
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shopping Sales and Events in New York City
text: Not on Fashion GPS? There are still plenty of ways to take part in New York Fashion Week festivities. On Thursday, from 2 to 6 p.m. at Fivestory, you can sip pink Champagne and shop Valentine’s Day confections — Treat House Rice Krispies bars ($24 for 12), heart- and penguin-shaped New York Cake Pops ($19.99 for six) and Jars by Dani parfait-like creations ($6.25 for a four-ounce Mason jar) — from some purveyors of the fashion flock’s favorite guilty pleasures. They are not the only goodies: There’s a new Kotur x Fivestory glitter globe minaudière ($445), as well as drapey tees from the London cult T-shirt label Rotten Roach with witty slogans by the illustrator Hugo Guinness ($106) for those wanting something a little less, well, sugar-coated. At 18 East 69th Street.

headline: Public School Is Giving Women Their Due
text: “Walk strong,” Piergiorgio Del Moro, the casting agent, urged. Avery, a model, complied, stalking the makeshift runway at Milk Studios in Chelsea the other day with a scissors-like stride and a scowl. Avery didn't make the cut, but those loose-limbed girls who did were invited to walk once more, each cocooned in a flyaway puffer coat.

headline: Lease Deal for Pier 55 Park in Hudson River Is Approved
text: Plans for a cultural island in the Hudson River took a step forward on Wednesday, when the Hudson River Park Trust approved a lease agreement with a group controlled by Barry Diller that plans to help create a new $130 million pier with performance spaces and sylvan paths.

headline: Nature’s Patterns in an Ancient Art
text: The pots made at the Acoma Pueblo in New Mexico “were digital before there was digital,” said Dan Brewster, an owner of DARA Artisans, an online store that sells handmade goods from around the world.

headline: Its Place in the Footlights
text: David and Donna Feldman were looking for a balance between modernist rigor and antique embellishment when they began to produce their own furniture out of a workroom in Chelsea. They named the business Dmitriy & Company, inspired by Mr. Feldman’s Russian-born grandfather, who had a pillow shop on the Lower East Side.

headline: Wood Dressed in Black Tie
text: Josh Vogel’s Blackline collection is a result of a kitchen accident of sorts: He set a knife on a cherry cutting board and it turned the board black.

headline: New Lookout for Solar Storms Lifts Off on SpaceX Rocket
text: On the third try, the Deep Space Climate Observatory rose into the sky above Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Wednesday night atop a Falcon 9 rocket built by the Space Exploration Technologies Corporation, or SpaceX.

headline: She Did the Traveling, You Get the Souvenirs
text: Folkthread, a collection of home furnishings by Kit Kemp for Anthropologie, was inspired by the folk art and textiles she has encountered in her travels. (Ms. Kemp, an interior designer, runs Firmdale Hotels with her husband, Tim; they own eight hotels in London and the Crosby Street Hotel in Manhattan.)

headline: A New Generation of Designers Chooses Anonymity
text: A few days before the beginning of New York Fashion Week, Christopher Peters was on the phone, talking about his forthcoming collection.

headline: Jewelry Boxes: My Bracelet’s Keepers
text: Paige Novick has her own line of costume jewelry, but she also designs fine jewelry, so she is well versed in the wearing and storing of both.

headline: Should We Replace the Patterned Wallpaper in Our Powder Room?
text: Q. Our cozy powder room has dark, dramatically patterned wallpaper. Should we replace it with something simpler and lighter before selling?

headline: Fashion’s Racial Divide
text: When Michelle Obama stepped onto the stage at the Democratic National Convention in 2012 to talk about her husband and the coming election, the Internet went into an effective group swoon. Words like “spotlight stealing” and “dazzling” were used with abandon. Not about the first lady’s speech, but about her dress: a shimmering pink and silver sleeveless number by the designer Tracy Reese.

headline: In Sort-of-Defense of Roy Moore
text: Chief Justice Roy Moore of the Alabama Supreme Court is trying to block same-sex marriage in his state, despite a federal court order allowing it. Moore told “Good Morning America” that he is confident he will “absolutely not” end up on the wrong side of history. The fact that 36 states (apart from Alabama) now allow same-sex marriage, with rising support from the public, suggests he’s probably wrong about that. His central legal claim — that same-sex marriage is a states’ rights issue, rather than one that implicates the guarantee of equality in the Constitution — is also a loser. Moore argued that “redefinition of the word marriage is not found within the powers designated to the federal government,” but Congress makes all kinds of rules involving marriage (and pensions and taxes) and the Supreme Court has previously ruled that marriage is a fundamental right.

headline: The Hollyhock House Comes Into Its Own
text: Finally, the planets seem to have aligned for Frank Lloyd Wright’s Hollyhock House. On Jan. 30, the United States Department of the Interior announced its decision, seven years in the making, to nominate the 1921 Los Angeles home, along with nine other works by Wright, to the Unesco World Heritage List, which includes icons like the Taj Mahal and Statue of Liberty. And tomorrow, the building, now a house museum, will reopen after a four-year $4.3 million restoration.

headline: Backpacks That Pack Power for Mobile Devices
text: WITH people juggling multiple digital devices that constantly need charging, backpack manufacturers have sensed a market opportunity. Some new backpacks are specifically designed not only to protect our smartphones, tablets, laptops, headphones and game players, but also to recharge them and track their whereabouts.

headline: Deadlier Ties to Ukraine?
text: If the fragile cease-fire plan for the country doesn't hold, should the U.S. provide Kiev with lethal aid?

headline: Furnishing the President’s House
text: Last year, the interim president of RISD found herself with a 21-room house to fill. Luckily, she knew a few suppliers.

headline: The Most Famous Macedonian Designer You’ve Never Heard Of
text: On Monday, a few days before New York Fashion Week was set to begin, one of its newest participants was at home in Bali, working to get his collection ready and fretting about the move from London Fashion Week, where he typically shows.

headline: It’s Empty at the Top
text: When Rosanne Somerson was promoted in January of last year, the good news was that her new job came with a historic house on a lush piece of property. The bad news? She had two and a half weeks to furnish it.

headline: His Game in Tatters, Tiger Woods Takes a Leave
text: The soap opera that has become Tiger Woods’s life took another shadowy turn Wednesday when Woods announced he was taking an indefinite leave of absence from competitive golf to work on his floundering game.

headline: In Community Gardens, a New Weed?
text: The trouble started with an R.F.Q: a “request for qualifications” in the bloodless shorthand of city government. But that’s not quite right. The shot that started the latest skirmish in New York’s never-ending garden wars wasn’t an R.F.Q., but an addendum to an R.F.Q.

headline: Six Nights, Seven Pillows
text: Can the right pillow fix what ails you? Penelope Green tests several in an effort to find out.

headline: Look Out Below!
text: I’ve occasionally been known to throw myself onto the face of a home-improvement cliff so steep that I can barely make it to the top, let alone finish with something pretty. Last week, I bailed halfway up the cliff, and the crash was gloriously, hideously ugly.

headline: Installing Molding and Tin Ceilings
text: Here’s what you’ll need.

headline: The Pillow Cure
text: My neck is killing me. Isn’t yours? My shoulder hurts, too. Not always the same one, but always in the morning. Herniated disks, spinal stenosis, bone spurs: It’s a mess in there. As for the shoulders, one gave out with a horrible popping noise in a yoga class a few years ago; the cause of the other’s decay remains a (very dull) mystery.

headline: Lincoln Prize Goes to Harold Holzer
text: Harold Holzer, a Lincoln scholar who recently announced his retirement as a public affairs executive at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has been awarded the 2015 Gilder Lehrman Lincoln Prize, to be announced Thursday.

headline: Education Is Newest Target of Kansas Budget Cuts
text: KANSAS CITY, Kan. — In November, shortly after Gov. Sam Brownback won re-election, experts forecast that the state would bring in $1 billion less than expected over the next two years. He responded by cutting state agency budgets and proposing the transfer of funds among various state accounts. In December came news of a revenue slump, falling to $15.1 million below estimates. Mr. Brownback proposed increasing taxes on liquor and cigarettes, slowed reductions in the income tax and changed the way money was distributed to public schools.

headline: Tesla Motors Met Its Output Goal, but Showed a 4th-Quarter Loss
text: DETROIT — Tesla Motors, the maker of high-end electric cars, said on Wednesday that a flurry of production in the fourth quarter helped it achieve its target of building 35,000 vehicles last year.

headline: Jury Pool for Trial in Aurora Shooting Is Pressed on Death Penalty
text: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — Lawyers on Wednesday began questioning potential jurors for the trial of the man accused of killing 12 people and wounding 70 during a showing of a Batman film in a packed Colorado movie theater in 2012.

headline: Council Speaker Seeks Criminal Justice Reforms in State of the City Address
text: The speaker of the New York City Council, Melissa Mark-Viverito, on Wednesday took aim at the “broken windows” approach to policing, proposing a significant easing of penalties for certain minor quality-of-life offenses like jumping turnstiles.

headline: British Revenue Chief Is Faulted on HSBC’s Efforts to Aid Tax Evasion
text: LONDON – The chief executive of Britain’s tax agency was questioned by politicians over leaked documents that describe how HSBC’s Swiss private banking arm helped clients, including politicians, rock stars and dealers of illicit diamonds, hide billions of dollars before 2007.

headline: Corruption Scandal at Petrobras Threatens Brazil’s Economy
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – The accusations of corruption at Brazil’s state-controlled petroleum giant Petrobras have already led to a political scandal and a change in management. Now, the problems are threatening other Brazilian companies and may even tip the country into recession.

headline: A Black Preacher Addresses Congress
text: On Sunday, Feb. 12, 1865, Henry Highland Garnet, minister of the Fifteenth Street Presbyterian Church in Washington, entered the halls of Congress. He could not escape notice. He was, his friend Alexander Crummell later wrote in his Eulogium on Garnet’s life, “tall and majestic in stature, over six feet in height, with a large and noble head, its front both broad and expansive, his chest deep and strong, his limbs straight and perfectly moulded.” Garnet was in the House of Representatives that morning at the invitation of William Henry Channing, chaplain of Congress, to deliver a sermon. Channing’s request was hardly a surprise; after all, the Capitol had served as a church for many decades, and preachers had long spoken in its halls. What was astonishing was that Garnet was a black man, no longer relegated to the galleries but standing at the speaker’s dais.

headline: Indonesia’s Graft Fight Strikes Fear Even Among the Honest
text: BANDUNG, Indonesia — One is a telecommunications executive, another the former president-director of a state airline, and the third a project manager for Chevron.

headline: F.B.I. Director to Give Speech Addressing Relations Between Police and Blacks
text: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, on Thursday will wade into the national debate about the relationship between police officers and African-Americans that was highlighted by the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man in Ferguson, Mo., in August. It will be the first time one of the bureau’s directors has publicly addressed the issue of race at length.

headline: Soldiers From Sudan Raped Hundreds in Darfur, Human Rights Group Finds
text: UNITED NATIONS — Sudanese soldiers raped more than 200 women and girls in Darfur last fall, Human Rights Watch concluded in a report issued Wednesday, confirming allegations that the large United Nations peacekeeping mission in the area could not.

headline: Former Head of Inquiry Into Gaza War Says He Faced Pressure and Threats
text: PARIS — The Canadian law professor who resigned this month as head of a United Nations inquiry into last summer’s Gaza conflict said his appointment had been troubled from the outset by intense pressure from Israel’s government, which accused him of a pro-Palestinian bias.

headline: Valentine’s Day Chocolate Will Cost More This Year, as Cocoa Prices Rise
text: This year, perhaps more than ever, kisses may not come cheap.

headline: At Cricket World Cup, a Group of Underdogs Gets a Rare Opportunity
text: It would be hard to find two words that seem so ill-matched as “Afghanistan cricket.”

headline: Funding Is Still Elusive for Homeland Security
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans who have been so disciplined in their opposition to President Obama are now finding themselves badly splintered over how to keep the Department of Homeland Security operating as they struggle to demonstrate they can govern effectively as the party that controls Congress.

headline: Comedy Central Ponders How to Replace Jon Stewart
text: Jon Stewart’s announcement that he will give up his anchor chair on Comedy Central’s “The Daily Show” by the end of the year reverberated on Wednesday through the corridors of power in Washington, New York publishing houses and most important, the network’s parent company, Viacom.

headline: At the Time Warner Center, an Enclave of Powerful Russians
text: In March 2009, a bookish-looking Russian senator stepped to the podium at the Brookings Institution in Washington. The occasion was the inauguration of a new think tank devoted to United States-Russia cooperation on financial and energy security, and the speaker, Andrey Vavilov, had donated money.

headline: Brian Williams Scandal Prompts Frantic Efforts at NBC to Curb Rising Damage
text: Hours before Brian Williams took the anchor’s chair for the nightly newscast on Feb. 4, a sense of dread began to spread through the Rockefeller Plaza offices of NBC News.

headline: Jet.com Gets Investment That Values It at $600 Million
text: Jet.com, a soon-to-start online marketplace that aims to loosen Amazon’s grip on e-commerce, said Wednesday that it had raised $140 million in a new round of funding.

headline: In India, Glimpses of Economic Optimism and Frustration
text: MUMBAI, India — Arriving at the new international airport here last month, I felt like I had gotten on the wrong connecting flight and ended up in Shanghai. Instead of the smelly and decaying terminal I remembered from the four years I spent here as a news correspondent, the building was sparkling. The walkway to the immigration counter doubled as a museum filled with paintings, sculptures and handmade crafts from around the country.

headline: Part Villain, Part Victim, Jerry Tarkanian Simply Won
text: It was strange that Dean Smith and Jerry Tarkanian died within days of each other. They were coaching peers from opposite sides of the reputational spectrum, with Smith, the longtime coach at North Carolina, remembered as the gentlemanly throwback to a time when coaching was done right and Tarkanian cast as the misunderstood pioneer of an era — the same era — when it all went wrong.

headline: Landlord Bribed Inspectors in Ruse to Evict Tenants, Prosecutors Say
text: One night last December around nine o’clock, tenants at 159 Suydam Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, were startled by loud banging on their doors and walls. A man in some kind of uniform was going up and down the four stories of their building, yelling that they had 72 hours to get out.

headline: In ‘Fashions for Men’ and ‘Everything You Touch,’ Clothes Are a Main Player
text: Many costume designers claim that the best examples of their work are the ones that go unnoticed, that serve the play while staying demurely in the background.

headline: Little League Scandal Shows Why Baseball Is Better Viewed From Afar
text: Here’s a tip on choosing the perfect seats for this summer’s Little League World Series.

headline: Taiwan: Six Inmates Kill Themselves, Official Says
text: Six inmates at a prison in southern Taiwan killed themselves Thursday morning, ending an overnight hostage situation, a Justice Ministry official said. Two prison staff members were released unharmed after being held for 14 hours at the Kaohsiung Prison, said the official, Chen Ming-tang, a vice minister in the Justice Ministry. The six inmates, who were all serving lengthy terms for crimes that included drug trafficking and murder, apparently complained about their living conditions to get a meeting with prison officials, whom they then took hostage on Wednesday, according to local news reports. The inmates later took firearms from a prison armory, Taiwan’s Central News Agency reported. Taiwanese news outlets broadcast a series of demands from the men, including that they be provided with vehicles and that former President Chen Shui-bian, who was convicted of embezzlement and taking bribes in 2009, be returned to prison. Mr. Chen was released on medical parole in January. But early Thursday, the six inmates shot themselves, Mr. Chen, the ministry official, said in a brief televised interview. He provided few details about the episode.

headline: Christophe Gbenye, Radical Nationalist in Congo, Dies at 88
text: Christophe Gbenye, a radical nationalist whose brutal rebel warriors seized control of eastern Congo in 1964 and held hundreds of foreigners hostage until they were rescued by Belgian paratroopers dropping from American planes, died on Feb. 3 in Kinshasa. He was 88.

headline: In Adolf Hitler’s Hometown, Trying to Overcome a Legacy of Evil
text: BRAUNAU AM INN, Austria — Days after this city across the river from Bavaria surrendered to the United States Army in May 1945, a group of German soldiers sought to flatten a three-story house here that had served as a Nazi pilgrimage site and shrine since the late 1930s.

headline: Response in Ferguson Draws Scrutiny
text: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — State legislators on Wednesday questioned Gov. Jay Nixon’s response last year to unrest in Ferguson as they opened hearings into how state money was spent and why a swath of suburban St. Louis was burned and looted even after the National Guard had been activated.

headline: Rose E. Frisch, Scientist Who Linked Body Fat to Fertility, Dies at 96
text: Rose E. Frisch, a scientist whose influential work showed that women without enough body fat would have trouble becoming pregnant, but that they also had a lower risk of breast cancer, died on Jan. 30 at an assisted-living facility in Cambridge, Mass. She was 96.

headline: Threading Needle in Wording of a Military Proposal
text: WASHINGTON — In formally asking Congress to authorize a three-year military campaign against the Islamic State, President Obama has carefully worded his request to soothe worried Democrats who do not want another big war. At the same time, he is assuring Republican hawks that the American military will do what it takes to defeat the Sunni militant group.

headline: Review: ‘Rasheeda Speaking’ Finds a Chilling Place to Work
text: Office politics are a headache for anyone working in the land of cubicles, copiers and water coolers, but they rarely rise to the four-alarm-fire levels of tension on view in “Rasheeda Speaking,” an incendiary but improbable play by Joel Drake Johnson that rather ham-handedly raises ever-topical (sigh) questions about the prevalence of ingrained racism in America.

headline: Where One Might Find a Date
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle by Jules Markey was the final round of the Westport Library crossword puzzle tournament. Once again, congratulations to winner Andy Kravis.

headline: Bob Simon, ‘60 Minutes’ Correspondent, Dies at 73 in Manhattan Car Crash

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE SLAP Hector (Peter Sarsgaard) is a public servant, a father and a potentially philandering husband who has just lost out on a big job promotion. He finds his life in additional turmoil on the day of his 40th birthday party when his hotheaded cousin (Zachary Quinto) slaps the bullying 5-year-old son of another couple, inciting legal action — and resurrecting some long-buried family secrets. Melissa George plays the boy’s mother; Thandie Newton is Hector’s beautiful wife; and Uma Thurman, Thomas Sadoski, Brian Cox and Makenzie Leigh round out the cast of this eight-part mini-series adapted by Jon Robin Baitz from an Australian series based on a novel by Christos Tsiolkas. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley called the show “a remarkable feat — a sophisticated, suspenseful comedy of ill manners that seems much more like a Showtime or Netflix drama than a broadcast network offering.” “The Slap,” she added, “connects, but it’s not a harsh blow. It’s more of a bracing surprise.”

headline: What Our Paranoia About Drones Says About Us
text: A lazy drift of mist obscured an already gray November morning as I stared skeptically skyward in Morningside Park. It was not, I told myself, technically raining; still, moisture had begun to collect in the folds of my jacket as I surveyed the weather conditions. Driven more by impatience than by prudence, I decided to go ahead with the plan. Carefully following the precise sequence prescribed by the instructions, I switched on my remote controller and then the Wi-Fi transmitter, and finally double-pressed the power button on the back of the DJI Phantom 2 Vision quadcopter I purchased the night before. The copter trilled, then emitted four consecutive beeps. The GPS system began searching for satellites to map its launch coordinates, and a moment later the rotors whirred to life, sending ripples across a nearby puddle. And then the drone was airborne, rising to a hover six feet above me, conducting an aerial choreography to maintain its position despite the wind pushing it toward Manhattan Avenue. The copter streamed an image to my iPhone — me with my cap pulled low against the November drizzle, head tilted to meet the camera’s gaze. A drone selfie. Portrait of a man under self-surveillance.

headline: Does Your Work Fit Your Life?
text: Flexible work schedules have come in for a lot of praise lately. Last year, President Obama called for greater flexibility for federal workers — “to attract, empower, and retain a talented and productive work force in the 21st century,” he wrote in a memorandum, “the Federal Government must continue to make progress in enabling employees to balance their responsibilities at work and at home.” This year, he’s been advocating for paid family and sick leave. In December, a study suggested that work might be contributing to Americans’ sleep deprivation — its authors argued that “making the work start time more flexible may help increase sleep time; even if total time spent working is kept constant.” And in January, Samantha Cole at Fast Company reported on another study, this one finding that employees who were given flexible schedules and the option to work from home slept more than other workers, and also felt more well rested.

headline: Oscars 2015: A. O. Scott and Manohla Dargis Discuss the Contenders
text: A love-fest and a hate-watch, the Academy Awards is one of the few widely seen real-time television events left. Last year, an estimated 43 million Americans watched the ceremony and clearly not because it’s good entertainment. It isn’t even obvious that people love the movies in contention. When “12 Years a Slave” won best picture, only about six million people had seen the film; “Gravity” sold many more theater tickets, but even so, more people watched the Oscars than had seen that movie then. To judge from the recent flurry of culture-war-inflected skirmishes about some of the nominees, it’s clear that it’s no longer a question of whether the Oscars matter but why. Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott have been observing the commotion and offer some late-breaking critical views on the race as it enters its frenzied final stretch.

headline: 1915: Wilson Sends Berlin Ultimatum
text: LONDON — In a firm, but respectful, Message, which New York papers, led by the New York Herald, described as ‘‘an ultimatum to prevent war,’’ President Wilson has notified Berlin that the sinking of an American ship by a German war vessel will constrain the American Government to hold the German Government to strict account, and to take any steps necessary to safeguard American life and property. The Note to Germany reminds the Imperial Government that ‘‘the sole right of belligerents is limited to visit and search unless a blockade is effectively maintained — which this Government does not understand is proposed in this case.’’ To Note continues: ‘‘To declare of exercise the right to attack or destroy any vessel entering the prescribed area on the high seas without first determining its belligerent nationality and the contraband character of its cargo is an act so unprecedented in naval warfare that this Government is reluctant to believe that the Imperial Government of Germany in this case contemplates it as possible.’’— The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 13, 1915

headline: ‘The Whites,’ by Richard Price Writing as Harry Brandt
text: Many years ago, in a magazine interview, Richard Price (now the author of nine novels, including “Clockers” and “Lush Life”) was asked why he devoted so much of his considerable literary talent to crime fiction and film scripts featuring criminals. He responded by saying that when you circle around a murder long enough you get to know a city. I cut that line out of the magazine and taped it above my computer screen. For several years, it presided over what I wrote in my own novels. With that answer, I believed that Price had crystallized what many writers knew and attempted to practice. That is, he considered the crime novel something more than a puzzle and an entertainment; he saw it as societal reflection, documentation and investigation.
