text: Here are the things we found on the web this week that you might enjoy as much as we did.

headline: Inside the List
text: Adaptation, Part I: Readers who have kept tabs on Nick Hornby’s career might not be surprised that his new novel, “Funny Girl” — new at No. 9 on the hardcover fiction list — devotes considerable attention to a couple of scriptwriters. That’s because Hornby, who made his name with the 1995 novel “High Fidelity,” has lately embraced Hollywood in a big way. He received an Oscar nomination for his screenplay for the 2009 movie “An Education” (adapted from Lynn Barber’s memoir), then went on to adapt Cheryl Strayed’s “Wild,” currently in theaters, and Colm Toibin’s novel “Brooklyn,” which had its premiere last month at Sundance. (Interestingly, Hornby did not write the screenplay for “High Fidelity,” which jumped to film in 2000, or any of his other books to become movies — confirming the wisdom that it’s better to operate on other people’s children than your own.) In a recent online interview with The Atlantic, Hornby, who is British, explained why he had actively pursued the “Wild” gig: “There’s a side of me that responds very deeply to American things,” he said. “The book to me felt like a Springsteen album. I always loved Springsteen, but he’s very American. That kind of directness is really interesting to me because it doesn’t have to be unsubtle. It’s just a different way of being, a different way of thinking. The great thing about adaptation is it gives you a chance to be someone else.”

headline: ‘A Bad Character,’ by Deepti Kapoor
text: The title character of Deepti Kapoor’s searing debut is dead by Line 1, but I still read “A Bad Character” in one frantic sitting. I wasn’t desperate for details about his mysterious death or his relationship with the narrator; it was Idha, a woman ready to defy societal conventions, who kept me on the line.

headline: Kelly Link’s ‘Get in Trouble’
text: So come on then, what’s your superpower? You must have one — everyone does. And who is your nemesis? What’s your origin story? Have you managed to find a reliable sidekick? How many shadows do you have? Do you currently have a boyfriend, or would you prefer a Boyfriend? And have you been to the pocket universe that’s like Florida, only better?

headline: Greg Baxter’s ‘Munich Airport’
text: Imagine being in a foreign airport with your father, and your sister is somewhere in the same airport in a coffin waiting for you to fly her home, but the airport is fogbound and heaving with unhappy souls and you are given hours and then days to contemplate her death and your life. This is the plot, such as it is, of Greg Baxter’s second novel. The airport in question is Munich, and the fog is a confusion that seeps into the whole novel — Baxter is the fog machine and we the readers are also fogbound.

headline: ‘The Patient Will See You Now,’ by Eric Topol
text: With his previous book, “The Creative Destruction of Medicine,” Eric Topol, a cardiologist and director of the Scripps Translational Science Institute, established himself as one of medicine’s most innovative thinkers about the digital future. In “The Patient Will See You Now,” his exhaustively researched follow-up, Topol turns his attention to medicine’s “democratization” via “unplugged digitization, with the smartphone as the hub.” With approximately two billion users worldwide, smartphones, Topol says, “are the most rapidly adopted technology in the history of man.”

headline: Flipping Through Film School
text: The film critic Matt Zoller Seitz met the filmmaker Wes Anderson in 1994 in Dallas, after seeing the short film “Bottle Rocket,” an expanded version of which would become Anderson’s first full-length feature. In 2013, their long relationship yielded “The Wes Anderson Collection,” Seitz’s lavishly illustrated book about Anderson’s seven feature-length movies up to that point.

headline: ‘The Jaguar’s Children,’ by John Vaillant
text: In 2003, a trailer truck crammed with immigrants trying to cross the United States border illegally was abandoned on the outskirts of Victoria, Tex. As the heat inside climbed over 100 degrees, 19 people died of asphyxiation and heatstroke — one a 5-year-old boy and one believed to be his father. Holes, which people had made by taking turns attempting to scratch their way toward breathable air, were visible in the insulation of the locked door.

headline: Love
text: THE BOOK OF LOVE  Improvisations on a Crazy Little Thing  By Roger Rosenblatt  Ecco/HarperCollins, $22.99.

headline: ‘Bonita Avenue,’ by Peter Buwalda
text: The title of the Dutch writer Peter Buwalda’s volatile, time-scrambling first novel alludes to a residential street in Berkeley, Calif., where its central characters, the Sigerius family, once experienced a fleeting year or two of happiness before returning to their native Netherlands. But an equally apt title might be “Breaking Glass.”

headline: A Moroccan Stew With Spice and Sweetness
text: I’ve never been to Morocco — at least not physically. But it’s the first place my mind goes when my body has become thoroughly fed up with February’s damp chill.

headline: Confessions of Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Wine Connoisseur
text: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg admitted Thursday night to not being “100 percent sober” when she dozed off at last month’s State of the Union address.

headline: Exclusive | 26 East 80th Street
text: A restored townhouse at 26 East 80th Street has returned to the sales market at $21 million.

headline: Classic and Contemporary
text: An exquisitely preserved townhouse at 26 East 80th Street that was built in 1888, became part of a landmark district in 1977 and was restored and updated inside and out in 1995, has returned to the sales market after spending two years as a specialized rental — the tenant was the Argentine mission to the United Nations.

headline: Drug Maker Salix Is Once Again a Potential Takeover Target
text: Salix’s stock is up 50 percent in the last three months on speculation about a deal.

headline: For Hip-Hop Radio and Its Voices, Change Is on the Air
text: Two familiar New York voices shared the radio airwaves on Thursday, talking as usual about hip-hop, but up higher on the dial.

headline: Gene-Altered Apples Get U.S. Approval
text: The government on Friday approved the commercial planting of genetically engineered apples that are resistant to turning brown when sliced or bruised.

headline: Peak Times for Loan Closings
text: The most popular times to close on a mortgage are on Fridays and at the end of the month — even though there is not necessarily any financial advantage to borrowers in doing so.

headline: Deleting Files From Microsoft’s OneDrive
text: Q. I have Windows 8.1 on my desktop computer. I moved a document to the OneDrive, which I did not mean to do, so how do I delete it?

headline: Posing for Fashion Houses, N.B.A. Stars Feel at Home
text: Nick Young was slouched in a booth inside Santina, a restaurant under the High Line park, where the Italian fashion house Ermenegildo Zegna had organized a private dinner Thursday to fete the Knicks’ Carmelo Anthony, a featured face in one of its coming campaigns.

headline: ‘A Spool of Blue Thread,’ by Anne Tyler
text: Picture a middle-class American family, four generations, living in the suburbs. The “founder” is an upstart with a murky past, a hard-working construction guy in a bleak marriage. Next in line are his son and the son’s wife — he’s a chip off the old patriarch, inherits the construction business, soldiers on. She’s the maddening, meddling family fixer-upper, determined that her four children will, against all odds, tolerate if not love one another. And then there are the children, at midlife and with children of their own: a couple of daughters who annoy each other, an “acquired” son (the product of a “crazy arrangement”) and of course the obligatory black sheep, Denny, the prodigal son who surfaces intermittently to provide the drama, which, after all, is his job — in the family as in the plot of Anne Tyler’s graceful and capacious new novel, “A Spool of Blue Thread.”

headline: ‘Once Upon a Revolution,’ by Thanassis Cambanis
text: Western coverage of the Arab Spring was often simple-minded, as journalists focused on the dramatic confrontations between the police and protesters in Tahrir Square in Cairo or on Libyan militiamen fighting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s soldiers on the road south of Benghazi. Uprisings were reported like scenes out of “Les Misérables,” with an oppressed people battling a brutal tyranny everywhere from Tunis to Bahrain.

headline: To a Friend, on His Divorce
text: YOU were 7 and I was 6 when we met near the jungle gym. After becoming bandmates in high school and enjoying a brief twinkle of local stardom, we became men and did man things, one of which was each finding someone we loved enough to marry. I have proof that both of us were happy then. The photos from our weddings show us laughing, smiling, greeting friends and relatives, eating cake, smoking cigars and dancing.

headline: Making Brokers Toe the Mark
text: If you are in the market for financial advice, good luck figuring out which financial advisers are legally obligated to act in your best interest. There is a big difference between glorified salesman and true investment advisers, and yet the onus is on consumers to sort it all out.

headline: When Italy’s Bad Bank Is a Good Idea
text: Italy’s bad bank is a good idea. Rome wants to set up a vehicle to sweep up banks’ toxic loans. It’s risky; government-funded bad banks can wind up losing taxpayers’ money. Yet it could also help lending and even spur consolidation in Italy’s fragmented banking system.

text: It’s not uncommon for fashion designers to branch out into home accessories — but rarely does a home design company make the reverse move. Enter Craig Bassam and Scott Fellows, the founders of the design brand BassamFellows, known for their work with the James Hotel and their aid in reviving the Swiss luxury brand Bally (and designing its corporate headquarters). On Monday, the duo will introduce its first line of apparel and accessories, imbued with the same attention to detail and craft as their rigorously Modernist furniture, interiors and architecture.

text: Arlene Alda, 81, and her husband, the actor Alan Alda, 79, say that one secret to a long-lasting marriage (theirs has been going for almost 58 years) is forgetfulness, which comes naturally to them at this point.

headline: Close but No Cigar
text: I have been close with a family member since she was a little girl. She is now the mother of two young children. I am also a mother, so I know how time-consuming that is. But I don’t understand why she has time to post on Facebook but doesn’t have time to answer my emails. I have tried commenting on her posts, but that doesn’t work, either. I am a baby boomer, and she is a Gen X-er. Can you explain what’s going on? Anonymous

headline: Not Your Bubbe’s Kasha
text: On Sunday I cooked up a big pot of nutty-tasting kasha, the cooked cereal made with toasted buckwheat groats. I enjoyed it all week. I stirred some into a frittata along with leeks and spinach, added it to two different salads and to buckwheat pancakes. I ate it plain, with a little milk and maple syrup as porridge for breakfast, and made a dinner in a bowl of kasha topped with mushroom ragout and kale.

headline: Roger Goodell’s 2013 Pay of $35 Million Keeps Him in Top Tier of Executives
text: Roger Goodell, the commissioner of the N.F.L., was paid $35 million in 2013, a year in which the league signed major television and sponsorship deals and settled a landmark concussion lawsuit, and in which two teams began work on new stadiums.

headline: The End of Trend
text: Typically, fashion editors sit at shows seeking out common threads or ideas to bring back to their offices and translate into fashion spreads that tell us what we ought to be wearing that season. This service is what you might think that we, at T, are here to provide. But times have changed. Technology and the economics of fashion have overthrown the old hegemony in which what was fashionable was proposed by designers, decreed by editors and proselytized for by department stores.

headline: Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon Resigns Amid Crisis
text: SALEM, Ore. — Gov. John Kitzhaber, long regarded as a wily survivor of Oregon politics, resigned Friday amid a spiraling crisis that included a criminal investigation of the role that his fiancée played in his administration and crumbling support from his Democratic Party colleagues.

headline: 1915: Britain Hails Air Raid’s Success
text: LONDON — All England is rejoicing to-day [Feb. 13] at the superb flight of her great air fleet, thirty-four strong, across the Channel, with not a serious injury to a pilot, and accidents to only two of the machines. It seems almost incredible that it was only five years ago that Blériot made the pioneer aeroplane trip across the Channel, so vast and rapid has been the progress since. The raid not only represents the largest fleet of air craft that has ever operated together, but it is a fitting reply to the German bombardment of British towns, and a warning to the Kaiser’s forces in Belgium of further damage. One fact well demonstrated by the raid is that in case of such an attack, land guns are unreliable defences, and it is necessary to meet aeroplanes with aeroplanes. The attack probably puts an end to Germany’s reputed intention to use Zeebrugge and other places on the Belgian coast as bases for submarines. The Admiralty states that no submarines were seen. This indicates that German preparations are too incomplete for them to trust these craft in Belgian harbors. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 14, 1915

text: Taken at face value, the reasons both Alan Gilbert and the New York Philharmonic are giving for his decision to step aside as music director in the summer of 2017 make some sense. Still, this move raises questions about how satisfied the administration is with Mr. Gilbert’s work and sends uncertain signals about the orchestra’s future.

headline: Refuse to Vaccinate? Little Religious Ground to Stand On
text: Earlier this month, a bill surfaced in the New York State Legislature proposing that parents be permitted to reject vaccinations for their children simply because they opposed them philosophically, as one might oppose Oreos or the Disney Channel. The bill had emerged before and gone nowhere; in the unlikely event that it was enacted, it would give parents even greater leeway to reject science for children who were ostensibly in school to gain an understanding of it.

text: The Alibaba Group’s dust-up with one of its Chinese regulators may have settled down, but the Securities and Exchange Commission is still interested in more information about the dispute.

headline: Lynn Hershman Leeson Explores Technology and the Split Self
text: The philosopher Isaiah Berlin once described David Hume’s idea of the self as a pure fiction, “a name for the concatenation of experiences out of which human personality and human history were formed, simply a kind of string which held together the onions, except that there was no string.” For decades, the artist and filmmaker Lynn Hershman Leeson has been playing with this un-string, which technology has rendered all the more evanescent. Starting Thursday, a broad sweep of her unsettling work will inaugurate Bridget Donahue, a new gallery on the Lower East Side being opened by a longtime director at Gavin Brown’s Enterprise, the West Village gallery. Ms. Donahue said she had been drawn to Ms. Hershman Leeson as a kind of prophet of “our cybernetic condition,” through early interactive works that delved into artificial intelligence and surveillance and yearslong performances that blurred the line between acting and life. The show, “Origins of the Species,” through April 5, will span from the late 1960s to recent work exploring the implications of genetic manipulation. (99 Bowery, 2nd floor; bridgetdonahue.nyc.)

headline: Why Movie ‘Facts’ Prevail
text: THIS year’s Oscar nominees for best picture include four films based on true stories: “American Sniper” (about the sharpshooter Chris Kyle), “The Imitation Game” (about the British mathematician Alan Turing), “Selma” (about the passage of the Voting Rights Act in 1965) and “The Theory of Everything” (about the physicist Stephen Hawking).

headline: Review: Douglas Dunn’s ‘Aidos’ Is Set to Bach at BAM Fisher
text: It’s about halfway through Douglas Dunn’s “Aidos” that things get weird. This 75-minute work, which had its debut on Wednesday at BAM Fisher, is set to 12 movements from Bach’s six suites for unaccompanied cello, played live and out of their original order by Ha-Yang Kim. Much of the choreography is politely balletic, its decorum ruffled only momentarily by a rough outburst here, a flash of louche hip motion there.

headline: Jason Wu Lets His Models’ Hair Down
text: It’s a new wave for Jason Wu, who usually sends his models down the runway in some sort of low ponytail but opted instead for a natural hairstyle on his fall/winter 2015 runway. “It was nonchalance and sexiness having their hair just the way it is, letting the girls really shine through,” explained the designer. “The clothing is very glamorous, very sexy. The hair down felt like the girls did it themselves.”

headline: Learn to Be a Bull

headline: Leaving Only Footsteps? Think Again
text: ONE of the most popular places for backcountry skiing in North America is Teton Pass in Wyoming, high above the adventure playground of Jackson Hole.

headline: Obama on Cybersecurity Executive Order
text: In a speech at Stanford University, President Obama introduced an executive order that will promote more information sharing to combat cyberthreats.

headline: Sexual Confusion

headline: Review: John Zorn and Talea Ensemble Play at Ecstatic Music Festival
text: Some of the composer John Zorn’s earliest works, from the 1970s and ’80s, were rule-driven improvisations that he called “game pieces,” which coyly suggested sports while also evoking the little markers that are moved around the board in Monopoly or Candy Land.

headline: Obama Calls for New Cooperation to Wrangle the ‘Wild West’ Internet
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Declaring that the Internet has become the “Wild Wild West” with consumers and industries as top targets, President Obama on Friday called for a new era of cooperation between the government and the private sector to defeat a range of fast-evolving online threats.

headline: The First Victims of the First Crusade
text: THE first victims of the First Crusade, inspired in 1096 by the supposedly sacred mission of retaking Jerusalem from Muslims, were European Jews. Anyone who considers it religiously and politically transgressive to compare the behavior of medieval Christian soldiers to modern Islamic terrorism might find it enlightening to read this bloody story, as told in both Hebrew and Christian chronicles.

headline: Rebecca Minkoff’s Bangin’ Beauty Look
text: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

headline: Review: Martha Graham Dance Company Performs With PeiJu Chien-Pott
text: In its season at the Joyce Theater, the Martha Graham Dance Company is presenting works by nine choreographers other than its founder, most of them acquired over the last two years. Next to this increasingly varied repertory, Graham’s work can stand out as drearily dated or intensely urgent. The mind jumps between asking, “Why does this still exist?” and “Can this please never go away?”

headline: Review: John Cariani’s ‘Love/Sick’ at Royal Family
text: The ratio of laughs to eye rolls runs about three to one in the whimsical romantic comedy “Love/Sick.” A pessimist would say, that’s a lot of eye rolls. An optimist would say, it’s just a play, shut up and stop keeping score.

headline: Joost Bakker: Flowers for Bones
text: A renegade florist takes recycling to a new level with a zero-waste restaurant.

headline: Close Quarters
text: Can I ask my neighbors to quiet their baby?

headline: Bill Cunningham | The Teddy Bear Coat
text: A row of teddy bears in a window display for Valentine’s Day show the color that is already the choice of many men and women.

headline: Off the Runway
text: Scenes from the second day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The Teddy Bear Coat
text: New York Fashion Week opened on Thursday with designers’ proposals for next winter, but many people on the street have already decided that the future is functional and classic, and the eccentricities of fashion are better left to the art world. A row of teddy bears in a window display for Valentine’s Dayshow the color that is already the choice of many men and women spotted in New York.

headline: Inside T’s Spring Women’s Fashion Issue
text: T’s spring women’s fashion issue celebrates the free thinkers whose distinct visions shape our culture today. On the cover is Bjork, whose genre-bending songs and mastery of design, technology and visuals have been pushing music forward for the past three decades, and who is being honored with her first retrospective at MoMA next month. We pay a visit to Sharjah, where the progressive sheikh’s daughter, Hoor Al Qasimi, has inherited — and subsequently boosted the profile of — a humble but growing art expo with some serious indie cred. Stateside, we take a closer look at Philip Johnson’s iconic Glass House, which may be the late architect’s greatest achievement (even if it’s not quite right to call it his home). And in the never-dull French capital, where politicians have been known to air their laundry for all to see, Liesl Schillinger spins a true-life tale of sex, lies and presidents truly befitting the City of Light. Elsewhere, Cathy Horyn assesses the promise and perils of a post-trend fashion world; a pair of authors and a visual artist spill secrets from their diaries; a writer with a rare skin condition that keeps her isolated from the outside world sheds light on her life in the darkness; the talented and at-times controversial French-Canadian filmmaker Xavier Dolan sets his sights on Hollywood; and the prolific makeup artist Pat McGrath gets a close-up of her own in By the Numbers. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Evening Hours | Florid Designs
text: Dinners, exhibitions and a traditional ball.

headline: Argentine Debt Dispute Remains Murky Even as London Court Sheds Some Light
text: A stalemate in the bitter dispute over Argentina’s bonds looks set to drag on, even after a ruling on Friday in an English court gave one side a small victory.

headline: Drake and Kanye West: Proven Paths to Stardom
text: Kanye West’s debut album, “The College Dropout,” ends with a rambling recitation, “Last Call.” In it, he recalls the conspicuous consumption of his younger years: “Get a Pelle Pelle off layaway, get some Jordans or something/Or get a TechnoMarine, that’s what we wore back then.”

headline: Review: Joan Shelley Offers Celtic-Tinged Melodies
text: Stars shine overhead, and rivers flow nearby in songs by Joan Shelley, who performed on Thursday night at Union Pool in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Her music is folky and pastoral, with a sense of scale that makes her humble about her place in mankind and the universe, and her songs are serene but never complacent. In “Electric Ursa,” the title song of her current album (No Quarter Records), Ms. Shelley sang, “Under your stars, your earthless movement/We are only feeble humans.”

headline: The AmfAR Gala: The Right Place, Just in Time
text: Fashion Week isn’t a safe space for Brian Williams, either.

headline: From Feuding Friends, Lovers From Russia and Ukraine
text: When tirades between Russians and Ukrainians overwhelmed Oksana Yushko’s Facebook feed, she issued a plea for understanding. Soon, love followed.

headline: Love in the Time of Binge-Watching
text: Like many couples, Jed Kolko and Eric Rice like to watch their favorite television programs together. The hardest part is hitting the play button at the same time.

headline: What Makes a Celebrity Gaffe Stick?
text: At the National Book Awards last November, Daniel Handler, better known as the children’s author Lemony Snicket, bounded onstage after Jacqueline Woodson won a top prize for “Brown Girl Dreaming,” the chronicle of her family’s history from slavery to civil rights. As the applause for her award died down, Mr. Handler, the evening’s M.C., told the crowd that Ms. Woodson had once shared with him over lunch that she was allergic to watermelon.

headline: Shelves Full of Superheroes
text: Alex’s MVP Cards and Comics has found a new home in Yorkville.

headline: Change, Slower Than a Speeding Bullet
text: “I’m not a big change guy,” said Alex Gregg, the owner of Alex’s MVP Cards and Comics. The depth of that understatement becomes clear as you get to know Mr. Gregg, who has been married for 28 years, tended bar at Elaine’s for 22 years and ran his comic store at 256 East 89th Street for 26 years.

headline: Gradual Transformation at Oscar de la Renta
text: Peter Copping, the successor to Mr. de la Renta, has made small but significant changes at the company.

headline: Bridget Everett, Curves and All
text: An encounter with Bridget Everett, for some of us at least, means acquiring a new vocabulary, terms like “meatballs,” “slingshots,” “low-riders” and “slip-and-sliders.” Turns out that in Ms. Everett’s colorful lexicon, they are synonyms for “breasts,” expressions she drops routinely in “Rock Bottom,” her wildly ribald thrice-weekly cabaret show at Joe’s Pub.

headline: A Deal at the 2009 Baze Senior Knockout Teams
text: The names of most great bridge players are well known in the game. A few experts, however, fly under the radar — their talent being recognized primarily by their peers. One of those was Garey Hayden, who died on Feb. 5 in Tucson, his hometown. He was 70.

headline: Catching Up at Upholstery Store, the Bar That Got Itself a Kitchen
text: Sometimes even the best old neighborhood haunt can use a little sprucing up. So it went with Upholstery Store: Food and Wine, once a narrow wine bar on a quiet block in the West Village, which reopened in late January, after a year of renovations, with a new food menu. “We always wanted to do something with oysters and with fish,” said Leo Schneemann, who owns the reincarnated Upholstery Store with the chef Kurt Gutenbrunner. But the bar had no kitchen.

headline: Jordanians See U.S. Reporting Bias in Coverage of Student Killings
text: AMMAN, Jordan — Whether three young students were shot and killed in North Carolina this week in a parking dispute or, as their families believe, because they were Muslims, online commentators here and outside the Middle East say the victims’ religion makes it a hate crime.

headline: Love Is in the Air
text: Over the past several years, the photographer Todd Heisler has captured moments of affection in New York, everywhere from baseball stadiums to subway stations.

headline: Betsey Johnson: A Role Model, Still
text: Fifty years ago, the designer Betsey Johnson — part rebel, part cheerleader — got herself from proper Connecticut to New York City, as many a respectable female adventurer was wont to do. She arrived in Manhattan by way of a 1964 Mademoiselle magazine guest editorship. (She was in good company: Joan Didion and Sylvia Plath preceded her.) But that wasn’t the New York she was searching for. She had been staying at the white-gloved Barbizon Hotel for Women, and knew there was another New York. Soon she found it: the dark new bohemia that was just then supplanting the earnest folk-singing scene of Macdougal Street. She was home.

headline: In Praise of the Cute Animal Video
text: It started with the wombat. Or was it the big blackbird that for reasons unexplained, landed and loitered on a man’s guitar while he skillfully played “Blackbird” by the Beatles? Or did it start with the raccoon sitting up on its hind legs and putting its agile little paws in the mouth of a beagle to give what looked like an unusually thorough checkup?

headline: Smoke-Free Policies
text: To the Editor:

headline: Iran: Delays Feared in Reporter’s Trial
text: The mother of Jason Rezaian, The Washington Post’s Tehran correspondent, who has been incarcerated without publicly explained charges since July 22, said Friday that she feared new delays in his trial, and that the Iranian authorities had sharply curtailed prison visits from Mr. Rezaian’s Iranian wife. Mr. Rezaian was formally charged in January, even though the judiciary has not disclosed any details. His mother, Mary Rezaian, said that under Iranian law, Mr. Rezaian should be put on trial by early March, within 60 days after formal charges are set. But now, she said, “there are rumblings” that her son’s case will not be heard until after the Persian New Year holiday, which falls on March 21 and lasts for about two weeks, “so it can only be assumed his trial date might not be set before April 6.” Mrs. Rezaian, an American who lives in Turkey, made the assertions in a written commentary posted on CNN’s website. American officials and The Post have repeatedly called on Iran to release Mr. Rezaian, 38, a dual Iranian-American citizen.

text: Chario Antonio, 79, a longtime waiter at Dangerfield’s comedy club on First Avenue in Manhattan, loaded a stack of dishes into a small dumbwaiter behind the bar, then turned the joke on himself.

headline: Conservative Politicians Abroad Seem More Accepting of Evolution
text: On Wednesday, in an interview in London, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a potential Republican presidential candidate, sidestepped the question of whether he believed in evolution.

headline: At Wes Gordon and Jason Wu, Seeing Blue Skies In a ‘Grey’ Horizon
text: “Fifty Shades of Grey,” which (as we all know — admit it) opens on Friday, has already racked up the highest advance ticket sales ever for a Valentine’s Day, and taken up acres of newsprint, whether it’s critics wondering why it is so successful given how boring/prurient/sophomoric it is, or dismissing other critics wondering the above, or rising above by trying to make it into some sort of bellwether of our times.

text: The members of Austin’s Mother Falcon are multi-instrumentalists, especially Tamir Kalifa, who is their man on accordion, piano, bouzouki, guitar and camera.

text: There’s one group, at least, that won’t be happy about the designer David Hart’s new men’s wear collection, and that’s the anti-man-spreading brigade.

headline: Lagat, 40, Seeks Different Kind of Millrose Triumph
text: Bernard Lagat, who has won the Millrose Games’ signature Wanamaker Mile a record eight times, will probably finish toward the back when the race is contested Saturday at the 168th Street Armory. But he has his sights set on another significant accomplishment.

headline: What Happened to the Big Armchairs in Grand Central Terminal?
text: Q. I live near the Throgs Neck Bridge. I watch the container ships passing under on a regular basis. They all have a tugboat either pulling or pushing them. How is the decision made to push or pull?

headline: Multicolored Snow in Russia? No Worries, Officials Say
text: MOSCOW — In some places, say New York, the panic over snow often begins as soon as there is a forecast for it. In Russia, where it is a bit more familiar, there is typically no fear, unless the snow on the ground happens to be blue, as it was in Chelyabinsk this week, or orange, as it was earlier this month in Saratov on the Volga River.

headline: At Brooklyn Police Station, Using Inmates’ Video (and Pizza) to Prevent Youth Crime
text: Instead of the evening tour of officers gathering in the muster room of the 73rd Precinct station house in Brownsville, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, a group of 10 teenagers slumped on folding chairs, joking and fidgeting as lights were dimmed for a video.

headline: Finally Married in Mobile, Ala.
text: Kim and Regina Gebauer found themselves in the news media spotlight while waiting for a federal judge to order Mobile County to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples.

headline: A New Fix for Obamacare
text: EARLY next month the Supreme Court will hear arguments in King v. Burwell, the latest significant legal challenge to the Affordable Care Act. The petitioners argue that under the statute, the federal government is not allowed to provide health insurance subsidies in the 37 states that have either declined or failed to establish their own exchanges.

headline: Banana Republic Arrives at Fashion Week
text: Marissa Webb, flanked backstage this week by assistants, stylists and a constant stream of admirers, has a lot riding on her shoulders at New York Fashion Week. There is her own designer label to manage, and then there is Banana Republic, set to make its Fashion Week debut this weekend.

headline: Tapas for a Winter Break
text: I first ate at Xunta Tapas España in Caldwell on a bleak day in January. It was the same day I had come to the realization that hibernating bears were onto something.

headline: Taking Risks in Love
text: SHE was 25. I was 24. We spent only a couple of days together and shared no language in common. But when I returned to the United States from that European music festival, I announced to my parents that I had met my future wife.

headline: Gary Owens, Droll Announcer on ‘Laugh-In,’ Dies at 80
text: Gary Owens, a television and radio announcer best known as the droll, deadpan voice of “Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In,” died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 80.

headline: Breaking a Record, 11 Days Pass in New York City With No Killings
text: Police commanders are almost afraid to mention it. One said on Friday that he was too superstitious to talk about the string of days without a killing in New York City.

headline: Hitching a Toy to a Star
text: Superheroes wage some of their deadliest fights on the big screen.

headline: Sifting Ukrainian Fact From Ukrainian Fiction
text: When Senator James Inhofe took the floor of the Senate on Wednesday to argue for arming the Ukrainian military, he brought with him what he called indisputable proof of Moscow’s support for the separatists in eastern Ukraine — a poster with three large photographs of “Russian tanks entering Ukrainian territory.”

headline: In Dunk Contest, Tallest Competitors Face Taller Odds
text: The N.B.A. may be a tall man’s league, but in the slam dunk contest, the taller you are, the harder it is win.

headline: N. Hoolywood: Fall 2015 RTW
text: New York

headline: League’s Visiting Stars Draw a Crowd and Leave a Sense of Longing
text: “Come on, you can get it up there,” LeBron James said.

headline: Teenager Pinned Under Bus in Brooklyn; Driver Charged
text: A bus driver with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was arrested and charged with failing to yield after his bus struck a 15-year-old girl on Friday, severely injuring her leg, officials said.

headline: Standards Are at Stake in a Fight Over Schools in Arizona
text: PHOENIX — Diane M. Douglas, a Republican, was elected state schools superintendent in Arizona after vowing to repeal the Common Core, a set of reading and math standards intended to guide teachers from kindergarten through high school graduation.

headline: Scott Walker Needs an Eraser
text: Lately, the big star in the race for the Republican presidential nomination has been Scott Walker, the governor of Wisconsin. He gave a rip-roaring speech at a conservative confab in Iowa last month, and it’s been his moment ever since.

headline: A Suburban Bistro Born of an East Side Legend: P. J. Clarke’s in Woodbury
text: Early on in James Salter’s recent novel “All That Is,” the hero, Philip Bowman, meets two women in an East Side Manhattan bar. “I was thinking of going over to Clarke’s,” he tells them. He is, of course, referring to P. J. Clarke’s, the 130-year-old saloon at Third Avenue and 55th Street. Bowman, recently back from the war in the Pacific and newly minted as an editor at a major publishing house, is meant to symbolize the romance and optimism of the “Greatest Generation.” That his preferred watering hole is P. J. Clarke’s is testimony to the author’s keen eye for detail. For a character like Bowman, there would be no other bar.

headline: Assia Djebar, Novelist Who Wrote About Oppression of Arab Women, Dies at 78
text: PARIS — Assia Djebar, an Algerian-born writer and filmmaker whose widely admired work explored the plight of women in the male-centric Arab world, died here on Feb. 7. She was 78.

headline: Ending Secrecy on Police Misconduct
text: The deaths of unarmed civilians like Eric Garner in New York City and Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., led to demands for greater transparency in the workings of police forces all over the country. The need for more openness is especially pressing in New York, where a uniquely strict disclosure law has shielded from public view the records of individual officers, even those who have committed crimes.

headline: A Shopper’s Guide to Asian Treasures
text: The best things in life may be free — if the lyrics from the 1927 musical “Good News” are to be believed — but few people can resist the siren song of shopping.

headline: New Hotels in Asia for Surf and Sand
text: Whether your idea of going coastal involves surf spray intensity, paddleboard calm or some gently lapping middle ground, this new crop of Asian hotels and resorts celebrates the sea in a range of moods. Room styles vary too, from dwelling above coral heads to fronting an industrial wharf. (Dollars are accepted at these properties unless otherwise noted.)

headline: Discovering Lodge Hospitality in New Zealand
text: As the co-founder, chairman and chief executive of the $30 billion investment firm Tiger Management L.L.C., Julian Robertson, 82, has achieved a high profile in the world of finance. His role as a luxury hotel proprietor, however, has been more under-the-radar.

headline: County Coroner in Washington Plans Inquest Amid Furor Over Police Killing
text: The coroner in Franklin County, Wash., plans to order an inquest into the killing of a Mexican-born orchard laborer who, a cellphone video shows, was fleeing police officers and was then shot by them from what appeared to be no more than 20 feet away as he turned toward them with his hands held out in front.

headline: A War on Workers in Illinois
text: As one of his first official acts, the new Republican governor of Illinois, Bruce Rauner, issued an executive order this week that would weaken state unions by barring them from assessing fees on some of the workers they represent in collective bargaining. Worse, the damage from the order could reach far beyond Illinois.

headline: Basis for Case in Brooklyn Police Shooting: No Threat Led Officer to Fire
text: On the surface, the police shooting of an unarmed man in a housing project stairwell in Brooklyn seemed like a freakish accident.

headline: An Uzbek Wave, ‘Made for Wrestling’
text: At least nine high schools in Brooklyn and one in Queens have Uzbek immigrants on their wrestling squads.

headline: Former Army Sniper Pleads Guilty in Murder-for-Hire Conspiracy
text: A former Army sergeant with the nickname Rambo pleaded guilty on Friday to conspiring to murder a federal drug agent and another man, in what the government has said was his post-military role as a contract killer.

headline: Sport Works to Stay Relevant in Changing N.C.A.A.
text: Michael Phelps is an outlier for reasons beyond his record haul of 22 Olympic medals. On the United States national team, he stands apart as one of the few swimmers not to use college as a stepladder to scale the world rankings. Of the 49 athletes who represented the United States in swimming at the London Olympics, only Phelps and the freestyler Chloe Sutton had pasts or futures, or both, not tied to N.C.A.A participation.

headline: An Infamous Gap
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I need to apologize to David Steinberg for saying in the past that the fill in his puzzles makes him seem older than his years.

headline: Craft Beer in an Unlikely Location: At the DeCicco’s Grocery Store in Armonk
text: On the steps leading to the second level of the DeCicco’s grocery store in Armonk are these names:

headline: The Double All-Nighter for Matisse
text: It made perfect sense: Henri Matisse did so much of his cutout art in the restless dead of night, why not view it in the exhibit’s unusual all-night visitation hours offered last weekend at the Museum of Modern Art?

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 13, 2015
Elevating the Ubiquitous
text: In Connecticut there’s no better culinary success story than that of Dorjan Puka, a self-taught chef who immigrated from Albania at 23 after winning a green-card lottery, labored a dozen years in various restaurants, then opened two superb places of his own, Treva and À Vert Brasserie, in West Hartford. Now Mr. Puka has taken his act east of the river, with the Artisanal Burger Company, just off the highway in Manchester’s Buckland Hills.

headline: Dr. Marcy’s March
text: As January 1865 drew to a close, Lt. Gen. William T. Sherman readied his army, then camped around Savannah, Ga., to march north into South Carolina. Some 60,000 men strong, Sherman’s troops sensed the Confederacy’s flagging will. Four years of carnage had cost Southerners dearly, and Sherman’s campaign across Georgia had dealt the Confederacy a devastating blow. With the Army of Northern Virginia crouched in defensive positions around Richmond and Confederates scrambling to defend the Palmetto State, Sherman’s men prepared to push on, determined to bring the long and bloody war to an end.

headline: High School Recruits Think Twice About Signing Letters of Intent
text: MONTEZUMA, Ga. — In a crowded gymnasium at Macon County High School on Feb. 4, Roquan Smith, one of the top high school linebackers in the country, picked up a U.C.L.A. hat and put it on his head, signaling his intention to play for the Bruins.

headline: Braving the Freezing Temperatures for Love, Religion and Chocolate Sales
text: One hundred couples plan to get married on the 86th floor of the Empire State Building on Saturday. Outside.

headline: Suspension Rules Altered in New York City’s Revision of School Discipline Code
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration on Friday announced changes to the discipline code that governs New York City’s public schools, an attempt to further rein in some of the most severe punishments while also keeping schools safe.

headline: Canada: Attack Plot Is Foiled, Police Say
text: The police said Friday that they had disrupted a plot by four people to kill a “large number of individual citizens” in the Halifax area of Nova Scotia. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police and the Halifax police offered few specifics about the planned attack except to say that its two leaders also planned to commit suicide at the conclusion of their armed assault, which was scheduled for Saturday. “There’s nothing in the investigation to classify it as a terrorist attack or terrorist incident,” said Assistant Commissioner Brian F. Brennan, the commanding officer for the mounted police in Nova Scotia. He said the plotters were motivated by “some beliefs,” which he declined to identify. A 23-year-old woman from Geneva, Ill., was arrested at the Halifax airport along with a 20-year-old man from Nova Scotia. A 17-year-old man was arrested separately, and a fourth man, 19, was found dead in a house.

headline: Suno: Fall 2015 RTW
text: New York

headline: Selling Cure for Being Gay Found Illegal in New Jersey
text: The plaintiffs described the methods used by the counseling group in Jersey City from which they had sought help: One of them, a young man hoping to overcome his attraction to other men, said he had been told to grab a tennis racket, scream and beat an effigy of his mother as if killing her.

headline: De Blasio Chief of Staff to Leave City Hall for U.N. Job
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio is set to lose another senior member of his inner circle as his administration reorganizes for its second year.

headline: At Vassar College, Canvases So Big They Are Seldom Seen
text: Back and forth, side to side — visitors to “XL: Large-Scale Paintings From the Permanent Collection,” at the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center at Vassar College, may find themselves moving around while viewing each of the works on display. That’s because many of the paintings are so vast that it can be hard to grasp their entirety from a single vantage point.

headline: When the Islanders Call, a Gritty Fourth-Line Wing Delivers
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Missing Kyle Okposo on their top line and scuffling to manufacture goals, the Islanders continue to win with the grit and determination embodied by their fourth line of center Casey Cizikas and wings Matt Martin and Colin McDonald.

headline: Nothing New Here: Anthony Endures Meaningless Loss
text: Robert Pera was among the first participants to arrive at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, and he wore the determined look of a welder.

headline: In Huntington, an Exhibition of Pioneering Photography Through the Ages
text: “Modern Alchemy,” a small gem of an exhibition at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington, is a good reminder that experimental photography did not begin in the age of the digital camera, although technology has certainly helped it evolve. A selection of diverse images, accompanied by thorough explanations of how various photographers worked, starting with Man Ray in the 1930s, supports this idea.

headline: A Celebrity Facialist’s Recipe for Remedying Winter Skin
text: On the red carpet this weekend, the New York-based stars Julianne Moore and Maggie Gyllenhaal appeared untouched by winter as they arrived at the 2015 Golden Globe Awards. Their skin was radiant, almost dewy — not dry like most faces in Manhattan these days. And not coincidentally, they were each prepped for the evening by the celebrity facialist Joanna Vargas, who also counts Naomi Watts as a regular client. The expert, who just launched her newest anti-aging solution — the Forever Facial ($700), designed to improve the skin’s elasticity through the use of heat and radio waves (“they push your collagen fibers back together again and trigger collagen production,” she explains) — says the secret to great skin, no matter the time of year, is a facial once a month. “Nothing you do at home can replace a professional exfoliation, extraction and attention,” she says.

headline: A Wedding Weekend and a Family Crisis
text: Every wedding weekend needs a family crisis, and the one in Danai Gurira’s “Familiar” is the arrival of an eccentric aunt from Zimbabwe with dollar signs in her eyes. But this play, having its world premiere at Yale Repertory Theater, already has other sources of tension: The bride is a 34-year-old virgin, and the groom, marrying into a Zimbabwean family, is white.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I had those normal jitters you have when you are going to say your vows. All of that was just crushed.”

headline: Corrections: February 14, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Game of Young Standouts Favors Dunks Over Defense
text: Andrew Wiggins was named the most valuable player after scoring 22 points for the World team in a 121-112 win over the United States team in the Rising Stars Challenge at Barclays Center on Friday night.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 4 P.M. (TBS) UN-VALENTINE’S DAY MARATHON Seven hours of disastrous dates, screwball romances and awkward moments come just in time for those looking to counter all the saccharine of Valentine’s Day. The marathon begins with four episodes of “Friends,” including the first date Rachel (Jennifer Aniston) had with Ross (David Schwimmer). In “Seinfeld,” beginning at 6 p.m., four episodes bring back some of Jerry’s most memorable girlfriends — including “Man Hands” and the one whose name he can’t remember. And major breakthroughs in science and love are the highlights of six episodes of “The Big Bang Theory,” beginning at 8 p.m.

headline: When Jim Crow Got Cut From Spring Training
text: Here, in March 1947, Jackie Robinson, who was vying to become the first African-American in Major League Baseball in the modern era, obliges an autograph seeker during spring training in Havana.

headline: China’s Top Taxi-Hailing Apps Say They Will Merge
text: HONG KONG — If you can’t beat them, join them.

headline: From Feuding Friends, Lovers From Russia and Ukraine
text: Oksana’s Yushko’s personal contribution to the long history of love stories started because of Facebook.

headline: Ferry Captain Is Convicted in Hong Kong

headline: Ukraine Cease-Fire Goes Into Effect, but Rebel Leader in Key Town Repudiates Accord
text: ARTEMIVSK, Ukraine — A fragile, European-brokered cease-fire deal for Ukraine appeared at risk of unraveling, at least in part, when a rebel leader announced Saturday night that he would not be bound by the accord on a central battlefield of the war.

headline: Polio Team Attacked in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Gunmen attacked a vehicle carrying a polio vaccination team in northwestern Pakistan on Saturday, killing the driver and wounding a health care worker, according to police officials.

With the Mojave Desert as a backdrop, Boots was directing a mini-movie called “Motorcycle Jesus” wrapped around five of his new songs to be released on his website just eight days later on his 28th birthday, which was Friday.

My eyes kept drifting from the alternative minimum tax to the screen — which felt right, because I like the Los Angeles Lakers about as much as I like the I.R.S.

headline: What Your Online Comments Say About You
text: When we comment on news stories, most of us hope to say something about the topic at hand — even (or maybe especially) if it’s that the author got it all wrong. But what do the comments we leave say about us — about our beliefs, our biases and how we act when the ordinary rules don’t apply? And how do our comments affect the beliefs of others?

text: Spring training camps open this week in Florida and Arizona, heralding the start of a baseball season sure to be full of surprises. Could the Giants win the title in an odd-numbered year? — but here’s a look at a calendar of the absurd:

headline: Freezy Freakies, a Colorful Blast From Winters Past

headline: A Preferred Guest Gets the Cold Shoulder

headline: Bank Hackers Steal Millions via Malware
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — In late 2013, an A.T.M. in Kiev started dispensing cash at seemingly random times of day. No one had put in a card or touched a button. Cameras showed that the piles of money had been swept up by customers who appeared lucky to be there at the right moment.

headline: His Eyes Fixed Straight Ahead, Tony Stewart Plans Resurgence After Two Trying Years
text: Eighteen months after badly breaking his right leg in a crash, Tony Stewart is still not fully healed. He has had four operations so far — the latest on Dec. 1 to replace a rod in the leg — and another is planned after this season. It will be the third straight Sprint Cup season in which Stewart is not physically 100 percent.

In addition to celebrating the Patriots’ fourth Super Bowl title at a victory parade and elsewhere, Edelman has been promoting

headline: Searching for a Safe Deposit
text: “The First Bank of Bud” (Feb. 8) reported on the Fourth Corner Credit Union in Denver, created to serve the unmet banking needs of the marijuana industry. The credit union has a license from Colorado but has yet to receive approval for a Federal Reserve Bank account that it needs.

headline: Letters to the Editor

headline: The Epidemic of Facelessness
text: A PART-TIME delivery driver named Peter Nunn was recently sentenced to 18 weeks in a British prison for tweeting and retweeting violent messages to Stella Creasy, a member of Parliament. He never saw his victim but the consequences of his virtual crime were real enough. In a statement, Ms. Creasy described fears for her physical safety, going so far as to install a panic button in her home. Mr. Nunn has been physically separated from the rest of society for posting abusive words on a social media site.

headline: The Lies Heard Round the World
text: DURHAM, N.C. — LYING may be an age-old part of politics, but it’s becoming easier to spot the fibs, fictions and falsehoods. A growing army of fact-checkers around the world is busy debunking falsehoods from presidents, prime ministers and pundits — and if their results are indicative, 2014 was a banner year. Some of the claims were so absurd that fact-checking groups honored them with awards, like Australia’s Golden Zombie and Italy’s Insane Whopper of the Year.

headline: Vitamins Hide the Low Quality of Our Food
text: THERE is much concern these days about what’s in our dietary supplements. Are they actually filled with the ingredients that the labels promise?

headline: Great! Another Thing to Hate About Ourselves
text: A FEW years ago I got a Groupon for laser hair removal.

headline: The Smoking Toll Gets Much Worse
text: It seems impossible to believe that smoking is even more harmful to health than we had thought. Yet that is exactly what a large and authoritative study published last week has revealed.

headline: Wildlife Slaughter Goes Unabated
text: As the world’s booming black market for body parts from endangered species continues to elude effective policing, rhinoceros deaths quadrupled in four years to the 1,215 killed by African smugglers in 2014. These magnificent animals were slaughtered so that urbanites in places like China and Vietnam can take a dose of powdered rhino horn, which fetches tens of thousands of dollars a pound as a luxury cure for hangovers.

headline: What Libya’s Unraveling Means
text: Largely overshadowed by the crises in Syria, Iraq and Ukraine, Libya’s unraveling has received comparatively little attention over the past few months. As this oil-rich nation veers toward complete chaos, world leaders would be wise to redouble efforts led by the United Nations to broker a power-sharing deal among warring factions.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: David Merriam
text: David Merriam, a former California state trial judge and champion bull terrier breeder, is the Best in Show judge at this year’s Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, which begins Monday.

headline: Too Much Prayer in Politics
text: GOD had a busy week. Alabama alone was a heavy lift, what with all those God invocations by state leaders trying to cast out the demon of gay marriage, then London called as well. Scott Walker was on a trip there, and he tugged God into the picture when he was asked about evolution and declined to answer, as if embracing it would be a heathen outrage.

headline: The Caligulan Thrill
text: IN a society where almost every cultural phenomenon ends up interpreted through an ideological lens, the success de scandale of “Fifty Shades of Grey” — the books, the movie, the branded cuffs and whips — has left culture warriors a little bit confused. Is this another transgressive breakthrough — the latest blow to whatever remains of traditional morality, the mainstreaming of a lifestyle long locked away from view? Or is the now-famous story, with its alpha male gazillionaire and his punished female prize, actually a reactionary fairy tale, encouraging submission to the latest version of the patriarchy?

text: President Obama asked Congress for formal authorization to use military force against the Islamic State terrorist group this week, which lawmakers will debate in committee hearings this month. Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee and chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, will talk about the upcoming hearings on CBS’s “Face the Nation,” along with Denis McDonough, the White House chief of staff.

headline: Evolution From Modest Start to a Bonanza
text: Among the striking sights of last year’s N.B.A. All-Star Game — the dunks, the no-look passes and the general tomfoolery — was the final score.

headline: Did a Text Kill My Brother?
text: ONE Wednesday afternoon in 2013, I received a frantic call. My older brother Bob had been in an accident. He had been babysitting for two of his granddaughters until just after lunch. Then, sensing it was one of the final bursts of summer, he put on his helmet, hopped on his 2007 Harley and headed down lazy back roads toward the New Jersey shore.

headline: Gunman Believed to Be Behind 2 Copenhagen Attacks Is Fatally Shot, Police Say
text: LONDON — The Copenhagen police said on Sunday that they had shot and killed a man believed to be behind two attacks that killed two people, one at a cafe and one outside a synagogue.

headline: A Curious Case of Writer’s Block
text: Dr. Yalom, I would like a consultation. I’ve read your novel “When Nietzsche Wept,” and wonder if you’d be willing to see a fellow writer with a writing block.

headline: In Spanish Abuse Scandal, a More Open Vatican
text: GRANADA, Spain — David Ramírez Castillo first met his parish priest, the Rev. Román Martínez, as a 7-year-old catechism student. Later, he became one of his altar boys. Step by step, Mr. Ramírez says, the priest convinced him that to deepen his faith he should spend more time with him and the other clergy members.

headline: At North Carolina, Throwing Javelins and Running for Office
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — Time is precious for Houston Summers, a 27-year-old junior at North Carolina, and not just because he is majoring in psychology, with two minors, in the hopes of attending medical school. Summers, a former professional baseball player, is now a walk-on javelin thrower on the track team, and he is also trying to become the student body president.

headline: Teaching the Needy
text: Readers react to an article about the decline in applicants for Teach for America.

headline: In Louisiana, Desire for a French Renaissance
text: VILLE PLATTE, La. — “Qui c’est qui parle?” Jim Soileau asked, his baritone filling the studio of radio station KVPI and traveling across the Cajun prairie.

headline: After a Nap, Mikaela Shiffrin Plods, Then Bursts to a Slalom Repeat
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Early this winter, Mikaela Shiffrin was beaten three times at her best event, the slalom. The youngest Olympic champion in the history of the event, Shiffrin was not even making it to the podium.

headline: Greece’s Excess Burden
text: What’s the state of the Greek crisis? I have no idea, or at any rate no idea beyond what any diligent reader of press reports might glean. I do, however, have a pretty good idea of what Greece is asking for on the fiscal side, and it might be useful to talk about the arithmetic behind that position.

headline: Roger Goodell Looks to the Future, but Troubles Cloud the View
text: During his address last month on the state of the league, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell appeared eager to turn the page on 2014, a year when he was under siege for mishandling several domestic violence cases and for seemingly every other misstep that befell the league.

headline: Koos van den Akker Dies at 75; Designed Bill Cosby’s Vivid Sweaters
text: Koos van den Akker, a Dutch-born fashion designer with a celebrity clientele who was called the “master of couture collage” for his prismatic creations, notably the bold sweaters popularized by Bill Cosby on his long-running sitcom, died on Feb. 3 in Manhattan. He was 75.

headline: Military and ISIS Clash Over Iraqi Town Near a Base Housing U.S. Troops
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqi soldiers and militants of the Islamic State group clashed again over the weekend in a western Iraqi town that has changed hands several times in skirmishes near a military base where American troops are training Iraqi soldiers.

headline: Experiencing the Alpine World Ski Championships From Above
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — The first ski race I covered was the Olympic women’s downhill in Meribel, France, in 1992, and I watched it from the finish area amid the cheers, the groans and the rubbing shoulders in the close-quarter mixed zone.

headline: Tim Duncan Is a Five-Time Champion. Enough Said.
text: Tim Duncan did not sound overjoyed to be in New York for his 15th N.B.A. All-Star weekend, or maybe it was more the company he was forced to keep late Friday morning.

headline: James L. Dolan, a Consummate 1 Percenter
text: N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver paused in preparations for the corporate branding orgy that is his league’s All-Star Game and tossed a spray of a bouquet at James L. Dolan, the owner of the Knicks.

text: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

headline: From Diabelli, a Variety of Variations
text: Two adventurous smaller events, both on Tuesday, look especially intriguing this week. One explores the context of Beethoven’s “Diabelli” Variations, which he composed after the publisher Anton Diabelli sent a little waltz he had written to the leading composers of the Austrian empire, asking them each to write a variation, with the idea of publishing the entire set. Beethoven turned out a stand-alone colossus of a piece.

headline: Fresh Cut Orchestra, a Jazz Band That’s Hard to Define
text: The Fresh Cut Orchestra is a new young 10-piece Philadelphia-jazz municipality, a little hard to define and very much worth looking into. It’s a well-drilled band with three different leaders: the trumpeter Josh Lawrence, the bassist Jason Fraticelli and the drummer Anwar Marshall. (You might know them from records or bands led by Orrin Evans, Taylor McFerrin, Erykah Badu and Dave Douglas).

headline: Films by Jessie Maple in Lincoln Center Series
text: The work of Jessie Maple, a filmmaker and the first African-American woman to join New York’s camera operators union in 1975, will be celebrated on Monday with the program “An Evening With Jessie Maple” at the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center (144 West 65th Street). Ms. Maple, who wrote a book, “How to Become a Union Camerawoman,” about her life and hard-fought battle to join the union, directed two narrative features.

headline: ‘Havana Rakatan’ at City Center Offers a History of Cuba
text: City Center begins its three-week festival of Spanish and Latin American dance, A Bailar, with “Havana Rakatan,” a lively, rhythmically rich production that condenses 500 years of Cuban musical history into two hours. The show was bound for New York before the United States and Cuba renewed diplomatic ties, but that news should only bolster its feel-good spirit, as embodied by the exceptional dancers of Ballet Rakatan and the live music of the Cuban son band Turquino. Before Wednesday’s performance, a panel of Cuban and Cuban-American artists — including Eduardo Vilaro, the artistic director of Ballet Hispanico — will discuss the countries’ shifting political and cultural relations.

headline: ‘Vikings’ on the History Channel Returns With a New King
text: The History channel remains a grab bag where you can find quirky reality shows like “Down East Dickering,” decent mini-series like last year’s “Houdini,” and assorted schedule-fillers about extraterrestrials and people who live in swamps. Amid this hodgepodge, “Vikings,” a scripted series that begins its third season on Thursday night, has emerged as an anchor.

headline: Requests and Recommendations: Jeb Bush’s Letters

headline: As Dynasty’s Son, Jeb Bush Used His Connections Freely
text: The stream of requests to the White House from Jeb Bush, a young but well-connected Republican leader in South Florida, ranged from the weighty and urgent to the parochial and mundane.

text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — How do you feel when your crossword answers go wandering off in different directions? Are you one of those solvers who likes their answers either Across or Down, but never the twain shall meet? You’re out of luck today, my friends.

headline: Yale Restricts a Fraternity After Sexual Misconduct
text: A Yale fraternity has been banned from conducting on-campus activities until August 2016 as punishment for violating the university’s sexual misconduct policy at an initiation ceremony last year and then trying to impede the resulting investigation, the university announced this week.

headline: Autopsy Cites Cancer as Cause in Death of David Carr, Times Reporter
text: David Carr, the New York Times media columnist who died unexpectedly Thursday night, had lung cancer, and died of complications from the disease, according to the results of an autopsy released Saturday evening.

headline: Heavy-Metal Hair and Makeup at Alexander Wang
text: What a dynamic duo the makeup artist Diane Kendal and the hairstylist Guido Palau made this evening at Alexander Wang’s fall 2015 show. Inspired by heavy metal, they together created a beautifully gothic and gloomy look. “I’m keeping the skin very pale, with a dark brown and gray greasy feel on the eye,” Kendal explained. With a clean brush, she dragged the eye makeup (Aigle Noir Velvet Shadow Stick, Transvaal Eye Paint, Bellissima Duo Eyeshadow and Vientiane Matte Multiple, all by Nars) downward, to create the effect of “a hint of dark circle,” as Kendal put it, around the models’ eyes.

headline: India Blocked an Activist From Traveling to Britain
text: NEW DELHI — The Indian Ministry of Home Affairs has said it prevented a Greenpeace India activist from boarding a flight to Britain in January, where she was scheduled to brief members of Parliament on the effect of mining on indigenous communities in central India, because her visit was “prejudicial to the national interest” and would hurt India’s image abroad.

headline: Threatened Smelt Touches Off Battles in California’s Endless Water Wars
text: RIO VISTA, Calif. — On a boat in the heart of California’s biggest river delta, a researcher pored over a sample of murky, weed-infested water, looking for a rare fish about the size of a finger. Spotting one, he shouted in triumph — then measured it and quickly tossed it overboard.

headline: Sexual Abuse Allegations Against Imam Stir Rifts in Insular Illinois Community
text: ELGIN, Ill. — She ordinarily did not wear a veil. But it was required at the Islamic school where she worked, and she remembers being surprised when the head of the school, a conservative imam, suggested that she remove it.

headline: A Community Mediator
text: Omer Mozaffar, an Islamic scholar in Chicago, acted as a mediator last year when a woman accused a prominent local imam, Mohammad Abdullah Saleem, of sexual assault.

headline: Obama to Intervene in Dispute at West Coast Ports
text: LOS ANGELES — Seeking an end to a protracted labor dispute that has led to costly delays in West Coast shipping, President Obama has decided to intervene, the White House announced on Saturday.

headline: Delhi’s Air Is Often More Polluted Than Beijing’s
text: The levels of harmful fine particulate matter, called PM2.5, are significantly higher in Delhi during the winter months than they are in Beijing.

headline: Museum Rules: Talk Softly, and Carry No Selfie Stick
text: In a famous lab trial, a chimp named Sultan put two interlocking sticks together and pulled down an elusive prize, a bunch of bananas hanging just out of arm’s reach.

headline: Delhi Wakes Up to an Air Pollution Problem It Cannot Ignore
text: NEW DELHI — For years, this sprawling city on the Yamuna River had the dirtiest air in the world, but few who lived here seemed conscious of the problem or worried about its consequences.

headline: Raw Eggs and No Husband Since ’38 Keep Her Young at 115
text: VERBANIA, Italy — Celebrity came late to Emma Morano. Her routine life, in fact, might have raised barely an eyebrow were it not for the fact that she’s managed to hold on to it for so long.

headline: Dikembe Mutombo and John Calipari Are Among 12 Finalists for Basketball Hall of Fame
text: As famous for his wagging finger and charitable work as he was for his play on the court, Dikembe Mutombo, a four-time N.B.A. defensive player of the year, headlined a list of 12 finalists announced Saturday for induction into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame.

headline: G.M. Expands 2014 Recall for Power Steering Failure
text: General Motors is recalling more than 81,000 cars because their power steering systems could suddenly fail, making the vehicles harder to turn. The action expands a recall from last March that covered 1.3 million vehicles in the United States.

headline: Hundreds Protest Fatal Police Shooting in Washington
text: PASCO, Wash. — A protest held here Saturday over the police killing of a Mexican-born apple picker had the air of a mournful family picnic.

headline: LaMarcus Aldridge Will Replace Anthony Davis in West’s Starting Lineup
text: After recently labeling himself a “boring All-Star,” LaMarcus Aldridge can add “starter” to that moniker. He replaces the injured Anthony Davis, who just happens to be one of the most exciting young players in the N.B.A.

headline: At Millrose Games, Bernard Lagat Sets a Mark for 40-Year-Olds
text: Bernard Lagat, in his return to the event he has owned for more than a decade, did not disappoint the local fans jammed into the 168th Street Armory’s New Balance Track & Field Center in Manhattan on Saturday.

text: A gunman sprayed bullets into a cafe where a cartoonist who had caricatured the prophet Muhammad was speaking, followed hours later by a shooting near the city’s main synagogue.

headline: Facing the N.B.A.’s Best 3-Point Shooters, Stephen Curry Finishes First
text: In one of the best groupings of shooters to ever participate in the N.B.A.’s 3-point contest, Stephen Curry of the Golden State Warriors cruised to victory Saturday, at one point hitting 13 consecutive shots, much to the delight of a Brooklyn crowd that seemed to be rooting for him from the start.

headline: Allison Polland, Adam Roth
text: Dr. Allison Rachel Polland, a daughter of Diane L. Polland and Elliot R. Polland of Kings Point, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Adam Joseph Roth, the son of Anne W. Roth and Dr. Stuart M. Roth of Columbia, Md. Cantor Daniel Neiden is to officiate at the home of the bride’s parents.

headline: Anthony Hird and Reed Caldwell
text: Anthony Raymond Hird and Dr. John Reed Caldwell are to affirm their partnership Sunday with a commitment ceremony at Las Caletas Hideaway Beach in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico. Andrew A. Hopping, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, is to lead the event.

headline: Review: Paul McCartney Offers an Intimate Valentine’s Day Gift
text: A holiday, a song title and a free night before a TV appearance were pretext enough for Paul McCartney to book a sudden show on Saturday night at Irving Plaza; its capacity, about 1,000, is an order of magnitude smaller than the arenas he usually headlines. The audience, he said joshingly, was “so close you can see my dental work.” On Sunday, Mr. McCartney was scheduled to perform on “Saturday Night Live’s” 40th-anniversary prime-time special. But Saturday was also Valentine’s Day, and Mr. McCartney announced, “Tonight it’s all about love.”

headline: 1915: Amputation Scheduled for Sarah Bernhardt
text: In connection with the postponement of the operation which Mme. Sarah Bernhardt was to have undergone Sunday [Feb. 14], it is now announced that it’s a question of amputating her right leg, and the delay is occasioned because of a decision to carry out a preparatory treatment lasting about ten days. Mme. Bernhardt was lately taken from Arcachon to a private hospital in Bordeaux, where the operation was to have taken place on Sunday, but after a consultation, a postponement was thought advisable.

headline: Weimar and Greece, Continued
text: Try to talk about macroeconomics, and you’re sure to encounter accusations that your policies would turn us into Weimar Germany; those wheelbarrows full of cash remain the ultimate bogeymen for many, despite years of being wrong about everything. As some of us have noted, however, there’s a peculiar selectivity in the use of Weimar as cautionary tale: it’s always about the hyperinflation of 1923, never about the deflationary effects of the gold standard and austerity in 1930-32, which is, you know, what brought you-know-who to power.

headline: ‘Taxi’ by Jafar Panahi Takes Top Prize at Berlin Film Festival

Mr. Panahi’s young niece, who appears in the film and steals the show with her luminous curiosity, accepted the award on her uncle’s behalf.

headline: Philip Levine, a Poet of Grit, Sweat and Labor, Dies at 87

headline: What’s On TV Sunday

headline: Derek Lam’s Simple, Pretty ’70s-Inspired Ponytail
text: Inspired by a pair of bell-bottom trousers from Derek Lam’s fall 2015 collection, the hairstylist Orlando Pita mimicked the wide shape in a textured ponytail. To get the look, Pita blow-dried the hair using, depending on the density of the model’s tresses, either Phyto’s Phytovolume Actif or Phyto’s Intense Volume mousse for texture. He kept the top portion slick and tidy, with an off-center, controlled part, and pulled the rest back into a ponytail at the nape of the neck, finishing the look with Phyto Phytolaque Soie hairspray. And, for a little extra interest: “We have this accessory in the hair, in the ponytail, which women would use in the ’70s when I went to high school,” Pita said. “We made a streamlined New York version for today.”

headline: 1940: Spy Plot, Including a Beautiful Blonde, Revealed
text: For the first time in five-and-one-half months of war, romantic Frenchmen were given the details yesterday [Feb. 15] of an espionage affair which conforms to all the traditional demands of fiction: an allegedly faithless government employee, a beautiful blonde and a number of enemy spies. What made the case more interesting was the fact that it occurred before war broke out and not until yesterday was it revealed that a certain Baroness von Einem was supposedly the ringleader of the gang. All Paris was surprised to learn of the implication of the beautiful young Baroness von Einem and of Gaston Amourelle, a stenographer in the French Senate.

headline: Review: In ‘Green on Blue,’ an Afghan Boy Narrates Story of War
text: This haunting debut novel by Elliot Ackerman — a decorated veteran who served five tours of duty in Afghanistan and Iraq — is told not from the point of view of an American soldier, but in the voice of an Afghan orphan named Aziz who is forced to join a United States-funded Afghan militia called the Special Lashkar after his beloved older brother Ali is gravely wounded. “Green on Blue” is a novel that conveys, with harrowing power, the fallout that decades of war (going back through the Soviet occupation of the 1980s) has had on that country’s people, and at the same time, it’s a kind of Greek tragedy about the cycles of revenge and violence that can consume families and tribes, generation after generation.

headline: Review: Original Leads Return in City Ballet’s ‘Romeo + Juliet’
text: It was 2007 when Peter Martins unveiled his “Romeo + Juliet.” At the time, the New York City Ballet production — which began a run of nine performances on Friday at the David H. Koch Theater — had one thing going for it: Mr. Martins’s decision to cast his leads, particularly Juliet, young. (His Romeos required more experience and strength for partnering.) He worked with students at the City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet, including the now-esteemed soloist Russell Janzen, but eventually settled on two fresh company members for the premiere: Robert Fairchild and Sterling Hyltin.

headline: Review: Summation Dance, in a Kaleidoscope Repeatedly Snapping Into Focus
text: In 2010, when Sumi Clements and Taryn Vander Hoop founded Summation Dance Company, they were just about to graduate from the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University. Five years later, their all-female ensemble still looks young, and the choreography by Ms. Clements retains the feel of high-level student work, adeptly constructed but emotionally and artistically immature.

headline: Imprint on a Dirt Road
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — On the face of it, this looks like an ordinary crossword puzzle, which is what you would expect, especially on a Monday. But then you would remember that it’s Washington’s birthday, or Presidents’ Day, or whatever they’re calling it these days, and you would probably say, “Hey! Where my presidents at?”

headline: Writers Guild Chooses Top Screenplays of 2014
text: “The Grand Budapest Hotel” and “The Imitation Game” were named best original and adapted screenplay, respectively, at the Writers Guild of America Awards, given out Saturday in Los Angeles and New York. The script for “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” a comedic caper about a charismatic concierge and a young bellboy at a popular 1930s European ski resort, was written by Wes Anderson. “The Imitation Game” was written by Graham Moore and based on Andrew Hodges’s book about the British code-breaker Alan Turing. Other winners included Brian Knappenberger’s “The Internet’s Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz,” about a computer programming prodigy and information activist, for best documentary screenplay; Nic Pizzolatto’s “True Detective,” the HBO mini-series that revisits a 1995 murder case in rural Louisiana 17 years later, for best drama series and best new series; and “Louie,” a fictionalized series starring the comedian Louis CK, for best comedy series (written by Louis CK and Pamela Adlon) and best episodic comedy.

headline: Auction May Reveal Secrets of ‘American Pie’
text: Decades of speculation about the meaning behind of one of the 20th century’s most renowned and enigmatic songs could finally end when the notes and manuscripts of Don McLean’s “American Pie” go up for sale this spring — that is, of course, if the highest bidder chooses to publicly share what insights they may hold. The auction house Christie’s announced last week that the original working manuscript and typed drafts to the song — 16 pages total — would be auctioned on April 7 in New York. Mr. McLean, 69, told Reuters he decided to sell the documents on a whim. Other than admitting that a line in the song, “the day the music died,” refers to the Feb. 3, 1959, deaths of Buddy Holly, Ritchie Valens and J. P. Richardson, known as the Big Bopper, Mr. McLean has been mostly vague about the meaning of other parts of the song. He told Reuters that the “writing and lyrics will divulge everything there is to divulge.” “American Pie” was released in 1971. The manuscript is estimated to fetch between $1 million and $1.5 million.

headline: David Carr’s Last Word on Journalism, Aimed at Students
text: David Carr was known at The New York Times as a supreme talent scout, a mentor to young reporters and a blunt critic of those who didn’t measure up. He was a natural teacher, and right up until the day he died last week, he was bent on minting the next generation of journalists. Last fall, David joined the faculty at Boston University’s communications school. While David did not write his curriculum as a column, it has all the essential ingredients of one. So here it serves as the final Media Equation under David’s byline.

headline: Dangers, Frustrations and Snow Keep Piling Up in New England

It was the latest installment in a relentless string of storms that have blended, one into the next, enveloping every car and every home so that nothing has a distinct shape anymore; the landscape is just one seamless blanket of white.

headline: Michele Ferrero, Tycoon Who Gave the World Nutella, Dies at 89
