headline: In New York City, Jobs Come Back Without Wall Street
text: New York City has created more jobs over the past five years than during any five-year period in the last half century. But the city is not pulsing with the same boomtown swagger it radiated in past growth spurts.

headline: U.S. Revels in Victories and Its Rising Status in a Sport
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — When the Alpine world ski championships came to the United States this month for the first time since 1999, the 13-day event was quickly defined by two competitive challenges taking place simultaneously.

headline: Louis Jourdan, Suave Star in Europe and Hollywood, Dies at 93
text: Louis Jourdan, a handsome, sad-eyed French actor who worked in films and on television in Europe and the United States for more than 50 years, as a romantic hero in movies like “Gigi” and later as a suave villain in movies like “Octopussy,” died on Friday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 93.

headline: Polk Awards in Journalism Are Announced, Including Three for The Times
text: Reporters who uncovered systemic failure within the Secret Service and the Department of Veterans Affairs, and whose work led to reforms at both federal agencies, were among the winners of the George Polk Awards in Journalism for 2014, announced on Sunday by Long Island University, which administers the prizes.

text: Abbots, nothing gets between the Crawleys and their dinner.

headline: Bo Ryan Is Weaned to Win in Wisconsin
text: PLATTEVILLE, Wis. — As one approaches this town of 11,000 in the southwest corner of Wisconsin, the largest letter M in the world looms to the north. Made of 400 tons of whitewashed limestone, measuring more than 200 feet in each direction and symbolizing the University of Wisconsin-Platteville’s mining tradition, it is peaked on the kind of hill not ordinarily seen in the northern Midwest.

headline: Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon and His Fiancée Walked Tangled Path to Exit
text: SALEM, Ore. — Cylvia Hayes was a long-shot state legislative candidate — armed with a passion for renewable energy and a boundless well of enthusiasm — when she first met one of the state’s best-known Democrats, Gov. John Kitzhaber.

headline: Newspaper in India Pays a Price for Reprinting a Charlie Hebdo Cartoon
text: MUMBAI, India — The Charlie Hebdo slaughter in Paris has reverberated into the multireligious ethnic sprawl of Mumbai, where an Urdu newspaper has closed and its editor faces charges and death threats for having reprinted a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad from the satirical French weekly.

headline: Popular Demand
text: Every tweet, video or comment online has branding power, just like ads on television or online. In a measure of media value that included conversations on Twitter, Facebook, news sites, Google Plus and blogs, the N.F.L. joined four media giants in the $1 billion-plus club. Starbucks, at No. 11, captured $560 million in equivalent value in 2014.

headline: As Immigrants Settle Beyond City Limits, Help Is Hard to Find
text: José was looking for peace and quiet, in addition to work, when he decided to settle in the hinterlands of upstate New York 14 years ago. “A lot of farmland and trees,” he recalled, speaking in Spanish. “It reminded me of my village in Mexico.”

headline: A Lineup of New York Icons, With Carmelo Anthony on the Bench
text: Inside the Javits Center complex on the windy, frigid West Side of Manhattan on Sunday morning, there was genuine warmth for the N.B.A. legends most identified as belonging to New York. None of them were named Carmelo Anthony.

headline: Cablevision and Union Reach Brooklyn Contract Deal
text: Cablevision and the Communications Workers of America have reached a two-year contract agreement that gives the company’s 262 Brooklyn technicians considerable pay raises and ends a three-year standoff between the two sides.

headline: Record-Low Temperatures or Not, New Yorkers Are Feeling the Chill
text: In Grand Forks, N.D., where the average low temperature for February hovers around 2 degrees, Mike Roufs, a streets department supervisor with 42 years of snow-fighting experience, could have been forgiven for raising an eyebrow at New Yorkers who complained of the cold.

headline: Richard Meryman, Journalist and Wyeth Biographer, Dies at 88
text: Richard Meryman, a former Life magazine writer and editor who conducted the last interview with Marilyn Monroe, wrote an intimate portrait of the reclusive artist Andrew Wyeth, collaborated with Joan Rivers on a memoir about her quest for stardom and recounted a wrenching emotional journey after his first wife became fatally ill, died on Feb. 5 in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 15, 2015
Irving Singer, M.I.T. Professor Who Wrote ‘The Nature of Love,’ Dies at 89
text: Stung by family members urging him to be more affectionate, Irving Singer, a philosophy professor, spent years researching and writing a 1,300-page, three-volume examination of the subject titled “The Nature of Love.”

headline: Wary of a New Threat, Community Garden Activists in New York Look Back
text: One night 15 years ago, word spread across the East Village: The bulldozers are coming.

headline: Amar’e Stoudemire and Knicks Said to Be Parting Ways With Contract Buyout
text: The Knicks have agreed to buy out the remainder of forward Amar’e Stoudemire’s contract, freeing him to join another club before the N.B.A. resumes its schedule this week, according to a person with knowledge of the situation.

text: “They would say, ‘Grandpa, I don’t want to die young,’ and I held them, and they were shaking, and I looked in their eyes, and they were afraid. Now we are hoping.”

headline: Titles Carved in Ice
text: A look back at the 2015 Alpine world championships in Beaver Creek, Colo., where the United States won five medals on its home snow.

headline: Snow Buries Boston Again
text: A storm on Sunday put the city near its record for accumulation, and economic damage piled up, too.

headline: An All-Natural Beauty Site With a Cult Following Opens Up Shop
text: It’s barely a year old, but the wellness web store CAP Beauty has already gained a cult following among the celebrity set, including Helena Christensen and Brooke Shields, for its all-things-natural approach. And this weekend, the brand opened its first brick-and-mortar boutique-spa hybrid in New York’s West Village. “The available means of discovery in New York has really been limited,” says the cofounder Kerrilynn Pamer, who teamed up with her friend Cindy DiPrima Morisse to launch the shopping platform last May. “There’s a health food store, a grocery store, and bits and pieces of different brands in different outlets — but if you wanted to take on a clean beauty routine, that experience of going to one place to smell perfume and try eye cream, all while feeling safe, has been missing.”

headline: Senate Democrats Lobby for a Reprieve for Some Who Failed to Get Insurance
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats urged President Obama on Sunday to allow extra time for some people to sign up for health insurance as hundreds of thousands of Americans raced to beat the enrollment deadline.

headline: No Corrections: February 16, 2015
text: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. headline: Yankees Set to Retire Andy Pettitte’s Jersey
text: The Yankees are set to retire Andy Pettitte’s No. 46 jersey and honor him with a plaque in Yankee Stadium’s Monument Park in a ceremony on Aug. 23. Pettitte’s son Josh, a pitcher at Rice University, broke the news on his Twitter account that the Yankees would honor his father.

headline: What’s On Monday
text: 10 P.M. (13) INDEPENDENT LENS Thomas Allen Harris’s documentary “Through a Lens Darkly: Black Photographers and the Emergence of a People” tells the story of the men and women who have captured African-American culture over the past 170 years, including Carrie Mae Weems, Lorna Simpson, Anthony Barboza, Lyle Ashton Harris, Hank Willis Thomas (“Crossroads,” above), Coco Fusco and Clarissa Sligh. A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called the movie “a family memoir, a tribute to unsung artists and a lyrical, at times heartbroken, meditation on imagery and identity.” He added, “The film is always absorbing to watch, but only once it’s over do you begin to grasp the extent of its ambitions, and just how much it has done within a packed, compact hour and a half.”

headline: In N.B.A. All-Star Game, Pizazz Returns to Garden, and West Stars Shoot Their Way to a Win
text: In a spectacle of lights, music, fancy sneakers and flamboyant athleticism, the N.B.A. on Sunday night presented what should be, barring a dramatic turn of events, the final notable professional basketball game to be played at Madison Square Garden this season.

headline: N.B.A. All Star Game
text: The 64th N.B.A. All-Star Game, played at Madison Square Garden, was a typically high-scoring affair,, with celebrities not only on the court, but also in the stands.

headline: Russell Westbrook, Tight-Lipped Before Game, Makes a Statement as the M.V.P.
text: Russell Westbrook was one of the least enthusiastic players at the N.B.A.’s media day on Friday. Sitting on a podium and continually checking his phone, he gave one-word answers and seemed as if he would rather have been anywhere else.

headline: Save the Wisconsin Idea
text: MILWAUKEE — EARLIER this month, Scott Walker, the governor of Wisconsin and potential Republican presidential candidate, unveiled a proposed budget that would cut $300 million of funds to the University of Wisconsin system and shift power over tuition from the Legislature to a new public authority controlled by appointed regents. The initial draft of Mr. Walker’s budget bill also proposed to rewrite the university’s 110-year-old mission statement, known as the Wisconsin Idea, deleting “the search for truth” and replacing it with language about meeting “the state’s work-force needs.”

headline: Weimar on the Aegean
text: Try to talk about the policies we need in a depressed world economy, and someone is sure to counter with the specter of Weimar Germany, supposedly an object lesson in the dangers of budget deficits and monetary expansion. But the history of Germany after World War I is almost always cited in a curiously selective way. We hear endlessly about the hyperinflation of 1923, when people carted around wheelbarrows full of cash, but we never hear about the much more relevant deflation of the early 1930s, as the government of Chancellor Brüning — having learned the wrong lessons — tried to defend Germany’s peg to gold with tight money and harsh austerity.

headline: How to Force Prosecutors to Play Fair
text: When prosecutors cheat and lie repeatedly to win convictions, should their office be held accountable?

headline: George Washington, Slave Catcher
text: AMID the car and mattress sales that serve as markers for Presidents’ Day, Black History Month reminds Americans to focus on our common history. In 1926, the African-American historian Carter G. Woodson introduced Negro History Week as a commemoration built around the birthdays of Abraham Lincoln and Frederick Douglass. Now February serves as a point of collision between presidential celebration and marginalized black history.

headline: The Health Law, in the Real World
Goodbye to the Electronics Store
text: I was assembling a home audio system recently and needed speaker wires. A friend recommended RadioShack. I went to two — in Manhattan and in Brooklyn — but, to my surprise, neither carried any. How could RadioShack, the place Americans go to for cables, connectors, circuits and all kinds of other electronic doodads, not have speaker wires?

headline: A Kaffeeklatsch on Race
text: In our collective imaginations, we tend to conceive of the constantly called-for “national conversation on race” as having the formality of some grand conclave of consciousness — an American Truth and Reconciliation equivalent, a spiritual spectacle in which sins are confessed and blame taken and burdens lifted.

headline: Nigeria’s Miserable Choices
text: The Nigerian government was supposed to hold presidential elections this past weekend, which presented voters with the dispiriting choice of keeping a lousy incumbent or returning to power a former autocratic leader. Now they will have to wait at least six weeks to cast votes.

headline: What Alabama’s Roy Moore Got Right
text: Roy Moore, the chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, escalated the conflict over same-sex marriage last week, when he ordered probate judges in the state not to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, even after a federal judge struck down Alabama’s ban on the practice. In a recent radio interview, Moore said that he would continue to resist federal intervention: “There’s nothing in the U.S. Constitution that authorizes the Supreme Court of the United States or any federal court anywhere to misinterpret the word marriage to include something outside that.” The government, he added, does not have the power to “redefine marriage.”

headline: Hong Kong Ferry Captain Sentenced to 8 Years in Prison for Deadly Collision
text: HONG KONG — The captain of a ferry involved in Hong Kong’s deadliest maritime accident in more than four decades was sentenced on Monday to eight years in prison after being found guilty of 39 counts of manslaughter.

headline: Happy Presidents’ Day
text: We’re taking the day off on this national holiday — but we’ll be back with most of our regular content, including the Weekly News Quiz, on Feb. 17.

headline: Deutsche Wohnen Offers to Buy Austrian Real Estate Rival
text: LONDON – The German real estate company Deutsche Wohnen is planning a takeover bid for its Austrian rival Conwert Immobilien Invest that values the company at 1 billion euros, or about $1.1 billion.

headline: Recording Music, With a Camera
text: As with any scrappy aspiring rock band, when Mother Falcon goes on tour, its members endure the hardships of the road — sleeping in the van, hauling instruments, recouping after canceled shows, eating cheaply, quickly, and imprudently, and taming the tensions that flare up in close quarters among musicians.

headline: British Gambling Website 888 Holdings Ends Takeover Talks
text: LONDON — The British online gambling company 888 Holdings said on Monday that it had ended takeover discussions with its larger competitor, William Hill.

text: Google is all over the place. From biotechnology and robots to satellites and space exploration, the company has dipped into a dizzying and often confusing range of projects, especially when you consider that the core business is to sell advertising.

headline: When Grief Won’t Relent
text: Bereavement — how one responds and adjusts to the death of a loved one — is a very individual matter. It is natural to experience a host of negative reactions in the weeks and months following the loss of a loved one: among them, sadness, difficulty sleeping, painful reminders of the person, difficulty enjoying activities once shared, even anger.

headline: Anger of Suspect in Danish Killings Is Seen as Only Loosely Tied to Islam
text: COPENHAGEN — When Aydin Soei, a sociologist in Denmark, met members of an inner-city gang in 2008, one teenage tough stood out as more intelligent than his peers, and more mercurial. He showed little interest in Islam, but a deep loathing for Denmark, the country where he was born and spent his entire life.

headline: Matthew Lightner Will Leave Atera
text: Matthew Lightner, the well-traveled chef whose tasting menu at the tiny TriBeCa restaurant Atera has won huge acclaim, will leave there after March 28 to embark on a new project.

headline: Veteran Communist Leader Is Shot in India
text: NEW DELHI — A veteran Communist leader and critic of right-wing groups was shot along with his wife in central India on Monday morning as they were out for a stroll, the police said.

headline: SNS Reaal Agrees to Sell Dutch Insurance Arm to Anbang of China
text: LONDON – SNS Reaal, a state-owned Dutch financial services company, said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its Vivat Verzekeringen insurance arm to a unit of Anbang Insurance Group of China.

headline: Fatal Accidents as a Global Health Crisis
text: Worried about what to worry about? Accidents should move higher up your list.

headline: Restaurant Critic Pete Wells on How He Does His Job
text: Pete Wells has been restaurant critic for The New York Times since January 2012. As restaurant critic, he says that he has probably eaten close to 800 meals. (And he says, miraculously, he hasn’t gained weight.) Here he gives Insiders a sense of how he does the job.

headline: Daily Report: Two Start-Ups Offer Calls Via Wi-Fi First
text: It would not be an insult to say Republic Wireless and FreedomPop are obscure little companies. But they dream big, Brian Chen reports.The two companies are at the forefront of a tantalizing wireless communications concept that has proved hard to produce on a big scale: Reduce cellphone costs by relying on strategically placed Wi-Fi routers. And when there are no routers available, fall back on the traditional cellular network. Read more »

headline: Good Odds But Odd Goods
text: This paper using a dynamic search model to explain why “most single people are crazy” is brilliant — and I don’t just say that because it starts with homage to a classic forerunner.

headline: Bard SummerScape to Feature Work of the Composer Carlos Chávez
text: The music of Carlos Chávez, a key 20th-century Mexican composer whose works blended modern, folk and pre-Columbian influences, will be explored this summer at the Bard SummerScape Festival in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., the festival announced Monday.

headline: 1940: Women Called to New Fight
text: NEW YORK — A call to leaders of American women to meet in New York next fall for a Woman’s Centennial Congress to make plans for a campaign to extend feminine rights during the next century was issued today [Feb. 16] by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, president of the National American Woman’s Suffrage Association. Mrs. Catt announced that the congress was also intended to commemorate ‘‘the almost unbelievable changes that have taken place in the status of women’’ in the last 100 years. She said the fight for women’s rights had been so successful in this period that it might well be called the ‘‘Women’s Century.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 17, 1940

headline: New York Diversifies
text: One thing I learned from Ed Glaeser’s fine work on the economy of New York was that the city, after a complex past, had become essentially a monoculture. That is, its export sector — the part of the economy that sells to other locations, as opposed to providing local, nontraded goods and services — was basically finance and nothing else.

headline: ‘Imitation Game,’ ‘Grand Budapest Hotel’ and Decorum Win Over Writers Guild
text: Stories of freewheeling Writers Guild Awards ceremonies of yore was one of the reasons the Bagger traveled to the tourist-chocked confines of Midtown Manhattan on a frigid Saturday night. The event isn’t broadcast, booze freely flows, and writers supposedly can be a devilish bunch. Antics of years past included a tipsy Patton Oswalt letting rip and a sloshed Jonathan Ames railing against the cancellation of his HBO show “Bored to Death.”

headline: 1965: Anti-U.S. Rally in Indonesia
text: DJAKARTA — About 5,000 high school students, including President Sukarno’s daughter Rachmawati, 15, staged an anti-American demonstration today  [Feb. 16] in Djakarta streets. The students paraded after attending a rally at the hall of the Communist-inspired Youth Front Organization, where they burned effigies personifying Americans and Prime Minister Tengku Abdul Rahman of Malaysia. The rally and demonstration were sponsored by the Communists. The demonstrators did not attempt to go near the U.S. embassy. —New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 17, 1965

headline: In Hospitals, Board Rooms Are as Important as Operating Rooms
text: If you or a loved one is having a heart attack, your most pressing concerns probably include how quickly you can get to the hospital and the quality of care you’ll receive. You’re probably not thinking about the hospital’s board room, even though quality of care for heart attacks and many other conditions may be determined in large part by decisions made there.

headline: Research Finds a Reason Leprosy Has Persisted
text: The bacteria that cause leprosy can survive for months inside amoebae that are common in water and soil, and even in human eyes and noses, scientists at Colorado State University have found.

headline: Triumph of the Chart
text: I’ve been behind the curve on the Vox interview with President Obama. But the reactions to that interview — not just from the right, but from centrists — are remarkable. Jack Schafer compares it to a Scientology recruitment film; Rich Lowry compares it to Leni Riefenstahl. Why?

headline: Meeting on Greek Debt Produces an Ultimatum
text: BRUSSELS — The standoff between Greece and its European lenders appeared to reach a new low on Monday as European officials handed Athens an ultimatum: Agree by Friday to continue with a bailout program or risk the funding that the country needs to avoid a default.

headline: Up to 14 Years of Hot Flashes Found in Menopause Study
text: Conventional wisdom has it that hot flashes, which afflict up to 80 percent of middle-aged women, usually persist for just a few years. But hot flashes can continue for as long as 14 years, and the earlier they begin the longer a woman is likely to suffer, a study published on Monday in JAMA Internal Medicine found.

headline: Health Care Success for Midwest Co-op Proves Its Undoing
text: RED OAK, Iowa — A few days after Christmas, Lisa Lovig’s doctor called with jarring news. The health insurer covering her cancer treatments had run out of money, and its future was at best uncertain.

headline: What Children Think of the Internet (and Why It Matters)
text: On a recent late afternoon, my 5-year-old son requested pizza for dinner, as he does pretty much every day. I wasn’t sure if we had one in the freezer. “Let’s ask the Internet,” he suggested. A few days later, he proposed consulting Google to find out what time his father would be home from work.

This week’s challenges are from Greg’s recently-released Futility Closet 2. Let’s give them a try, starting with —

headline: Sweetest Violins Explained: Holes Fill In Blanks
text: Some of the world’s most prized violins were made in Cremona, Italy, in the 17th and 18th centuries by the Amati, Guarneri and Stradivari families. Researchers at M.I.T. wanted to know what accounted for the instruments’ unique acoustical properties.

headline: Disorder Rules the Universe
text: “On or about September 1927,” wrote the philosopher Ray Monk, “the physical world changed.” Until then, according to Robert P. Crease and Alfred Scharff Goldhaber’s rich and entertaining new book, “The Quantum Moment,” we lived in a homogeneous, continuous, Newtonian world in which all objects moved seamlessly from the past to the future, governed by universal mathematical laws.

headline: At the Fall/Winter 2015 Shows, Designers Are Pushing Buttons
text: What is in a button? It’s functional and fastens, usually without being noticed — until now. On the fall/winter 2015 runways in New York, the utilitarian little notions have been upgraded from behind the scenes to front and center. We saw them first at Victoria Beckham, who sewed large horn buttons onto knit shift dresses and sculpted outerwear. A few hours later, Derek Lam introduced double-breasted vests fastened with oversize white buttons and turtlenecks dotted with black ones. And at Edun, buttons embellished extra-large pea coats and the necks of dresses. Practical or not, they’re poised to be a fixture for fall.

headline: In Arena’s Shadow, Holdouts at Atlantic Yards Site Must Now Leave
text: Last week was a busy one at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn. The rusticated arena lost its shot at hosting the 2016  Democratic National Convention, but there was still plenty to cheer during its first N.B.A. All-Star celebration.

headline: A Cancer Cluster Is Tough to Prove

The decision, involving people exposed to contaminated drinking water while stationed at Camp Lejeune, a base in North Carolina, didn’t consider the science.

headline: Jewish Graves Vandalized in France
text: PARIS — Teenage vandals are suspected of overturning as many as 250 gravestones in a cemetery in a rural part of eastern France near the German border, where many Jews once lived but have long since left.

headline: Quiz: Westminster Dog Show Look-Alikes
text: Do dogs really look like their owners? Put the theory to the test by trying to guess which dog from the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show belongs to which owner.

headline: A Moth’s Tail Can Deceive Bats
text: Like a caterpillar blending into a leaf to escape a bird’s gaze, luna moths that have tails can use them to generate a noise that guides attacking bats away from their bodies. Using high-speed infrared cameras, researchers at Boise State University watched big brown bats hunt moths by means of echolocation. The ones with tails had a 47 percent survival advantage over those without, the researchers reported Monday in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

headline: An Angular, Runway-Inspired New Track From New York’s White Prism
text: There’s an undeniable visual quality to White Prism’s sound. The project features cool, breathy vocals that float above a bed of icy, angular synths and syncopated beats, simultaneously harkening back to ’80s dance pop and conjuring something strangely futuristic. “I really wanted to concentrate on marrying the two things that I love, which are fashion and music,” says White Prism’s lead singer and songwriter Johanna Cranitch, whose blunt bleached bob and shockingly blue eyes even seem suited to the music she makes.

headline: Review: In ‘Paradox of the Urban Cliché,’ Verse Melts Into Drama
text: The soft sound of snapping fingers rippled through the audience at “Paradox of the Urban Cliché,” a thoughtful new play by Craig Grant, as a character named Smiles laid down her rhymes. The pain-filled verses flowed with an easy grace, and the snaps on a recent night at the Wild Project were a sign of approval borrowed from the world of performance poetry.

headline: U.N. Delays Release of Report on Possible War Crimes in Sri Lanka
text: The United Nations Human Rights Council on Monday agreed to defer the release of a landmark inquiry into possible war crimes in Sri Lanka, after an intense lobbying campaign by the country’s newly elected government and what the United Nations’ top rights official described as “signals of broad cooperation” from Sri Lankan officials.

headline: Genes Tell Only Part of the Story
text: I had intended to discuss President Obama’s plans for personalized precision medicine with my patient Barbara last week, but she missed her appointment. Or, more accurately, she arrived two hours late, made the usual giant fuss at the reception desk and had to be rescheduled.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 4
text: Despite freezing temperatures, the fashion faithful kept the parties going. Diane von Furstenberg held a party at her meatpacking district studio that included Cindi Leive, the editor in chief of Glamour. See the photos.

headline: The Science of Online Dating
text: One in 10 American adults is registered with an online dating service. The number of people looking to find love online has never been greater, but the wealth of options also means that singles can spend months combing through hundreds of profiles without ever securing a successful date.

headline: Transocean Chief Steps Down Suddenly With Company in Doldrums
text: HOUSTON — After five tumultuous years at the helm, Steven L. Newman, the chief executive of Transocean, a leading offshore drilling service company, has abruptly stepped down.

text: Aaron Smart flies two or three times a week and prefers private jets, but he doesn’t own a plane. He has a smartphone for that. Mr. Smart, who is an owner of Manhattan’s ArtNowNY and Joseph Gross galleries, has homes in Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif., and New York, making for a lot of time spent on planes.

text: I’M in the inventions business, hosting a radio show called “My Cool Inventions,” and I’m a frequent guest on HSN and QVC International showcasing inventions. I work in the product development end of things, too. All of these ventures involve a lot of travel, about 150,000 to 200,000 miles a year.

text: Amar’e Stoudemire’s tenure with the Knicks came to a bittersweet conclusion on Monday when the team announced that it had bought out the remainder of the 33-year-old forward’s contract.

headline: Debating the Rules and Ethics of Digital Photojournalism
text: The disqualification of a large number of images from this year’s World Press Photo contest has sparked a debate over the need for more explicit rules on what is — and is not — acceptable in digital photography.

headline: Dillon Gee Arrives in Mets Camp With Status Unsettled
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Dillon Gee spent his off-season at home in Texas, hunting and spending time with his family. It was relaxing for the most part. But whenever he saw his agent calling, he would become anxious. The Mets had been shopping him in trades, and on more than one occasion, he thought a deal might be close.

headline: With Ukrainian Troops Trapped, a Cease-Fire Grows More Fragile
text: ARTEMIVSK, Ukraine — The plight of as many as 8,000 Ukrainian troops trapped in the vicinity of Debaltseve, as well as the prospects for an already fragile truce, look decidedly dimmer on Monday after a Russian television correspondent strolled down what was supposed to be a hotly contested road.

headline: Scenes From the All-Star Game
text: The 64th N.B.A. All-Star Game, played at Madison Square Garden, was a typically high-scoring affair, with celebrities not only on the court but also in the stands.

headline: U.S. Embedded Spyware Overseas, Report Claims
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The United States has found a way to permanently embed surveillance and sabotage tools in computers and networks it has targeted in Iran, Russia, Pakistan, China, Afghanistan and other countries closely watched by American intelligence agencies, according to a Russian cybersecurity firm.

headline: At Opening Ceremony, the Clothes Are Only the Start
text: It’s not at all unusual to be invited to a Chelsea gallery during fashion week. Designers love to rent out the galleries that line the far-west blocks of Chelsea — even in February, when frigid winds blow off the nearby river — to stage their fashion shows.

headline: Review: Ballet Arizona’s ‘Napoli’ Embodies a Culture of Exuberance
text: PHOENIX — Naples, a city I adore, and its environs burst to life onstage in “Napoli,” a ballet choreographed in 1842 by August Bournonville. When the curtain rises on Act I, the audience applauds the view of the city’s famous bay, with Vesuvius dominating the horizon. When it rises on Act II, the applause is accompanied by gasps, because here we’re in the Blue Grotto of Capri. Act III is not set in any location so famous, but there’s something so picturesque about its bridge and pilgrim shrine that the audience applauds anyway.

headline: Your Letters: Carbon Dioxide Storage, H.I.V. Drugs and Ebola Management
text: Climate: Energy Use

headline: On the Fall 2015 Runways, Fresh Takes on an Old Standby: Black Eyeliner
text: Black lines are defining the eyes in unexpected ways at the fall/winter 2015 shows. Last Thursday at Coach’s presentation, a seamless, symmetrical cat-eye immediately drew attention; the black stroke went across the top lid and back down halfway along the lower lid, with just enough of a pull at the corner of the eye. DKNY explored the trend with a little more adventurous oomph, outlining the outskirts of the eye with a thick black line; and at Cushnie et Ochs, it was more rock-n-roll, a smoky eye that stole the beauty moment – thick and smeared, with a slight interruption at each corner that separated the top and the bottom portion of the eye like the ends of a brushstroke.

headline: Review: Berlin Philharmonic Goes to London in Simon Rattle Homecoming
text: LONDON — Whenever the conductor Simon Rattle takes his Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra to London, there’s a sense of reckoning: about the boy who went away, made good and is now bringing home the proof. For British audiences, the very idea that a conductor from England — what Germans used to call “the land without music” — is in charge of Germany’s flagship orchestra is a continuing source of national delight. British music lovers are always curious to know how the relationship has worked out.

headline: Review: ‘Rap Guide to Religion’ Examines Why Humanity Created God
text: You know what would make Baba Brinkman happy this weekend? If just one winner would get up at the Oscars and make an acceptance speech that began not with an expression of gratitude to God but with “I want to thank Charles Darwin.”

headline: Review: Auryn Quartet Forges a Radiance at the Frick
text: A warm sound is invariably an appealing attribute of solo or ensemble playing — and as temperatures plummeted on Sunday afternoon, it felt particularly welcome to bask in the Auryn Quartet’s glowing timbres in the snug acoustical cocoon of the Frick Collection’s intimate Music Room.

headline: A Bold, Punky Lip at 3.1 Phillip Lim
text: It’s unquestionable (and understandable) that designers have lately preferred to keep their beauty looks simple, and the choice to eschew that effortless style in favor of a bold one feels innovative and inspired. During a season that’s so far been filled with natural-looking lips, it’s refreshing to see a color speak for itself, as we did at 3.1 Phillip Lim’s fall 2015 show today. Backstage, the makeup artist Francelle Daly professed her love affair with Nars Cosmetics’ newest lip color, VIP Red, taking us down a nostalgic burgundy punk path. “I fell in love with this shade when they showed it to me,” Daly said. “I remember in the ’90s and late ’80s, it was all about my red leather Dr. Martens boots.” The oxblood red lipstick is also the perfect complement to the clothing Lim showed: “It really fits into all these beautiful gold, brown and green tones that you see in the collection,” Daly said.

headline: Vaccinations Are States’ Call
text: Henning Jacobson just said no. Even though Massachusetts required it, he did not want to be vaccinated. He had had a bad reaction to a vaccine, and he opposed vaccination in general.

headline: Review: Estelle, Adam Birnbaum, and Sonny and the Sunsets Release New Albums
text: ESTELLE

headline: Prison Architecture and the Question of Ethics
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Faced with lawsuits and a growing mountain of damning research, New York City officials decided last month to ban solitary confinement for prison inmates 21 and younger. Just a few weeks earlier, the American Institute of Architects rejected a petition to censure members who design solitary-confinement cells and death chambers.

headline: Review: Martha Graham Dance Company Displays Unorthodox Humor
text: On Friday at the Joyce Theater, an unusual sound rippled through the audience, a sound not often heard at performances by the Martha Graham Dance Company: laughter.

headline: Review: Dianne Reeves Leads Journey of Jazz History at Rose Hall
text: Trains of musical thought that wind from one part of the world into another and from one century to the next: A sense of boarding and changing trains on a far-reaching journey ran through Dianne Reeves’s concert at Jazz at Lincoln Center’s Rose Hall on Friday evening.

text: What do Laurence Olivier, Ingrid Bergman and Kim Jong-il have in common? “A Kim Jong-il Production,” Paul Fischer’s elaborately complicated book about that North Korean dictator’s grand passion for cinema, may be the first and last time anybody answers that question.

headline: Review: Jessye Norman’s Salute to the Love Song at Carnegie Hall
text: There was a moment late in Jessye Norman’s Carnegie Hall recital of popular standards on Saturday evening when the clouds parted, a shaft of lightning illuminated the hall, and an adoring audience that had waited patiently for a burst of vocal fireworks erupted in a spontaneous standing ovation.

text: A lawyer for the photographer Donald Graham has sent cease-and-desist letters to the artist Richard Prince and the Gagosian Gallery, requesting that they stop displaying or disseminating any artworks or other materials that include Mr. Graham’s images.

text: There’s nothing like extreme weather to focus the mind. When you are freezing, or thinking about the fact that you are about to be freezing, or defrosting from being freezing, suddenly clothes take on whole new meaning. It’s cold outside! Where’s the design proposition to solve that?

Assembled by the media mogul John C. Malone, its chairman, the company quietly exerts its influence across a vast portion of the European media business.

headline: Canadian Rail Strike Ends as Parties Agree to Arbitration
text: OTTAWA — A strike by about 3,000 locomotive engineers and conductors at the Canadian Pacific Railway unexpectedly ended on Monday, its second day, as both sides agreed to arbitration. The announcement came about half an hour before a bill was to be introduced in Parliament ordering the members of the union, the Teamsters Canada Rail Conference, back to work.

text: PARIS — When diamond thieves struck a Harry Winston jewelry store with clockwork precision, it appeared to be a perfectly executed $100 million heist. But a video of their 2008 caper in the capital’s golden triangle of luxury boutiques, playing in a courtroom here, offers a grainy trailer of comedy and greed.

headline: Westminster Dog Show Offers No Joy for Fans of a Charming Galoot

headline: Southeast Region Hit by a Heavy Blast of Snow, With an Icy Cold Follow-Up
text: A winter storm churning through the Southeast dumped sleet, snow and freezing rain from the Mississippi River Valley to the mid-Atlantic Seaboard into the night on Monday. Flights were canceled, schools closed, Mardi Gras parades were rescheduled, and at least two state legislatures, in Kentucky and Tennessee, announced they would not meet on Tuesday as the storm continued into North Carolina.

headline: Numbers May Not Give a Complete Picture of Passenger Unruliness
text: IN 2014, reported incidents of so-called unruly passengers were at the lowest level in 20 years, down 60 percent from the high of 310 in 2001, according to new data from the Federal Aviation Administration.

text: Athletes who spent the past few years embracing or scorning barefoot running can now consider whether increasingly popular “maximalist” shoes — with their chunky, heavily cushioned soles — are the sport’s new wonder product.

headline: Arnaud de Borchgrave, Journalist Whose Life Was a Tale Itself, Dies at 88
text: Arnaud de Borchgrave, a Belgian count’s son and storied foreign correspondent who cabled back bell-ringing scoops throughout the Cold War decades, often from the battlefield, died on Sunday in Washington. He was 88.

headline: Despite Amenities, South Street Seaport Redevelopment Plans Stall Over a High-Rise
text: For years, a developer at the South Street Seaport in Manhattan has been planning a $1.5 billion redevelopment that it said would rehabilitate crumbling piers, preserve landmark buildings and bring new vitality to the 400-year-old historic district on the East River.

headline: European Stocks Shrug Off Faltering Talks on Greek Debt
text: PARIS — European stocks fell early Tuesday, then recovered by midday despite weakness in Athens, as investors reacted to news that Greece and its European creditors appeared to have reached a fresh stalemate over whether to continue with a bailout that expires at the end of the month.

headline: U.S. Intensifies Effort to Blunt ISIS’ Message
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is revamping its effort to counter the Islamic State’s propaganda machine, acknowledging that the terrorist group has been far more effective in attracting new recruits, financing and global notoriety than the United States and its allies have been in thwarting it.

headline: Yankees Plan to Honor Four Former Players
text: Whatever the Yankees may do on the field this season to generate interest and ticket sales, it is clear that they will also lean heavily on their recent history. On four separate home dates this season, the Yankees will honor four different players, three of whom will have their numbers retired, the team announced Monday.

headline: 2000 Novelty Hit
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — It has been a rough winter so far, with a seemingly endless supply of bad news, weather-wise. We could use a puzzle that puts a smile on our collective faces, yes?

headline: Hurricane Sandy Victims Say Damage Reports Were Altered
text: When Frank Johnston’s insurance carrier rejected his claim that flooding from Hurricane Sandy had severely damaged the foundation of his Fire Island home, the company cited an engineering report that seemed to establish his problems were “unrelated” to the storm, and were caused instead by the “long-term deterioration” of wooden piers beneath his house.

headline: With Lunar New Year Show, Another Link to China for a New York Fireworks Family
text: Viewed from one angle, a hopeful tableau of Chinese-American relations unfolded over the weekend on a pier in Red Hook, Brooklyn: American and Chinese pyrotechnicians loading three barges with equipment for a major fireworks display in honor of the Lunar New Year, using Chinese-made explosives and American-made hardware.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 16, 2015
Sam Andrew, Guitarist for Big Brother and the Holding Company, Dies at 73
text: Sam Andrew, who as a founder of the band Big Brother and the Holding Company was a mainstay of the fertile San Francisco rock scene of the 1960s and played a key role in Janis Joplin’s early career, died on Thursday in San Rafael, Calif. He was 73.

headline: Federal Offices in Washington Shut Down Over Snow
text: Boston may be digging out of nearly seven feet of snow, but in Washington, predictions of about seven inches of snow are enough to force the federal government to close its District of Columbia offices.

headline: Villanova Serves Notice With Romp Over Seton Hall
text: VILLANOVA, Pa. — After Monday night’s game at the Pavilion, Villanova Coach Jay Wright and Seton Hall Coach Kevin Willard exchanged back slaps and compliments. Willard laughed at a joke by Wright but then turned serious.

headline: Jim Jarmusch Soundtracks Surrealism With His Rock Band Sqürl
text: “Music is very much a release for me because it’s so immediate,” says the director Jim Jarmusch. Though Jarmusch is best known as the radically independent mind behind art-house classics like “Down by Law” and “Dead Man,” the filmmaker is also a member of the “amorphous” post-rock group known as Sqürl. (The band composed the scores to the recent Jarmusch films “The Limits of Control” and “Only Lovers Left Alive.”) Tonight, Sqürl will debut a new soundtrack — not to one of Jarmusch’s own films, but to four silent works from the surrealist Man Ray. The concerts are part of WNYC’s New Sounds Live series, Silent Films/Live Music, which pairs movies, both classic and contemporary, with performances from acclaimed musicians. (The current run of shows also features the composer Alfonso Villalonga and the Wordless Music Orchestra performing the score to the Spanish film “Blancanieves.”)

headline: Group Seeks New Tolls in Manhattan to Pay for Region’s Transportation Needs
text: A group of transit advocates will release a proposal on Tuesday to overhaul New York City’s bridge toll system and to raise money for the region’s transportation needs.

headline: Measuring Inequality Trends During the Great Recession
text: This post discusses in some more technical detail the issues that are the subject of David Leonhardt’s Feb. 17 column.

headline: Inequality Has Actually Not Risen Since the Financial Crisis
text: The notion that income inequality has continued to rise over the past decade is part of the conventional wisdom. You’ve no doubt heard versions: The rich just keep getting richer. Inequality is higher than ever. Nearly all of the gains from the economic recovery have gone to the top 1 percent.

headline: Enrollment Period for Health Insurance Ends; Now the Tax Penalties Start
text: The Affordable Care Act’s second open enrollment period ended on Sunday. Well, almost. Some computer problems over the weekend have led the administration to give a one-week extension to people who tried and failed to sign up.

headline: Dealt Setback, Obama Puts Off Immigrant Plan
text: WASHINGTON — One day before hundreds of thousands of undocumented immigrants were to begin applying for work permits and legal protection, administration officials on Tuesday postponed President Obama’s sweeping executive actions on immigration indefinitely, saying they had no choice but to comply with a federal judge’s last-minute order halting the programs.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE ITALIAN AMERICANS More than four million Italians emigrated to the United States from 1880 to 1924, mostly coming from southern Italy and Sicily to escape poverty. This series, narrated by the actor Stanley Tucci and written by John Maggio, spans four generations of Italian-Americans, beginning with the large wave of immigration in the late 19th century and continuing to the present day. Along the way, the two-part series uses archival material and interviews with experts and prominent Italian-Americans (like Mario M. Cuomo, above; Tony Bennett; and Gay Talese, to name a few) to tell the stories of those who played important roles in shaping the relationships between Italians and Americans, and how immigrants, once considered outsiders, have risen over time to become leaders in business, politics and the arts.

headline: Primed, and Primped, for Competition
text: The 139th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show in New York features 192 breeds. Here are a few.

headline: Soft Recruits Hinder China’s Military Modernization
text: Many armies have trouble molding capable soldiers from fresh-out-of-school 18-year-olds. China is no exception and, it turns out, has a particular problem with soft recruits.

headline: Debating the Rules and Ethics of Digital Photojournalism
text: Significant questions have arisen after a large number of images were disqualified from this year’s World Press Photo competition because of excessive — and sometimes blatant — post-processing. After independent experts examined the images being considered for prizes in the final rounds, and presented their findings to the jury, 20 percent of the photos were disqualified by the judges. This was often because of significant addition or subtraction to the image content.

headline: The Roadblock to Sentencing Reform
text: For more than a year, members of Congress have been doing a lot of talking about the need to broadly reform harsh federal sentencing laws, which are a central factor in the explosion of the federal prison population. It’s an overdue conversation, and one of the few in which Democrats and Republicans find some agreement — but, so far, they have nothing to show for it.

headline: The Moral Injury
text: David J. Morris returned from Iraq with a case of post-traumatic stress disorder. The former Marine turned war correspondent was plagued by nightmares. His imagination careened out of control; he envisioned fireballs erupting while on trips to the mall. His emotions could go numb, but his awareness was hypervigilant. Images and smells from the war were tattooed eternally fresh on his brain, and he circled back to them remorselessly.

headline: Reform the Condominium
text: FROM New York to Miami, from South Padre Island, Tex., to Park City, Utah, the American condominium has become the hot new investment for global capital. In Manhattan, the trend is so pronounced that a whole new category of real estate has emerged around the southern edges of Central Park: supertall, ultraluxury buildings, with more than half of the homes being sold to anonymous buyers (some perhaps looking to stash ill-gotten gains) who rarely, if ever, occupy them. The city, meanwhile, struggles to produce sufficient housing for those who do live here.

headline: How Useful Are Standardized Tests?
Airlines Against Open Skies
text: In the last 30 years, the United States has signed more than 100 open skies agreements with other countries to remove restrictions on international air travel — a policy that has been great for travelers because it has lowered fares and increased service.

headline: In Europe, Car Sales Gain for 17th Straight Month
text: PARIS — The European car market maintained its modest upward momentum in the first month of the year, industry data showed on Tuesday, with sales gaining for a 17th straight month. But the market is still far below where it was before the 2008 global financial crisis.

headline: Profit Falls at French Luxury Conglomerate Kering

Even if temperatures are higher than they’ve been earlier this week, we’re still a ways off from temperate. Can’t blame a fashion weeker for dreaming.

headline: Morning Agenda: Greek Bailout Talks Collapse
text: GREEK BAILOUT TALKS COLLAPSE | European officials handed Athens an ultimatum on Monday: Agree by Friday to continue with a bailout program or risk the funding that the country needs to avoid a default, James Kanter and Liz Alderman write in The New York Times. The demand appeared to be part of a strategy by eurozone creditors to get Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece and his finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, to back away from their anti-austerity pledges. In exchange, eurozone officials said they would consider rolling back some of the austerity terms at a later date.

headline: Suicide Bomber, Failing to Reach Pakistani Police, Strikes Busy Neighborhood

The latest work from the troupe the Civilians, the show features a book by Bess Wohl and words and music by Michael Friedman, who accompanies Ms. Mason on piano. It runs through March 1 at the Abrons Arts Center.

headline: ‘Animated Life: Pangea’
text: Just as biology tells us about the origin of life, geology tells how our physical world came to be. The field explains how the mountains and rivers, oceans and shores were born. Surprisingly, one of the first people to propose one of the most important theories in geology, continental drift — the idea that the continents were once pressed together and have since drifted apart — wasn’t a geologist at all.

Now, after picking up a Golden Globe and a SAG Award, among other prizes, she’s a front-runner for the Oscar for best actress .

headline: Modi Promises to Punish Religious Violence in India
text: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India said on Tuesday that his government would not “accept violence against any religion, on any pretext,” and that it would take forceful steps if such crimes occurred, in a speech widely interpreted as a response to a series of attacks on Roman Catholic churches in and around New Delhi.

headline: 1965: Troops Clash After Bombing
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — Congolese troops crossed the border and exchanged fire with Ugandan troops south of Lake Albert, Uganda Minister of Internal Affairs Feli Onama announced today [Feb. 17]. Other Congo troops crossed the Ishasha river into southwest Uganda and tried to enter the Uganda customs post there. ‘‘In both cases they were forced to return into the Congo,’’ Mr. Onama said. The border with the Congo is already closed following a weekend bomb attack of two Uganda villages. In Nairobi, Kenya, the government there warned the United States of ‘‘the serious repercussions arising from its policy on the Congo.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 18, 1965

headline: Does Fiction Have the Power to Sway Politics?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Mohsin Hamid and Francine Prose debate literature’s influence on politics.

headline: Hillary Clinton and the 2016 Democrats: Mostly Liberal, Together

headline: Fast Action Needed to Stave Off Greek Tragedy
text: Greece desperately needs a quick fix. Time is running so short that a deal is needed in the next few days to stop Athens from going bust. That will be, at best, a short-term patch while a long-term solution is worked out.

headline: Shuko

headline: Restaurant Review: Shuko in the East Village
text: “You like spicy?” Jimmy Lau asked from behind the counter at Shuko, the new restaurant just below Union Square where he and his partner, Nick Kim, prepare an elevated and memorable species of Japanese food. Before I could answer, he handed me a spicy tuna roll that would casually knock over my ideas about spicy tuna rolls, and spice, and tuna.

headline: For Fall/Winter 2015, Designers Cozy Up to Buffalo Plaid
text: Uniform dressing, from military greens to prep-school pleats, has always been a popular inspiration for designers, and this season, several have taken on the unofficial uniform of hunters: the oversize checks of buffalo plaid. First, at Coach, Stuart Vevers put a spin on the classic American print with pastel hues, balancing out the mostly black collection. Buffalo plaid also brightened another show consisting otherwise of almost entirely black looks: Alexander Wang’s, to which the designer added a splash of color with a red buffalo plaid coat shown halfway through. And the 3.1 Phillip Lim show featured the print expressed in multiple colorways: a classic black and white with red accents near the beginning, and an earthier version in beige, black and ochre near the end. Lim’s eye-catching interpretation, cool and a little tough, was perfect for his downtown girl.

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘Maleficent’
text: Though nominated twice for an Oscar already, the costume designer Anna B. Sheppard was taken by surprise last month, she said, when her assistant interrupted a fitting with Morgan Freeman to announce it had happened again: she was up for her costume design for “Maleficent,” Disney’s “Sleeping Beauty” tale told from the antagonist’s point of view.

headline: Review: With ‘Queen and Country,’ John Boorman Continues a Tale
text: To appreciate “Queen and Country,” John Boorman’s gently nostalgic, quasi-autobiographical film about Britain in the early 1950s, it isn’t entirely necessary to have seen his earlier “Hope and Glory.” You should, of course, see it, if you haven’t already: One of a handful of great movies that look at World War II through the eyes of a child, “Hope and Glory” is distinguished by mischievous good humor and by the unashamed acknowledgment that war can be fun as well as horrible.

headline: Exchanging Sword for Pen, Rodriguez Apologizes to Yankees and Fans
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Preparing to make a highly scrutinized return to baseball after a long suspension for drug use, Alex Rodriguez issued a brief, handwritten statement on Tuesday afternoon to say he was sorry for his behavior.

text: Some businesses struggle to stay afloat during the nation’s economic crisis because of austerity measures and bureaucracy.

headline: Swiss Museum Unable to Get Gurlitt Art Trove Amid Dispute Over Will
text: Nearly three months after announcing that it would accept the gift of an art collection amassed by a Nazi-era dealer, including several pieces known to have been looted from Jewish families, the Kunstmuseum Bern expressed frustration Tuesday that a dispute over a will was preventing it from taking possession of the works.

headline: Reclaiming Puerto Rico’s Food Paradise

What would he be cooking?

headline: Princeton Gets a $300 Million Trove of Rare Books
text: Princeton University has announced the largest gift in its history: a trove of rare books valued at nearly $300 million, including a Gutenberg Bible, an original printing of the Declaration of Independence, all four of Shakespeare’s Folios and significant musical manuscripts written by Bach, Beethoven, Mozart, Schubert and Wagner.

headline: Inquiry by Israeli Comptroller Criticizes Spending Habits of Netanyahu and Wife

The state paid about $2,000 a month to clean the Netanyahus’ private home in the seaside town of Caesarea, though the family spent most of its time in Jerusalem.

headline: Washington Landmarks Covered in Snow
text: A winter storm throughout the Mid-Atlantic region brought heavy snowfall to Washington on Monday night, in a season that has seen unusually high levels of snowfall in the East.

headline: Rethinking Money, Not as Good or Bad but as a Tool
text: Almost everything we’re taught about money is focused on spending it and saving it. Parents, teachers and even personal finance books discuss saving money as keeping it, increasing it and controlling it. Saving money involves figuring out ways to get more of it, to build a bigger cushion. We’re taught that’s the ultimate goal.

headline: Southeast Snowstorm Leaves Beauty and Danger
text: ATLANTA — Communities across the Southeast were paralyzed by snow and ice, left without power and rushing to clear frozen roadways Tuesday morning after a pounding winter storm, with officials warning of more trouble that may come with a second round of cold weather later this week.

headline: Coach’s Ph.D. in Psychology Is Applied on Court and in Classroom
text: ST. PAUL — Thirty-two students sat at long tables in a University of St. Thomas classroom one recent morning, reviewing notes or checking their smartphones, when John Tauer walked in. Tauer wore a purple dress shirt and gray pleated slacks under his black topcoat, but not the tie and blazer he would wear that night for his other job, coaching the St. Thomas men’s basketball team.

headline: Filmmakers Set Sights on ’52’, the World’s Loneliest Whale
text: If a crowd-funding push succeeds, a unique and solitary whale known as “52” may soon have its silver screen moment.

headline: ​Advice for Finding Your Groove
text: Last week, I invited Christine Carter, author of “The Sweet Spot: How to Find Your Groove at Home and at Work,” to coach a few of us through the real world issues that get in our way when it comes to settling into a happy, functional routine at home and at work.

headline: Fishing for Sweaters for Fall 2015
text: Never have the runways looked so tempting, as designers continue to introduce fur-hooded parkas, oversize shearling coats and rugged boots for fall — an appealing lot for the fashion set, which continues to trudge through snow and slush from one venue to the next. And a few fresh takes on the classic fisherman cable-knit sweaters are in the running for the coziest crop yet of winter-weather staples on fall 2015 runways. At Coach and Alexander Wang, the cream-colored tops — decked out with fringe and stud details, respectively — brightened up otherwise dark collections. And in Vera Wang’s gender-bending fashion show today, her oversize rendition of the traditional knit again lightened things up — especially paired with long shorts and high booties.

headline: The Chevrolet Trax Is a Crossover in a Smaller Package
text: AMERICANS shun station wagons and hatchbacks, but they cannot get enough of sport utility vehicles and crossovers. The Chevrolet Trax, a name that word processors desperately want to correct, is much like a small hatchback dressed in North Face gear. It’s something you’ll be seeing much more of — the subcompact crossover. Look for Jeep Renegade, Mazda CX-3 and Honda HR-V at a campsite (or Jamba Juice) in the near future.

headline: Shake-Up at Mattress Company May Be Due
text: The “burning bed” is flaring up again. The investment firm H Partners, complaining of a dormant stock price at Tempur Sealy and private equity directors asleep on the job, wants the top executive replaced and a seat on the board. A torturous financial history suggests it’s probably time to shake up the mattress company and the industry again.

headline: U.N. Envoy to Syria Announces Possible Truce in Aleppo
text: UNITED NATIONS — In what could be a diplomatic breakthrough in the Syrian conflict, a senior United Nations envoy said Tuesday that he had persuaded President Bashar al-Assad to stop bombing and shelling the northern city of Aleppo as part of a proposed six-week truce.

headline: Diesel Black Gold: Fall 2015 RTW
text: New York

headline: Judge Hears Arguments Over G.M.’s Exposure to Recall Suits
text: In the fraught summer of 2009, the federal bankruptcy judge Robert E. Gerber proved to be a crucial figure in General Motors’ struggle for survival. With the economy in deep recession and the once-dominant automaker bleeding red ink, he presided over a fast-track bankruptcy process that allowed G.M. to remake itself — with the help of $49 billion from federal taxpayers — as a new company free of onerous liabilities.

headline: A Taste of Japan at Grand Central

headline: Judge Says Cuomo Must Set Election to Fill Grimm’s House Seat
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo must soon schedule a special election to fill the vacant congressional seat representing Staten Island and parts of Brooklyn, or a federal court will do it for him, a judge ordered on Tuesday.

headline: Getting Closer to the California Print Junkie Who Designed Jay Z’s “Holy Grail”
text: From a young age, the artist, graphic designer and California native Brian Roettinger grew up acutely aware of design in his daily life — in large part, he says, “because of the stuff my parents and grandparents had around the house, including a vast record collection, not to mention quintessential suburban ’70s furniture. Looking and talking about photos was a common affair in our household. My mother, meanwhile, would make macramé and paint.”

headline: Senior Swagger
text: Bermuda shorts and bucket hats usher in the season of the septuagenarian.

headline: When Consumers Don’t Spend
text: Consumer spending is at the heart of a strong economy. It is the source of pay and profits. It is the engine of economic activity.

headline: President Obama and Whig History
text: Finishing up business left undone last week, I’m grateful to Ta-Nehisi Coates for taking the time to critique my own critique of President Obama’s prayer breakfast speech. A few thoughts in response, working my way around his points.

headline: Ashton Carter Sworn In as Secretary of Defense
text: WASHINGTON — Ashton B. Carter was sworn in Tuesday as the 25th secretary of defense — and the fourth to serve the Obama administration — taking the oath of office in a small White House ceremony where Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. called him “a thinker and a doer.”

headline: Carter Sworn In as Defense Secretary
text: Ashton B. Carter pledged his commitment to help the president “make the best possible decisions” during his swearing-in ceremony as defense secretary.

headline: Nashville’s Clandestine Black Schools
text: On Monday, March 4, 1833, the nation’s seventh president and Tennessee’s most famous son, Andrew Jackson, was sworn in for his second term. On that same day another Tennessean, Alphonso M. Sumner, clandestinely opened a school for black children in Nashville. It was a bold move: In the wake of Nat Turner’s uprising two years earlier, Southern whites had begun a particularly violent reign of terror against black efforts at organizing institutions like schools and churches – were critical to the black struggle for freedom, justice and civil rights. But Sumner, a free black barber, bet that the paternalistic sympathies of white Nashvillians would allow them to turn a blind-eye to a school for free black children, owned and operated by him.

headline: An Encore of Over-the-Knee Boots at Rodarte
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: A Wheeldon Nutcracker for the Joffrey
text: Christopher Wheeldon will create a new “Nutcracker” in December 2016 for Chicago’s Joffrey Ballet, the company announced on Tuesday. The new production will mark the end of a Chicago tradition; Robert Joffrey, who founded the Joffrey Ballet with Gerald Arpino, choreographed “The Nutcracker” for the company in 1987, and it has been performed each December since the company moved to Chicago from New York in 1995.

headline: Re-election Bid Offers Test of Mayor’s Appeal to ‘Two Chicagos’
text: CHICAGO — In some of this city’s predominantly black neighborhoods on the South Side, Rahm Emanuel was not well known when he swept into the mayor’s office in 2011. After all, he had been a congressman from the other, mostly white side of town. But most voters knew that President Obama, himself a South Sider, had trusted him to be White House chief of staff, and that backing went a long way. Mr. Emanuel won every majority black ward in the city.

headline: Israeli Girl Injured in Palestinian Rock-Throwing Attack in 2013 Dies
text: JERUSALEM — A 4-year-old Israeli girl who was critically injured in a car accident caused by Palestinian rock throwers two years ago died on Tuesday after a severe bout of pneumonia that relatives said was complicated by her neurological trauma.

headline: Fallout Over Argentine Prosecutor’s Death Draws International Tensions
text: INTENDENTE ALVEAR, Argentina — Fallout from the mysterious death of a federal prosecutor raised diplomatic tensions between Argentina and the United States on Tuesday, on the eve of a controversial march in the prosecutor’s honor that has fueled unease between the government and parts of the judiciary.

headline: Spanish Judge Drops Charges Against 9 Priests in Sexual Abuse Case
text: MADRID — A Spanish judge leading an investigation into accusations of sexual abuse against priests in the southern city of Granada has decided that the case can proceed against only one of the priests because the statute of limitations has expired for the lower-level criminal charges filed against 11 other people, including nine priests.

text: In the current issue of The New York Review of Books, in an essay about the films and fiction of Miranda July, Lorrie Moore writes, “We don’t always know what intimate life consists of until novels tell us.”

headline: A Child, Coping, with Autism and Everything Else
text: My son has started turning. Turning his body, I mean, pivoting 360 degrees on the threshold before going through doors, mostly, though sometimes it’s an N.B.A.-like fake left or right just before he starts to move forward. Once we noticed, we asked him about it and got, eventually, a pretty clear answer: “I was turned the wrong way.” Ah.

headline: To the Readers: Alex Rodriguez Is Not Going Away. Sorry.
text: Tents are perfect for the circus. If Alex Rodriguez had used one for his latest apology, he might as well have shown up in grease paint, floppy shoes and a rainbow wig. Rodriguez, the clown prince of baseball, would be setting himself up for laughs.

headline: Review: Matthew Perry in an ‘Odd Couple’ Refitted for a New Century
text: In comedy, opposites don’t attract. Instead they repel each other attractively. And by that standard, the CBS remake of “The Odd Couple,” that has its premiere on Thursday, isn’t so bad. It may even work.

headline: Review: A ‘La Donna del Lago’ With Melting Tenderness at the Met
text: For years, the superb mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato has sung “Tanti affetti,” the final showpiece aria from Rossini’s “La Donna del Lago” (The Lady of the Lake), as a surefire encore in recitals. But on Monday night on the Metropolitan Opera stage, vocal display seemed the last thing on her mind.

headline: Review: Ensemble ACJW Performs Meredith Monk’s Instrumental ‘Backlight’
text: The composer Meredith Monk is known for her uncanny ability to coax the human voice into sonorities both ethereal and startling. Ms. Monk, also a dancer, singer, choreographer, director and filmmaker, has been honing this extended vocal technique since the 1960s, championed by her own ensemble. Her otherworldly vocal quilts are often a patchwork of noises, cries and ululations, interwoven with chanting and humming. Other works are more lyrical, with plaintive, folk-tinged vocal lines stretched over somber, spare accompaniments.

headline: Review: Blue Heron Performs ‘Missa De plus en plus’ at Corpus Christi Church
text: Clever or pretty? Spiritual or erotic? When it comes to the music of the 15th-century Franco-Flemish composer Johannes Ockeghem, certain distinctions become moot.

headline: Review: ‘Cop Show,’ Colin Quinn’s Police Procedural Satire
text: The comedian Colin Quinn is a cunning self-deprecator: He makes fun of his own middling level of fame with an aggressive edge that suggests that he really ought to be bigger by now. On Twitter, he draws attention by encouraging his haters, retweeting their most imaginative insults. (Recent sample: “My girlfriend and I are going to play the CQ game. Every time you come on screen, we drink arsenic.”)

headline: Mac Wellman, a Playwriting Mentor Whose Only Mantra Is Oddity
text: On a recent Tuesday afternoon, Mac Wellman, the Donald I. Fine Distinguished Professor of Play Writing, sat at the head of a table in a Brooklyn College classroom. It was the first meeting of the semester, and he needed to arrange tutorials with his graduate students. He asked them to draw up a plan for the term’s work: something small, something secret.

headline: Robert E. Herzstein, Who Foiled Nixon Over White House Tapes, Dies at 83
text: Robert E. Herzstein, who successfully sued on behalf of historians and journalists to prevent former President Richard M. Nixon from removing and even destroying his White House papers and tapes after his resignation, died on Thursday at his home in Washington. He was 83.

headline: Hungary Keeps Visit by Putin Low-Key as It Seeks to Repair Relations With West
text: WARSAW — When Vladimir V. Putin played host at the Kremlin early last year to Hungary’s prime minister, Viktor Orban, the notion of a reciprocal visit that would bring the Russian president onto European Union soil seemed perfectly in keeping with a whole series of stick-in-the-eye moves toward Europe by the two leaders in recent years.

headline: Rand Paul Is Looking to April to Announce Plan to Run for President, Associates Say
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Rand Paul is eyeing April 7 as the day he will announce his plans to run for president, people close to him said, a step that would position him ahead of his potential Republican rivals as a declared candidate and allow him to begin raising money directly for his campaign 10 months before the Iowa caucuses.

headline: After Public Acrimony, Quieter Steps by Mayor de Blasio and Police to Mend Rift
text: It was an unusual lunch date, powered by political winds and a heap of pastrami: Mayor Bill de Blasio and the police union leader who had, weeks earlier, appraised the mayor publicly as a “total nincompoop.”

headline: Facing Suits, a Nursing Home in California Seeks Bankruptcy
text: A California nursing home fined by the state for substandard care and facing multiple lawsuits by patients and their families has taken the extreme measure of filing for bankruptcy protection in the face of millions of dollars in potential payouts.

headline: Give Greece Room to Maneuver
text: Greece’s lenders, most notably Germany, insist that they are defending important principles: a country must pay its debts, and the long-term success of the euro depends on everyone abiding by the rules.

headline: Veterans in Congress Bring Rare Perspective to Authorizing War
text: WASHINGTON — Veterans of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan now serving in Congress have emerged as some of the most important voices in the debate over whether to give President Obama a broad authorization for a military campaign against the Islamic State or something much more limiting.

headline: Americans May See Appeal of Medical Tourism in Cuba
text: HAVANA — Anuja Agrawal jumped on the phone. President Obama had just announced that he would restore diplomatic relations with Cuba — and Ms. Agrawal, who runs a medical tourism company in Orlando, Fla., did not want to miss her opening.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 17, 2015
Doctors Strive to Do Less Harm by Inattentive Care
text: Suffering. The very word made doctors uncomfortable. Medical journals avoided it, instructing authors to say that patients “ ‘have’ a disease or complications or side effects rather than ‘suffer’ or ‘suffer from’ them,” said Dr. Thomas H. Lee, the chief medical officer of Press Ganey, a company that surveys hospital patients.

headline: A Different (and Surprising) Economic Tale of New York City Emerges
text: When Bill de Blasio ran for mayor in 2013, he declared that New York City’s middle class wasn’t just shrinking, but also stood “in real danger of disappearing altogether.” The claim was part of the tale-of-two-cities theme that drove his campaign, the gilded metropolis indifferently snuffing out its gasping work force.

headline: 30 More Problem Days, Boston Transit Chief Says
text: BOSTON — As if the record snowfall and piercing subzero temperatures were not bad enough, residents here awoke Tuesday to reports that the already crippled Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, one of the largest transit systems in the country, would not be fully functional for at least 30 more days.

headline: Anne Moody, Author of ‘Coming of Age in Mississippi,’ Dies at 74
text: Anne Moody, whose searing memoir, “Coming of Age in Mississippi,” told what it was like to grow up black in the era of Jim Crow, died on Feb. 5 at her home in Gloster, Miss. She was 74.

headline: Celebrating Oscar de la Renta and His Successor
text: On one side of the runway sat the old guard, the perfectly coifed, expensively furred women who made Oscar de la Renta a Park Avenue icon, women like Nancy Kissinger and Mercedes Bass. Barbara Walters was settled in their company; Annette de la Renta, the designer’s widow, was too, seated beside Anna Wintour. Bill Cunningham, before the show, hurried over to give her a warm hug.

headline: Japan Post Offers $5.1 Billion for Australian Package Delivery Company
text: TOKYO — Japan’s national postal service is buying the largest private package and freight delivery company in Australia, Toll Holdings, for 6.5 billion Australian dollars, the two groups said on Wednesday.

headline: Head of New York’s Top Court Says Judges Should Oversee Grand Juries in Deaths Involving Police
text: New York’s top judge proposed on Tuesday that judges oversee grand juries deliberating police-related killings of civilians and be granted greater leeway to make the testimony to such juries available to the public.

headline: Review: ‘Little Children Dream of God,’ a Drama of Haitian Refugees
text: The presence, or absence, of a presiding deity may be a question we all ponder from time to time, but it’s a matter of daily significance in “Little Children Dream of God,” a warm and fanciful drama by Jeff Augustin about a Haitian immigrant trying to forge a new life on the rough streets of Miami.

headline: Review: In ‘Hamilton,’ Lin-Manuel Miranda Forges Democracy Through Rap
text: They’re brewing up a revolution down on Lafayette Street. And even theater reactionaries seem destined to be swept up in its doubt-defying ardor.

headline: Puzzle the Blogging
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — It’s tough to construct and edit a midweek puzzle. Your theme can’t really turn too many cruciverbal somersaults, lest it be pushed into Thursday territory (despite Will Shortz’s claim that Thursdays are not meant to be anything special themewise, that’s where the really cool ones tend to hang out). The clues need to wander surreptitiously away from Monday straightforwardness, but not creep into weekend-level brain-twisting. You can see how getting it just right might be difficult.

headline: Islamist Faction in Libya Now Strikes From the Sky
text: CAIRO — The Islamist-backed faction in Libya’s civil conflict said Tuesday that it had carried out its first airstrike, targeting opponents in the town of Zintan in an escalation of the violence tearing the country apart.

headline: In a Logistical Riddle for the Court, a Terrorism Suspect Is His Own Lawyer
text: Abid Naseer, who is accused of being a Qaeda operative and planning an attack in Manchester, England, stood at a table on Tuesday for opening statements in his trial.

headline: Presidents Cup in South Korea May Lack Native Sons
text: LOS ANGELES — The golf calendar is stuffed fuller than a pro-am goody bag, with 43 PGA Tour events, including the four majors, plus the FedEx Cup playoffs.

headline: New Rules Set on Armed Drone Exports
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Tuesday issued new rules for the international export of armed drones, a move that seeks to preserve an American lead in a fast-growing market but one likely to speed the proliferation of a much-criticized weapon in the battle against terrorism.

headline: Obama Cites Health Plan Tally of 11.4 Million
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Tuesday that 11.4 million people had selected private health insurance plans or renewed their coverage under the Affordable Care Act in the enrollment period that ended Sunday.

headline: Transit Group’s Next Challenge: Selling a New Version of Congestion Pricing
text: A transit advocacy group unveiled a proposal on Tuesday to remake the way tolls are set across New York City. Now comes the hard part — persuading lawmakers and drivers to embrace an idea that was defeated in Albany nearly seven years ago.

headline: Illinois: Imam Charged With Sex Abuse
text: A Chicago-area imam was charged with sexual abuse on Tuesday in a case that has raised questions about whether a cloistered South Asian community’s conservative views on sex and purity had discouraged women from coming forward with accusations of abuse. The charge was announced hours before four women filed a lawsuit accusing the imam, Mohammad Abdullah Saleem, who founded a school called the Institute of Islamic Education, of a pattern of sexual abuse dating back to the 1980s. A 23-year-old woman who worked as a school secretary last year told the police that Mr. Saleem had repeatedly groped her and once pulled her onto his lap and held her there over her objections. “He categorically denies the allegations,” his lawyer, Thomas T. Glasgow, said after a court appearance. He said the school had investigated and found no evidence for the claims.

headline: Fear of Israeli Leaks Fuels Distrust Over U.S. Talks With Iran
text: WASHINGTON — With the Obama administration racing to negotiate the outlines of a nuclear deal with Iran by the end of March, aides to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel have charged in recent days that they are being deliberately left in the dark about the details of the talks. The Americans have said that is untrue, but even one of Washington’s closest negotiating partners reports being warned about being too open with the Israelis, “because whatever we say may be used in a selective way.”

headline: 16 Die in Crush at Carnival in Haiti Capital
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — A stampede on Tuesday left 16 people dead and 78 injured when a singer atop a Carnival float struck an overhead power line, igniting sparks and panic, the authorities said.
