headline: As N.B.A. Trading Deadline Nears, Celtics Have Lots of Picks and Possibilities
text: The N.B.A. trading deadline is Thursday at 3 p.m. Eastern time. Until then, there will be stories on the Phoenix Suns’ potential trade of Goran Dragic, the overhaul of the Denver Nuggets and the Houston Rockets’ ongoing analytic search for better players.

headline: The State of Your New York Block
text: The State of the City speech, delivered each winter by the mayor, is a time-honored policy platform. But it doesn’t tell you what’s really going on out there. For that, you need to ask residents.

headline: A Regal Beagle Seizes the Spotlight
text: It took 20 minutes for David Merriam, the Best in Show judge at the Westminster Kennel Club Show on Tuesday, to give the dog-loving audience at Madison Square Garden a bit of a shock. After a devilishly long route to making up his mind — he seemed to enjoy building the suspense, smiling a bit impishly as he deliberated — he made the surprising choice of Miss P, a 15-inch beagle and the grandniece of Uno, the first beagle to ever win the big show, in 2008.

headline: Gaps in France’s Surveillance Are Clear; Solutions Aren’t
text: PARIS — Last June, Patrick Calvar, the head of France’s domestic intelligence service, faced a decision: continue surveillance on a French Islamist who had been viewed as a potential threat for a decade, or shift limited resources to help monitor a swelling new generation of fighters returning from Syria.

headline: Russia: Court Upholds Activist’s Suspended Sentence
text: A Moscow appeals court on Tuesday upheld a suspended three-and-a-half-year prison sentence against Aleksei A. Navalny, a leader of Russia’s opposition to President Vladimir V. Putin who was convicted last year of fraud in a case widely seen as politically motivated. The court also released Mr. Navalny, an organizer of an opposition rally planned for March 1, from house arrest. A three-and-a-half-year prison sentence handed down to Mr. Navalny’s brother, who was convicted in the same case, remained unchanged. Mr. Navalny called his brother “a hostage.”

headline: Miu Miu Women’s Tales Taps a Cannes Grand Prix Winner
text: For the latest installment of the Miu Miu short-film series Women’s Tales — an ongoing project that has included commissions by Miranda July, Ava DuVernay and Zoe Cassavetes — the brand enlisted Alice Rohrwacher, the writer and director of “Corpo Celeste” (2011) and the Cannes Grand Prix recipient “The Wonders” (2014). “In fact, it was my first short,” Rohrwacher says of her 15-minute-long piece, “De Djess.” “With a short film, you’re able to do some experimenting and still stay within formal guidelines.” That, and Miu Miu allowed Rohrwacher an enormous amount of artistic freedom; the house’s designer, Miuccia Prada, only asked to see the completed film, a rare occurrence in the movie-making realm.

headline: Word of the Day | auxiliary

headline: Critic of N.F.L. Settlement on Concussions Reverses Position
text: Joe DeLamielluere, one the biggest critics of the settlement in a suit that accused the N.F.L. of failing to warn former players about the dangers of concussions, has reversed himself and joined the agreement, according to a court filing on Tuesday. DeLamielluere, a former offensive lineman, joined nine others who initially opted out but will now take part in the settlement, which provides up to $5 million for a limited number of severe neurological conditions. In all, 211 retired players, or about 1 percent of the total, opted out of the deal, which lawyers for the N.F.L. and the former players revised Friday to meet some concerns of Anita B. Brody, the federal judge in the case.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (ABC Family) MATILDA (1996) For every child who ever thought the world was unfair, there’s hope that, like Matilda (Mara Wilson), he or she may one day discover a way to even the score. In this film based on Roald Dahl’s novel, Matilda is a clever heroine born to a loathsome set of parents — played here by Danny DeVito, who also directed the film, and Rhea Perlman — who is sent to a school overseen by a monstrous woman who torments her students. But things begin to change when Matilda realizes that she can use her telekinetic powers to defend herself and her fellow underdogs. Though the film may be too twisted for very young children, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, the “sweet, self-possessed little heroine” is someone to admire: “Even when addressed by her father as ‘You lyin’ little earwig,’ Ms. Wilson’s poised Matilda never loses the quiet confidence that guarantees she will prevail.”

headline: Civilian Toll in Afghan War Rose in 2014, U.N. Reports

text: ITHACA, N.Y. — INTUITION, and a long line of social science research, suggests that citizens are more motivated to become politically involved when an issue is personally important to them.

headline: The Modern Asylum
text: LAST month, three ethicists from the University of Pennsylvania argued in the Journal of the American Medical Association that the movement to deinstitutionalize the mentally ill has been a failure. Deinstitutionalization, they wrote, has in truth been “transinstitutionalization.” As a hospital psychiatrist, I see this every day. Patients with chronic, severe mental illnesses are still in facilities — only now they are in medical hospitals, nursing homes and, increasingly, jails and prisons, places that are less appropriate and more expensive than long-term psychiatric institutions.

headline: The Mission of College? Think About It
Records in Child Abuse Case: Acting D.A. Responds
text: To the Editor:

headline: Democracy Is in Recession
text: Every month now we get treated to another anti-Semitic blast from Turkey’s leadership, which seems to be running some kind of slur-of-the-month club. Who knew that Jews all over the world were busy trying to take down President Recep Tayyip Erdogan? Last week, it was Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu’s turn to declare that Turkey would not “succumb to the Jewish lobby” — among others supposedly trying to topple Erdogan, the Hurriyet Daily News reported. This was after Erdogan had suggested that domestic opponents to the ruling Justice and Development Party, or A.K.P., were “cooperating with the Mossad,” Israel’s intelligence arm. So few Jews, so many governments to topple.

headline: A Stronger Freedom of Information Act
text: Congress came tantalizingly close last year to passing a bill to strengthen the Freedom of Information Act, which allows journalists and the public to access federal government records. The legislation, which would have brought more transparency, was blocked in December when the House speaker, John Boehner, refused to hold a vote on the Senate bill with no explanation. Two months later, lawmakers have a second chance.

headline: College, Poetry and Purpose
text: PHILADELPHIA — Over four decades at two universities, Anne Hall has taught thousands of students, enough to know that they come to college for a variety of reasons, with a variety of attitudes. Many are concerned only with jobs. Some are concerned chiefly with beer.

headline: My Mother Is Not a Bird
text: I stood watching my mother’s last bellowing breaths. There were three of us holding her — me, my husband and my father — in the room we’d designed just for her. She was propped up in a rented hospital bed, lying on brown cotton sheets with the highest thread count I could find. My mother had been gasping like this for two days — a raspy, gurgling sound that I struggle to describe accurately with metaphors: a choking fish, a crackling microphone, a dying deer. But they all sidestep the truth. That was the sound of my 60-year-old mother dying of cancer.

headline: Resuming Drilling in the Atlantic
text: Given the slump in oil prices, why has the Obama administration moved to open up the Atlantic coast to offshore drilling exploration?

headline: Test Yourself | The Westminster Dog Show
text: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 16 article, “Westminster Dog Show Offers No Joy for Fans of a Charming Galoot.”

headline: An Expensive Sunset for the Brent Oil Field
text: LONDON — Cleaning up an oil field in a forbidding environment like the North Sea may be almost as formidable a task as developing one, and in the coming years, those waters are likely to serve as a laboratory for what happens when the useful lives of oil fields expire.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Hand of a Superhero
text: In “Hand of a Superhero,” Jacqueline Mroz writes about prosthetic hands made with 3-D printers.

headline: Altice Offers $4.4 Billion for Vivendi’s Stake in Numericable-SFR
text: LONDON — The French media group Vivendi said on Wednesday that Altice had offered to buy its 20 percent stake in Numericable-SFR.

headline: Crédit Agricole Earnings Beat Expectations
text: PARIS — Crédit Agricole, one of France’s largest banks, on Wednesday reported quarterly profit that beat market expectations, helped by a resurgence in its investment banking activities and a sharp reduction in its provisions against loan losses.

headline: Should Farm Animals Have More Legal Protections?
text: The Animal Welfare Act, enacted in 1966, protects dogs, cats, rabbits and reptiles — but excludes farm animals. For example, Nicholas Kristof recently wrote about how chickens are often raised to have breasts so large that their legs can’t support their body weight. And other Times writers have written about abuse of pigs, sheep and cattle.

headline: Crossed Fates in Central African Republic
text: The moment Sam Phelps left the Central African Republic, he knew he had to return.

headline: Hong Kong’s Leader Hails Year of the Sheep —  and Suggests a Role Model
text: Just what to call the next Lunar New Year has vexed English speakers, as the Chinese character can represent both sheep and goats. In his official New Year message, Hong Kong’s leader, Leung Chun-ying, opts for a little of both. The video of his statement is filled with goats of all varieties: live, stuffed, illustrated. But Mr. Leung asked residents to look to sheep, the meek creature that lives in flocks, as a guide.

headline: State Media Outlet Faults Billionaire’s Son for Crude Comment
text: When the son of one of the richest men in China responded to a reporter’s question about what he sought in a mate, the response shouldn’t have surprised anyone. “That’s simple,” said 27-year-old Wang Sicong. “A big chest is enough.”

headline: To Jump-Start Your Exercise Routine, Be Mindful
text: By now, many of us, beset by bad weather and declining motivation, are struggling to maintain our New Year’s exercise resolutions. But a timely new study offers encouragement, suggesting that by paying more attention to the experience of exercise itself, even the most reluctant of exercisers might begin to find pleasure in movement.

headline: What to Expect on Day 7 of Fashion Week
text: Homestretch, fans!

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: City Blocks, Reviewed
text: Good morning on this soon-to-be-sunny Wednesday.

headline: Swiss Prosecutors Search Offices of HSBC Unit
text: LONDON – Local prosecutors in Switzerland conducted a search of the offices of HSBC’s Swiss private bank in Geneva on Wednesday as part of a new investigation into potential money laundering.

headline: Daily Report: U.S. Sets New Rules for Export of Armed Drones
text: The Obama administration on Tuesday issued new rules for the international export of armed drones, a move that seeks to preserve an American lead in a fast-growing market but one likely to speed the proliferation of a much-criticized weapon in the battle against terrorism, Scott Shane reports.

headline: Tesco, Britain’s Largest Retailer, Names John Allan as Chairman
text: LONDON — Tesco, the embattled British retailing giant, said on Thursday that John Allan, a deputy chairman of the electronics company Dixons Carphone, would take over as chairman on March 1.

headline: Ukrainian Soldiers’ Retreat From Eastern Town Raises Doubt for Truce
text: ARTEMIVSK, Ukraine — Ukrainian soldiers were forced to fight their way out of the embattled town of Debaltseve in the early hours of Wednesday, casting further doubt on the credibility of a days-old cease-fire and eroding the promise of ending a war in Europe that has killed more than 5,000 people.

headline: Sony Aims for Huge Leap in Profit
text: HONG KONG — The light at the end of the tunnel may finally be coming into focus for Sony.

headline: Project Sheds Light on What Drives Genes
text: More than 200 scientists working on an ambitious federal project have begun to understand the complicated system of switches that regulates genes, turning some on and others off, making some glow brightly while others dim. They hope these discoveries, described in two dozen papers released on Wednesday, will eventually lead to a deeper understanding of diseases and new ways to treat or cure them.

headline: Today in Politics
text: Immigration Ruling in Texas Muddies the Debate in Washington

headline: Morning Agenda: Snapchat Reaches for $19 Billion Valuation
text: SNAPCHAT REACHES FOR $19 BILLION VALUATION | Snapchat, the start-up with disappearing photo messages, is said to be raising a round of venture capital that could value the company at up to $19 billion, Mike Isaac writes on the Bits blog, citing a person with knowledge of the discussions. Snapchat could raise up to $500 million in the round of financing, the person said. If the round closes, Snapchat’s value will have nearly doubled since last year, when the company was in talks to raise money at a $10 billion valuation.

headline: A Lunar New Year With a Name That’s a Matter of Opinion
text: HONG KONG — China said goodbye to the Year of the Horse on Wednesday, and on the first day of the new lunar year revelers welcomed the Year of the Sheep.

headline: Poland to Pay $262,000 to Inmates Held at Secret C.I.A. Prison
text: WARSAW — Poland will abide by a European court ruling that ordered it to pay a total of $262,000 in reparations to two former inmates of a “black site” prison run by the C.I.A., the minister of foreign affairs said on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Magnificent Obsessions’ Show at the Barbican Explores Portraits of the Artist as Collector
text: LONDON — Their works may be coveted by collectors, but artists often have a predilection for building eccentric collections of their own. Many like to pick up bric-a-brac from curiosity shops, market stalls and auction houses. Predictably enough, Damien Hirst owns skulls and stuffed animals. Less widely known is that Peter Blake hoards vintage shop signs, while Martin Parr boasts an impressive collection of Soviet souvenirs.

headline: High-Spirited Comedies Rush the Stage
text: To get the gist of the comedy in the coming Broadway musical “Something Rotten!,” about a playwright competing against Shakespeare in 1595 London, consider this exchange between two characters who happen to be named Shylock and Nostradamus about the most avid theatergoers of the Elizabethan era.

headline: Larry David on Broadway Theater, ‘Seinfeld’ and Death Etiquette
text: In his dressing room at the Cort Theater, Larry David started eating dinner, but not before lowering expectations. “I should warn you: I’m not a skilled eater,” he said, leaning forward to grab a white plastic takeout bag. “I have problems getting the food onto my utensil and getting it into my mouth properly. It’s not a pretty picture.”

headline: Subtle Bias, Fed Head Edition
text: This isn’t a big deal, but it nonetheless had me doing a double-take. I was looking up educational backgrounds of prominent economists, for a post I haven’t found time to put together yet, and when I got to Janet Yellen I saw something that seemed off; so I went to see whether there was anything comparable on her predecessor. No, there wasn’t:

headline: Video Shows Racist Behavior by Chelsea Soccer Fans in Paris
text: LONDON — Video footage showing white fans of the English soccer team Chelsea shoving a black subway rider in Paris has revived concerns about racism in what is often labeled “the beautiful game.”

headline: Jeb Bush on Obama’s Home Turf to Attack His Foreign Policy
text: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida is in President Obama’s hometown on Wednesday to lay out a foreign policy vision that he says is in contrast to the “inconsistent and indecisive” policies of the current White House.

headline: Daily Clip Report
text: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Don’t Ask for the Menu
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Student Crossword | Black History Month
text: Test your knowledge of Black History Month by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Fox Searchlight Outshines Rivals in Oscar Hunt
text: LOS ANGELES — At the Academy Awards on Sunday, Fox Searchlight Pictures will have two films in the running for top honors: Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s “Birdman” and Wes Anderson’s “The Grand Budapest Hotel.”

headline: Admiring Mount Fuji From a Black-Sand Beach
text: Mount Fuji is a beloved and sacred peak that is an unforgettable sight and easily viewable, which is why I was frustrated when on a visit in 2013 I was able to get to within a few miles of the mountain only to find it obscured by thick clouds.

headline: Island Hopping Off the Coast of Borneo
text: It seemed like a good idea at the time. Adam Dean, a photographer working for The New York Times, and I had just returned from several back-to-back voyages in the South China Sea last November, reporting on the fishing industry and sleeping on cramped, roach- and rat-infested boats from Thailand and Indonesia. While waiting in Kota Kinabalu, Borneo, for our next boat to arrive, we had a couple of down days. So I suggested we try the Coral Explorer day package on offer from an adventure tours company called Intrepid Travel, based in Melbourne, Australia.

headline: A Call for Law Firms to Go Public
text: Many law firms have been seeking new ways to keep themselves financially sound as their clients become more cost conscious.

headline: In Wilton, Conn., Historic Homes and Fine Schools
text: Heather and Christopher Mah went looking for a place to live in Fairfield County, and wound up choosing a house before they’d chosen a town.

headline: Photoshop at 25: A Thriving Chameleon Adapts to an Instagram World
text: The history of digital technology is full of innovations that are praised for having changed the world: the Mac, Microsoft Windows, the Netscape Navigator browser, the iPod and countless others. Then there are the many products that changed the world and were suddenly overtaken by some newer, supposedly better thing: the Mac, Microsoft Windows, Netscape Navigator, the iPod and countless others.

headline: Khmer-Inspired Shopping by Angkor Wat
text: Siem Reap, the gateway city to Angkor, is renowned for a lot of things — more than 100 ancient temple ruins dot the surrounding jungles — but shopping isn’t one of them. It’s often an afterthought, with visitors snagging the prerequisite temple souvenir. But the heart of the city on the west side of the Siem Reap River is brimming with a clutch of stylish, recently opened boutiques carrying contemporary wares that often reference traditional Khmer culture. The shops are found along narrow lanes and well-trodden streets in a roughly 10-block radius, many owned by well-traveled expatriates breathing new energy into this tourist-oriented city. (Note: U.S. dollars are widely accepted.)

headline: Obama Urges Global United Front Against Extremist Groups Like ISIS
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama called on Americans and more than 60 nations on Wednesday to join the fight against violent extremism, saying they had to counter the ideology of the Islamic State and other groups making increasingly sophisticated appeals to young people around the world.

headline: Anna Ewers Transforms at Rodarte
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Anna Ewers before (left) and after (right) makeup by James Kaliardos, hair by Odile Gilbert.

headline: New Artistic Director for Guthrie Theater
text: The Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis has named its next artistic director: Joseph Haj, who currently leads PlayMakers Repertory Company in North Carolina. Mr. Haj, one of the few Arab-American artistic directors in the country, will take over the Guthrie on July 1, succeeding Joe Dowling, who is stepping down after 20 years. The Guthrie board’s chairman, Lee Skold, said Tuesday that the search team and board members – who spent a year looking for a leadership match – had been drawn to Mr. Haj’s “inspired vision, collaborative spirit, and standard of excellence.”

headline: David Ives's ‘Lives of the Saints’ From Primary Stages
text: The playwright David Ives is all over the place. “The Metromaniacs,” his verse adaptation of an 18th-century play, has just opened at the Shakespeare Theater in Washington. His comedy “Venus in Fur,” seen widely at regional theaters, may get another goose from the movie release of a certain hugely popular series of novels about erotic transgression. It has also been announced that Mr. Ives will collaborate with Stephen Sondheim on a new musical adapted from a pair of Luis Buñuel films.

headline: 1915: Italians Clamor for War
text: ROME — All adherents of the democratic parties had been convoked for to-day [Feb. 18] to the Piazza Monte Citorio for the purpose of a demonstration in favor of war. The square was barricaded by troops and police, but in the neighborhood of the Chamber a grave demonstration took place in spite of all precautions. Immense crowds gathered and clamored for war, interspersing their cries with shouts of ‘‘Down with Austria!’’ Processions of demonstrators marched through the streets with flags at their heads shouting against Germany and Austria. German and Austrian shops had all had their shutters put up. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 19, 1915

headline: Peter Carey’s ‘Amnesia’
text: Now that the politics of hacking has ­assumed an importance hitherto unknown, the theme Peter Carey has chosen for his latest novel seems especially timely. In many ways, it’s a departure from his previous work, although throughout “Amnesia” he maintains the temper and Rabelaisian fury of a prose we know all too well. You can pick any page at random and locate an energy that never seems to flag. His sentences hit their intended marks with an emotion that often feels like exasperated cruelty, and none of his characters are spared a little bloodletting.

headline: House Hunting In ...Thailand
text: A FOUR-BEDROOM VILLA WITH WATER VIEWS IN PHUKET, THAILAND

headline: Jeff Augustin on Haiti, Voodoo and Roundabout Underground
text: Magic realism doesn’t work in a world where anything goes as a matter of course. At some point, the magic needs to give way to — or at least nestle alongside — reality.

headline: ‘Head of State,’ by Andrew Marr
text: Early in this comic political thriller, an eminent historian is shown round 10 Downing Street. It is mid-September, 2017, a few days before a referendum on whether Britain should leave the European Union. (In real life, such a referendum is a virtual certainty if the Conservatives are still in the government after this year’s general election.) The historian, who has been promised “unparalleled access” in order to produce an authorized history of the vote, has come to interview the prime minister, a man whose charisma seems to be all that keeps Britain from decamping. But the prime minister is not available, and instead an aide conducts a tour of the premises — up the famous staircase with portraits of previous occupants and into a grand state room. The historian is unimpressed. “He was all too aware that the real work went on one floor below them, in the cabinet room and the P.M.’s office and the private secretaries’ rooms.”

headline: Michael Kors’s Fall 2015 Collection at New York Fashion Week
text: [Watch the live stream.]

headline: ‘Mark Twain’s America’ and ‘Huck Finn’s America’
text: Fresh and funny today as he was more than a century ago, Mark Twain wittily distrusted everything bogus, inflated, predictable or empty. He was a man of a thousand American parts — novelist, stand-up comic, travel writer, impresario, capitalist, full-time celebrity and coruscating social critic — whose ear for dialogue, nuance, slang and absurdity seldom failed him. No wonder we still read him, debate him, scold him, censor him. William Dean Howells aptly canonized him as the “Lincoln of our literature.”

headline: No Bitterness From Victoria Azarenka After Surprise Split With Coach
text: In a time of increased shuffling in the coaching ranks of professional tennis, the partnership between Victoria Azarenka and her longtime coach Sam Sumyk ended abruptly, at least from Azarenka’s perspective.

headline: Sketching Shakespeare
text: “Macbeth” — unlike, say, “Hamlet” or “Romeo and Juliet” — doesn’t feature classically adolescent themes, and its main characters are grown-ups. Yet with its simple, linear plot, its witches and its ghosts, its clear-cut moral questions about the lure of evil and whether and how we control our own fates, it is well suited for teenagers. Gareth Hinds’s stellar new graphic-novel adaptation, aimed at a young adult audience, makes that abundantly clear. The play also, of course, features some epic fight scenes and lots and lots of blood, and Hinds makes the most of these opportunities to show how naturally Shakespeare takes to the comics form.

headline: Probing the Mysteries of a Photographer and Her Images
text: One of the most fascinating art world stories of recent years is the discovery of the work of Vivian Maier and her rapid elevation to one of the great American photographers of the 20th century. It was John Maloof who found thousands of her negatives and undeveloped rolls of film at an auction house in Chicago, and paid $380 for them, and he is also the director, with Charlie Siskel, of “Finding Vivian Maier,” one of five films competing for the Oscar for best feature-length documentary.

headline: 1965: Vatican and Protestants Agree
text: GENEVA — The Roman Catholic and Protestant churches today [Feb. 18] reached a historic agreement to try to end their differences and achieve Christian unity. The first giant step toward a common understanding came during the unprecedented visit of a Roman Catholic cardinal to the World Council of Churches this morning. Augustin Cardinal Bea, on behalf of the Holy See, accepted the council’s proposal to establish a mixed committee to determine the principles and methods for future inter-church collaboration. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 19, 1965

headline: Hospitals Try to Reduce Suffering: Reporter’s Notebook
text: Gina Kolata wrote a Feb. 18 front-page article about hospitals and their increased interest in reducing suffering. She explains how the story took shape.

headline: Earthquake Dangers in Dutch Gas Field Were Ignored for Years, Safety Board Says
text: LONDON — An independent Dutch safety panel has found that the operators of Europe’s largest natural gas field, Royal Dutch Shell and Exxon Mobil, as well as the Dutch government, for years ignored the dangers posed by earthquakes in the field.

headline: A Bid for Guns on Campuses to Deter Rape
text: As gun rights advocates push to legalize firearms on college campuses, an argument is taking shape: Arming female students will help reduce sexual assaults.

headline: Greece to Propose Extension of European Union Bailout Program
text: ATHENS — Greek officials are planning to submit a proposal to eurozone finance ministers for breaking the impasse in debt negotiations between the new government in Athens and Greece’s European creditors.

text: Matthew Perry and Thomas Lennon star in a CBS update of the classic sitcom.

headline: Trade Group Accelerates Push for a ‘Fast Track’ Deal
text: Members of Congress might be home for the Presidents’ Day recess, but they cannot avoid the debate over trade.

headline: New York City Rail Crossings Carry a Deadly Past
text: New Yorkers may not think railroad grade crossings have anything to do with them, but the city owes its immensely popular High Line to a campaign that began more than a century ago against the carnage caused by a street-level freight line.

headline: Memorable Sports Apologies Through the Years
text: The most believable part about Alex Rodriguez’s public apology to the Yankees and fans Tuesday for past misdeeds might have been the section in which he acknowledged that most people would not believe anything he said. The most unusual part might have been his chosen medium for the moment: a handwritten letter, in cursive, in 2015. Most offensive, stylistically, was probably his decision to stretch the letter to a second page, making it aesthetically unpleasing on social media.

headline: What You Get for … $1,050,000
text: A former hunting retreat in Colorado, a contemporary in Alabama and a cottage in West Virginia

headline: $1,050,000 Homes in Colorado, Alabama and West Virginia
text: MEREDITH, COLO.

headline: What’s the Most Godless State?
text: A new Gallup poll finds that more than half of Utah residents say they attend religious services weekly, the highest percentage of any state in the union. In Vermont, only 17 percent of residents say they attend religious services weekly, the lowest percentage. Click on the Gallup link for a complete list.

headline: New Dr. Seuss Book, ‘What Pet Should I Get?’, Coming in July, With More to Come
text: When Harper Lee’s “Go Set a Watchman” hits bookstores in July, it will face sales competition from another long-lost manuscript by a beloved author: Dr. Seuss.

headline: Nick Hornby’s ‘Funny Girl’
text: The unassuming title of Nick Hornby’s regular column about books for The Believer magazine perfectly matches its author’s conversational style: “Stuff I’ve Been Reading.” At a literary festival last October, Hornby spoke, not for the first time, in defense of taking the pain out of literature. Struggling through a book out of a sense of duty, he argued, is “reinforcing the ­notion that reading is something you should do but telly is something you want to do. It shouldn’t be like that. Novels should be like TV. It shouldn’t be hard work.”

headline: Kate Brown, New Governor in Oregon, Seeks Public’s Trust
text: SALEM, Ore. — Kate Brown took the oath of office as governor here on Wednesday, capping a decades-long climb through the ranks of state government but also commencing what is certain to be a wrenching transition fraught with political risk. Her predecessor, John Kitzhaber, announced his resignation last week, just weeks into his fourth term, amid an onslaught of criminal and ethical investigations and a collapse of support from his own party.

headline: Amazon Orders Full Seasons for Five New Shows
text: In January, Amazon Studios, the online retail giant’s television production wing, posted 10 original pilots for viewers to watch and vote on. This morning, five of them were ordered to series: “The Man in the High Castle,” based on the Philip K. Dick novel that imagines an alternate reality in which the Axis powers won World War II; “Mad Dogs,” a dark comedy executive produced by Shawn Ryan (“The Shield,” “Terriers”); “The New Yorker Presents,” a docu-series overseen by Alex Gibney (“Taxi To the Dark Side,” “We Steal Secrets”); and the kids series “Just Add Magic” and “The Stinky & Dirty Show.”

headline: Real Runners Do Take Walk Breaks
text: When a runner friend suggested I run my first distance race by adding walk breaks, the idea startled me. I didn’t think you were allowed to walk in races, not if you wanted to be a real runner. But the thought of running in New Jersey, all the way to the boardwalk in North Wildwood from Cape May in a single clip, seemed impossible, and I came around.

headline: Below the Line: Editing ‘Whiplash’
text: Those who have seen their fair share of films about musicians may go into a movie like “Whiplash” with certain expectations. But this best picture nominee is not your typical music drama. Instead, in its pacing,  acting and particularly  its editing, the film behaves more like “Bullitt” than, say, “Bird.” The focus is mainly on Andrew (Miles Teller), a jazz drum student at a prestigious music school, and his mentor, Fletcher (J.K. Simmons), an intense, strict and frequently verbally abusive  teacher. The film’s editor, Tom Cross, worked closely with the director, Damien Chazelle, to shape the cuts.

headline: Designers Take Cues From Scottish Lads to Make Fall Skirts for the Girls
text: Designers have always loved borrowing from the boys for women’s collections; and for fall 2015, ​they tapped into the structure of a kilt. At Coach, pleated, knee-length skirts, the default bottoms throughout the collection, added femininity to looks featuring structured shearling coats and heavy boots. Tim Coppens, who got his start in men’s wear,​ kept to his usual sporty aesthetic, topping kilt-inspired bottoms with boyish knits and bombers. And at Diesel Black Gold, Andreas Melbostad added texture to his all-black collection with lace, leather and, in this instance, layers of materials in a miniskirt version of the traditional Scottish garment. In all black, the trending color on this week’s runways, the new iterations are much chicer than the tartan originals.

headline: ‘Infrastructure Joe’ Visits Another 2016 Early Primary State
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday continued his sweep through 2016 early primary states, stopping in Charleston, S.C., to deliver a broad speech on infrastructure as part of the administration’s “Grow America” tour.

headline: Same-Day Delivery Resurges, Adding Alcohol
text: There are many bodies in the delivery graveyard. Webvan, Kozmo and Urbanfetch were all seen as the next big thing before crashing spectacularly.

headline: Obama Picks Joseph Clancy to Be Secret Service’s Permanent Chief
text: President Obama on Wednesday appointed Joseph P. Clancy, who had guided the Secret Service on an interim basis for the last four and a half months, to be the agency’s permanent director.

headline: Reader Mailbag: Questions and Comments About Orders at Chipotle
text: In an article Tuesday, we set out to answer a question that we’ve always wondered about — what do people actually order when they go to Chipotle? We found that a typical order had about 1,070 calories and almost a full day’s worth of sodium and saturated fat.

headline: 8 Tax Loopholes the Obama Administration Could Close
text: “Let Bartlet be Bartlet” was the title of a stirring episode of the progressive wish-fulfillment television series “The West Wing.” In the episode, staff members struggle to be taken seriously on Capitol Hill, working in the shadow of the timid and ambivalent president, Josiah Bartlet. In the face of falling job approval ratings, the chief of staff, Leo McGarry, challenges the president to be true to his values and take the staff off the leash. Mr. McGarry asks the staff members if they are ready for the fight. Each responds, “I serve at the pleasure of the president.”

headline: Company in Bangladesh Agrees to Union Peace
text: After wielding intense pressure against a Bangladeshi apparel maker over assaults on union leaders outside its factories, Western companies have agreed to resume business with that manufacturer, on the condition that it stay committed to halting further violence and make peace with its labor unions.

headline: In Philadelphia, Extended Stays With Boutique Touches
text: The extended-stay hotel category gets a boutique-style update in the form of the new Roost Apartment Hotel, recently opened in Philadelphia.

headline: Chris Christie Makes a Fund-Raising Push in Bush Country
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, struggling to catch up to the early financial gains of his potential rival Jeb Bush, made an aggressive fund-raising push last week in Greenwich, Conn., the affluent enclave where residents have been part of the Bush family donor network for years.

headline: Michael Kors: Fall 2015 RTW
text: New York

headline: Japan Post Paying a Rich Price to Show Global Expansion
text: Japan Post Service is paying a hefty price to stamp “global expansion” on its roadshow presentation.

headline: Pakistani Taliban Kill 3 in Suicide Attack at Shiite Mosque
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least three people were killed and two wounded on Wednesday when a suicide bomber detonated his explosives outside a Shiite mosque on the outskirts of Islamabad, officials said. A faction of the Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility.

headline: Yemen’s Last Jews
text: The rise of the militant Houthis and their anti-Semitism has reduced an ancient and once vibrant community to only a few people.

headline: Crew Member Injured in Another Bond Movie Accident
text: The shooting of the new James Bond movie, “Spectre,” continued along its accident-prone way with an on-set crash Tuesday, according to the Hollywood Reporter.

headline: 36 Hours in Beijing
text: Compared with China’s other megacities, Beijing is still a traditionalist at heart, so delve into the shops, galleries and restaurants in the city’s old, alleyway-threaded hutong neighborhoods.

headline: Persecution Defines Life for Yemen’s Remaining Jews

headline: Classical Playlist: Beethoven, Mozart, Hugo Wolf and More

The players bring jaunty exuberance to Wolf’s “Italienische Serenade,” an epic sweep to Grieg’s String Quartet in G minor and fiery temperament to Janacek’s String Quartet No. 2. headline: In Nigeria, Boko Haram Loses Ground to Chadians

headline: A True Bedhead Look at Michael Kors
text: “If I could, I would have started last night,” said the hairstylist Orlando Pita, who instructed the models to wash their hair last night and sleep with it slightly damp before arriving backstage at the fall/winter 2015 Michael Kors fashion show this morning. Pita explained his goal was to achieve a disheveled look — the one you naturally have fresh “out of bed, almost like you didn’t have time to get ready, putting an elastic on your hair and running out the door.”

headline: A Boom in Private Equity’s Secondary Market

headline: 36 Hours in Beijing
text: It seems like only yesterday that Beijing had its much-ballyhooed “coming out” party — the 2008 Summer Olympics — but things don’t slow down much in China’s frenetic capital. Already, the city is eyeing another Olympics bid (it’s one of two finalists for the 2022 Winter Games) and planning a $13 billion airport that is expected to be among the busiest in the world when it opens in 2019. And yet compared with China’s other vertical megacities, Beijing is still a traditionalist at heart. The city may have fantastic new sculptural monuments designed by Zaha Hadid and Rem Koolhaas, but to truly understand Beijing, one has to delve into the remaining hutong neighborhoods — traditional alleyways lined with courtyard homes — and smell the sweet potatoes roasting on coal fires in the winter.

headline: Pussy Riot Releases ‘I Can’t Breathe,’ a Protest Song for Eric Garner
text: Two members of Pussy Riot, the Russian activist group, have made their first foray into English-language protest music, with the help of a who’s who of indie rockers. In a video released Wednesday for a song called “I Can’t Breathe,” Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, who were jailed for protesting in Russia, are buried in black dirt, while wearing Russian police uniforms. Their collaborators on the song, made in memory of Eric Garner and using his last words as its title and closing lyrics, include Nick Zinner of Yeah Yeah Yeahs and Andrew Wyatt of Miike Snow, as well as two Russian acts, Scofferlane and Jack Wood, which supplied the vocals (“It’s getting dark, New York City/I need to catch my breath”). Richard Hell, the punk musician and writer, reads out Mr. Garner’s last words.

headline: Walton Street Is Charmingly Old-Fashioned — at Least for Now
text: London’s Walton Street, in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, to the west of the city, has remained largely unchanged for the last 30 years. But for an increasingly international set of locals, that is its chief delight. Once home to the humorist P.G. Wodehouse, Walton Street still emanates an old-school English charm. Though flanked by Harrods and The Conran Shop, it’s an enclave of independent, if occasionally chichi, antiques and interiors shops, and art galleries and boutiques that has — so far — bucked the trend for high-end homogenization. There are, however, signs that change is afoot: Many of the streets’ stucco homes are straining under the scaffolds of hi-spec redevelopment, and rumor has it that the James Perse store may soon be joined by Charlotte Olympia and Christian Dior.

headline: In Defense of Islam
text: Consider this post a kind of complement, maybe, to my anti-anti-Crusades commentary of late. The big foreign policy piece that everyone is talking about this week, and deservedly, is Graeme Wood’s deep Atlantic dive into the religious premises underpinning the Islamic State’s vision and grand strategy. Wood’s argument is rich enough to defy easy summary, but his core point is that Western analysts tend to understate not only the essential religiosity of ISIS’s worldview, but the extent to which that worldview has substantial theological grounding. It isn’t just a few guys making up a cult out of random bits of scripture; its political-religious vision appeals precisely because it derives “from coherent and even learned interpretations of Islam.” And we ignore the coherence of those interpretations at our peril: The Islamic State’s “intellectual genealogy” is intensely relevant to its political strategy, and its theology “must be understood to be combatted.”

headline: Rosanne Somerson Named RISD President
text: When Rosanne Somerson became interim president of Rhode Island School of Design, the job came with a 21-room historic house in Providence, R.I., but not much furniture. Fortunately, Ms. Somerson was a founder and longtime head of the school’s furniture department with close ties to the academic community. As described in the “On Location” feature of Feb. 12, she filled the rooms with dozens of furniture and art pieces made by RISD faculty, students and alumni, creating not only a comfortable second home but also a public showcase of the school’s talent.

headline: Review: ‘Schubert’s Winter Journey’ Allows Ian Bostridge to Obsess
text: When Schubert played “Winterreise,” one of the greatest cycles of art songs, or lieder, ever written, for a gathering of his friends, they were puzzled. As one member of his circle recalled decades later, they were “utterly dumbfounded by the mournful, gloomy tone of these songs.”

headline: Paula Hayes Reimagines a Victorian Totem in Madison Square Park
text: Paula Hayes can see into the future. “I’ve always been a bit witchy,” she squeals. It’s true: Hayes has been infusing her sculptures with a bit of history and magic since she began creating work back in the 1990s. But it wasn’t until her first show in 2004 with Salon 94, which represents her to this day, that it became clear the environmentally focused artist’s iconic medium, the round terrarium, would trickle down into critical mass. These days, retailers like Target unknowingly shill imitations of her work. Now that every twentysomething in Brooklyn (and their mothers elsewhere) own the little glass spheres that contain living plants, succulents and crystals, Hayes has moved on. “I’m contemplating in the realm of nature, but it has moved into sculptural form and illumination,” the 57-year-old says. On top of her terrariums, Hayes is internationally lauded as a landscape artist — even divining the backyards and terraces of the art world’s elite, including the gallerists Jeanne Rohatyn Greenberg (of Salon 94), David Zwirner and Marianne Boesky. For her next project, though, “I’m not using living plants,” Hayes says. “That’s a huge departure for my audience, the aspect of the botanical or horticultural, with more than 15 years in garden design,” Hayes continues. So what is she doing?

headline: Review: Jamie Barton Shows That She’s a Powerhouse of a Mezzo-Soprano
text: Pity the pianist who has to accompany Jamie Barton. It’s not that Ms. Barton, a dramatic mezzo-soprano who has found stardom in the opera world since her double first prize in the 2013 Cardiff Singer of the World Competition, treats her chamber music partners callously. During her recital debut at Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening, she exuded immense likability and down-to-earth charm. No, the predicament for Bradley Moore, her very able pianist on this occasion, was that next to the magnificent power of Ms. Barton’s voice, virtually everything he played came out sounding forlorn.

An engineer turned product designer, Mr. Vann recently seized on the rolling pin, which he said was long due for an update. Experience had taught him that two features guarantee the success of any modern object: anodized aluminum and LEDs.

That destination, along with three others (Vienna, Bora Bora and Bandol, France), formed the inspiration for her latest collection of wallpaper, out next month.

headline: The Mystery of Moore
text: Jonathan Chait seems boggled at an op-ed from Stephen Moore, the chief economist at the Heritage Foundation, attacking Obamacare: Not one alleged fact cited in the piece is right. And we’re not talking about matters of interpretation. CBO has not changed its view that the ACA will reduce the deficit; health costs have not increased faster than before; premiums are not skyrocketing.

headline: Film Society of Lincoln Center Lauds Cannon Films
text: “My education was Bogart, Cagney and Cooper,” the director and producer Menahem Golan once said. Somewhere along the line, jiggling babes and giggling psychos, Sylvester Stallone and a voracious appetite for schlock became part of the mix, too. Mr. Golan is best known for the Cannon Group, the company he ran in the 1980s with his cousin Yoram Globus. The two men and the strange, wonderful and often terrible cinematic world they made are the subject of the buoyantly funny opening-night attraction of this year’s Film Comment Selects, the annual showcase that invades the Film Society of Lincoln Center on Friday, bringing with it edge and mess, a splatter of guts and some real glory.

headline: A Classic Moment by the Pool

A third, all legs and carefree attitude, strides toward them with a drink in her hand. In the background is a modern glass-and-stone house and purplish mountains. The landscape is idyllic. The sunlight is hazy and golden. You would live inside the photo if you could.

headline: A Broken Heart, a Child’s Life

headline: Fashion Designers Finally Notice That Hot Dude
text: What are “Hot Dudes Reading” actually reading. You know the ones, the guys spotted and surreptitiously snapped on the subway with their heads buried in books. In under a month, this anonymous Instagram account, with just over 20 posts, has pulled in more than 300,000 followers, and it’s safe to assume the draw is not their actual reading matter.

headline: Maxim, Famous for Skin, Makes a Foray Into Fashion
text: It was mid-January, the beginning of a new year, and at the men’s wear fashion shows in Milan and Paris, a new if not exactly unfamiliar face had appeared in the crowd. Among the magazine editors who traffic in men’s fashion, this was unusual. The men’s industry, unlike the women’s, is cozy and small, many of its high-ranking officials more or less tenured. In 2015, the editors of GQ, Details and Esquire celebrate 12, 15 and 18 years at their posts, respectively.

headline: Dropcam Keeps an Eye on the Neighborhood
text: SAN FRANCISCO — WHEN I set up a Dropcam last year, my original goal certainly wasn’t to become some sort of neighborhood watchdog.

headline: Tricks of the Hairstyle and Makeup Nominees
text: Sometimes a well-placed prosthetic or a stylish mustache are just what an audience needs to buy into a story, as evidenced by this year’s Oscar nominees for makeup and hairstyling:  “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” “Foxcatcher” and “Guardians of the Galaxy.”

headline: N.F.L. and American Needle Agree to Settle Lawsuit
text: One of the longest lawsuits involving the N.F.L. appears to be nearing an end. American Needle, a cap maker that sued the league after Reebok became the league’s exclusive apparel provider, agreed to settle its case against the N.F.L.

headline: Basketball and Fashion Share the Court
text: This was not your typical fashion party. Waiters in basketball jerseys carried platters of popcorn and mac ‘n’ cheese. The jewelry designer Jennifer Fisher brandished an orange Givenchy handbag that resembled a basketball. And Jeremy Scott, the Moschino designer, was unfamiliar with the party’s host, J. R. Smith.

headline: Two Deals Bring Attention to Banking’s Safra Family
text: On a single day last fall, two deals were coming together that would draw unusual attention to a banking family that prefers to remain in the shadows.

text: And so a page was turned.

headline: Illinois Governor Proposes $6 Billion in Cuts and Reducing Pension Benefits
text: CHICAGO — Expecting significant budget shortfalls this year and in the years ahead, Bruce Rauner, Illinois’s new Republican governor, on Wednesday proposed more than $6 billion in cuts in state spending on universities, health care, local governments and other areas and called for sharply reducing pension benefits for state workers.

headline: Israeli Court Ruling on Protester’s Death Is Criticized
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli Supreme Court’s rejection of an appeal for damages by the family of Rachel Corrie, a young American woman who was run over by a military bulldozer in Gaza in 2003 as she protested Israeli Army actions there, has prompted criticism from the family and from Human Rights Watch.

headline: Bush Adviser May Skip Campaign to Work for ‘Super PAC’
text: Mike Murphy, the Republican strategist who has played a critical role in getting out Jeb Bush’s message and rolling out his all-but-certain presidential run, may not end up working for the campaign itself.

headline: In New York, Immigrants’ Advocates Vow to Fight After Judge Halts Obama Programs
text: Immigrants and their supporters gathered on Wednesday at rallies and news conferences in New York and across the nation to denounce a judge’s order halting President Obama’s sweeping executive actions on immigration and to vow a redoubled effort in support of the initiatives.

headline: As Health Exchange Sign-Ups Rise, So Do Stakes for Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Wednesday that 8.6 million people in 37 states had selected or renewed health plans through the federal insurance marketplace, and that most of them would suffer if the Supreme Court blocked premium subsidies for consumers in those states.

headline: Ebola Risks Linger, Officials Warn
text: Top United Nations officials on Wednesday warned against complacency over the waning Ebola epidemic in three West African countries and emphasized the difficulty of eradicating the disease that has left nearly 9,400 people dead. Speaking to the General Assembly, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon noted that Liberia had progressed rapidly over the past month and was now reporting fewer than five new cases per week. But new cases have generally been increasing in Guinea and Sierra Leone in recent weeks, and Mr. Ban said that more than half of the newly infected people in those two countries had not been in contact with people known to have been infected. “This reminds us that setbacks can quickly follow apparent gains,” he said. Dr. David Nabarro, appointed by Mr. Ban to lead the United Nations anti-Ebola effort, also spoke to the General Assembly and expressed concern about unsafe burials of Ebola victims, considered a major source of new transmissions. He said an Ebola-infected corpse, not handled safely, could spread the virus to as many as 30 others.

headline: AT&T’s Offer: Share Your Data for Personalized Ads, or Pay More
text: Would you pay an extra monthly fee just to avoid seeing some online ads based on your web browsing history?

headline: Ex-Fortune Editor Joins Yahoo Finance
text: Andrew Serwer, the longtime editor of Fortune magazine, will join Yahoo Finance as editor in chief, the company said Wednesday.

headline: Vice Media Chief Said to Pay $300,000 for Dinner for 30
text: Never one known for restraint, Vice Media’s Shane Smith may now have outdone even himself.

headline: Fresh Challenge to Gay Marriage Increases Confusion in Alabama
text: Though most county probate judges in Alabama are now issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples, the fight over the matter continues to simmer in state and federal courts, fueled by two conservative groups that have asked the state’s Supreme Court to halt the practice.

headline: Anna Sui: Fall 2015 RTW
text: New York

headline: New York Compels 20 School Districts to Lower Barriers to Immigrants
text: Twenty New York school districts found to be blocking access for undocumented immigrant children will be forced to modify their enrollment policies to break down illegal barriers to education, the state attorney general’s office said on Wednesday.

headline: Alabama Apologizes to India for Police Assault on Indian Visitor
text: The governor of Alabama offered a written apology to the people of India on Tuesday for the severe injuries suffered by an Indian visitor hurled to the ground by a police officer this month.

headline: Lying, Lying, Gone? Fans Should Hope So
text: Hasn’t everyone had enough of Alex Rodriguez by now? Enough of the lies and the apologies, and then the lies again, and the apologies again?

headline: 35 Artists Donate Works to Benefit Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art
text: LOS ANGELES — Many of the artists who voiced strong support — and also criticism — of the Museum of Contemporary Art here during its struggles of the last decade are now lending a hand financially: they have agreed to donate their own artworks for an auction to benefit the museum’s endowment. Only instead of taking place between courses at some gala dinner, these sales will take place at Sotheby’s New York, as part of the auction house’s flagship contemporary art sale on the evening of May 12 and its day sale on May 13.

headline: Acting as His Own Attorney, Defendant in Bomb Case Cross-Examines a Witness
text: A federal jury in Brooklyn on Wednesday watched a defendant who is accused of planning a terrorist attack question a government witness who has admitted to working with Al Qaeda.

headline: White House Struggles on Immigration Ruling
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s lawyers, facing what could be months of delay on the White House’s immigration efforts, are struggling for a response to a Texas judge’s ruling that has imperiled one of the president’s potential legacy achievements.

headline: After Former Player’s Death, Concussion Litigation Against N.H.L. Gains Heft
text: It was more than a year ago that a group of 10 former N.H.L. players sued the league for, in essence, ignoring the growing evidence surrounding the long-term effects of concussions.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 18, 2015
Guantánamo Conviction of Australian Is Overturned
text: WASHINGTON — A military appeals court on Wednesday overturned the terrorism conviction of an Australian whose guilty plea was once hailed as a sign that the tribunal system at the Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, prison would be swift and effective.

headline: Pakistanis Try to Nudge Taliban Along the Path to Peace Talks With Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Pakistan’s top military and intelligence officials have begun pressing the Taliban to sit down for face-to-face discussions with the Afghan government, potentially opening a path for direct peace talks for the first time since the start of the American-led invasion in 2001, according to Western and Afghan officials briefed on the discussions.

headline: Indian Guest Workers Awarded $14 Million
text: A federal jury in Louisiana awarded $14 million in damages on Wednesday to five Indian guest workers who said they were lured to the United States with false promises of permanent residency by a Gulf Coast maritime services company and forced to live in inhumane conditions and threatened when they objected to their treatment.

headline: An Observance of Ash Wednesday
text: Alexis Delacruz and his daughter Amos Delacruz, 18 months, at Rose of Lima Church in Manhattan. The observance, which uses ashes as signs of penance and mourning, marks the start of Lent, a time of penitence before Easter, which is on April 5.

headline: Reverent Tribute to a Coach Befits a Rivalry, and So Does the Game
text: DURHAM, N.C. — At 9:02 p.m. Wednesday, eight minutes before No. 4 Duke and No. 15 North Carolina tipped off the 239th game of their rivalry, players and coaches from both teams huddled at midcourt of Cameron Indoor Stadium.

headline: New York City Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Are Suspended on Thursday
text: Because of the Asian Lunar New Year, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Unlikely Cause Unites the Left and the Right: Justice Reform
text: WASHINGTON — Usually bitter adversaries, Koch Industries and the Center for American Progress have found at least one thing they can agree on: The nation’s criminal justice system is broken.

headline: Faulted for Avoiding ‘Islamic’ Labels to Describe Terrorism, White House Cites a Strategic Logic
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama chooses his words with particular care when he addresses the volatile connections between religion and terrorism. He and his aides have avoided labeling acts of brutal violence by Al Qaeda, the so-called Islamic State and their allies as “Muslim” terrorism or describing their ideology as “Islamic” or “jihadist.”

headline: Focus on Transportation and Justice System in Connecticut Governor’s Budget
text: HARTFORD — Gov. Dannel P. Malloy on Wednesday presented a nearly $40 billion two-year budget that proposes to overhaul the aging transportation infrastructure in Connecticut, cuts the state sales tax and revamps the state’s criminal justice system.

headline: Digital Currency
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — If you’re looking for the Dramamine, it’s right here. Today’s puzzle by Jason Flinn had a few wild loop-de-LOOPS in it but, if you’re reading this, everyone’s stomachs should be settling down by now.

headline: Review: ‘Verité’ With Anna Camp, About a Memoir or a Tale Barely Like It
text: “I doubt my life is so interesting anyone would want to read about it,” says the heroine of “Verité,” a new play by Nick Jones that opened on Wednesday at Lincoln Center’s Claire Tow Theater. The confession seems radical, even heretical in today’s culture, when a book or three, or several seasons of reality television, could conceivably hang on a recalcitrant hangnail. Mr. Jones’s play, a comedy-drama that bleeds uncertainly into dark fantasy, deftly satirizes the mania for memoirs that has felled so many trees and fired up so many Kindles.

headline: ‘Out of My Mouth Comes Unimpeachable Manly Truth’
text: On a cold, sunny New Year’s Eve in 2014, I am sitting at the edge of my king-size bed at the Four Seasons hotel in New York, munching through a stack of Wagyu beef slices and demolishing a bottle of pinot noir while watching a woman play a man playing a bearded woman on Russian state television. Standing on a stage lit by gleaming chandeliers before an audience of Russia’s elite celebrities, the parodist Elena Vorobei sings to the tune of Gloria Gaynor’s “I Will Survive,” in a crude impersonation of Conchita Wurst, the Austrian drag queen who won the 2014 Eurovision song contest. Vorobei is dressed in a sparkling gown, winking cheekily, scratching at her bearded face and swishing her lustrous wig around. “I have a beard!” she belts. At one point she throws out a Hitler salute, a gesture that’s meant to evoke Austria, Conchita’s homeland. The camera pans the laughing audience, cutting for a moment to a well-known actor-singer-writer-bodybuilder and then to one of the show’s M.C.s, Russia’s pop king, the also-bearded Philipp Kirkorov (widely assumed to be gay). The men, who are almost all tanned, in sharply cut suits, grin with unconstrained glee. The bejeweled women wear tight, knowing smiles. Everyone sways and claps.

headline: Hong Kong’s Umbrella Revolution Isn’t Over Yet
text: On the final night of Hong Kong’s largest Occupy camp, a crowd of protesters swelled along an empty highway. It had been 74 days since the first canister of tear gas hit democracy supporters armed with only umbrellas, setting off what the city soon came to call the Umbrella Revolution. It had been more than two months since protesters first sat on that street in their raincoats, sleepless and worried that the military would soon arrive. The fear had now dissipated, and on this cool December evening, the atmosphere was raucous and festive. People filled the empty spaces between tents, spilling out of a metro stop and pouring over concrete barriers with the help of carefully constructed wooden steps. They lined up for free souvenirs — silk-screened T-shirts, leather necklaces, protest stickers — and gathered around microphones for open meetings. They threw glitter and snapped photographs. They sang along to pop songs crooned by a man called Bananaooyoo (now a protest icon whose signature color, like that of the protest itself, is yellow). Archivists removed pieces of artwork for safekeeping, and a few activists hung yellow banners: “We’ll be back.”

headline: ‘Why Not Us Women?’
text: By the time Sgt. Madot Dagbinza showed the photographer Michael Christopher Brown a handful of snapshots, she’d been fighting with the 42nd Commando Battalion of the Armed Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo for four years. A member of an elite unit, the baby-faced soldier in her mid-20s rarely left the front lines where the Congolese military (known as F.A.R.D.C.) was battling the Rwanda-backed rebel group M23.

headline: Richard R. Buery Jr.’s Pre-K Letter
text: A letter from Richard R. Buery, a deputy mayor, that private preschool providers will receive this week.

headline: The National Front’s Post-Charlie Hebdo Moment
text: St.-Raphaël, a resort town on the French Riviera, is subdued in January, suspended in a state of waiting. Its seaside carousel is brilliantly lit but scarcely used, its hotels are mostly shuttered, its streets are nearly deserted by nightfall. On Jan. 16, however, just nine days after French jihadists stormed the Paris offices of the magazine Charlie Hebdo, a crowd gathered in the drizzling rain outside a small St.-Raphaël storefront. In summer days past, the shop sold cheap floppy sun hats to tourists on a table outside, but now a pole with a French flag stood there instead, and a banner had replaced the signs of commerce over the door. The space had been converted into a campaign office for two candidates running for local office, both of whom belonged to the National Front.

headline: Meet the Unlikely Airbnb Hosts of Japan
text: Let me introduce you to Yoppy. Yoppy is young and friendly and lives in a small apartment in the Shinagawa neighborhood of Tokyo. His full name is Yuhsuke Yoshimoto, but at least with visitors who come to stay with him through his listing on Airbnb, he prefers to go by Yoppy. He wears heavy-framed black glasses, has a boyish haircut and likes to talk to foreigners, even though his English is admittedly poor. In the one photo I’ve seen of him — his profile shot on Airbnb — he’s wearing a navy blazer, a collared shirt and a thin silver necklace. He smiles at the camera in a pleasant but not overbearing way. It would be hard, I imagine, not to like Yoppy if you were to meet him at a dinner party or at a gathering of pharmacists or financial planners (according to his profile, Yoppy is both a pharmacist and a financial planner), but still that says little about how you would feel when putting your toothbrush on the sink next to his late at night in a city that’s far, far from home.

headline: New York City Eases Pre-K Rules to Allow Prayer Breaks
text: Starting in September, some children attending taxpayer-funded prekindergarten programs in New York City may have school on Christmas and Thanksgiving. And their school day may be interrupted by a period for religious prayers.

headline: As Bobby Parnell Recovers, Mets Hold His Place
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Bobby Parnell, the Mets’ closer, has had two major operations in the last two seasons: a procedure for a herniated disk in his neck in 2013 and Tommy John surgery in 2014. He has thrown only one inning in about a year and a half. He has sat and watched three young relievers flourish and establish themselves in his absence.

headline: ‘The Media Doesn’t Care What Happens Here’
text: The favelas of Complexo do Alemão, one of the largest urban slums in Brazil, spill across 700 hilly acres in the North Zone of Rio de Janeiro, not far from the city’s international airport. Bounded on three sides by bustling highways and on the fourth by a forested ridge, Alemão can no longer grow outward, and so it has grown upward instead, in increasingly unstable conglomerations of quadruple-decker concrete boxes. “The grandfather builds the first floor, the son the second, the grandson the third and the great-grandson the fourth,” residents like to say. Rebar sprouts from the rooftops, awaiting the installation of the next story and the next generation that will occupy it.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: Paige and Kimberly, Growing Up Too Fast
text: Season 3, Episode 4: “Dimebag”

headline: Behind the Relaunch of The New York Times Magazine
text: Welcome to the new New York Times Magazine. For the past four months, as we’ve been putting out the magazine you read every weekend, we’ve also been busying ourselves behind the scenes, crafting something new and different. It is as if we have been bidding our dinner guests adieu each week, busing the dessert plates and then hurrying out to the garage to tinker with our strange creation under a flickering bulb.

headline: A Family Affair
text: Gianni Piscitelli, a home cook I met on a recent trip to Naples, grew up cooking with his grandmother, Maria d’Orsi, and later with his father, Attilio, in Montesanto, a residential neighborhood of the city. His grandparents were smart: They bought a sprawling place high on a hill with a view of the sea in 1933, when the area was still countryside — a home where the extended family could all live and cook together. What this family has always cooked is the food of Naples. Which is not what I thought it was.

headline: The Visitor
text: A year ago, I was teaching in eastern Thailand, and the dean told me I could have free housing on campus. I went to visit the house. There was a professor living there who was planning to move out. “You won’t be alone,” he said.

headline: Ava DuVernay Didn’t See the Reaction to ‘Selma’ Coming
text: The filmmaker talks with A.O. Scott about the shifting discussion over “Selma.”

headline: The Great Divide
text: In Lahore, Pakistan, the city where I was born and where I once again live after two decades abroad, my experience of picking up my children from school has recently changed. As of this term, I can no longer enter my daughter’s kindergarten. I must show an ID card with her photograph at the fortified gate, a rectangular aperture in a high wall, and she is then brought out to me, emerging like a blue-clad fairy from some strange castle.

headline: ‘Abide’
text: The poet Jake Adam York died of a stroke in 2012, when he was only 40. This poem calls to mind the hymn “Abide With Me,” a prayer for constancy: “In life, in death, O Lord, abide with me.” I have been in a plaintive mood recently, as I remember the many friends I’ve lost over the years, including Jake. When I read the poem now, I am struck by a kind of prescience in the elegiac lines, as if he were speaking his last words to the beloved, knowing how those of us who lost him must now abide. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

headline: How to Cry on Command
text: “If you are happy, having the best day ever, you still have to cry, because that is your job,” says Ana Brenda Contreras, a veteran of Mexican soap operas, or telenovelas. The genre’s operatic plotlines require high-volume, wet-cheeked waterworks, and Contreras, who recently played the lead in 162 episodes of “Corazón Indomable” (“Wild at Heart”), weeps on camera almost every day during production. “TV screens are small — people need to see that tear to feel the emotion,” the 28-year-old actor says.

headline: Re: Eddie Huang
text: “What did I expect?” the author, chef and television host Eddie Huang asked in Wesley Yang’s Feb. 8 profile. “I expected I could change things.” Specifically, Huang — whose memoir, “Fresh Off the Boat,” has been adapted into a sitcom that had its premiere this month on ABC — wants to change pop-culture depictions of Asian-Americans. “Culturally, we’re in an ice age,” he told Yang.

headline: A History of Success, but an Uncertain Future
text: NEWARK — For Jaromir Jagr, the oldest active N.H.L. player, simply suiting up for games is significant.

headline: Why Couldn’t She Stand Up for More Than a Minute?
text: She was dizzy — very dizzy. Doctors couldn’t tell if it was vertigo or lightheadedness.

headline: Can I Ask My Neighbors to Quiet Their Baby?
text: A couple downstairs has started letting their baby cry it out. Having no kids myself, I don’t know if this is a valid parenting strategy. What I do know is that it kept me up for an hour at 2 a.m. last night and has woken me up several times this week. Is it within my rights to talk to them about it? J.B., BROOKLYN

headline: How to Build a Solid Drinking Library
text: Are there places I like as much as great bars? Yes: great bookshops. And if I had to pick a favorite in the latter category, it’s Dog Ears Book Barn in the little town of Hoosick, N.Y. Conveniently, it’s just a little ways down Route 7 from the Man of Kent, one of America’s best bars. A couple of hours spent digging through Dog Ears for treasure, then bringing those books to the Man of Kent and perusing them over a few pints for a few more hours? That’s what I call a perfect day.

headline: Should We Stay, or Should We Go?
text: Say you’re Holly Golightly in hot water with a librarian in “Breakfast at Tiffany’s.” Let’s get out of here. Or you’re Danny in “Grease,” angling to get sweet Sandy alone. Let’s get out of here. Or tragic Jack, aboard the flooding “Titanic”; or Han Solo in “Star Wars,” gagging on Death Star garbage. Let’s get out of here.

headline: A True Picture of Black Skin
text: What comes to mind when we think of photography and the civil rights movement? Direct, viscerally affecting images with familiar subjects: huge rallies, impassioned speakers, people carrying placards (“I Am a Man”), dogs and fire hoses turned on innocent protesters. These photos, as well as the portraits of national leaders like Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X, are explicit about the subject at hand. They tell us what is happening and make a case for why things must change. Our present moment, a time of vigorous demand for equal treatment, evokes those years of sadness and hope in black American life and renews the relevance of those photos. But there are other, less expected images from the civil rights years that are also worth thinking about: images that are forceful but less illustrative.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Fleetwood Mac’s ‘Tusk’
text: There is a species of spider that hunts by releasing chemicals that imitate the sex pheromones of moths. When its prey arrives, high on fantasies of romance, the spider hits it with a sticky blob of web, then devours it. Scientists call this “aggressive mimicry.”

headline: My Dear, Dear, Dear Watson
text: Part of the Internet’s beauty is the space it affords people to take an idea and run with it . . . and run with it and run with it, until they end up miles away from where they started. Among a subset of online superfans of the BBC show “Sherlock,” solving mysteries is mere window dressing for the real story: one about unrequited love between Sherlock Holmes (Benedict Cumberbatch) and Dr. John Watson (Martin Freeman). This sort of wholesale invention, by viewers, of a romance between fictional characters who are not romantically linked on-screen is a form of something known as “shipping” (short for “relationship-ing,” the term can also refer to rooting for actual fictional couples). It is by no means limited to “Sherlock” — any form of pop culture, from “Scandal” to One Direction, is fair game — but that show has inspired vast and vivid fictional worlds, completely imagined by shippers who share screenshots, drawings and even entire books speculating about what a dalliance between Sherlock and Watson (or Johnlock, as it’s known) might look like. These fans wring meaning out of every lingering glance and anguished expression that crosses Cumberbatch’s impressively dimensioned face and superimpose their own dialogue atop these moments, amassing a trove of erotic imaginings that is in some respects more compelling than the canon, at least in the unpredictability of the plot twists. For example, one offshoot of Johnlock, known as Fawnlock, imagines Cumberbatch as an ethereal deer, complete with graceful antlers and a speckled coat — and of course his lover, Watson, cradled in his forelimbs.

headline: Proenza Schouler: Fall 2015 RTW
text: New York

headline: Jon Jerde, Architect of Merging Visions, Dies at 75
text: Jon Jerde, an architect whose designs seized on the human yen to shop, merging the mall and downtown, commercial and public space, and faux environments and real experiences, died on Feb. 9 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 75.

text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

text: migrant • \ˈmi-grənt\ • noun and adjective

headline: Herald Price Fahringer, a Defender of Free Speech, Dies at 87
text: Herald Price Fahringer, an urbane New York lawyer who forswore most vices himself but who, on free speech grounds, gamely defended Larry Flynt and Al Goldstein when they were accused of distributing pornography, and represented other high-profile clients like Claus von Bülow and Jean S. Harris, died on Feb. 12 at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Emails to Florida Reporters Show a Jeb Bush Eager to Engage
text: The email that a Los Angeles Times reporter sent to Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida in April 2006 asked how his early years in Midland, Tex., had shaped him. Attached was an article the reporter had written about the immigration policies of Mr. Bush’s brother, President George W. Bush.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
text: 8:30 P.M. (CBS) THE ODD COUPLE Matthew Perry stars as Oscar Madison, a slovenly sports radio host, and Thomas Lennon is Felix Unger, an avowed neat freak, in this remake of the ’70s Jack Klugman-Tony Randall sitcom about roommates struggling to survive their divorces. Wendell Pierce plays Oscar’s agent; Leslie Bibb lives in their building and is willing to date Oscar, but only for sex; and Lauren Graham is his ex-wife. “The new show updates the surface details without dissolving the central bond between the two friends,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “This is Mr. Perry’s third attempt at sitcom success after a decade on ‘Friends,’ and there is an uneasiness to his performance — in some scenes he looks startled, even frightened — that makes it hard to play off Mr. Lennon, who seems very comfortable as a nervous nelly. That chemistry could come with time, but even if the show flops, it’s an interesting experiment.” In “The Big Bang Theory,” leading in at 8, Wolowitz (Simon Helberg) gets some startling news as the gang prepares to help Stuart (Kevin Sussman) celebrate the reopening of his comic book store. And in the finale of “Two and a Half Men,” at 9, rumor has it that Charlie Harper, the character played by Charlie Sheen, may still be alive.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “You have to understand, I am in pain. My son is gone.”

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: U.S. to Monitor Air Quality in India and Other Countries
text: HONG KONG — The United States says it will expand air-quality monitoring at some overseas diplomatic missions, following several years of reporting pollution data in China.

headline: A Broken Heart, a Child’s Life
text: Martin Lehmann says that between Afghanistan’s war and Thailand’s tsunami, he has photographed “so many dead people you wouldn’t believe it.” Yet nothing has affected him more than Rose, a little girl with “half a heart” who lived in Copenhagen, his hometown.

headline: Good Puzzle News in The New York Times Magazine
text: SPECIAL POST — Good news: Beginning today, the newly redesigned New York Times Magazine has an extra half-page of puzzles, making two pages altogether. The expanded puzzle section will contain three new mini-challenges of various sorts, all in the easy-to-easy/medium range, and all by well-known puzzlemakers. Everything will appear online, too (some of it in the form of PDFs), for Times crossword subscribers.

headline: Changes at the Morgue
text: To the Editor:

headline: How to Hold Colleges Accountable
text: WASHINGTON — THE problems with college are well known. Too many students aren’t learning, don’t finish and fall deeply in debt. What will make college better? Federal officials, who are already alarmed by soaring tuitions, must tackle the mediocre education and outcomes at many schools with similar urgency.

headline: Regulating the Drone Economy
text: Interest in drones has been growing faster than government rules about how they can be used. That’s what makes the Obama administration’s  proposed rules for unmanned aircraft by businesses and federal agencies so important. The measures include many good ideas but do not do enough to protect the privacy of Americans.

headline: Superfluous Selfie Sticks
