text: The New York Times Company announced two new nominees for its board, Dara Khosrowshahi, the chief executive of Expedia, and Rebecca Van Dyck, a Facebook executive, on Thursday.

headline: Long-Term Care Insurance: Costs Are Up but Vary Widely
text: Rates for long-term care insurance, which can help pay for care in your own house or in a nursing home, rose this year an average of nearly 9 percent, a new industry report finds.

headline: Marc Jacobs: Fall 2015 RTW
text: New York

headline: Howard University Fills in Wikipedia’s Gaps in Black History
text: WASHINGTON — Wikipedia is a vast ocean of erudition, with entries on virtually every subject, obscure to earth-shattering, and, it may seem, every human being of even vague renown. It is also, its leaders concede, very white.

headline: Review: ‘Wild Tales’ Explores the Blurred Limits of Morality
text: As high-spirited as its title suggests, “Wild Tales” opens on a savage note and ends, well, that’s for you to find out. In between its shocker start and equally startling windup, this Argentine anthology offers up a scabrous, often unsettlingly funny look at human behavior in extremis. It’s a mad, mad social Darwinian world, churning with men and women who, whether pushed a lot or just a little, are all eager to do the worst to one another. They pounce and then they pummel, engaging in drag-down fights that leave them black and blue and sometimes stone-cold dead.

headline: For Nascar Drivers, Switching Teams Has Paid Off Before
text: When Kyle Busch was dropped by Hendrick Motorsports after 2007 and signed to race for Joe Gibbs Racing, few could have predicted what happened next. Busch went from one win with Hendrick in 2007 to eight victories with Gibbs in 2008.

headline: Review: ‘All the Wilderness,’ a Tale of a Teenage Outsider
text: The kind of kid who’s a dinner bell for bullies, James (Kodi Smit-McPhee), the gangly antihero of “All the Wilderness,” wears the teenage-misfit badge on his bony frame like a romantic totem. A recent tragedy has exacerbated James’s already ingrowing personality, and now his quirks — quoting Carl Sandburg; drawing pictures of dead houseflies — have acquired a morbid cast that neither his therapist (Danny DeVito) nor his concerned single mother (Virginia Madsen) can pierce.

headline: In Turkey, Even Snow Can Be Tainted by Politics
text: ISTANBUL — “You are free to throw snowballs at this window,” the signs say in the Kadikoy district on the Asian side of Istanbul, and not because the shopkeepers here love the sound of breaking glass.

headline: Review: In ‘Approaching the Elephant,’ an Experimental Classroom Jungle
text: In “Approaching the Elephant,” the director Amanda Rose Wilder embeds herself in a tiny New Jersey “free school” that practices a style of self-directed learning, an idea originated by anarchists in Barcelona in the 1900s. Her film invites questions about what makes good schooling, or a strong documentary, but she seems most enamored by what children do, period.

headline: Review: In ‘The DUFF,’ a Wounded Teenage Girl Combats Mockery
text: Adapted from a novel by Kody Keplinger, whose website says that she wrote the book as a senior in high school, “The DUFF” begins, in an apparent nod to “The Breakfast Club,” by informing us that teenage stereotypes have changed: “Jocks play video games, princesses are on antidepressants.” You could have fooled these characters, who ruthlessly enforce the traditional pecking order.

headline: Moves Don’t Get Knicks and Nets Too Far
text: It was one of the wildest N.B.A. trade deadline days in recent memory, with 11 transactions taking place across the league before the 3 p.m. cutoff time, and both New York teams had a small hand in it.

headline: Iraqi Assault to Retake Mosul From Islamic State Is Planned for Spring
text: WASHINGTON — The assault to retake Mosul, Iraq, from the Islamic State will require 20,000 to 25,000 Iraqi and Kurdish troops and is expected to begin in April or May, an official from the United States Central Command told reporters on Thursday.

headline: Review: ‘Kung Fu Elliot’ Documentary Follows a Martial Arts Enthusiast
text: Matthew Bauckman and Jaret Belliveau’s gritty documentary, “Kung Fu Elliot,” feels at first as if it’s gently parodying a “making of” movie. Its subject, Elliot Scott, is a quirky, sweet-faced martial arts enthusiast and filmmaker from Nova Scotia who hopes to become, he says, “Canada’s first action hero.” Hey, everyone needs a hobby.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Inevitability: This Time Is Different
text: Whenever I mention that Hillary Clinton is an overwhelming favorite for the Democratic nomination — and would be even if Senator Elizabeth Warren ran — the conversation usually comes back to 2008. “She was supposed to be inevitable last time,” the refrain goes, “and she lost.”

headline: Addressing Dysfunction, Port Authority Plans to Install ‘Nonpolitical’ C.E.O.
text: For decades, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has been a house divided, an agency overseen by people who owed loyalty to one governor or another. The internal division often devolved into dysfunction and has occasionally led to misfeasance, such as the move in 2013 to close some traffic lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge.

headline: Utilities Push Into Fuel Stations for Electric Cars
text: Since hitting the mass market about five years ago, electric vehicles have failed to take off, largely, experts say, because a robust network of public charging stations has not been built.

headline: India Deploys Expert Teams to Study Rise in Flu Cases
text: JAIPUR, India — Indian officials this week scrambled to cope with a rise in cases of the flu, which they say has sickened thousands of people and caused the deaths of 700 since the beginning of January.

headline: N.F.L. Teams With Eye to Future Train a Lens on Marcus Mariota
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Inside a luxurious lounge that had been transformed into an area filled with cameras, laptops and seemingly endless ropes of cable cords at Lucas Oil Stadium, Marcus Mariota faced a line of questioning that ended with his being asked whether he possessed the skills to succeed in the N.F.L.

headline: Giuliani: Obama Had a White Mother, So I’m Not a Racist
text: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York on Thursday defended his assertion that President Obama did not love America, and said that his criticism of Mr. Obama’s upbringing should not be considered racist because the president was raised by “a white mother.”

headline: Turkey: Deal Set to Aid Syrian Rebels
text: After months of talks, Turkey and the United States on Thursday signed an agreement to train and equip moderate Syrian rebels to fight militants from the Islamic State, Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu said, according to the Anadolu News Agency. Mr. Cavusoglu also suggested that the fighters could join the rebellion against the Syrian government, although American officials have emphasized that the primary goal is to combat the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL. Turkey, along with Jordan and Saudi Arabia, will provide training sites for the program, which is scheduled to begin in March and is expected to train about 15,000 fighters over three years, Turkish and American officials have said. The United States has said that it plans to send about 400 soldiers and other military personnel to train the fighters.

headline: Ideology Seen as Factor in Closings in University of North Carolina System
text: An advisory panel of the University of North Carolina’s Board of Governors has recommended closing three academic centers, including a poverty center and one dedicated to social change, inciting outrage among liberals who believe that conservatives in control of state government are targeting ideological opponents in academia.

headline: After Shake-Up Last Year, Sanofi Names New Chief
text: The French pharmaceutical giant Sanofi on Thursday named Olivier Brandicourt, a top executive at Bayer, as its new chief executive, replacing Christopher A. Viehbacher, who was fired in October.

headline: F.B.I. Chief Not Invited to Meeting on Countering Violent Extremism
text: WASHINGTON — The White House did not invite the most senior American official charged with preventing terrorist attacks — the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey — to the three-day conference this week on countering violent extremism in the United States and abroad because the administration did not want the event too focused on law enforcement issues, according to senior American officials.

headline: Yann Demange, Director of ’71,’ Poised for Cinematic Breakout
text: PARK CITY, UTAH — By his own admission, the director Yann Demange has a fetish for darkness. Night photography, urban decay, ghostly sodium lighting — he incorporated it all into his debut feature, “ ’71,” set in that tumultuous year in Belfast during the Troubles, as the conflict in Northern Ireland was known.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Traffic Law Vilifies Bus Drivers, Union Says
text: A new law penalizing drivers who fail to yield and injure or kill a pedestrian who has the right of way is a central piece of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan to eliminate traffic deaths. But the arrest last week of a bus driver who struck a 15-year-old girl angered union officials, who sent a memo to members this week warning that bus drivers were under attack and were being treated like “criminals.”

headline: The Man Who Knows Too Much
text: LOS ANGELES — The first mistake, ordering tickets a day in advance, left 24 hours for the second: telling anyone in this town you’re seeing “The Judge.”

headline: New Details Revealed in Shooting by Police in Washington State
text: New details emerged Thursday about the fatal police shooting of a man in Pasco, Wash., that was captured on video and has resulted in local and federal investigations.

headline: ‘In the Land of the Head Hunters,’ a Recreated Artifact of Ancient Ways
text: “In the Land of the Head Hunters,” out on Blu-ray and DVD from Milestone, is the reconstruction of a reconstruction. It preserves an artifact that used a once advanced technology to document a no longer extent way of life, and was itself all but lost to history.

headline: Apple Is Forming an Auto Team
text: SAN FRANCISCO — While Apple has been preparing to release its first wearable computers, the company has also been busy assembling a team to work on an automobile.

headline: Awarded Stolen Wages, Workers Struggle to Collect
text: After due consideration of records and testimony, the State of New York found that Marco Lino, who chopped vegetables and mopped floors and hoisted crates six days a week in a Bayside, Queens, greenmarket, was owed $51,025.20 in unpaid wages. For Gregoria Geronomina Jimenez and 34 other workers at three restaurants in Upper Manhattan run by the same owners, the Industrial Board of Appeals ruled that $385,364.34 in earnings had not been paid over four years. Jin Ming Cao, a waiter at a Chinese restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, was underpaid by $142,812.05, part of $1.8 million that a federal judge decided was due to 26 employees of that restaurant and two others run by the same people.

headline: N.J.I.T. Will Get an Arena, but It Still Needs a Home
text: For a man who was dealing with no heat upstairs and frozen pipes in his basement at home, Lenny Kaplan was remarkably upbeat on Thursday.

headline: Roger’s Cousin
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — It’s not often that a constructor expresses his regrets so clearly in a crossword puzzle, but today we need to lend some support to David Woolf, who is rethinking his avocation of choice.

headline: New York City and State Officials Joining Forces to Combat Tenant Harassment
text: With tenant harassment complaints against landlords on the rise, New York City and state officials announced on Thursday the creation of a multiagency task force aimed at weeding out and punishing bad landlords.

headline: Jerome Kersey, Stalwart of Top Trail Blazers Teams, Dies at 52
text: Jerome Kersey, a hard-working forward from a small college who overachieved in pro basketball, starting on two Portland Trail Blazers teams that reached the N.B.A. finals, died on Wednesday in Tualatin, Ore., near Portland. He was 52.

headline: In Hearing, Judge Revisits a 1990 Killing on a Subway Platform
text: The victim was a tourist from Utah, and his murder on a Manhattan subway platform seized the city in a way that few killings of the era did. Now, almost 25 years after the man, Brian Watkins, was stabbed to death, the case is back in State Supreme Court.

headline: Owner of the Colts Pays Six Figures for a Les Paul Six-String
text: The owner and chief executive of the Indianapolis Colts — who has a collection of guitars that were played by the likes of Bob Dylan, Jerry Garcia and Elvis Presley — added another on Thursday night, a 60-year-old electric guitar that some musicians say occupies an important place in guitar history.

headline: Never an Islander, Eric Nystrom Returns Home to Nassau Coliseum
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Skating at Nassau Coliseum without igniting a flood of memories is most likely impossible for the Long Island native Eric Nystrom of the Nashville Predators, the N.H.L.’s best team.

headline: Plaques, Yes. Pennants, No.
text: A busy year at Monument Park once meant adding one or two plaques to its walls. And every so often, a Yankee uniform number would be retired.

headline: F.D.A. Reverses Course on 23andMe DNA Test in Move to Ease Restrictions
text: The genetic testing company 23andMe on Thursday took a step toward being able to offer consumers health-related information again, winning approval from the Food and Drug Administration for a test for mutations that cause a rare disease.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 19, 2015
Driver Faces Life Sentence in Crash That Killed Expectant Brooklyn Couple
text: A man accused of plowing his car into a livery cab carrying a pregnant Orthodox woman and her husband, killing the Brooklyn couple and their newborn son, was convicted Thursday of second-degree manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide, prosecutors said.

headline: Harris Wittels, Television Comedy Writer, Is Dead at 30
text: Harris Wittels, a producer and writer for the NBC sitcom “Parks and Recreation” who also performed as a stand-up comic and musician, died on Thursday. He was 30.

headline: Rangers, Again Prolific Late in Game, Are Beaten at Their Own Game
text: The Rangers were unbeaten on a four-game trip, scoring 11 third-period goals, including three in a come-from-behind 6-5 win over the Islanders on Monday.

headline: Illinois: Cubs Allowed to Continue Renovations
text: The Chicago Cubs can proceed with a construction project at Wrigley Field, a federal judge ruled Thursday, but the project’s future remains uncertain as a lawsuit continues by property owners who say the renovations will block their views of the stadium. Owners of properties across the street from the outfield have long sold tickets to spectators who watch from their rooftops. Some owners have argued in federal court that a renovation project underway at the stadium, which includes large signs that would be placed in the outfield, violates a contract between them and the team. Judge Virginia M. Kendall of United States District Court in Chicago said Thursday that she did not have the evidence needed for a temporary restraining order to stop construction, as the rooftop owners requested. Both sides will be back in court next month for a hearing on a preliminary injunction that could derail the renovations. “We’ve got Opening Day on April 5,” Judge Kendall said. “I’m going to get my job done before then.”

headline: Big Hello for the Year of the Yang
text: The Hung Sing Kwoon Kung Fu and Lion Dance Club stopped at Jade Asian Restaurant in Flushing, Queens, on Thursday to celebrate the Chinese Lunar New Year, symbolized this year by a zodiac animal whose Mandarin name, yang, is translated into English variously as sheep, goat or ram.

headline: New York City Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Are Suspended Through Saturday
text: Because of snow cleanup, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday and Saturday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel: The Artist That Never Was
text: In this new series for T, notables from the worlds of fashion, art, design and entertainment illustrate their responses to a brief questionnaire, revealing their favorite things, darkest secrets — and how they see themselves and the world around them.

headline: The Art and Allure of Marc Jacobs’s Dramatic Stage Sets
text: New York’s fall/winter 2015 Fashion Week went out on a high note, as per usual, with Marc Jacobs’s presentation at the Park Avenue Armory last night. As big a draw as the clothes (a darkly opulent ode to Diana Vreeland) and the people-watching (Nicki Minaj and Deborah Harry sat front-row) was the set: a Stefan Beckman-designed backdrop inspired by Jeremiah Goodman paintings of Vreeland’s famous red room, the latest in a series of immersive — and sometimes provocative — installations. Here, a look back at some of the brand’s other memorable set designs.

headline: Word of the Day | clout
text: clout • \ˈklau̇t\ • noun and verb

headline: What’s on TV Friday
text: 8 A.M. (CUNY) A TIMESTALKS CONVERSATION: DAVID CARR INTERVIEWS LAURA POITRAS, GLENN GREENWALD AND EDWARD J. SNOWDEN On Feb. 12 Mr. Carr, who wrote about media for The New York Times, sat down at the New School with Ms. Poitras, the Oscar-nominated director of the documentary “Citizenfour,” about Mr. Snowden, the National Security Agency whistle-blower; Mr. Greenwald, the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist who first wrote about Mr. Snowden’s revelations; and Mr. Snowden himself, who joined the discussion via a video link from Russia. Mr. Carr died later that night. (Repeats at 4 and 9 p.m.) In “Science Goes to the Movies,” a new series at 7:30 p.m., Faith Salie, an NPR host, and Heather Berlin, a neuroscientist, dissect the science portrayed in some current films, starting with hallucinations in “Birdman,” black holes and gravity in “Interstellar” and the work of the theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking in “The Theory of Everything.” Emily Rice, an astrophysicist with the Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History, weighs in.

headline: Slowly Learning to Fill Big Shoes
text: Bol Bol, Manute Bol’s 15-year-old son, carries high expectations as he begins to navigate high school basketball in suburban Kansas.

headline: Corrections: February 20, 2015
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “If I talk to him for an hour, they undo him in two hours.”

headline: Girls, Math and Science
text: To the Editor:

headline: Our Remaining Days
text: To the Editor:

headline: Guns on Campus?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Plot to Kill Health Care
text: Republicans hate activist judges — those black-robed elites who are willing to upset the lives of millions of people just to further a political cause. Ditto trial lawyers trolling for clients, the ambulance-chasing, “Better Call Saul” guys. They hate them, until they need them.

headline: Cranking Up for 2016
text: Scott Walker, the governor of Wisconsin, is said to be a rising contender for the Republican presidential nomination. So, on Wednesday, he did what, these days, any ambitious Republican must, and pledged allegiance to charlatans and cranks.

headline: Helping to Heal the Trauma of War
Separate Philanthropy From Political Clout
text: The Clinton Foundation has become one of the world’s major generators of charity, mobilizing global efforts to confront issues like health, climate change, economic development and equality for women and girls.

headline: In Boston, 50 Shades of White Snow
text: BROOKLINE, Mass. — THE first snow day was perfect. My husband and I lay in bed in January and watched the falling snow cover trash cans and quince bushes and pine trees alike, a democratizing force on the landscape. Downstairs, our three kids watched cartoons (or pretty much whatever they wanted) and raided the usually off-limits snack shelf.

headline: When Americans Lynched Mexicans
text: THE recent release of a landmark report on the history of lynching in the United States is a welcome contribution to the struggle over American collective memory. Few groups have suffered more systematic mistreatment, abuse and murder than African-Americans, the focus of the report.

headline: Indonesia’s Corruption Fighters in the Fight of Their Lives
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Over the past decade, Indonesia was so determined to erase the tainted legacy of Suharto, the strongman forced to resign in 1998, that it established one of the world’s more effective anticorruption agencies. Now the future of that agency, the Corruption Eradication Commission, known as the K.P.K., is under serious threat in a standoff with the police and President Joko Widodo.

headline: Boston’s Winter From Hell
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — BY now you’ve seen the starkly beautiful shots of Boston buried under snow: the panoramic city under a white blanket; snowbanks so high they crest over parked cars; piercing icicles glinting for two full stories from gutters dammed with ice; coat-muffled people dwarfed by snow-walled corridors that once were sidewalks.

headline: Empathy, not Expulsion, for Preschoolers at Risk
text: CHICAGO — A few years ago, a boy here was on the verge of being expelled because his teacher felt he was a danger to his classmates.

headline: The Nationalist Solution
text: The struggle against Islamic extremism has been crippled by a failure of historical awareness and cultural understanding. From the very beginning, we have treated the problem of terrorism through the prism of our own assumptions and our own values. We have solipsistically assumed that people turn to extremism because they can’t get what we want, and fail to realize that they don’t want what we want, but want something they think is higher.

headline: Test Yourself | An Apology Letter From Alex Rodriguez
text: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 17 article, “Exchanging Sword for Pen, Rodriguez Apologizes to Yankees and Fans.”

headline: Man Group to Buy London-Based Investment Manager
text: LONDON — The British hedge fund company Man Group continued its recent spending spree on Friday, reaching a conditional agreement to acquire the investment management business of NewSmith. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The Year of the Goat
text: To mark the beginning of the Year of the Goat (or is it the sheep?), we pose questions that link to a variety of Times articles from the past and present, as well as to outside resources. Use this collection to teach students about the holiday and its cultural significance and traditions.

headline: Is the Minimum Wage Too Low?
text: About half of all workers in the United States who are at or below the federal minimum wage of $7.25 an hour are ages 16 to 24. Would a higher minimum wage help young people get ahead? Would it help lift families out of poverty? Or would it unintentionally have the opposite effect by dampening hiring? Economists disagree about the effects of a higher minimum wage. What do you think?

headline: Children, Caged for Effect, to Mimic Imagery of ISIS
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The killings have been both deliberately lurid and strangely intimate. Designed for broadcast, they have helped the Islamic State militant group build a brand of violence that shocks with its extreme brutality, yet feels as close to viewers as the family images on their smartphones.

headline: At New York Private Schools, Challenging White Privilege From the Inside
text: On a recent morning, 20 or so high school students, most of them white, milled about the meetinghouse at Friends Seminary, a private school in Manhattan. They were trying to unload on their classmates slips of paper on which they had jotted down words related to the topic “Things I don’t want to be called.”

headline: Mariam Ghani, a Brooklyn Artist Whose Father Leads Afghanistan
text: Mariam Ghani’s apartment is a map to her layered identity.

headline: Looking Back With Intensity
text: Shalmon Bernstein arrived in the New York magazine world in the early 1970s with a fully developed eye, a clear, sober voice and a sense of purpose. “I thought in terms of being able to change people’s perceptions,” he said. Then, a decade later, he simply stopped, for reasons that even now are hard for him to explain. “What made me stop?” he asked the other day from his home in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. “What was more important to me?” Money was a part of it, he said. But looking back now, he saw another force at work.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Feb. 20
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images from Chinese New Year and Niagara Falls.

headline: Internet Taxes, Another Window Into the Net Neutrality Debate
text: In a rare act of bipartisan unity, Republican and Democratic senators last week presented legislation that would permanently ban taxes on high-speed Internet service to American homes.

headline: Punch Lines and Laughs as TV Show in Vietnam Mocks Government Policy
text: HANOI, Vietnam — The Kitchen Gods were asked by the emperor’s assistant: “What curves gently?”

headline: J. W. Anderson: Clear Desks, Full Days
text: In episode two of our “In the Studio” series, we go inside the workspace of Jonathan Anderson, the 30-year-old British designer behind J. W. Anderson, to discuss the need for efficiency, the difference an LVMH investment makes and the problem with desks (among other burning questions that did not make the final cut). This conversation has been condensed and edited.

headline: Eurozone Economy Gains Momentum, Survey of Private Sector Shows
text: PARIS — The eurozone economy perked up again this month, a private sector report showed on Friday, powered by continuing strength in Germany and surprisingly strong growth in France.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Student Crossword | Virus Outbreaks
text: Test your knowledge of virus outbreaks by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: New York’s Forecast: Rising Seas, Continual Heat Waves, and a Little Hope
text: As you went spelunking through snowdrifts in recent days, pondering the moral necessity of pet-friendly ice melt and perhaps noting in horror the story of a Manhattan woman who froze to death hiking in subzero New Hampshire temperatures over the weekend, you were thinking about the future, defined in the moment as July. City functionaries were looking further ahead to a potentially more “Hunger Games” epoch.

headline: Fears Persist That Violence Against Albinos in Tanzania Will Grow
text: The boy was just a year old when five men with machetes snatched him from his home. Two days later, the police found his body with the arms and legs lopped off.

headline: New York Today: The Lunar New Year, in Pictures
text: Good morning on this frigid Friday.

headline: Daily Report: A Boom in Technology Investments in Hunt for Next Blockbuster Company
text: What a difference a year makes, Michael J. de la Merced and Mike Isaac report.

headline: Raul Rodriguez, Who Showered Rose Parade With Bouquets on Wheels, Dies at 71
text: Raul Rodriguez, who designed more than 500 floral floats for the Tournament of Roses Parade and conceived dazzling confections for other private and public celebrations around the world, died on Wednesday at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 71.

headline: Today in Politics
text: Giuliani Counters Criticism of Obama Comments: ‘This Isn’t Racism’

headline: GFI Group’s Board to Support BGC Partners Takeover Bid
text: The board of the GFI Group, the New York brokerage and clearing house, threw its support on Friday behind a takeover bid by BGC Partners after shareholders rejected a tie-up with the CME Group last month.

headline: Ask Well: Sick With Two Kinds of Flu?
text: Question:

headline: Emerging From a Father’s 7-Foot-6 Shadow
text: ROELAND PARK, Kan. — It is not by happenstance that toy basketball hoops are scattered about the house of 15-year-old Bol Bol, or that his bedroom in the basement is home to about 40 pairs of basketball shoes. His love for the game was passed down by his father, Manute Bol, the 7-foot-6 shot blocker whose impossibly long arms and lighthouse smile made him a fan favorite for 10 N.B.A. seasons before he died in 2010.

headline: With High-Profile Departure, Kerry’s Team Faces a Transition
text: The departure of Jen Psaki, the State Department spokeswoman, is only part of a larger transition for Secretary of State John Kerry and his team two years into his tenure.

headline: Morning Agenda: Markets Await Greek Deal
text: MARKETS AWAIT GREEK DEAL | Uncertainty over the outcome of negotiations between Greece and its European creditors made for nervous markets on Friday morning, as shares in Europe eased off seven-year highs. Germany rejected Greece’s formal request on Thursday to extend its loan program by six months, with one German official describing the Athens proposal as “a Trojan horse, intending to get bridge financing and in substance putting an end to the current program,” according to a Greek government official. Eurozone finance ministers will try again on Friday to break an impasse over Greece’s need for further financing.

headline: The Unsinkable R.B.G.
text: RUTH BADER GINSBURG isn’t planning on going anywhere any time soon.

headline: Kevin Spacey, Star of ‘House of Cards’ and a Bromance With Bill Clinton
text: Before Kevin Spacey got into character as Francis Underwood, the fictional congressman who by the third season of “House of Cards” has murdered and manipulated his way into the Oval Office, he liked to portray a real-life president: Bill Clinton.

headline: Daily Clip Report
text: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Q. and A.: Barnett Rubin on China’s Role in Afghanistan
text: In recent months, China has made pronouncements that reveal it is willing, perhaps even eager, to grow its engagement with troubled Afghanistan, whose remote Wakhan Corridor abuts China’s western border. On Feb. 12, while visiting Pakistan, Foreign Minister Wang Yi reiterated China’s desire to play a “constructive role” in a hypothetical peace process.

headline: Eurozone Officials Reach Accord With Greece to Extend Bailout
text: BRUSSELS — Ending an acrimonious standoff, European leaders hashed out a deal on Friday to extend Greece’s bailout by four months, giving the troubled country a financial lifeline and avoiding a bankruptcy with potentially destabilizing consequences for the region.

headline: An Engineer Creates for Fun After a Lifetime of Workaday Rules
text: I don’t need your rockin’ chair,

headline: Giuliani Comments Draw Tweets From Martina Navratilova, Judd Apatow and Others
text: In the rapid-response world of social media, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York caught fire this morning. By defending his assertion that President Obama does not love America — and by arguing that his criticism of Mr. Obama’s upbringing should not be considered racist because the president was raised by “a white mother” — he has attracted an array of commentary from prominent figures in the worlds of sports, media, movies and, of course, politics.

headline: A Helping Hand (and a Forklift)
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Home Shrunken Home
text: For most single New Yorkers, the tyranny of living in a small space, or worse, a shared space, is all too familiar.

headline: Mystery Solved: The Man Behind a G.O.P. Trend-Setting Poll
text: The source of the extensive, private polling data on the 2016 Republican presidential field was shrouded in secrecy. But its conclusions were widely felt.

headline: Citi’s Mexico Chief to Retire After Rough Year of Scandals
text: The chairman of Citigroup’s Mexico operations, Manuel Medina-Mora, is retiring in June, after a tumultuous year at one of the bank’s most profitable units.

headline: Chip Maker to Investigate Claims of Hacking by N.S.A. and British Spy Agencies
text: LONDON — Gemalto, a French-Dutch digital security company, said on Friday that it was investigating a possible hacking by United States and British intelligence agencies that may have given them access to worldwide mobile phone communications.

headline: Obama Asserts G.O.P.’s Actions Fail to Match Its Words
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama ridiculed Republicans on Friday, describing them as seeking to mimic the Democratic Party’s message to the middle class even as they pursue policies that enrich the wealthy.

headline: Midtown Condo, Brooklyn ‘Lab’
text: In an industrial section of Sunset Park, Brooklyn, where the street ends at the waterfront, an unassuming door opens to a cold and cavernous warehouse. There, beyond a labyrinth of boxes and dark hallways, lies an unexpected piece of Midtown Manhattan: a full-scale mock-up of a $10 million apartment planned for 53W53, an ultraluxury residential tower being built next to the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Reading Restaurant Wine Lists, for Blockbusters and Values
text: THE chief executive who oversees one of the world’s most highly sought Tuscan wines was in New York this month, trying to persuade people to buy one of his less expensive brands, something that would seem counter to his interests.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Marc Jacobs Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: What’s On This Week Around the World
text: Krakow, Poland

headline: Muslim Scholar, Looking to ‘Speak the Truth,’ Teaches the Holocaust and Islam
text: Early in the summer of 2007, a doctoral student named Mehnaz M. Afridi traveled from her California home to a conference in southern Germany. Her official role was to deliver a paper on anti-Semitism in Egyptian literature, a rather loaded subject for a Muslim scholar. Seventy miles away, she had another appointment, and an even riskier agenda.

headline: How to Fill Out Your Oscar Ballot
text: We at The Upshot have entered our share of friendly Oscar pools over the years. We’ve done so even in years when we have not seen many of the nominated movies. If you find yourself in that position this year — or if you have seen a lot of movies but still aren’t sure how to fill out your ballot — we’re here to help.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Marc Jacobs Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: Bush or Christie in 2016? Giuliani Says He Hasn’t Decided
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has made headlines this week for comments he made about President Obama’s fealty to America, is uncertain about whom he will support to replace the president in 2016.

headline: 1915: Dardanelles Forts Bombarded
text: LONDON — The Admiralty announces that yesterday [Feb. 19] morning a British fleet of battleships and battle cruisers accompanied by flotillas and aided by a strong French squadron, the whole under the command of Vice-Admiral Sackville Hamilton Carden, began an attack upon the forts at the entrance of the Dardanelles. The forts at Cape Helles and Kum Kale were bombarded with deliberate long-range fire. Considerable effect was produced on two of the forts, and two others were frequently hit, but, being open earthworks, it was difficult to estimate the damage. The forts, being outranged, were not able to reply to the fire.

headline: Europe Needs To Stop The Clock
text: I’ve been in correspondence with various people trying to track the current Greece/euro crisis, and everyone seems to have reached the same conclusion I’ve reached — namely, that what’s needed above all right now is some way to stop the clock, call a time-out, whatever. We’re talking about weeks, maybe a month or two — but that pause is desperately needed, because otherwise it will be all too easy to stumble into a preventable disaster.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Frederique Morrel Brings French Whimsy to Bergdorf Goodman
text: “My inspiration is life and all its aspects,” says the designer and artist Frédérique Morrel. That may sound like a particularly broad subject matter, but Morrel’s work, which is crafted by covering three-dimensional objects with vintage tapestries, does have an all-encompassing approach to its pastoral aesthetic. And beginning today, her newest pieces will be on view at Bergdorf Goodman’s 5th Avenue flagship store in New York — the result of an exclusive partnership with the department store (“We share the same values of exclusivity, rarity and the love of well done savoir-faire,” she says). The shoppable exhibition (prices range from $900 to $120,000) also marks her U.S. debut.

headline: London Fashion Week: J. JS Lee Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Hot Tub Time Machine 2,’ ‘McFarland, USA’ and ‘Wild Tales’
text: In this video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Hot Tub Time Machine 2,” “McFarland, USA” and “Wild Tales.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: 1940: Sweden Divided Over Aid to Finland
text: STOCKHOLM — The domestic situation in Sweden tonight [Feb. 20] was tense as the result of King Gustav’s refusal to give military aid to Finland. Despite the King’s effort to keep Sweden at peace, as he has during the thirty-three years of his own reign and as it has been kept during more than a century, the undertone of discontent over official aloofness in the aggression on Finland was distinctly audible.

headline: London Fashion Week: J. JS Lee Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Chastened Exceptionalism
text: Jamelle Bouie has a very good article responding to Rudy Giulani’s attack on Obama’s patriotism, making the point that Obama, while clearly deeply patriotic, does talk about America a bit differently from his predecessors.

headline: Britain and Europe ‘Sleepwalked’ Into the Ukraine Crisis, Report Says
text: LONDON — Britain and the European Union made a “catastrophic misreading” of Russia and President Vladimir V. Putin and “sleepwalked” into the Ukraine crisis, treating it as a trade issue rather than as a delicate foreign-policy challenge, British lawmakers said Friday in a scathing report.

headline: The Lively Look of Green Chorizo
text: Chorizo sausage can be many things, but I did not realize that one of them was green.

headline: The Zen of Plane Crashes
text: Late in 2012, Allan Lokos, who founded the Community Meditation Center in New York, had to put his meditation and stress-management techniques to the test in a dire situation: The plane on which Mr. Lokos, his wife and 69 other passengers were traveling crashed in Myanmar.

headline: U.S. Agency Sets Fines for Maker of Airbags
text: In an escalating standoff with Takata, federal regulators said on Friday that they would begin to fine the Japanese auto supplier $14,000 a day, saying it had not fully cooperated in an investigation into defective airbags.

headline: Tax Error in Health Act Has Impact on 800,000
text: WASHINGTON — About 800,000 taxpayers who enrolled in insurance policies through HealthCare.gov received erroneous tax information from the government and were urged on Friday to hold off on filing tax returns until the error could be corrected.

headline: Snow Blankets Holy Sites in Jerusalem
text: A heavy snowstorm blanketed the city with a rare layer of white, covering landmarks with several inches of snow.

headline: Mayor’s Arrest on Sedition Charges Deepens Sense of Crisis in Venezuela
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The abrupt arrest of the mayor of Caracas on accusations that he had plotted an American-backed overthrow of the government threatened to plunge Venezuela into new political convulsions on Friday, as his supporters rallied in the capital and pockets of protest erupted elsewhere.

headline: New York in a Deep Freeze as Frigid Air Descends on the Nation
text: From frosty orange groves in Florida to the frozen waters of Niagara Falls, nearly half the nation was plunged into a deep freeze on Friday morning.

headline: How a Friendship Built in Europe Turned Fatal in Queens
text: For William Klinger, Queens was the dream. There, life would be free of the frustrations he had known in Italy, where a stalled academic career had left him working in a highway tollbooth.

headline: A Second Chance to Avoid a Second Tax Penalty Over Obamacare
text: About six million people face a tax penalty this year for failing to sign up for health insurance last year. Now, many of those people will get an extra chance to enroll in coverage for this year and avoid a second penalty.

headline: Eavesdropping on the Seventh Grade ‘Instagram Show’
text: I may be a little too interested in my seventh grader’s Instagram account. It’s a peephole into the social lives of her classmates. It’s a juicy new reality show: “The Private Lives of Private School Pubescents.” Until it all turned sour, my daughter and I would snuggle up around the iPhone and watch what we called “The Instagram Show,” starring the boys and girls we’ve known since kindergarten.

headline: ‘Khirbet Khizeh,’ by S. Yizhar
text: Nearly 70 years ago, an intelligence officer with the newly formed state of Israel moved with a group of soldiers into a Palestinian village whose women, children and old people were rounded up, herded into trucks and sent across the border. The village was demolished to make way for the new Jewish state. The deportation was a small piece of the Palestinian exodus — some of it at gunpoint, some of it not — that accompanied the upheavals of the birth of Israel in 1947 and 1948.

headline: Scouting Teams’ Biggest Holes as N.F.L. Combine Begins
text: The N.F.L.’s scouting combine moves to on-field drills Friday, and as with every other year, an event where no football is played will heavily influence draft decisions based on various measurements that may not translate to on-field success. The 40-yard dash in particular has a tendency to send some prospects soaring and others reeling. For every Kyle Boller who runs his way into being a first-round pick, there are players like NaVorro Bowman who see their stock tumble when their feet prove a bit slow.

headline: What If We Lost the Sky?
text: What is the sky worth?

headline: Bombing in Somalia Capital Kills at Least 10 People, and the Shabab Claims Responsibility
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — About 10 people were killed Friday and a dozen more wounded, including several government officials and lawmakers, when two explosions ripped through the entrance of a hotel in the Somali capital, officials said. The Shabab, an Islamist rebel group, claimed responsibility.

headline: Superfandom
text: A subset of online superfans of the BBC show “Sherlock,” imagine unrequited love between Sherlock Holmes (Benedict Cumberbatch) and Dr. John Watson (Martin Freeman).

headline: Appraising Solar Energy’s Value
text: New research sponsored by the Department of Energy shows that buyers are willing to pay more for homes with rooftop solar panels — a finding that may strengthen the case for factoring the value of sustainable features into home appraisals.

headline: What’s Next for Jon Stewart? Blogging. Or Maybe Not.
text: Jon Stewart may not be on our televisions for much longer, but his appearance Thursday night before a packed house at Joe’s Pub on “Employee of the Month”, Catie Lazarus’s long-running talk show, gives hope that he’ll be seen around town a bit more.

headline: Seems Like Old Times for Distillers and Bourbon
text: WASHINGTON — At 80, Jimmy Russell finds his knees are not quite what they used to be. So he enjoys a comfortable chair where his admirers — millennial mixologists, their arms covered in tattoos; moneyed moms who have jettisoned their cosmopolitans for manhattans; and random professionals toting rare bottles of Wild Turkey — may approach to greet him.

headline: A Thankless Task
text: “A few inquiries remain unanswered. I would still be delighted to hear from: David Cesarani, Liane Dirks (on Polityka), Guido Knopp (on sources), Jörg Müll­ner (on the sound editing of the tapes) and Time Inc.” — Bettina Stangneth, writing in the acknowledgments section of “Eichmann Before Jerusalem.”

headline: A Tour for Introverts: Landmarks and Alone Time
text: For introverts, group travel can be a noisy, rushed, herd-mentality experience of interacting with strangers on a daily basis: a draining, not relaxing, vacation. But a new concept by Sacred Introvert Retreat Tours aims to change that this spring, with a trip to Glastonbury, England, and surrounding areas.

headline: About That Giuliani Uproar: He Wasn’t Even Listed to Speak
text: Rarely has a political event been so overtaken by someone who wasn’t initially even invited.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘H Is for Hawk’
text: This week, Vicki Constantine Croke discusses Heather Macdonald’s “H Is for Hawk”; Parul Sehgal has news from the literary world; John Williams talks about Nick Hornby’s “Funny Girl”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Letters: ‘Founders’ Son’
text: ‘Founders’ Son’

headline: Chuck Lorre on Charlie Sheen and the Finale of ‘Two and a Half Men’
text: Charlie Sheen filed a $100 million lawsuit after getting fired from the CBS sitcom “Two and a Half Men.” Angus T. Jones (the young half-man of the show’s title) made a video for his church that went viral on the Internet in which he said that the show was “filling your head with filth.”

headline: A Pool of One’s Own
text: A six-story Queen Anne townhouse on Central Park West, which underwent an elaborate renovation that included a 60-foot indoor lap pool in the basement, sold for $25,000,000 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘H Is for Hawk’
text: This week, Vicki Constantine Croke and John Williams.

headline: ‘West of Sunset,’ by Stewart O’Nan
text: F. Scott Fitzgerald was both a perfect and a terrible fit for Hollywood. His youthful fame gave him a shrewd perspective on that shallow, tinselly world. Yet while working there in the last three years of his life, he was a sad case: a debt-ridden genius, alcoholic, selling himself to collaborate on second-rate screenplays. Ever hear of “A Yank at Oxford”? No wonder his great, unfinished novel, “The Love of the Last Tycoon,” deals with the romance, illusion and tawdriness of the movie industry.

headline: ‘The Evil Hours,’ by David J. Morris
text: The field of psychiatric studies exploded during World War II because of an influx of traumatized soldiers. War is a kind of grand opening for studies of the mind. Historically, interest in trauma studies rises sharply during wartime, then wanes in its aftermath. But this time, even as the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan recede from public attention, rates of post-traumatic stress disorder have continued to increase. PTSD is currently the fourth-most-common psychiatric disorder in America.

headline: ‘Irritable Hearts,’ by Mac McClelland
text: The American journalist Mac McClelland has reported from crisis zones like Myanmar and the Democratic Republic of Congo, but in her memoir “Irritable Hearts” she chronicles a crisis she can’t leave behind.

headline: Jeb Bush Turns to Walmart Executive to Help Build Team
text: As Jeb Bush recruits a fast-growing team of policy advisers for his presidential campaign in waiting, he is turning to a former chief executive at Walmart, the country’s largest private employer, to help him pull it together.

headline: ‘Fatherland,’ by Nina Bunjevac
text: In peacetime we enjoy the luxury of imagining our private experiences are separate from public history. We consume the news of wars, regime changes and assassination plots with our morning coffee but consider ourselves, our families and our relationships as self-contained worlds. This luxury was never available to Nina Bunjevac. In her graphic memoir, “Fatherland,” she tells the story of a family torn apart by nationalism and historical trauma.

headline: Experimental Fiction
text: BINARY STAR  By Sarah Gerard  Two Dollar Radio, paper, $16.

headline: New Rules Are Set Out to Reduce the Length of M.L.B. Games
text: TAMPA, Fla. — With spring training camps opening in Florida and Arizona, after a baseball season in which the average major league game lasted a record 3 hours 2 minutes, Major League Baseball and the players’ union took their first formal steps on Friday to quicken the pace of play.

headline: Creature Lit
text: Helen Macdonald’s “H Is for Hawk,” reviewed on this week’s cover, joins a distinguished list of memoirs that explore the complicated relationships between humans and animals.

headline: ‘Thieves of State,’ by Sarah Chayes
text: Across much of the world, populations suffer daily shakedowns by the police. At roadblocks, market stalls and entrances to government buildings, thugs in uniform gather “like spear fishermen hunting trout in a narrows,” as Sarah Chayes writes. But that isn’t the half of it. Globally, the three most important desiderata of our age — security, resilience and poverty reduction — are consistently being hollowed out by structural theft on a much larger scale, operating across corporations, governments, military establishments and civil services.

headline: ‘Street of Thieves,’ by Mathias Énard
text: Mathias Énard is a French novelist who has gained recognition in Europe for the scale of his ambitions and the hurtling, anarchic energy of his prose. He has a large appetite for disaster, and his books are packed with wars, massacres, terrorism — with human depravity of every kind.

headline: Tom McCarthy’s ‘Satin Island’
text: After traveling widely throughout the world and studying its various peoples in all their kaleidoscopic glory, Claude Lévi-Strauss, the father of structural ­anthropology, finally arrived at a dispiriting conclusion. “Mankind has opted for monoculture,” he observed ruefully in “Tristes Tropiques,” his classic 1955 ­memoir-cum-case study detailing his years spent among the indigenous tribes of Brazil. “It is in the process of creating a mass civilization, as beetroot is grown in the mass. Henceforth, man’s daily bill of fare will consist only of this one item.”

headline: Jonathan Lethem’s ‘Lucky Alan’
text: Jonathan Lethem’s extraordinary career is a reminder of the not-so-distant past when working novelists published their new creations regularly and with a seemingly free-flowing hand. If one book wasn’t up to snuff, there would be another to redeem it a year or two later. It was all part of the ebb and flow of a lifetime of work.

headline: The Case of Georges Simenon
text: Georges Simenon (1903-89) had, at the very least, two identities. One was the Belgian altar boy who quickly made the transition from failed pastry chef to legendary cub reporter for the Gazette de Liège when he was only 16 and went on to write nearly 200 pulp novels between 1924 and 1931 (he referred to them as his “novels for secretaries”). Then, when he decided to write “good” books, he took the advice of his mentor, Colette — “Get rid of all the literature, and you’ve got it” — and spent the next five decades producing more than 200 serious novels, keeping meticulous accounts of his multitudinous foreign translations and film adaptations, and moving his family from the French countryside to Arizona, New England, Quebec and back to Europe again, even while finding time to enjoy three very French family meals each day, and to walk with his adored children in the local parks.

headline: ‘Lies, First Person,’ by Gail Hareven
text: Why are so many of our novels so good-mannered these days? Where is Ignatius J. Reilly’s cackle, the self-thwarting abdication of Graham Greene’s comedians, the fear and loathing of Dostoyevsky’s underground man? Where are the lunatics, madmen, misfits and misanthropes, the perfectly good people cracking up and squandering it all to nourish some sweet, unsubtle hatred? With so much enmity in our world, why is there so little in modern American fiction? Is there a liberal bias in books, too?

headline: Wait, Guns Do Kill People?
text: Last July, William DeHayes was practicing some innocent gun-slinging tricks in his kitchen in Brooksville, Florida, when he accidentally shot Katherine Hoover, the wife of his old friend, point blank in the temple as she sat eating at the kitchen table. Ms. Hoover was five months pregnant at the time, and doctors tried in vain to save both her and her fetus, a boy she had named Rehlin.

headline: Glass Amid the Limestone
text: An anachronism in an Upper Fifth Avenue neighborhood dominated by the Metropolitan Museum of Art and limestone co-ops with prewar pedigrees, 1045 Fifth Avenue, the apartment building the developer Manny E. Duell considered his masterpiece, is a bronze glass column crowned by a duplex penthouse with two levels of panoramic 40-foot vistas across Central Park’s reservoir. From the start, the one-of-a-kind penthouse was reserved and customized for Mr. Duell, who died in 1977 just a decade after moving in, as a present to his wife, Irene, who lived and entertained there until her own death last summer at age 92.

headline: Tina Fey’s ‘Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt’ Heads to Netflix
text: If “30 Rock,” their screwball sitcom about television’s backstage antics, had lasted a bit longer, Tina Fey and Robert Carlock say, they might have pursued a plot about the fatuous executive Jack Donaghy and his further degradation of the traditional broadcast TV model.

headline: Red Cedar: An Urban Pioneer
text: Show me a dry field and I’ll show you a red cedar. Though it is a common tree in New York City, few ever stop to recognize or appreciate its merits.

headline: What I Love | Carmen de Lavallade
text: The dancer, actor and choreographer lives on the Upper West Side surrounded by artwork by her husband, Geoffrey Holder, who died in October.

headline: A Spur-of-the-Moment Risotto
text: When it’s 20 degrees and windy in Manhattan, the closest place to shop for dinner is in your cupboard. Even a minimally stocked pantry can provide a comforting spontaneous feast.

headline: Currency’s Weakness Troubles China’s Policy Makers
text: HONG KONG — Every weekday morning this year, China’s currency has followed the same ominous path.

headline: Oscars 2015: Parties for ‘Boyhood’ and the Beautiful People
text: LOS ANGELES — Sixty hours till the Oscars are behind us – hurrah! – and if you think the Bagger has been counting this down for weeks now, you’re absolutely right.

headline: Persian Gulf Council Retracts Statement Defending Qatar
text: CAIRO — The organization of Persian Gulf monarchies on Friday withdrew a statement issued the previous day that defended Qatar against Egyptian allegations of supporting terrorism. The turnabout raised questions about possible discord or confusion within the organization, and about what appeared to be signs of reconciliation after a long dispute over Egypt between Qatar and its neighbors.

headline: At Brasserie Favored by Celebrities, Big Mirror Falls, but Lunch Is Served
text: As accidents go, it was so very New York.

headline: Inside the List
text: Out There: From 1993 to 2002, David Duchovny starred in “The X-Files” as the persistent and slightly paranoid F.B.I. special agent Fox Mulder, investigator of and true believer in paranormal activity. Then, from 2007 to 2014, he took on the even scarier role of Hank Moody, the wild-boy writer in “Californication” — surely the most debauched novelist to appear on television since Angela Lansbury’s Jessica Fletcher in “Murder, She Wrote.” But Lansbury never produced a novel of her own. Duchovny has done just that, and the book — “Holy Cow,” his debut — enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 16. It’s not necessarily the novel you’d expect from the man who played Hank Moody. The protagonist, Elsie Bovary, is a talking cow who sets out for India after she learns that cattle there are viewed as more than hamburger meat; along the way she’s joined by a pig determined to reach Israel (where pork is off the menu) and a turkey bound for Turkey (“That was really just a play on words,” Duchovny told the trade magazine Kirkus Reviews). But beneath the goofy plot, which The Huffington Post described, not wholly favorably, as “a mash-up between ‘Animal Farm’ and ‘Chicken Run,’ ” Duchovny is thinking seriously about environmentalism and animal rights. “It’s an attitude of brotherhood,” he told Kirkus, “not only with other human beings, but with all the animals on the planet. I think it’s because of climate change that everyone is coming around to the idea that this is the finite planet and there’s a lot of unnecessary pain and overconsumption on it and there are things around us that have feelings that we don’t normally ascribe to having feelings. I don’t think rocks have feelings; I draw the line there.”

headline: A Hall of Fame Trainer Seeks to Reclaim His Old Magic
text: BOYNTON BEACH, Fla. — When Nick Zito ranked among the most prominent trainers the previous two decades, this time of year was special to him. It brought an unveiling of sorts as his newly turned 3-year-old colts justified his keen eye for talent by distinguishing themselves in prep races ahead of the Kentucky Derby.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE PROBLEM OF SLAVERY IN THE AGE OF EMANCIPATION,  by David Brion Davis. (Vintage, $16.95.) This final volume in an exceptional trilogy on slavery in the Western Hemisphere focuses on 19th-century trans-Atlantic abolitionism and, in particular, the intellectual and theological origins of the antislavery movement in America. Davis explores how the Haitian Revolution respectively terrified and inspired white and black Americans, and examines the significance of the colonization project to move freed slaves back to Africa.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE WHITES,  by Richard Price writing as Harry Brandt. (Holt, $28.) Most readers will never come close to a New York homicide investigation, but they will instinctively know that Price’s insightful crime novel has this world down right.

headline: Former First Lady of Virginia Is Sentenced to Prison for Graft
text: WASHINGTON — Maureen McDonnell, the wife of former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia, who along with her husband was found guilty last year of trading favors in return for loans, vacations and gifts from a wealthy businessman, was sentenced Friday to a year and a day in prison for her role in a bribery case that upended her husband’s political career.

headline: The Government’s Bad Diet Advice
text: FOR two generations, Americans ate fewer eggs and other animal products because policy makers told them that fat and cholesterol were bad for their health. Now both dogmas have been debunked in quick succession.

headline: London Fashion Week: Felder Felder Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: The Top 10 Moments From Fall/Winter 2015 New York Fashion Week
text: T’s senior market editor rounds up the most memorable happenings both on and off the runways.

headline: Luxury Cars Imprint Their Brands on Goods From Cologne to Clothing
text: Ever since he was a child, Rodney Foster has coveted all things Bentley.

headline: Financial Advice by the Demographics
text: When a woman calls Fidelity about her investments there, her questions are likely to be handled a bit differently from those asked by a man.

headline: London Fashion Week: Felder Felder Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: Mets Envision Playoffs, and Idea Isn’t So Blurry
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Sandy Alderson held a news conference Friday morning at the beginning of spring training, his fifth as the Mets’ general manager. Naturally, he was asked about his expectations for the team.

headline: In China’s Modern Economy, a Retro Push Against Women
text: BEIJING — Fresh out of college, Angela Li was proud of her job as a teller at the state-owned China Everbright Bank — maybe it wasn’t exciting, but it had prospects. After a year and a half she applied for a promotion, along with a male colleague who had joined with her.

headline: Category Close-Up: ‘Citizenfour’ Leads the Race for Best Documentary
text: If any film other than Laura Poitras’s “Citizenfour,” an unsettling look at pervasive electronic snooping by the United States government, wins the Oscar for best feature documentary, it will constitute a huge upset. With the whistleblower Edward Snowden as its main subject, “Citizenfour” doesn’t just recount recent history, it actually puts a camera in the room as Mr. Snowden makes one explosive revelation after another to Ms. Poitras and other journalists.

headline: The Top 10 Moments From Fall/Winter 2015 New York Fashion Week
text: T’s market director rounds up the most memorable happenings both on and off the runways.

headline: Slowly Learning to Fill Big Shoes
text: Bol Bol, Manute Bol’s 15-year-old son, carries high expectations as he begins to navigate high school basketball in suburban Kansas.

headline: Stuff We Liked: Mapping American Diversity, and a Taco Solution
text: The Upshot staff found an eclectic mix of articles and graphics on the web this week.

headline: A Legacy in Paint and Wire
text: Geoffrey Holder never lived in the Upper West Side prewar apartment that his wife, the dancer, actor and choreographer Carmen de Lavallade, has occupied since 2011.

headline: A Magician Happy to Reveal the Secrets of His Tricks (on Mondays)
text: On Monday night, a dozen young magicians gathered around a long table in the Atrium public plaza just off East 54th Street and began fanning decks of cards and making coins disappear.

headline: Waiting for Eurogodot
text: So we’ll be hearing from the Eurogroup soon; word is that there will be a deal, which will either be a big defeat or a big win for Tsipras. Huh? Here’s why I think there may be confusion.

headline: Administration to Try to Block Ruling That Postpones Immigration Actions
text: WASHINGTON — The White House on Friday said it would seek an emergency ruling to allow President Obama’s executive actions on immigration to go into effect, underscoring its urgent desire to resolve a legal challenge to the programs and reassure anxious supporters in the immigrant community.

headline: Yankees’ Masahiro Tanaka Is Confident His Right Elbow Will Hold Up
text: TAMPA, Fla. — A small, sinewy piece of human anatomy has held precariously in place for several months, and with it perhaps the hopes of the Yankees’ season. The tissue in question is the ulnar collateral ligament in Masahiro Tanaka’s right elbow, the one that tore slightly last July and required more than two months of rest and rehabilitation to repair.

headline: A Friendly Office Debate Over Wages
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Salads Don’t Have to Be Green
text: I used to insist on making a green salad to go with every meal. It is the way I grew up eating – in fact the first thing I learned to make in the kitchen was a vinaigrette, and my first kitchen tasks were preparing all of the lettuces and vegetables for our mixed green salads. Now my salads are not always green. This is especially true in winter, when root vegetables, roasted vegetables, grains and year-round vegetable staples like celery are often at the center of my salad plate.

headline: Compromise Reached on Yemen Council, U.N. Says
text: SANA, Yemen — Leaders of the Houthi militia that dominates Yemen agreed on a compromise legislative council on Friday, according to a United Nations mediator, but the move fell far short of the goal of forming a new government and choosing a leader.

headline: Designer Paula Gerbase Shares Her Favorite London Haunts
text: As the mastermind behind the understatedly modern London-based men’s and women’s wear line 1205, Paula Gerbase has, until recently, maintained a profile as discreet as the clothes she creates. Last year, however, the Brazilian-born designer vaulted into the majors when she was named artistic director of John Lobb, the esteemed British footwear house. Though the appointment ruffled a few traditionalist feathers, to Gerbase, the pairing makes perfect sense: The designer, who studied at Central Saint Martins and spent several years training with tailors on Savile Row, retains a reverence for her adopted city’s customs even as she works to reinvent them. “The diversity and wealth of culture present in London is unparalleled and is endlessly inspiring,” she says. “There is also a unique freedom to it that allows you to express yourself creatively without boundaries.”

headline: Building New York’s Future and Its Past
text: Eric Alterman’s “Equality and One City: Bill de Blasio and the New York Experiment, Year One” (ebookNation) is a de Blasio booster’s handbook to how much the mayor has already accomplished and a sober reminder — no matter how many poor people vote for empathetic local candidates — of just how much Albany and Washington can scuttle his agenda.

headline: A French Education Minister Who Knows Immigrants’ Struggles
text: PARIS — IN late January, shortly after the Charlie Hebdo attacks in Paris, Najat Vallaud-Belkacem sat in her office lined with gold leaf in the 18th-century Hôtel de Rothelin-Charolais, reflecting on the identity crisis among young French Muslims.

headline: Raul Rodriguez, Who Showered Rose Parade With Bouquets on Wheels, Dies at 71
text: Raul Rodriguez, who designed more than 500 floral floats for the Tournament of Roses Parade and conceived dazzling confections for other private and public celebrations around the world, died on Wednesday at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 71.

headline: Leandra Medine, Angelo Flaccavento and the Faces of New York Fashion Week, Part Two
text: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares more impressionistic portraits of the stylish personalities around the city at the fall/winter 2015 shows this week.

headline: London Fashion Week: Daks Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Why Do So Many Windshield Wipers Stick Out During Winter?
text: Q. I’ve lived in other northern cities, but since moving to New York, I’ve noticed a winter habit I never saw before: People who park outside in snowy weather often pull their windshield wipers forward so they are sticking out at an angle, away from the windshield. Why is that?

headline: Attention, Office Oscar Pool Players
text: It’s predictions day at the Carpetbagger blog and as you pore over your Oscar ballot, here are some thoughts to keep in mind:

headline: Opening Soon: An Art Gallery From a Taittinger
text: Richard F. Taittinger is opening a new 5,000-square-foot gallery in the Lower East Side of New York.

headline: Greek Debt Vastly Overstated, Investor Tells the World
text: High in a Morgan Stanley office tower, Paul B. Kazarian, one of the largest holders of Greek government bonds, was recently trying to persuade a room full of investors that Greece’s debt load of 318 billion euros was actually a tenth that size.

headline: Calculating the Odds of a Comcast-Time Warner Cable Deal
text: Time Warner Cable’s deal risk is going down to the wire.

headline: Who Is Boots?
text: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss the 28-year-old singer, songwriter and producer.

headline: U.N. Panel Threatens to Name Those It Accuses of War Crimes in Syria
text: UNITED NATIONS — A United Nations panel investigating potential war crimes in Syria’s civil war threatened on Friday to release a closely guarded list of names of those it accuses of having raped, tortured and carried out executions during the conflict. The move was part of an effort to increase pressure on world powers to pursue justice for what it calls crimes that “shock the conscience of humanity.”

headline: London Fashion Week: Daks Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Advocate for Syrian ‘Moderates’ Changes His Mind
text: Predictions that so-called “moderates” in Syria could ever prevail over President Bashar al-Assad were always a long shot. Few had military experience. And throughout the civil war, now going into its 5th year, they have been fractured and unable to coalesce under a unified command.

headline: Illustrations by Amy Reeder
text: Ms. Reeder, who lives in Greenwich Village, likes to wake up gently and ease into the day.

headline: From ‘Rocket Girl’ to Karaoke Superstar
text: Amy Reeder, 34, is the artist behind the Image Comics series “Rocket Girl,” which she created with the writer Brandon Montclare. It is about a teenage cop from an alternate, high-tech future (um, 2013) who travels back to 1986 in New York City on a mission to save her world. Ms. Reeder, who lives in Greenwich Village, completed her fifth year in New York City on Friday. A new issue of “Rocket Girl” will be published in May.

headline: Category Close-Up: A Tough Call in the Foreign-Language Race
text: For the first time in several years, the competition for the Oscar for best foreign-language film seems to be a toss-up. The last three winners (Iran’s “A Separation,” Austria’s “Amour” and Italy’s “The Great Beauty”) had victories that seemed pre-ordained, and even before that, it was easy to identify a front-runner. But this year looks like a real horse race between two movies from neighboring countries that are somber in tone but otherwise seem to have little in common.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s properties include a condo in East Harlem and co-ops in Yorkville and Park Slope.

text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: The Art and Allure of Marc Jacobs’s Dramatic Stage Sets
text: A look back at some of the house’s recent feats of interior design.

headline: Speaking Freely About Politics Can Cost You Your Job
text: HERE’S a quiz for the coming campaign season. Which one of these actions could get you disciplined or fired?

headline: Activist Investor Demands $500 Million Stock Buyback by Sotheby’s
text: Last year, Mick McGuire and Daniel S. Loeb agreed on the same thing: Change was needed at Sotheby’s.

headline: Complete Coverage
text: From red carpet fashion to show highlights, a look at our 2015 Oscars coverage.

headline: Giuliani Comments Echo Old Republican Attacks on Obama
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani has stirred a furor this week by claiming that President Obama does not love America, but his suggestion is not a new one.
