text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York City Region:

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
text: This week’s properties include a ranch in Mahwah, N.J., and an updated 1908 house in Bronxville, N.Y.

headline: Obama Challenges Republicans’ New Plan
text: President Obama, speaking at the Democratic National Committee’s winter meeting, said that if Republicans want to rebrand themselves as the party of the middle class, they have to “walk the walk.”

headline: Popcast: Boots, Beyoncé Producer, Steps Out
text: Beyoncé’s self-titled album from late 2013 had an unfamiliar name in many of its credits: Boots. Who is Boots? We were theorizing about it on the Popcast 14 months ago. Jon Pareles said, “I have the feeling he’s holding it together.”

headline: Leandra Medine, Angelo Flaccavento and the Faces of New York Fashion Week, Part Two
text: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares his impressionistic portraits of the stylish personalities around the city this week.

headline: Lead Belly, Folk-Music Giant, Has a Smithsonian Moment
text: In 1980, when Bob Dylan was baffling much of his audience by writing and singing gospel songs, he stood on the stage of the Warfield Theater in San Francisco and spoke about the folk singer known as Lead Belly. He explained that Lead Belly had been a prisoner in Texas who was discovered by a musicologist and brought to New York.

headline: Merce Cunningham Revivals, on His Home Ground
text: In July 1999, three months after his 80th birthday, the choreographer Merce Cunningham received this city’s highest honor for a contribution to its intellectual and cultural life, the Handel Medallion. At the presentation, in front of the curtains of what was then the New York State Theater (now the David H. Koch), Mr. Cunningham said how, 60 years before, he had first stepped onto a New York sidewalk and “knew this was home.”

headline: Ernestine Anderson, Colleen Green and Vexx Have New Releases
text: Ernestine Anderson

headline: Anticipating Coachella, Bonnaroo, Lollapalooza, Firefly and More
text: Festival season starts to rev up in spring where climate permits, and then it roars along all summer, with far too many choices. At its best, a music festival is more than just a multitude of bands booked for a marathon weekend. It’s inevitably a test of outreach for artists who are getting a chance to perform for casual listeners as well as committed fans. It can also be a site-specific environmental experience, a glimpse of a pop-up community and something like a live playlist from a trustworthy D.J.

headline: Chris Stapleton’s ‘Traveller’ to Be Released This Spring
text: At the 2013 CMA Awards, Luke Bryan performed “Drink a Beer,” probably the most melancholic number of his brawn-and-booze career. He sat on a stool, surrounded by smoke, in a noncommittal T-shirt and jeans and sang about losing a loved one with a tender, lovely flutter in his voice. He seemed like a man in pain. You wanted to give him a hug.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Village Vanguard Celebrates 80 Years, Not All Jazzy
text: The Village Vanguard, the greatest jazz club in New York and possibly anywhere, opened 80 years ago, in 1935, at 178 Seventh Avenue South. It didn’t book jazz at first. One of the best chapters in “Live at the Village Vanguard,” the 1980 memoir written by Max Gordon, the club’s original proprietor, is about poetry readings.

headline: Christian Gerhaher Sings ‘Winterreise’ Without All the Frills
text: Schubert’s “Winterreise” (“Winter Journey”), an hourlong song cycle about heartbreak, loneliness and alienation published in 1828, is a masterpiece of austere beauty. In recent years, the work has been subjected to a flurry of stage adaptations, including one by the British director Katie Mitchell that weaves in poems by Beckett, and one, shown at the White Light Festival last November, with animated drawings by the South African artist William Kentridge. Theater and opera companies as far afield as Chicago, Anchorage and Melbourne have put on productions featuring actors, video art, sound design and dancers.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘H Is for Hawk’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Vicki Constantine Croke reviews Helen Macdonald’s “H Is for Hawk.” Ms. Croke writes:

headline: ‘The Rake’s Progress’ and Anne-Sophie Mutter Are Spring Must-Sees
text: New productions are typically the big news of a Metropolitan Opera season. But this spring I’m especially looking forward to a revival: Jonathan Miller’s production of Stravinsky’s “The Rake’s Progress,” introduced in 1997 and last seen at the house in 2003.

headline: Before Bach at Carnegie Hall: Really ‘Early Music’
text: Back in the day, the term “early music” meant pretty much what it said. In the United States, Noah Greenberg and the New York Pro Musica Antiqua started their systematic explorations of medieval and Renaissance repertory in 1952, and the Baroque boom of the ’60s installed a capstone of sorts, the music of Bach.

headline: Marcelo Álvarez Is Twice Unhappy in ‘Cavalleria’ and ‘Pagliacci’
text: Mascagni’s “Cavalleria Rusticana” and Leoncavallo’s “Pagliacci” have been yoked together for so long that it is easy to think of them as two halves of the same work. Both are short operas written in response to the literary verismo movement that swept Italy in the final decades of the 19th century with an emphasis on real-life stories featuring ordinary people: unhappy lovers caught in the rigid moral code of a Sicilian village in Mascagni’s work, unhappy lovers in a troupe of traveling comedians caught in the glare of the footlights in Leoncavallo’s. Yet each opera inhabits its own musical and aesthetic universe.

headline: Antonacci, Röschmann and Anonymous 4 in Spring Concerts
text: Spring is said to be about renewal and the birth of fresh things, but three vocal highlights are coming from veteran performers. One, though, is still fairly new to New York: the sometime soprano, sometime mezzo-soprano Anna Caterina Antonacci.

headline: From Mark Morris, Seasonal Rituals Lusty and Solemn
text: Put together, the words “dance” and “spring” may conjure a mental image of barefoot people with flowers in their hair holding hands and skipping in circles. You can find such people in Mark Morris’s 2013 “Spring, Spring, Spring,” which will have its New York debut during his company’s season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music (April 22 through 26). What you won’t find is the ritual sacrifice from the original scenario for this work’s score, Stravinsky’s “The Rite of Spring.”

headline: Mastering Basketball in Australia
text: The New Zealand Breakers are the only team in the N.B.L. not from Australia, and they have won three of the league’s last four championships.

headline: A Basketball Outlier With an Inside Track
text: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — The New Zealand Breakers are the most unconventional team in Australia’s National Basketball League. For starters, they are the only team in the league that is not from Australia. It is also worth noting that they practice in a converted power tools warehouse, where they have two full-length courts, a film room, offices for staff and several well-appointed vending machines.

headline: Enough Color to Wake the Dead
text: At Fuego 718 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Day of the Dead skeletons and skulls turn up on countless items, including magnets, shadow boxes and Christmas ornaments.

headline: Fuego 718 in Williamsburg, a Shop Where Every Day Is the Day of the Dead
text: With Day of the Dead art and paper flowers strung everywhere, a section devoted to luchador toys and masks, bags imprinted with Frida Kahlo’s portrait and Latin American keepsakes arranged floor to ceiling, Fuego 718 is more Mexican street market than Williamsburg boutique.

headline: Proenza’s Boy, Fran Lebowitz on Fashion and YSL’s Revenue Doubles
text: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Hillary Clinton Begins Process of Vetting — Herself
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton, the subject of intense news media attention and public scrutiny for the last three decades, is preparing for another thorough vetting as she plans for a likely presidential campaign. In this case, however, it’s not Republicans trying to thwart her or journalists looking for a juicy scoop, but researchers she herself has hired.

headline: Delphic Demarche
text: OK, we have an agreement re Greece, according to which … what?

headline: Protests in Caracas After Mayor’s Arrest
text: Protesters gathered on Friday to demand the release of Mayor Antonio Ledezma, a longtime critic of Venezuela’s government, after the police arrested him at his office on Thursday.

headline: Complicating the Picture of Urban Life
text: A new exhibit features three Bronx-born photographers whose work explores the idea of community while challenging outdated, lingering notions.

headline: Daring Ventures From Four Choreographers
text: Four experimental choreographers leap out of the pack this spring: Beth Gill, Rebecca Patek, Rebecca Serrell Cyrand Gillian Walsh.

headline: Bahamas Told to Improve Conditions at Center Housing Haitian Immigrants
text: An international human rights commission has told the Bahamas that it must take measures to protect people housed at the country’s detention center for immigrants, where a “serious and urgent situation” places migrants’ “lives and physical integrity at risk.”

headline: Ties to Islamic State Cited by Group in Libya Attacks
text: CAIRO — Militants pledging allegiance to the Islamic State claimed responsibility for three car bombs that killed at least 38 people in a town in eastern Libya on Friday in the latest escalation in a surge of violence linked to the group.

headline: Medicare Toughens Standards on Nursing Homes
text: The star ratings of nearly a third of the nation’s nursing homes were lowered on Friday, as federal officials readjusted quality standards in the face of criticism that the ratings were inaccurate and artificially inflated.

headline: From a Bad First Impression to I Do
text: Alicia Menendez and Carlos Odio were married Feb. 15, at the Coral Gables United Church of Christ in Coral Gables, Fla.

headline: Jameis Winston, in Job Interview, Tells 32 Bosses They Can Trust Him
text: INDIANAPOLIS — On a blustery Friday afternoon, Jameis Winston arrived for his news conference at Lucas Oil Stadium seemingly carrying N.F.L. aspirations on one shoulder and the baggage of Tallahassee, Fla., on the other.

headline: Outdoor Shows on Television for Those With Cabin Fever
text: Subzero temperatures. Preposterous quantities of snow. Ice storms in places where road crews don’t normally stock salt. For many Americans, the only sane thing to do lately has been to stay inside.

headline: Public-Service Driven, and Into Each Other’s Arms
text: Asked about her upbringing in a Union City, N.J., household in which her father, Robert Menendez, was a New Jersey assemblyman and her mother was working in the state’s public schools, Alicia Menendez said: “I grew up driven and nerdy and feeling a sense of responsibility to help people. My mother was a go-getter and guidance counselor, and Dad was an original tiger mom who expected nothing short of excellence.”

headline: Review: Behzod Abduraimov Nurtures and Protects in Full Exposure
text: Deep into Chopin’s Ballade No. 4 is a passage of hushed emotion, almost a memory of feeling. When the young Uzbek pianist Behzod Abduraimov reached that moment in his New York debut recital on Wednesday at Weill Recital Hall, he seemed to stretch his entire upper body over the keys, as if suppressing the sound — or, perhaps, protecting it.

headline: Hollywood  Sighting
text: According to The Hollywood Reporter, the display is courtesy of the street artist Plastic Jesus, who last year created a giant Oscar with a needle in his arm, a commentary on Philip Seymour Hoffman’s death.

headline: An Award to Honor Julius Rudel
text: Before he became the music director of New York City Opera during its heyday and embarked on a conducting career that took him to podiums around the world, the first ensemble that Julius Rudel conducted was the Mannes Orchestra, during his student days there.

headline: Well-Known Faces Honor a Fashion Mentor
text: A slew of recognizable faces showed up for Louise Wilson’s memorial service.

headline: Review: Tovah Feldshuh Embraces Life at 54 Below
text: Tovah Feldshuh, unlike most performers in their 60s, isn’t afraid to bare her arms. At Thursday’s opening-night performance of her spunky one-woman show, “Aging Is Optional,” at 54 Below, she stepped onto the stage wearing a shiny orange and purple outfit that might be described as an entertainer’s adaptation of a workout suit. Removing the jacket, she displayed her biceps, which are well-toned from her trapeze work in “Pippin.” By any standard, this woman appears almost alarmingly fit. Along the way, she mentioned that she is making plans to climb Mount Kilimanjaro.

headline: Bringing Big Data to the Fight Against Benefits Fraud
text: A few years ago, the New York City Human Resources Administration decided to try a new way to root out fraud among people receiving government benefits. Data detectives began running benefit recipients through a computerized pattern-recognition system.

headline: The Reality of Quantum Weirdness
text: IN Akira Kurosawa’s film “Rashomon,” a samurai has been murdered, but it’s not clear why or by whom. Various characters involved tell their versions of the events, but their accounts contradict one another. You can’t help wondering: Which story is true?

headline: The Fashion World Remembers Louise Wilson
text: LONDON — St. Paul’s Cathedral, rebuilt by Sir Christopher Wren following the reduction of its ancient structure to ashes during the Great Fire of London in 1666, has long been the setting of some of England’s most notable events, from the Jubilee celebration of Queen Victoria, to the wedding of Prince Charles and Diana Spencer, to the funerals of the Duke of Wellington, Winston Churchill and Margaret Thatcher.

headline: The Baroque Anachronisms of Mr. Bronstein
text: Pablo Bronstein has created a home that revels in the artist’s favorite things: opulent furnishings, striking juxtapositions and fine examples of historical confusion.

headline: Making Valentine’s Day a Double-header
text: The Vows section of The Times publishes an occasional series of wedding-themed Instagram photos, called Wedding Album. This month’s theme was Valentine’s Day weddings.

headline: Zinged by Rivals, Indian Prime Minister’s Suit Fetches $693,234
text: NEW DELHI — Indian tycoons jockeyed on Friday to demonstrate their allegiance to Prime Minister Narendra Modi by bidding on a widely discussed item of clothing: the tailored suit that Mr. Modi wore last month to meet President Obama. The suit’s yellow pinstripes, upon closer examination, proved to be tiny lines of script spelling out Mr. Modi’s name.

headline: NEC Bridge Festival’s Last-Day Pair Event
text: At the 20th NEC Bridge Festival in Yokohama City, Japan, from Feb. 10 to Sunday, the final day featured the two-session Asuka Cup. From an entry of 158 pairs, the winners were Dawei Chen and his wife, Masako Sakurai, from Japan.

headline: Did the Torture Report Give the C.I.A. a Bum Rap?
text: WASHINGTON — IN December, when the Senate Intelligence Committee issued its long-awaited report on the C.I.A.’s detention and interrogation program, it seemed to confirm what I and many human-rights advocates had argued for a decade: The C.I.A. had started and run a fundamentally abusive and counterproductive torture program. What’s more, the report found that the C.I.A. had lied repeatedly about the program’s efficacy, and that it had neither disrupted terror plots nor saved lives.

headline: Winter’s Sculptures
text: This winter has left much of the U.S. chilled to the bone with record cold, but it has also created its own beauty.

headline: Review: Works by Stefano Gervasoni at Miller Theater
text: From the serialists to the spectralists, a fascination with timbre has long been a feature of contemporary composition. As the Italian composer Stefano Gervasoni, 52, explained during his worthwhile Composer Portrait at Miller Theater on Thursday, he started dealing explicitly with the character of sounds, as opposed to their pitch or volume, a decade ago.

headline: Review: Ballet Rakatan Delivers Sizzling Cuban Moves
text: When the Cuban choreographer Nilda Guerra named her company Ballet Rakatan, she created a word to sum up her vision. For her, “Rakatan” refers to rhythm, power and movement. But witnessing the dynamic, ardent members of her company in “Havana Rakatan” brings to mind another word: seduction. Her lively dancers flirt — with one another, with the audience — like there’s no tomorrow.

headline: Giuliani’s Comments Part of a Complicated History on Race
text: For those who first dialed into Rudolph W. Giuliani during his “America’s mayor” phase, right after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks — when he wowed the world with his civic leadership, soaring oratory and unifying largess — the former New York mayor’s racially charged comments about President Obama might seem puzzling.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Friday Night Music: 10,000 Maniacs
text: Lots of new music I intend to feature soon. But the wonders of online video mean that I also get to watch old live performances, including by bands that I was oblivious about at the time. And here’s the ultimate complain about the weather song, more or less appropriate during the deep freeze we’re in:

headline: Review: In ‘Platform 2015,’ Will Rawls and Kaitlyn Gilliland Perform a ‘Dance Dialogue’
text: Two people sit opposite each other at a table and talk: Can this be a dance? Tentative answer: Maybe. After all, the speakers are the downtown choreographer Will Rawls and Kaitlyn Gilliland, who danced with the New York City Ballet until 2011. You could feel the question rustling through the audience on Thursday night during this opening event of “Platform 2015: Dancers, Buildings and People in the Streets,” a two-month series of performances, workshops and panels organized by Claudia La Rocco and presented by Danspace Projects in St. Mark’s Church.

headline: Imagine Dragons, a Rock ’n’ Roll Survivor by Any Definition
text: Anyone concerned that there is no more opulence left in rock ’n’ roll need only take a look at Imagine Dragons, by some measurements the most popular rock band in the country.

headline: Conferences Consider Restoring Freshman Ineligibility
text: Several prominent conferences are considering rules to make freshmen ineligible in men’s basketball to discourage the so-called one-and-done phenomenon, in which the most talented players, who are prevented by N.B.A. rules from being drafted right out of high school, attend college for only one year.

headline: Times Fashion Director on Oscar Coverage
text: I will watch the Academy Awards from my brother’s basement in London, after flying overnight on Saturday and effectively going straight from the plane to London Fashion Week. I have five shows to make Sunday afternoon, ending with David Koma, a young designer who also moonlights as the creative director of Mugler, around 9 p.m. Which leaves me just enough time to get back to my brother’s house (he moved to London last September, which is very convenient for Fashion Week purposes, if not family) and find E! on his large-screen TV.

headline: Photos of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
text: Israel and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Review: Olivia Chaney, a Willfully Modern Singer of Folk
text: In parts of her concert on Thursday night at SubCulture the English singer-songwriter Olivia Chaney sounded like a next-generation bearer of British folk traditionalism. Her voice holds the purity, tension, dignity and sorrow of a heritage full of songs about lost love and cruel fate. She drew material from folk stalwarts like Peter Bellamy, Andy Irvine, Alasdair Roberts and Shirley and Dolly Collins, as well as the Chilean songwriter Violeta Parra. When she introduced a song as “kind of sexy rock ’n’ roll,” it turned out to be from Purcell’s 1692 semiopera “The Fairy Queen.”

headline: Feb. 20, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Israel, India, China and Ukraine.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Is a Married Man’s Photo on a Hookup App Appropriate?
text: Plus: Questions about a lack of courtesy at restaurants, headache-inducing perfume and group texting.

headline: A Festival to Celebrate New Zealand-China Ties
text: The Auckland Lantern Festival, now in its 16th year, will raise awareness of Chinese culture in New Zealand from Feb. 26 to March 1 with a series of events designed to welcome the zodiac year of the goat.

headline: Review: New York Philharmonic and Yo-Yo Ma’s Silk Road Ensemble Join Forces
text: At a time when symphony orchestras struggle at the box office and surefire audience draws are few, the cellist Yo-Yo Ma continues to work magic. The New York Philharmonic’s three subscription concerts this week, in which the orchestra is joined — all but displaced — by Mr. Ma’s Silk Road Ensemble, were sold out well in advance.

headline: Raiders and Chargers Are Willing to Share Stadium Near Los Angeles
text: The N.F.L.’s race to return to the Los Angeles area took a new twist Friday when the Oakland Raiders and the San Diego Chargers said they were willing to build a stadium together near the city if they were unable to get new homes in their current cities.

headline: In Iowa, Lindsey Graham Talks Up Threat From Islamic State
text: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, who might plunge into the already crowded pool of Republican presidential hopefuls, made a foray to Iowa this week to test the political strength of his signature issue: the threat from the Islamic State, which in his view requires American boots on the ground.

headline: Stocking Up for the Cold
text: Gifts for those who enjoy playing out of doors in frigid weather.

headline: Review: In Sheila Heti’s New Play, Canadians Lose Themselves in Paris
text: How should a person inhabit a perfectly elegant, black-and-white cartoon panel? That’s the issue faced by the cast of “All Our Happy Days Are Stupid,” the play in pursuit of a style by Sheila Heti, best known for the identity-pursuing novel “How Should a Person Be?” It is an issue that’s never resolved.

headline: For Sofia Coppola and Anjelica Huston, Oscar’s a Family Friend
text: No matter who takes home Academy Awards this weekend, Sofia Coppola and Anjelica Huston will remain an exclusive club of two: the only third-generation winners in Oscar history.

headline: Brrrrrrrrrr
text: Another Alberta clipper has just swept in from Canada, followed by a blast of air so cold that it brought back predictions by weathermen like Al Roker of another polar vortex. The weather is generating debate as some seek to tie it to global warming, but others declare this effort to be little more than a new left-wing weather conspiracy. But hey, it’s winter, and there are lots of gifts for those who wait for this frigid season to play out of doors.

headline: Two New Cézanne Works Discovered by Barnes Foundation Museum
text: PHILADELPHIA — In 1921, the wily art collector Albert C. Barnes wrote to Paris to his friend and fellow collector Leo Stein, who was in dire need of money and had deputized Barnes to sell some of his holdings in the United States. They included five watercolor landscapes by Paul Cézanne, but Barnes reported that he had failed to find “anybody who seems to think they are sufficiently important to want to own them.”

headline: For Doctors, Less Is More
text: To the Editor:

headline: Putting a Stop to Shell Companies, in Two Steps
text: To the Editor:

headline: At New York Fashion Week: Small Fish, Lost in a Big Pond
text: Shortly before noon on Sunday, with Derek Lam showing in West Chelsea and Hood by Air on Wall Street, Lincoln Center was almost empty.

headline: Rating Uber Riders
text: To the Editor:

headline: Preventing Crime
text: To the Editor:

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: A look back at the week in political pictures.

headline: The Beauty Paradox
text: To the Editor:

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: A look back at the week in political pictures.

headline: In Vietnam Tradition Meets Satire
text: A hugely popular annual television program featuring folkloric figures is embraced for its light, but sharp mockery of official misdoings.

headline: Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Manny Pacquiao Showdown Is Finally Set
text: The welterweights Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Manny Pacquiao, widely considered two of the greatest boxers of their generation, have agreed to terms for a bout on May 2 at the MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas.

headline: Cecile Emeke Isn’t Worried About Hollywood
text: The work of the Jamaican-British filmmaker Cecile Emeke offers a portal into a world rarely seen on American screens: the everyday experiences and culture of black youths in Europe, rendered with a complexity and depth that is exhilarating to watch.

headline: Review: ‘The Groundling,’ a Backstage Farce With Heartbreak
text: Victoria (Kendall Rileigh), a New York actress, was promised a gig “at a regional theater near the Hamptons.” So what is she doing in a garage just off the Long Island Expressway? “This is a nightmare,” she says.

headline: Cuomo Sets Special Election to Fill Grimm’s Seat
text: ALBANY — Moving to fill offices vacated by a prosecution and a promotion, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced two special elections in New York after being chided by a federal judge for not acting sooner. The elections will be held on May 5, the governor said on Friday.

headline: Shutterbug Parents and Overexposed Lives
text: In “The Entire History of You,” the third episode of the dystopian British series “Black Mirror,” humans have developed implanted memory “grains” that record everything they see and hear. When users “redo” a memory by playing it back, the recreation even surpasses the original; they can zoom in on details or activate a lip-reading function to decipher unheard speech.

headline: J.B. Smoove: ‘I’m Not on the A-list Yet. And I’m Satisfied Being a B.’
text: The combustible brew of New York Rangers and Boston Bruins fans at Madison Square Garden was already riled up. Then J. B. Smoove arrived.

headline: When Rewarding Talent Becomes Political
text: A pretty funny comedy about a somewhat angry conflict gets an above-average staging in “The Most Deserving” at Dreamcatcher Repertory Theater in Summit. If the play doesn’t always inspire superlatives, the next level of adjectives — including enjoyable, amusing and capable — is enough reason to see this production.

headline: Hobnobbing Through Fashion Week
text: The dance floor at Space Ibiza was open on Wednesday night. A woman with a mohawk mingled by the bar. An androgynous man in a black tank top and platform shoes swiveled his hips, then gave a Beyoncé-like roll of the neck.

headline: Marc Jacobs’s Mind, Live and On Stage
text: Marc Jacobs has somehow become the punctuation mark of New York Fashion Week: the last show by far, scheduled hours after any other equally big name, and at a time many editors have already flown the city for London Fashion Week.

headline: The Making of Celebrity Stylists
text: Once a fashion show begins, the front row tends to be as hushed as a pew. But Brooke Wall was maintaining a steady patter of commentary as the latest gowns of Naeem Khan, a designer favored by Jennifer Lopez and Michelle Obama, emerged under the Lincoln Center tents last Tuesday.

headline: How Hypochondriacs Say ‘I Love You’
text: The evening I convinced my boyfriend that he had leprosy defined a moment in our relationship that I can best describe as glorious. Leprosy represented a gold medal in my lifelong pentathlon of hypochondria, and I had never been remotely close to it before.

headline: Evening Hours | A Fashion Week for All
text: More than 200 brands participated in New York Fashion Week, each with its own audience and point of view.

headline: Newly Released Documents Reveals Advice to Fed in A.I.G. Bailout
text: WASHINGTON — The unusual case playing out in the United States Court of Federal Claims between the former top executive of the American International Group and the federal government took a new and significant turn this week as both sides feverishly prepared their voluminous final written arguments.

headline: What Lies Beneath That Oscars Outfit?
text: When Hollywood walks the red carpet Sunday night for the Oscars, one label will be worn surreptitiously by many of the A-list stars. But it’s not a secret couture line or, heaven forbid, something from the local mall.

headline: VSCO Cam: Filtered Photos, No Emojis Allowed
text: Last week, as fashion designers staged runway shows in New York City, the street-style photographer Tommy Ton hopped around the city, snapping nattily clad models and other sartorial standouts.

headline: Still Shivering From Deadly Cold, South Awaits More
text: ATLANTA — The freezing winter weather that has gripped much of the South this week has been responsible for record low temperatures and at least 31 deaths, and officials across the region were bracing Friday for potential snow and ice moving in from the West.

headline: What Would Malcolm X Think?
text: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. — FIFTY years ago today my father, Malcolm X, was assassinated while speaking at the Audubon Ballroom in New York City. I think about him every day, but even more in the last year, with the renewed spirit of civil rights activism after the tragic events in Ferguson, Mo., on Staten Island and in countless other parts of the country. What would he have to say about it?

headline: Bill Cunningham | New York Fashion Week
text: People at New York Fashion Week had many style ideas and found creative ways to stay warm.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Coats on Display at New York Fashion Week
text: People at New York Fashion Week had many style ideas and found creative ways to stay warm. This was the last fashion week at Lincoln Center, which provided a spectacular setting for the shows and the attendees.

headline: New Mexico: Board Votes to End Doctor’s Suspension
text: State medical officials have cleared the way for an obstetrician-gynecologist in Hobbs to return to practice after his medical license was suspended last year over accusations including having sex with patients and drinking on the job. The New Mexico Medical Board voted Thursday to lift the suspension of Christopher S. Driskill, the president-elect of the New Mexico Medical Society and one of the few practicing obstetrician-gynecologists around Hobbs, a city of about 40,000 on the eastern edge of the state. Dr. Driskill, who completed an evaluation at the Sexual Recovery Institute in Los Angeles as part of the settlement, can resume his practice after completing a course on professional and ethical behavior, board officials said. Upon his return, he is required to submit to monitoring, including random drug testing, therapy and having a chaperone with him when he meets patients.

headline: The Gift of Oliver Sacks: A Life in Full
text: To the Editor:

headline: Credit Card Balance Transfer Can Reap Savings if Done Cautiously
text: Now that consumers are taking on more debt, credit card issuers are responding with more attractive balance-transfer offers, a new analysis finds.

headline: Ukraine Town Eases Back Into Life After Deadly Week of Fighting
text: DEBALTSEVE, Ukraine — While the Ukrainian government accused Russia of sending more tanks and troops into the country despite a cease-fire agreement, the few residents who remained in the fiercely contested town of Debaltseve emerged from basements and other refuges on Friday to a Dickensian scene of destruction and gloom.

headline: New Virus Suspected in Death of Kansas Man
text: A new virus appears to have caused the death last spring of a man in Kansas, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported Friday in its journal Emerging Infectious Diseases. The virus, called Bourbon virus after the county where the man lived, is probably spread by ticks; the man was healthy before seeking treatment for fever and fatigue after getting a tick bite. Bourbon virus belongs to a group called thogotoviruses, the C.D.C. said. It is the first time a thogotovirus has been known to make an American ill; there have been seven cases in Africa, Europe and Asia, the report said.

headline: She’s the One, After All
text: In 2010, Hormis Thaliath logged into the Indian dating site Shaadi.com for the first time. Dating online had always struck him as awkward, but he learned the process wasn’t half as dubious as it had seemed when his sister first told him she had created an account on his behalf. In fact, it was almost comically easy. After browsing only four profiles, he had found someone interesting enough to stop looking further.

headline: Spider-Man, in Sketch Form, Visits an 8-Year-Old Fan in Harlem
text: The intercom was broken outside the front door at the Washington Houses project in East Harlem on Thursday. No way to buzz a visitor up. Finally, someone leaving held the door open.

headline: In Newly Sophisticated Boko Haram Videos, Hints of Islamic State Ties
text: WASHINGTON — Until recently, the propaganda videos released by Boko Haram, one of the most feared extremist groups in Africa, were an amateur affair. The videos were grainy, shot on hand-held cameras. They tended to feature the group’s wild-eyed leader screaming or shaking his finger at the viewer, as he delivered an incoherent tirade.

headline: Walmart Gives a Raise
text: Half a million low-wage workers will get a raise in April, when Walmart lifts hourly wages at its stores in the United States to at least $9. The raise, announced this week, appears to be an attempt to stem employee turnover and to respond to pressure for higher wages from politicians, labor groups and employees. Walmart also pledged to raise its wage floor in 2016 to $10 an hour.

headline: Nobel Winner Is Quitting as Head of Revived University in India
text: NEW DELHI — Amartya Sen, the Nobel-winning economist and Harvard professor, confirmed on Friday that he would step down as chancellor of Nalanda University this summer, ending his role as head of an ambitious academic project he helped start last year.

headline: At Princeton, Women Make Strides at Clubs That Once Barred Them
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — Princeton University’s 11 eating clubs are where most of its upperclassmen go for dinner every night, as the name implies.

headline: Bold Plans for New York Courts
text: The “justice gap” in New York State, which leaves many low-income people without the legal help they need to deal with evictions, foreclosures and other serious legal problems, must be narrowed. That is a central message of the state’s chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, who has come up with innovative ideas and programs for making the court system more equitable and accessible.

headline: Mastering Basketball in Australia
text: The SkyCity New Zealand Breakers are the only team in the N.B.L. not from Australia, and they have won three of the league’s last four championships.

headline: Obama Proposes Single Overseer for Food Safety
text: WASHINGTON — To understand America’s fragmented food safety inspection system, consider a slice of frozen pizza. The pepperoni is examined by the Agriculture Department, the cheese and tomato sauce by the Food and Drug Administration, each agency using its own methods for inspecting and testing.

headline: Canada Attack Suspect Is Now Charged in 3 Killings
text: OTTAWA — His exceptional longevity and vigor had made Ernest Côté something of a celebrity among Canadian military veterans. So in December, when someone posing as a city employee invaded Mr. Côté’s luxury apartment here, tied up the 101-year-old veteran, pulled a plastic bag over his head and left him for dead, the news attracted national attention.

headline: After Ruling, Kurt Busch Is Suspended Indefinitely
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — The Sprint Cup driver Kurt Busch was suspended indefinitely by Nascar on Friday after a Delaware judge determined that Busch had choked his former girlfriend during a confrontation last September.

headline: Celebrating Long Shots and  Outcasts
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Rory Kennedy was fully expecting not to go home with the Oscar for best documentary feature on Sunday, yet nonetheless she was in high spirits Friday, at a sun-dappled lunch in the courtyard of the famous, and infamous, Chateau Marmont hotel.

headline: Ernest Sternglass, Physicist and Nuclear Critic, Dies at 91
text: Ernest J. Sternglass, whose research in radiation physics laid the foundation for important technological advances and who became a prominent opponent of nuclear weapons, died on Feb. 12 at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 91.

headline: Leaders of Ebola Fight at U.N. Express Worry About Eradication
text: The top two health officials managing the Ebola epidemic cast doubt Friday on a pledge by West African leaders to reduce new cases to zero by mid-April, and expressed concern about a possible rebound of the disease.

headline: Fate and Frailty May Test Miami Heat’s Front-Office Wizardry
text: According to Dwyane Wade, he and Chris Bosh “got very close over the last year and a half,” suggesting their enhanced bonding began around the beginning of LeBron James’s final season in Miami. Did Wade and Bosh already suspect that James was destined to dissolve the Big 3 partnership and leave them behind?

headline: In Remarks on Obama, Rudy Giuliani to the Core
text: He showed up unannounced and was initially not even invited, but he was prepared all the same.

headline: Judge Orders Stop to Detention of Families at Borders
text: A federal judge in Washington has ordered the Obama administration to stop its practice of detaining most women and children who were caught crossing the border illegally whether or not they had applied for asylum in the United States.

headline: No More Exploding Tank Cars
text: By some miracle, considering how close it was to the city of Charleston, the huge fireball from an enormous explosion of oil tank cars in West Virginia this week did not cost lives. But this latest explosion has served as a terrifying reminder that the industry’s ability to safely ship oil from North Dakota’s booming oil fields lags well behind its capacity to get that oil out of the ground.

headline: Lacrosse Star Carries Familiar Mantle in a Transitional Year
text: ALBANY — In the office of the Albany lacrosse coach Scott Marr, awards pile up like dishes in the sink. The all-American plaques are scattered across shelves. Assorted trophies fill bookcases and boxes in the corner.

headline: Talking Tough With the Banks
text: Several big banks are reportedly close to settling charges of price rigging in the multitrillion-dollar market for trading foreign currencies. The settlements being negotiated by the Justice Department are expected to be tougher than past settlements, but that is not saying much.

headline: Focus in Bronx: Stopping Opponents’ Bombers
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees did not assign a new player to Derek Jeter’s old locker at Steinbrenner Field. They knocked down the wall instead.

headline: Football’s L.A. Trick Play
text: Like most big cities in America, San Diego has its share of problems. It has issues with gangs, poverty and income inequality. It needs to do about $2 billion worth of infrastructure repairs. It has suffered through an epic drought.

headline: For Immigrants, Fear Returns After a Federal Judge’s Ruling
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — For Tomás Péndola, an immigrant from Argentina, it was a normal week teaching chemistry in a public high school here, filling a whiteboard with dense equations and coaxing his students to decipher them.

headline: Animated Character Who’s Five Apples Tall
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — If you had asked me when I started writing Wordplay that a constructor, much less a pair of them, would admit to using former Miss America Bess MYERSON as a seed entry in a themeless puzzle, I would have said you were crazy. But here we are, and it’s not so bad. As my mother used to say, “You live long enough, you eventually see everything.”

headline: Duke Energy Is Charged in Huge Coal Ash Leak
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — Federal prosecutors have filed criminal charges against Duke Energy, the nation’s largest electric utility, accusing the company of violating the federal Clean Water Act by illegally dumping millions of gallons of toxic coal ash into the Dan River in North Carolina. They also accused the company of failing to maintain equipment around at least two plants.

headline: Despite Cuomo’s Opposition, de Blasio Requests Housing Proposals for Queens Rail Depot
text: The de Blasio administration moved forward on Friday with a plan to reimagine a Queens rail depot as a haven for affordable housing, issuing a request for proposals to study the feasibility of developing the area known as Sunnyside Yards.

headline: Officials Defend Handling of Ferguson Case
text: ST. LOUIS — Last November, as a grand jury was wrapping up its review of the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager by a police officer in Ferguson, the prosecutor hoped that the decision could be announced on a Sunday morning. At that time, he reasoned, many people would be in church or at home, and the chances of a violent protest might be reduced.

headline: Breaking Ice on the Hudson
text: Along the frozen Hudson River, Coast Guard ice cutters clear a channel for barges carrying essential winter supplies such as heating oil and road salt.

headline: On the Hudson, an Icebreaker Ship Aids Boats
text: The Sturgeon Bay, a Coast Guard ship, can break through a field of ice more than a foot thick.

headline: Under Thick Coating, an Icebreaking Ship Uncovers the Hudson
text: HUDSON, N.Y. — As the sun came up on Friday morning, the Sturgeon Bay, a 140-foot Coast Guard icebreaker, creaked and lurched through a frozen river, sending cracks scattering as dark water rose to the surface in pools, spraying beads of water that hit the ice like marbles, solid by the time they landed.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 20, 2015
Bronx Man Sentenced to 50 Years in Killing of Girl, 10, in 2002 Gang Fight
text: It had been more than a decade since Danna Garrido saw her best friend, Malenny Mendez, who was 10 years old, killed by a stray bullet to the head after the two girls attended a christening party at a church in the Bronx.

headline: Heat Roll Past Knicks Amid Concern Over Chris Bosh
text: Moments before the national anthem on Friday at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks produced a highlight reel, featuring players whom fans could expect to see over the remaining 29 games of the season. It was not so much an inspirational video as a reminder of who was still on the team.

headline: What to Do if You Got the Wrong Tax Forms
text: One month into the tax-filing season, the federal government said it sent out incorrect tax forms to about 800,000 taxpayers who bought health insurance through HealthCare.gov.

headline: Ashton Carter, Defense Secretary, in Afghanistan for Security Talks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Four days after he was sworn in as defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter arrived in Afghanistan on Saturday morning to begin his own assessment of the security situation here since the United States wound down its combat mission last year.

headline: Events in New Jersey for Feb. 22-28, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island for Feb. 22-28, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: A Winter Quest With Mythology and a Map
text: “We’re doing something magical,” Kate Mueth told the 10 women and three girls on an empty stage at the John Drew Theater at Guild Hall in East Hampton a few weeks ago. This was the first rehearsal for “Zima!” — an outdoor performance by the Neo-Political Cowgirls, an East End dance theater company, founded by Ms. Mueth in 2008, that specializes in original site-specific works.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE FAULT IN OUR STARS (2014) Two teenage “cancer kids” — Hazel Grace Lancaster (Shailene Woodley), who expects to die soon from the thyroid cancer that has plagued her since childhood, and Augustus Waters (Ansel Elgort), known as Gus, who lost part of his leg to cancer but has been healthy since — fall in love while trying to lead extraordinary lives in Josh Boone’s adaptation of the young-adult novel by John Green. Willem Dafoe plays Peter Van Houten, the misanthropic author of Hazel’s favorite cancer story, who lectures the couple on the difference between fiction and reality; Sam Trammell and Laura Dern are Hazel’s stricken parents; and Nat Wolff is Gus’s slightly goofy wingman. “Though it is a tragic love story, it is also a perfect and irresistible fantasy,” A. O. Scott wrote of the film in The New York Times. “Hazel and Gus possess an absolute moral authority, an ability to assert the truth of their experience that few can share and many might covet.” He added, “The loudest weeping you hear — including your own — may arise not from grief or admiration, but from envy.”

headline: At the College of New Rochelle, a Show Meant to Provoke Double Takes
text: Entering the Castle Gallery at the College of New Rochelle, visitors encounter an arrangement of cherry blossoms in a glass vase. At least that’s what it appears to be. Closer observation reveals that the branch holding the flowers is actually a segment of plumbing pipe and that each delicate bud is a tiny pink toilet made of urethane foam.

headline: Events in Westchester for Feb. 22-28, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Corrections: February 21, 2015
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “When is a deal not really a deal? When it kicks the can down the road and when no one can agree on what was agreed.”

headline: Tentative Agreement Is Reached in West Coast Ports Dispute
text: LOS ANGELES — Shipowners and dockworkers reached a tentative deal on Friday night to end a protracted labor dispute that had jammed ship traffic at ports along the West Coast and taken a deepening economic toll on farmers, retailers and merchants across the country.

headline: Events in Connecticut for Feb. 22-28, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: N.H.L. Unveils Website Featuring Advanced Statistics
text: The N.H.L., working with the German software company SAP, unveiled a new statistics website Friday, including a section devoted solely to advanced statistics.

headline: In Service Sector, No Rest for the Working
text: On the nights when she has just seven hours between shifts at a Taco Bell in Tampa, Fla., Shetara Brown drops off her three young children with her mother. After work, she catches a bus to her apartment, takes a shower to wash off the grease and sleeps three and a half hours before getting back on the bus to return to her job.

headline: Yemen’s Former Leader, Held by Rebels, Leaves Capital
text: SANA, Yemen — To hear the Houthi militants who control this capital describe it, the country’s former president escaped from house arrest on Saturday by dressing as a woman, wearing a long black chador covering all but his eyes.

headline: Somali Deaths Climb to 25 In Hotel Attack
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — The death toll in an attack by suicide bombers at a hotel compound in Mogadishu on Friday rose to 25 people, with more than 40 people wounded, Somali officials said Saturday.

headline: How to Leave a Comment on Wordplay
text: SPECIAL POST — As some readers have noticed, there is no link on the opening page of Wordplay to leave a comment. However, you can still be part of the daily conversation.

headline: London Fashion Week: Central Saint Martins Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Making a Promise to Stay Silent
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: An Officer and a Thespian
text: Jinho Ferreira, 39, left, is a sheriff’s deputy and performer in Alameda County, Calif.

headline: Debt’s Two Sides: Riches and Misery
text: Debt is a double-edged sword. Charles Dickens’s character Wilkins Micawber warned eloquently of debt’s downside: “Annual income twenty pounds, annual expenditure nineteen nineteen and six, result happiness. Annual income twenty pounds, annual expenditure twenty pound ought and six, result misery.”

headline: When Smoke Gets in Your Closet
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Lew Cirne of New Relic: Six Chairs for an Ideal Meeting
text: This interview with Lew Cirne,  chief executive of New Relic, a software analytics company based in San Francisco, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Why Giuliani and Other Obama Critics Play the ‘American’ Card
text: When Rudolph Giuliani said that he does “not believe that the president loves America,” he became the latest in a long line of public figures to question the loyalty or allegiance of the country’s first nonwhite president. While these criticisms are ostensibly directed at Barack Obama’s worldview, as Mr. Giuliani later said, they appear to reflect — or exploit — the tendency to associate being American with being white.

headline: In Whole Foods Backlash, a Chance to Air Out Stagnant Boardrooms
text: Large, institutional investors in the United States are generally a passive lot. In board elections and other corporate governance matters, they’re hesitant to speak up. All too often they vote their shares in lock step with management.

text: Scenes from the Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Kerry Raises Prospect of More Sanctions Against Russia Over Ukraine
text: LONDON — Nearly one week after a cease-fire was supposed to have gone into effect in Ukraine, Secretary of State John Kerry met with his British counterpart to discuss the imposition of additional sanctions because of what he called Russia’s “brazen” violations of the agreement.

headline: Kleiner Court Memorandum
text: Kleiner, Perkins, Caulfield & Byers court memo in Ellen Pao’s discrimination case against her former employer.

headline: Pao Complaint for Damages
text: The complaint for damages in Ellen Pao’s discrimination case against her former employer, Kleiner, Perkins, Caulfield & Byers.

headline: Variety: A Filmy Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — The quote from today’s acrostic puzzle by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon is just what you might expect to hear from “The Divine Miss M,” or BETTE MIDLER.

headline: London Fashion Week: Central Saint Martins Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Battle to Retake Iraqi City Looms as Test of Obama’s ISIS Strategy
text: WASHINGTON — American intelligence agencies and the Pentagon are struggling to determine how difficult it will be to retake Mosul, the Islamic State’s de facto capital in Iraq, as planning intensifies for a battle that is becoming a major test of the Obama administration’s strategy to stop the spread of the terrorist group in the Middle East.

headline: Bush Spouse Backs Jeb, but Is Wary of Family Business
text: CORAL GABLES, Fla. — For 20 years, Columba Bush anticipated the day she would have to answer one big question: Would she support her husband, Jeb Bush, if he decided to run for president?

headline: Sibling’s Subversive Yet Chic Punk Mohawks
text: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

headline: The Creative Commerce of Peter Lik, Landscape Photographer
text: The seller of many millions of dollars worth of prints made a calculated splash with a photograph that reportedly sold for over $6 million.

headline: Peter Lik’s Recipe for Success: Sell Prints. Print Money.
text: Peter Lik is in awe of himself. When he describes his career as a fine-art photographer, he speaks with the satisfaction of a guy who has performed miracles, at the pace of a bystander who just caught a glimpse of Superman. The words tumble forth in self-exalting, run-on sentences, most of them laced with profanity, all of them in the sunny, chummy accent of his native Australia.

headline: On Oscars Weekend, Tom Ford Draws the Starriest Front Row of the Fashion Season
text: Tom Ford staged a fashion show in Hollywood on Oscars weekend, and it turns out that, yes, everyone would show up for it.

headline: J.W. Anderson: Fall 2015 RTW
text: London

headline: Venezuela Mayor Is Accused of U.S.-Backed Coup Plot
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The mayor of Caracas, Antonio Ledezma, who was arrested last week by intelligence agents, has been indicted on charges of conspiracy against the Venezuelan government and plotting an American-backed coup.

headline: The Star-Studded Tom Ford Fashion Show
text: Celebrities like Scarlett Johansson and Julianne Moore show up for Tom Ford’s show in Los Angeles..

headline: With Hendrick Motorsports Dominant, Sprint Cup Is Becoming a One-Team Race
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Las Vegas bookmakers have already set the odds for the 2015 Nascar Sprint Cup championship, and the consensus is that Jimmie Johnson is the driver to beat. Kevin Harvick, last year’s champion, and Jeff Gordon are among the other favorites, along with the 2012 winner, Brad Keselowski.

headline: U.S. Open to Slowing Troop Pullout in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Four days into his tenure as defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter arrived in Afghanistan on Saturday morning and opened up the possibility of slowing the withdrawal of the last American troops in the country to help keep the Taliban at bay.

headline: Cavaliers Take Off Behind Soaring Offense
text: As the N.B.A. arrives at the stretch run of its grueling 82-game season, LeBron James and the Cleveland Cavaliers are far from the pole. In fact, if the playoffs started today, they would not even have home-court advantage. But after a blistering run in the month leading up to the All-Star break — at one point they won 12 in a row — the Cavaliers appear to have hit their stride and are gaining quickly on the rest of the Eastern Conference.

headline: Veteran Helps Islanders Win and Laugh
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Johnny Boychuk brings a booming slap shot, veteran leadership and a vital bonus quality to the first-place Islanders.

headline: Verbatim: Rudy Giuliani Comments Further on Obama and America
text: — Former New York Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in an interview Friday with the New York Times.

headline: An Ex-Yankee Starts Over, and May Win a Starting Job
text: BRADENTON, Fla. — This is the way it can happen in baseball. An organization signs you at age 16, a decade or more passes, and then you take a phone call from the general manager while working out in the off-season. Just like that, traded to the Pittsburgh Pirates.

headline: Coloring Sports in Action
text: Photographs from Steve Boyle’s Powder Sports series, in which colored powder helps bring out the action.

headline: Debating a Change of Faith Under Brutal Captivity
text: VATICAN CITY — The Islamic State’s beheading in August of the journalist James Foley stirred global outrage, fury and despair. But for many of his fellow Roman Catholics, Mr. Foley’s death in Syria transformed him into a symbol of faith under the most brutal of conditions.

headline: Photos: Six Sports and a Cloud of Dust
text: Photographing sports is as much about capturing the action as it is about presenting the athlete. These days, I’m off the sidelines for many assignments, instead working in studio environments for editorial and commercial projects. Athlete portraiture is all about showing the athlete’s personality, strengths, weaknesses, motivation, intensity, commitment. But for the Powder Sports series, a personal project, I wanted to step away from all that.

headline: People Aren’t Androids
text: My soon-to-be-colleague Branko Milanovic writes forcefully against the term “human capital”; Elizabeth Bruenig notes an especially unpleasant use of the term by reformicons trying to sell child tax credits to their conservative allies.

headline: Red Carpet Poetry
text: Actors and directors recite a standout line from their films during the 2015 movie awards season.

headline: For Tens of Millions, Obamacare Is Working
text: In its second year, Obamacare is proving to be a success. From Feb. 22, 2015.

headline: The Bright Side of Parkinson’s
text: EUGENE, Ore. — FOUR years ago, I was told I had Parkinson’s disease, a condition that affects about one million Americans. The disease is relentlessly progressive; often starting with a tremor in one limb on one side of the body, it spreads. The patient’s muscles become more rigid, frequently leading to a stooped posture, and movements slow down and get smaller and less fluid. As the disease advances — usually over a number of years — the patient becomes more and more disabled, experiencing symptoms from constipation to sleep disorders to cognitive impairment.

headline: Straight Talk for White Men
text: SUPERMARKET shoppers are more likely to buy French wine when French music is playing, and to buy German wine when they hear German music. That’s true even though only 14 percent of shoppers say they noticed the music, a study finds.

headline: Uniting Europe’s Financial Markets
text: The leaders who created the European Union hoped that binding together their economies would increase prosperity and reduce the chance of conflict. But the union is far from complete, especially in the financial sector.

headline: The G.O.P. Policy Test
text: THE economy is sluggish but improving. President Obama’s approval rating is mediocre but not disastrous. Memories of Mitt Romney’s unsuccessful presidential campaign are relatively fresh — not least because Romney popped up briefly to remind everyone of them. And the Republicans pondering a run for president in 2016 all seem to sense that they need do to things a little, well, differently if they expect to ultimately win.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Doug Biesecker
text: Doug Biesecker, a solar physicist, is the chief program scientist overseeing the Deep Space Climate Observatory satellite (nicknamed DSCOVR) that was launched this month.

headline: Whose Great Outdoors?
text: Readers respond to a Sunday Review article, “Leaving Only Footsteps? Think Again.”

headline: In Big Media Town, ‘Core’ Beat in Flux
text: AS Dean Baquet sees it, there are some coverage areas at which The Times simply must excel.

headline: Hillary, Jeb and $$$$$$
text: LAST week began with the comedy extravaganza of the “Saturday Night Live” reunion, but not one of its sketches or jokes was half as funny as four words three days later by Jeb Bush.

headline: Mountaineering’s Greatest Climb Unravels
text: ESTES PARK, Colo. — THE greatest climb in the history of alpinism, a story of mythological proportions, occurred on Jan. 31, 1959. Cerro Torre, a 10,262-foot spire of granite, rises from the Southern Patagonia Ice Cap like a sharpened spear, so steep that climbing it had long been deemed impossible.

headline: Don’t Give Up the Gains in Education
text: Congress made the right decision a decade ago when it required states to administer yearly tests to public school students — and improve instruction for poor and minority students — in return for federal education aid.

headline: Campus Life and Guns
text: The gun lobby is flirting with self-parody as it exploits the issue of sexual assaults on college campuses by proposing a solution of — what else? — having students carry guns. Experts who study the complicated issue of predatory behavior and advise colleges point out that rapes often begin in social situations. “It would be nearly impossible to run for a gun,” said John Foubert, the national president of One in Four, a rape-prevention organization.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Brainless Trust
text: WASHINGTON — I had been keeping an open mind on Jeb Bush.

headline: Beware the Beagle
text: CHEVY CHASE, Md. — A BEAGLE, Miss P, was the surprise winner of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Tuesday. What a perfect name for a beagle! Our beagle was Sasha, but we could have called her Miss Pee, because the only solution to our decade-plus struggle to housetrain her was to take away all the rugs.

headline: Establishment Republicans Question Scott Walker’s Handling of Giuliani Comments
text: While former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York has been criticized for remarks he made at a small dinner event in Manhattan about President Obama and his “love” for America, establishment Republicans also have questioned the reaction of the person being honored at that reception, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, who is a likely Republican presidential contender in 2016.

headline: Deeper Ties to Corporate Cash for Doubtful Climate Researcher
text: For years, politicians wanting to block legislation on climate change have bolstered their arguments by pointing to the work of a handful of scientists who claim that greenhouse gases pose little risk to humanity.

headline: Please Don’t Thank Me for My Service
text: HUNTER GARTH was in a gunfight for his life — and about to lose.

headline: Eovaldi’s Untapped Potential Has the Yankees Dreaming of Big Things
text: TAMPA, Fla. — When pitchers and catchers reported for spring training Friday, there were questions about the frayed right elbow of Masahiro Tanaka, the surgically repaired right knee of C. C. Sabathia and the expected return of Ivan Nova from elbow surgery by June. Then there is the frailty of Michael Pineda, who has been a revelation when he has not been on the disabled list, which is almost constantly.

headline: A Deal That Preserves Greece’s Place in Eurozone, and Fiscal Restraints
text: BRUSSELS — Just a month ago, after being propelled to power by a wave of anger at Greece’s economic miseries, Alexis Tsipras declared his left-wing Syriza party’s election victory the start of a Europe-wide revolt against austerity. “Europe is going to change,” he said before setting off on a tour of European capitals to rally support for a more relaxed new direction.

headline: An Ex-Coach’s Spirited Ascent of a 140-Character Soapbox
text: After winning 648 games as a Division I coach, Tom Penders now retreats to a winter home in Miami during college basketball season.

headline: Concern in Britain as Schoolgirls Seek to Join Islamic State
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said Saturday that the country’s authorities would do everything they could to help three British schoolgirls who were believed to be traveling to Syria to join the Islamic State militant group.

headline: Disclosures of Battle Plan by Pentagon Startle Many
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has been eager to show momentum against the Islamic State after a conference last week dramatized the hurdles to countering the terrorist group’s propaganda. But the Pentagon may have gone too far in sharing its military planning.

headline: Not a Splashy Move, but Maybe a Key One for the Thunder
text: At the trading deadline, a flurry of activity had some people wondering how Goran Dragic would turn around the fortunes of the Miami Heat and others celebrating Kevin Garnett’s return to Minnesota. Brandon Knight, in the middle of a breakout season for the Milwaukee Bucks, was on the move to the Phoenix Suns, and the Philadelphia 76ers continued their pursuit of players no one has ever heard of.

headline: Party Girl Hair at J.W. Anderson
text: Eastern European club girls were the high-energy beauty inspiration backstage for J.W. Anderson’s fall/winter 2015 runway. “It’s like this girl has been up all night dancing, and then goes to the nightclub bathroom to pull her hair back out of her eyes,” explained the hairstylist Anthony Turner of the unfinished feel. After saturating the hair with L’Oreal’s Infinitum mousse, he pulled it back into a chignon, twisting and scrunching it up into a bun. This haven’t-made-it-to-bed hair is aligned with the ’80s, good-taste-bad-taste mood of the show (and its banging techno sound track). Finally, he secured the bun with the kind of cheap, plastic comb that you’d discover in one of London’s discount pound stores. “It’s an antidote to the somber mood of last season,” explained Turner. “It’s not meant to look perfect — she’s having too much fun!”

headline: Flood of Briefs on the Health Care Law’s Subsidies Hits the Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — Liberal groups are emphasizing states’ rights, a theme calculated to appeal to conservative Supreme Court justices. The insurance industry, once a foe, has come to the aid of President Obama.

headline: Eighties-Inspired, Fire-Engine-Red Boots at J.W. Anderson
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: The Dinner Party as Teachable Moment
text: Chef Matt O’Connor displayed considerable finesse as he puréed broccoli florets and butternut squash at the home of Liza Wang in Irvington on a recent Friday night. But as the evening progressed, he discovered that a dazzling set of kitchen skills does not always guarantee the undivided attention of a roomful of amateur cooks.

headline: The Nose Knows the Way to Barbecue
text: Just approaching the front door at Walrus + Carpenter — an eatery in Bridgeport’s Black Rock neighborhood that is locally famous for its barbecue — gives a good idea of what awaits inside. The rich, greasy aroma of slow-cooked meat drifts from the property’s back-lot smoker; festooning the outer wall of the restaurant building is a painted mural in the shape of a swine. There might as well be a giant overhead neon sign, flashing Abandon Diets, All Ye Who Enter Here.

headline: C. C. Sabathia Hopes His Results Recover With His Knee
text: TAMPA, Fla. — C. C. Sabathia looked as imposing as ever as he walked into the Yankees’ clubhouse Saturday morning. Whether he returns to being so imposing on the mound remains an open question.

headline: Little Bit Country, Lots of Other Stuff
text: At the peak of their powers, the country duo Florida Georgia Line took hip-hop attitude, retrofitted with rural twang and concerns, and stomped to the top of Nashville on the backs of the status-quo bros who came just before them. Florida Georgia Line — Brian Kelley and Tyler Hubbard — weren’t any good at the status quo, but it turned out they were positively great at tossing it out.

headline: Art: Scenes Inspired by ‘Don Quixote’
text: Cervantes’s comic masterpiece, “Don Quixote,” inspired many artworks, most notably tapestries by Charles Coypel, Louis XV’s artist. Coypel created 28 tapestries woven at the Gobelins Manufactory in Paris. Starting on Wednesday, the Frick Collection will present a complete series of the scenes. The exhibition, “Coypel’s Don Quixote Tapestries: Illustrating a Spanish Novel in Eighteenth-Century France,” will include five of the original paintings they were based on; these have never been seen before in New York and are on loan from the Palais Impérial de Compiègne and the Musée Jacquemart-André, Paris. The museum will also show three Gobelins tapestry panels from the J. Paul Getty Museum and two Flemish tapestries inspired by Coypel from the Frick Collection, which have not been on view in more than 10 years. The Frick’s tapestries — rarely seen, because they take so much room to display — were cleaned in 1999 and restored at the Textile Conservation Lab at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. (Through May 17, frick.org.)

headline: For This Musician, the Time Has Come
text: The excellent Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes waited until his 40s — when he said he felt emotionally ready to perform Beethoven — to begin recording the Beethoven concertos with the Mahler Chamber Orchestra. Judging by the result, the wait has paid off. On Monday, Mr. Andsnes and the ensemble offer Beethoven’s second, third and fourth concertos, with Mr. Andsnes conducting from the keyboard. On Wednesday, they perform the first and fifth concertos. (8 p.m. Monday and Wednesday, Carnegie Hall, carnegiehall.org.)

headline: Are You Going to Eat That?
text: Shocker: actors consuming food. Or are they? In the premiere of “Dinner at Tiffani’s,” Wednesday night on the Cooking Channel, the running gag is whether the show’s host, Tiffani Thiessen, late of “White Collar,” and her friends Nathan Fillion, Willie Garson and Lindsay Price actually ate the morsels they were shown scarfing down on their hit shows, or even from the catering table off screen. On “Sex and the City,” Mr. Garson reports, cast members had carte blanche at any New York restaurant, with food guaranteed in their trailers in 20 minutes. In “Beverly Hills 90210,” Ms. Price says, no one dared eat. (Bikini bodies, duh.) On the screen in “Castle,” Mr. Fillion prefers to wave his fork around and mime chewing. Whether Ms. Thiessen’s guests applied their sleight of hand to her roasted chicken, brussels sprouts with pancetta and fresh figs drizzled in lavender honey is anyone’s guess. But food isn’t really the point when you’re promising a walk down memory lane with Jason Priestley, Lance Bass, Elizabeth Berkley and Jonathan Silverman.

headline: Watch That Lady and See a Star
text: “Vivacious Lady” (1938) is a good place to start when contemplating the charms of Ginger Rogers, the subject of a MoMA Acteurism series. First there’s that title, a reminder of Rogers’s always welcome presence, whether dancing with Fred Astaire or falling in love, as she does in this movie with Jimmy Stewart, whose own acteurism is also nicely on display. And then there’s the story, which gets at what made Rogers such an invaluable star.

headline: Designed to Miss Their Connection
text: When the choreographer Pam Tanowitz contemplated her commission for Works & Process at the Guggenheim, her first idea was a story ballet. One hitch. She had decided to use music by four composers: David Lang, Ted Hearne, Hannah Lash and Caroline Shaw. And during her research for the piece, “Broken Story (wherein there is no ecstasy),” she came across J. D. Salinger’s “The Heart of a Broken Story,” a love story about two people who never meet.

headline: Among the Navajos, a Renewed Debate About Gay Marriage
text: TOHATCHI, N.M. — Tradition reigns here on the Navajo reservation, where the words of elders are treated as gospel and many people still live or pray in circular dwellings called hogans.

headline: Navajo Nation’s Gay Marriage Controversy
text: Alray Nelson is an outspoken opponent of the tribal law that bans same-sex marriage.

headline: Polluted Air Cuts Years Off Lives of Millions in India, Study Finds
text: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — More than half of India’s population lives in places with such polluted air that each person loses an average of 3.2 years in life expectancy, according to a recent study by researchers from the University of Chicago, Yale and Harvard.

headline: Icons in the Struggle for Racial Equality
text: One day in the summer of 1955, when the artist Pamela Chatterton-Purdy was 15 years old, her father got a call from Jackie Robinson, the Brooklyn Dodgers’ second baseman and the first black man to play Major League Baseball in the modern era. Robinson was planning to buy a home in North Stamford, Conn., near where her family lived, and he wanted to hire her father’s van company for the move.

headline: Herman Rosenblat, 85, Dies; Made Up Holocaust Love Story
text: The first curse on mankind was imposed because of an apple, and for all that happened to Herman Rosenblat in his 85 years — the horrors inflicted in Nazi concentration camps, the gunshot wound he suffered when his Brooklyn television repair shop was robbed, the global fame bestowed by two appearances on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” — it is an apple for which he will be most remembered. That first bite of the fruit was built on a lie.

headline: Fear and Withdrawal
text: In the fall of 2014 the author decided to quit the prescription medications she has been taking to treat her anxiety, depression and insomnia, and began the process of gradually reducing her dosages. In Going Off, a series of Anxiety posts in the coming weeks, she will chronicle the challenges she faces from both the drugs and the withdrawal in her pursuit of a drug-free life.

headline: Making a Fresh Start, Keeping the Cozy Feel
text: There should be no doubt that the setting for the life story of Joseph Bonacore, the owner and chef of Lawson Pub, would be Oceanside. He was born and raised here, and when he was a teenager, he worked in the kitchen of a restaurant on the site of where the Pub is today.

A local cover band played just steps away from shelves of raw honey and refrigerated glass cases, while a large, bearded man watched the door, collecting the $5 cover fee from scores of locals, many bundled in fleece and flannel.

headline: Old India’s Village of Warriors Becomes Birthplace of Bouncers
text: GURGAON, India — In a smoky nightclub on the third floor of the Sahara Mall, blowing off steam to the thudding bass line of a Bollywood dance mix, are the inhabitants of the new India — the sales representatives and software developers and call-center cubicle dwellers, all of them dancing giddily, hands flung in the air.

text: Blissfully there is little to do on these islands beyond swimming, sunning and gazing at the coconut groves.

headline: Funding That Climate Researcher Failed to Disclose
text: These documents show that Wei-Hock Soon, a part-time researcher at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Mass., received funding from fossil-fuel interests that he subsequently failed to disclose in a string of scientific papers.

headline: Neighbors Step Up to Help New Yorkers Through Tough Times
text: The Maley family gets to see a lot more of one another.

headline: Matt Harvey’s Return Brings Rare Buzz to Mets Camp
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — A few hundred Mets fans crowded around the chain-link fence Saturday morning, down the right-field line, taking pictures and holding out baseballs to sign. They jockeyed for position just to watch Mets pitchers stand around, just to catch a glimpse of the next step in Matt Harvey’s return tour.

headline: N.F.L. Teams Dissect Differences Between Marcus Mariota and Jameis Winston
text: INDIANAPOLIS — For the last four days, deep within Lucas Oil Stadium, Marcus Mariota and Jameis Winston have had their heights, weights, arm lengths and hand sizes carefully inspected.

headline: Carpetbagger Video: Remembering Their Lines
text: Throughout awards season, the Bagger has asked actors and directors on the red carpet to recite standout lines from their films, projects they finished many months before. Watch Ethan Hawke, Alejandro G. Iñárritu, Tilda Swinton and others give it a shot.

headline: In Derby Warm-Up Race, a Favorite Is Disqualified
text: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — Jack Wolf was not overly disappointed as he watched Itsaknockout, his blossoming 3-year-old colt, seemingly finish second by two and three-quarter lengths to the heavily favored Upstart in the Fountain of Youth Stakes on Saturday at Gulfstream Park.

headline: At Northern Trust Open, Frustration Gives Way to Being in the Hunt
text: LOS ANGELES — On Thursday, Sang-Moon Bae was so disgusted with his play, he signed for his round of even-par 71 at the Northern Trust Open and left the tournament grounds without bothering to try to find his swing on the range.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 21, 2015
Even as Many Eyes Watch, Brutality at Rikers Island Persists
text: On Sept. 2, four correction officers pulled Jose Guadalupe, an inmate classified in medical records as seriously mentally ill, into his solitary-confinement cell at Rikers Island and beat him unconscious.

headline: Retired White Plains Police Officer Said to Kill 2 Daughters and Himself
text: A retired police officer in White Plains shot and killed two of his children on Saturday before committing suicide, according to a local newspaper.

headline: Turkish Military Enters Syria to Evacuate Soldiers and Move Tomb’s Remains, Reports Say
text: ISTANBUL — The Turkish Army launched an operation into Syria to evacuate soldiers guarding the Tomb of Suleyman Shah, which has been besieged by Islamic State militants, and move the tomb’s remains, an official and Turkish news media reported on Sunday.

headline: Kyle Busch Will Miss Daytona After Crash
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Kyle Busch will miss Nascar’s showcase Daytona 500 on Sunday after breaking his right leg and left foot Saturday in a crash at Daytona International Speedway, an accident that quickly led track officials to vow to install safety barriers.

headline: Inmates to Be Transferred After Riot at Texas Prison
text: A federal prison in South Texas over the next week will transfer up to 2,800 inmates to other institutions in the area, after a riot on Friday rendered the facility uninhabitable, an official said.

text: “The demonization of detainees is embedded in everyday practice.”

text: A blistering combination of winter conditions — high winds, freezing rain, moderate snowfall — has struck the region as part of a cold snap, but on Friday it was predicted that temperatures will lift enough for the region to experience a warm Sunday afternoon.
