headline: What’s on TV Sunday
text: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 87TH ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS Neil Patrick Harris, that awards-show wonder, makes his debut as host of the ceremony, broadcast live from the Dolby Theater in Los Angeles. Oddsmakers are suggesting that Eddie Redmayne will take home the Oscar for his portrayal of the physicist Stephen Hawking in “The Theory of Everything” and that J. K. Simmons will win for best supporting actor as a music teacher from hell in “Whiplash.” In the best actress category, Julianne Moore is the front-runner for her portrait of a professor with early-onset Alzheimer’s in “Still Alice,” while Patricia Arquette, as a mother filmed across 12 years in “Boyhood,” is the favorite for supporting actress. And Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s “Birdman” may squeak by in the best picture category, which is filled out by Richard Linklater’s “Boyhood,” a close contender; Clint Eastwood’s “American Sniper”; Wes Anderson’s “The Grand Budapest Hotel”; Morten Tyldum’s “The Imitation Game”; Ava DuVernay’s “Selma”; James Marsh’s “The Theory of Everything” and Damien Chazelle’s “Whiplash.” Mr. Iñárritu, Mr. Linklater, Mr. Anderson, Mr. Tyldum and Bennett Miller, for “Foxcatcher,” are also nominated for best director. The countdown begins at 1:30 on E!; at 6 on Pop and WGN America; and at 6 on Channel 11. Red-carpet coverage begins at 7 on ABC. Postshow coverage follows at 11:30 on E!

headline: Lenovo and Superfish Penetrate the Heart of a Computer’s Security
text: The same week researchers reported that the National Security Agency had been embedding surveillance tools in the guts of thousands of machines in Iran, Russia and other countries, it was revealed that the world’s largest personal computer company had been doing something similar to its customers.

headline: Sri Lanka Premier Starts With Fixing Civil War Ills
text: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Paintings at Temple Trees, this country’s White House, are still leaning against walls waiting to be hung, and the gated grounds are no longer teeming with guards and stewards who served the home’s previous occupant like supplicants at a royal court.

headline: China Protests India Leader’s Visit to Disputed Border Area
text: HONG KONG — China summoned India’s ambassador in Beijing to protest Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s visit to a border area claimed by both countries, a reminder that the world’s two most populous countries have yet to resolve vast territorial disputes that have simmered for more than half a century.

headline: Turkish Military Evacuates Soldiers Guarding Tomb in Syria
text: ISTANBUL — The Turkish Army sent armored troops deep into Syria late Saturday to recover the remains of a major historical figure and to evacuate the guards at his besieged tomb, the prime minister announced in a televised news conference on Sunday.

text: Chris, my fiancé, headed down the steps as my 10-year-old daughter skipped behind him. “Don’t put her in the front seat!” I said. “Make sure she’s buckled in!”

headline: ‘Birdman’ and ‘Boyhood’ Split Top Independent Spirit Awards
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — The weird thing about the Film Independent Spirit Awards is that they’re genuinely kind of fun. Unlike other awards shows, which can skew stuffy, tedious, forced or odd, there’s a sort of devil-may-care frisson in the air. This is partly because of its locale – a giant tent on the beach here — partly because of the fact that Oscar voting has closed and the awards are a mere 24 hours away (hallelujah!), and partly because of the still scrappy and, yes, independent spirit of it all.

headline: Language Quiz: Are You on Fleek?
text: Yolo. Rekt. Bae. Xans. Lordt. How well do you know your Internet slang?

headline: 1915: Germans Own to Big Reverse, Bombard Rheims
text: LONDON — The Germans admit serious setbacks and heavy losses within the last few days. They admit it according to their now well-established code — by useless bombardment of civilians, or the destruction of a monument of architecture. Sometimes it has been a church destroyed, sometimes it has been women and children slaughtered. Sometimes is has been Arras, sometimes is has been Ypres. When everything else fails there is always Pont-à-Mousson. In admitting their recent reverse, the Germans have turned again to Rheims, where there is both a magnificent church to be shelled and plenty of civilians to be killed. This indicates that they regard their latest defeats as unusually serious, and wish to make their admission of them equally so.

headline: President Obama Has, in Fact, Expressed Love for His Country

headline: As a Social Service Agency Collapses, a Union Leader Worries for Its Workers

headline: Shoppers Cautioned After Threat Against Mall of America

headline: The Changing Nature of Middle-Class Jobs
text: The types of jobs that pay middle-class wages have shifted since 1980. Fewer of these positions are in male-dominated production occupations, while a greater share are in workplaces more open to women.

headline: Health Care Opens Stable Career Path, Taken Mainly by Women
text: HUNTINGTON, W.Va. — For Tabitha Waugh, it was another typical day of chaos on the sixth-floor cancer ward.

headline: The Health Care Wager
text: A surge in spending on health care is translating into well-paying jobs, but opportunities are only available to those willing to put in the time and money to retrain.

headline: In Pre-Primary Pivot to Right, Walker Shifts Tone on Abortion
text: DES MOINES — It was a memorable political ad: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin spoke directly into the camera in a 30-second spot last fall and called abortion an “agonizing” decision. He described himself as pro-life but, borrowing the language of the abortion rights movement, pointed to legislation he signed that leaves “the final decision to a woman and her doctor.”

headline: 1940: Washington’s Birthday Celebrated in Paris
text: Americans in Paris, celebrating Washington’s Birthday in the capital of a country at war, joined in a spontaneous enthusiastic ovation for heroic Finland at the banquet given by the American Club of Paris at the Grand Hotel yesterday evening [Feb. 22]. Rising from their seats, 300 members and guests of the club acclaimed Harri Holma, Finnish Minister, who was one of many foreign diplomats present. Sir Ronald Campbell, British Ambassador, was also given an ovation. It was the largest gathering the American Club has seen for a long time, and oldtimers recalled that during the World War the club rarely mustered 100 members at its function. Representing the French government, Camille Chautemps, Vice-President of the Council, paid tribute to the victims of Nazi aggression and recalled that George Washington was not only a victorious general, but a liberator and hero of democracy, defending individual liberty.

headline: Review: ‘Harlequinade’ Returns to New York City Ballet
text: Fifty years ago this month, when New York City Ballet danced the premiere of George Balanchine’s “Harlequinade,” it was already old-fashioned. Set to the same frothy score by Riccardo Drigo that Marius Petipa had used 65 years earlier for “Les Millions d’Arlequin,” this two-act ballet is one of Balanchine’s affectionate recreations of Petipa style and Franco-Russian tradition. It’s the kind of show that is always described as a confection, and when it returned to the David H. Koch Theater on Wednesday, after an absence of a decade, its antique charm was there, preserved. Yet the taste was not as fresh as possible.

headline: Review: American Symphony Orchestra Revives ‘Mona Lisa,’ Inspired by Leonardo’s Muse
text: Leonardo da Vinci’s Mona Lisa has inspired books, imitations, satirical spinoffs, songs and staged works — among them Max von Schillings’s opera “Mona Lisa.” It received over 1,200 performances in the decade after its 1915 composition, including a production at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Mary Katrantzou’s Doll-Inspired Eye Makeup
text: “A doll lash, but not a dolly look” is how the makeup artist Val Garland described the bold approach to beauty backstage at Mary Katrantzou’s fall/winter 2015 show. Borrowing tricks from the ’90s club kids, who would wear tiny dots beneath their eyes for dance floor drama, Garland followed the direct line of sight, drawing an oblong below the pupil with MAC’s Midnight Well eye shadow in black onyx. False lashes were then chopped into small, square sections and ironed (yes, actually ironed) flat before being layered onto the lower lashline just above the oblong for extra emphasis. The look was finished simply with a careful curl of the top lashes (for prettiness) and a generous dab of lip balm. In a collection where texture and vibrancy loomed large, this low-key but look-at-me beauty fit the bill.

headline: Review: ‘Belladonna,’ a Poisonous Duet at the 92nd Street Y
text: It’s all too easy for a dance based on a story to lose its way. In “Belladonna,” the choreographer Adam Barruch finds inspiration in Nathaniel Hawthorne’s spooky tale “Rappaccini’s Daughter,” in which a scientist cultivates a garden of poisonous plants for medicinal purposes. His beautiful daughter, Beatrice, takes care of them; Giovanni, a young student, rents a room overlooking the garden and becomes obsessed with her, only to learn that the reason she can take care of the plants is because she is poisonous herself.

headline: Review: Trinity Wall Street and Julian Wachner Play Carnegie Hall
text: Julian Wachner, the impressive director of music and the arts at Trinity Wall Street, didn’t seem the slightest bit nervous in his first performance as a conductor at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. He affably welcomed the audience, thanking everyone for braving not just the winter weather but the program he had planned. The concert paired Ives’s Fourth Symphony, generally considered one of the most complex and challenging 20th-century symphonic works, and a rare performance of an intense 60-minute oratorio, “Turbae ad Passionem Gregorianam,” by the Argentine-born composer Alberto Ginastera, first performed in 1975.

headline: A Rare Chair
text: In 1954, Hans Wegner created his famous Tub Chair, consisting of two upholstered shells on an elegant bent-plywood frame. The goal was that it “should be beautiful from all angles.” It has since become one of the most iconic examples of midcentury Modernism, and yet only three of the chairs were ever made — until now. The original is being produced by the Danish workshop PP Mobler and is sold in the U.S. exclusively at Wyeth.

headline: What’s on TV Monday
text: 9 P.M. (HBO) CITIZENFOUR (2014) Laura Poitras had been working on a film about surveillance for two years when Edward J. Snowden, the National Security Agency whistle-blower, contacted her in January 2013, using the name “Citizenfour.” When Mr. Snowden let Ms. Poitras know that he would not conceal his identity as the source of information about N.S.A. surveillance, she persuaded him to let her film their encounter. This Oscar-nominated documentary chronicles the encounter in a Hong Kong hotel room of Ms. Poitras; Glenn Greenwald, the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist who first wrote about Mr. Snowden’s revelations; and Mr. Snowden as he hands over classified documents that provide evidence of the N.S.A.’s invasion of privacy and copes with the resulting media storm. “Cinema, even in the service of journalism, is always more than reporting, and focusing on what Ms. Poitras’s film is about risks ignoring what it is,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It’s a tense and frightening thriller that blends the brisk globe-trotting of the ‘Bourne’ movies with the spooky, atmospheric effects of a Japanese horror film. And it is also a primal political fable for the digital age, a real-time tableau of the confrontation between the individual and the state.” He added: “Thinking about the issues Ms. Poitras raises can induce a kind of epistemological vertigo. What do we know about what is known about us? Who knows it? Can we trust them? These questions are terrifying, and so is ‘Citizenfour.’ ”

headline: Complicating the Picture of Urban Life
text: The 1980 image of Paul Newman, taken in the South Bronx during the filming of “Fort Apache, the Bronx,” could be a production still or a publicity photo. Finally, they arrived at the famed Südtribüne, the terraced stand at the south end of the stadium, which rises like a tilted baking sheet and clumps together some 25,000 spectators in what is known throughout soccer as the Yellow Wall.

headline: Oscars 2015: Passionate Speeches, but Few Surprises

headline: The Manifestation of Señor Bacon

We’d succumbed to the pastime of browsing cute animal photos, and together, on our respective screens, ended up looking at pig pictures. When I joked about getting one of our own, Jason said, “We could name him Señor Bacon.”

headline: Who Loves America?

The histrionics have shed their ability to shock. Most right-minded Americans — ethically speaking, not ideologically speaking — have moved on.

headline: Even Better Than a Tax Cut
text: WASHINGTON — WITH the early stages of the 2016 presidential campaign underway and millions of Americans still hurting financially, both parties are looking for ways to address wage stagnation. That’s the good news. The bad news is that both parties are offering tax cuts as a solution. What has hurt workers’ paychecks is not what the government takes out, but what their employers no longer put in — a dynamic that tax cuts cannot eliminate.

headline: Cutting Through India’s Smog
text: Proof of the grave air pollution problem confronting India is seen not just in the suffocating smog that on many days crowds out the sun in New Delhi, the world’s most polluted city. It can be measured as well in the fact that the country has the world’s highest death rate from chronic respiratory diseases, which kill an estimated 1.5 million Indians every year. A 2014 World Health Organization report concluded of the 20 most polluted cities in the world, India has 13.

headline: When Medical Devices Spread Superbugs
text: Germs that are resistant to antibiotics are cropping up with alarming frequency at American hospitals. A lethal “superbug” known as CRE infected seven patients at the Ronald Reagan U.C.L.A. Medical Center and killed two of them. The germs were apparently transmitted on inadequately sterilized medical scopes.

headline: A Bumpy Ride for the M.T.A.
text: Whether they fault the creaky trains or the endless track repairs or an aging communications network, millions of people who ride and depend upon mass transit in and around New York City are sensing a steady deterioration in the system.

headline: Prime Minister Seeks to Tighten Controls on Australians Suspected of Terrorism
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia said Monday that the government would seek to revoke the citizenship or curb the rights of Australians involved in terrorism and tighten immigration, visa and hate speech laws in a crackdown on terrorism.

headline: British Government Sells More of Its Stake in Lloyds Banking Group
text: LONDON — The British government has further reduced its stake in the Lloyds Banking Group, the bank said on Monday.

headline: 1965: Malcolm X Dies; Shot 4 Times at New York Rally
text: NEW YORK — Malcolm X, 39, the apostle of violence as a solution to the American Negro’s problems, was murdered today [Feb. 21].

headline: U.S. Expert Finds Faults in Chinese Military Command
text: As exchanges between the American and Chinese militaries increase, so, too, do the reports of publicly available research on the People’s Liberation Army by American experts working outside the Pentagon.

headline: Race, Foreign Armies and United States Colored Troops
text: On Feb. 14, 1865, while commanding the 32nd Colored Infantry during mop-up operations as part of Gen. William T. Sherman’s northern drive through South Carolina, Col. George Baird was wounded in fighting at James Island. Five days later, a Delaware native and formerly enslaved private named John Walter, of the 32nd’s Company K, shed blood in an explosion near Camden. Walter survived that event and received a $300 bounty when discharged in August, before disappearing from the public record.

headline: Would Arming College Students Help Prevent Sexual Assaults on Campus?
text: According to New York Times editorial “Campus Life and Guns“, “Lawmakers in 10 states are busy adapting the issue of campus sexual assaults to the campaign to arm college students. Carrying concealed weapons on college campuses is now banned in 41 states by law or university policy.”

headline: HSBC Profit Drops Sharply Amid Tax Backlash
text: LONDON — The British bank HSBC said on Monday that profit fell 15 percent in 2014, adding to the lender’s challenges as it continues to reel from revelations about efforts by its Swiss private banking arm to help wealthy clients evade taxes.

headline: Rescue Efforts Halted After Ferry Accident in Bangladesh
text: NEW DELHI — The authorities on Monday called off the search for survivors of a ferry accident in central Bangladesh, saying that 69 people, many of them women and children, died when the vessel capsized after a collision with a cargo ship on Sunday.

text: A major new study of smoking and death has banged more nails into the coffin of cigarette smoking, though chances are it will do little to persuade any of the 42 million American smokers to quit.

Kessler and Brian X. Chen report.

headline: Two Former Cabinet Ministers in Britain Deny Wrongdoing After Graft Allegations

headline: China Looks West to Bring ‘Wolf Totem’ to Screen
text: BEIJING — Ten years ago, when producers at the state-run Beijing Forbidden City Film Corporation began searching for a director for the movie adaptation of the Chinese novel “Wolf Totem” by Jiang Rong, they had no plans to look beyond China’s homegrown stable. It was a Chinese story, after all, written by a Chinese author, and had sold more than a million copies in this country in the year since its publication in 2004. (It has sold four million more there since.)

headline: Negotiators Weigh Plan to Phase Out Nuclear Limits on Iran
text: GENEVA — Iranian and American officials ended a round of high-level nuclear talks here on Monday considering a proposal that would strictly limit, for at least 10 years, Iran’s ability to produce nuclear material, but gradually ease restrictions on Tehran in the final years of any deal.

headline: Morning Agenda: Valeant Scoops Up Salix
text: VALEANT SCOOPS UP SALIX | Valeant Pharmaceuticals, the Canadian pharmaceutical company known for aggressively buying smaller drug companies, has agreed to pay $10.4 billion, or $158 a share in cash, for Salix Pharmaceuticals, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. Including debt, the transaction is valued at about $14.5 billion.

headline: Can Genetically Modified Bugs Save Lives?
text: Is it safe and sensible to put genetically changed mosquitoes into the environment to fight disease?

headline: Behind New Dietary Guidelines, Better Science
text: For decades, many dietary recommendations have revolved around consuming a low percentage of your daily calories from fat. It has been widely thought that doing so would reduce your chance of having coronary heart disease. Most of the evidence for that recommendation has come from epidemiologic studies, which can be flawed.

headline: We Keep Flunking Forecasts on Interest Rates, Distorting the Budget Outlook
text: Government economists try to predict the future of lots of indicators, including G.D.P., unemployment and inflation. Their record isn’t great, whether here or overseas. No less a figure than the Queen of England said to scholars at the London School of Economics about the deep recession in 2008: “Why did no one see it coming?”

headline: Honda, Grappling With Quality Problems, Will Replace Its President
text: TOKYO — Honda Motor said on Monday that it would replace its president and chief executive, Takanobu Ito, a sign the Japanese automaker may be trying to draw a line under recent quality problems.

text: WASHINGTON — Representative Alma Adams, a freshman Democrat from North Carolina, set a record the moment she took the oath of office. After winning election in November, she was sworn in immediately to fill a vacant seat, and for the first time in history, there were 100 women in Congress.

Kennedy Prize for a theatrical work inspired by American history, the stewards of the award announced Monday. A check for $100,000 will also go to Ms. Parks, a Pulitzer Prize winner for the drama “Topdog/Underdog.”

headline: 1890: Great Fire at Greenwich
text: LONDON—  A conflagration, which involved buildings nearly one hundred yards square, of a field of barrels of petroleum and over a dozen barges, all blazing at the same time, broke out at an early hour this morning [Feb. 23], and is still burning to-night. The scene of the outbreak was the Ordnance Wharf, Blackwall Lane, East Greenwich. Several engines were soon at the scene. Even then the flames were visible as far away as Southwark. The factory is about seventy yards long and fifty yards wide, and was used by the firm for general manufacturing purposes, and was crammed with thousands of tons of stock of the most inflammable description. How it originated is a mystery. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 24, 1890

headline: 1915: Russians in North Poland
text: PETROGRAD — The Germans have swept through Augustowo and are now fighting a fresh Russian column between Lypsk and Grodno, but they are being held at bay on the right banks of the Narew and Bebrz, they have not been able to invest either Osowiec or Lomza, and the Muscovites have resumed the offensive on the north bank of the Vistula, where Marshal von Hindenburg’s forces were most threatening to the safety of Warsaw. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 24, 1915

headline: Security Crackdown in Australia
text: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia announced national security revisions, including tighter immigration laws, and the revoking of citizenship or curbing rights of those involved in terrorism.

headline: As Tiger Woods Fades, a Fear That Revenue Will, Too
text: LOS ANGELES — Since joining the PGA Tour in 1996, Tiger Woods has been golf’s transcendent figure, credited with expanding the sport’s television audience, fan base, tournament purses and sponsorship deals. Over the last six years, he has missed chunks of time because of personal travails and injuries, enabling the tour to test its preparedness for life after the gold rush.

headline: Health Law Challenge Tests Supreme Court’s Firmness on Right to Sue
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court has developed elaborate tests to determine if plaintiffs have standing to sue. But their essence, Justice Antonin Scalia once observed, is a four-word question: “What’s it to you?”

headline: The Engel Macher
text: The end of January marked an important anniversary for those of us who work in women’s health care: the 42nd anniversary of Roe v. Wade. This eponymous Supreme Court decision carries a great deal of emotional weight, and once a year, much of this emotion boils over into a week of protests, both for and against it. The names “Roe” and “Wade” inspire passionate opinions in even the most apolitical of Americans; and yet, ironically, it was in a country where these two names are virtually unknown that I have learned the most about their legacy.

headline: How It Came to Be ‘Birdman’s’ Night
text: Well, there you go. With the Academy Awards, sometimes you just never know. Or, rather you do, if you know where to look.

headline: The Transformation of Duke Street
text: London’s quiet Duke Street, a few blocks from the international megastores on Mount Street, has seen an influx of boutiques with a decidedly local bent. The new location from the quirky-chic shoemaker Penelope Chilvers includes a studio for custom “dandy slippers,” and Philip Treacy’s protégée Laura Apsit Livens, a milliner to Rita Ora and the Duchess of Westminster, has set up her atelier inside a repurposed Victorian stairwell. Meanwhile, the historic men’s wear label E. Tautz — founded in 1867 and recently revived by the Norton & Sons designer Patrick Grant — just moved their first store into the neighborhood, with tailoring in the basement and the debut women’s collection on the racks. These boutiques join the recently opened Duke Street Emporium, a two-level concept store offering emerging fashion labels, beauty products and books amid exhibits from hometown artists.

headline: Oscars 2015: An Excellent Night for Prediction Markets
text: The prediction markets had another good year in predicting the Academy Awards. Perhaps more important, the categories that the markets seemed to get wrong underscored the ways in which such markets are useful without being clairvoyant.

headline: On the Ice Beat: Reporter’s Notebook
text: On Friday, the Times Metro reporter Tatiana Schlossberg, wearing three layers, boarded the Sturgeon Bay, a 140-foot Coast Guard icebreaker, and  wrote about her ride down the bone-chillingly cold Hudson River.

headline: A British View of Oscars Fashion
text: At the London shows Monday morning, the crowd, some looking bleary-eyed and sleep-deprived, rehashed the Oscars, which ended about 5 a.m. local time. There was palpable excitement about two key British wins, Eddie Redmayne for best actor and “The Imitation Game” for best adapted screenplay (though the actual winner, the writer Graham Moore, is American).

headline: At the Governors Ball, Winners and Even a Happy Also-Ran
text: One of the perks of being on the West Coast for an awards show is that it’s beholden to East Coast time. Which means when things finally wrap up after dragging on for far too long, it’s only, like, 9 p.m. Delighted to have a first awards season behind her, and having endured a surprise red carpet rainfall (the tent sprang massive leaks), the Bagger was torn between a determination to head home, stat – what else is there to say to people after three months of nonstop talking about the same thing, for heaven’s sakes? — and wanting to let off some steam.

headline: Patricia Arquette: To Every Woman Who Gave Birth to Every Taxpayer
text: There’s been a little backlash against Patricia Arquette’s decision to use her Oscar speech opportunity to call for wage equality for women. A little sniping that wage equality for women whose paychecks include six or even seven figures is a little different than wage equality on a lower scale. Even more complaining that Ms. Arquette “ruined it” with backstage commentary “dismissive” of equal rights for others.

headline: States Are Blocking Local Regulations, Often at Industry’s Behest
text: Darren Hodges, a Tea Party Republican and councilman in the windy West Texas city of Fort Stockton, is a fierce defender of his town’s decision to ban plastic bags. It was a local solution to a local problem and one, he says, city officials had a “God-given right” to make.

headline: At Burberry, Romantic (But Don’t Call Them “Smoky”) Eyes
text: The makeup artist Wendy Rowe built a layered beauty look for Burberry’s fall 2015 show. “It’s a folky collection that’s full of eclectic patterns and prints,” she explained backstage earlier today. “To complement that, I’ve created a patchwork of textures: a matte mouth, cashmere skin and iridescent eyes.” Keeping the skin very clean and the lips tinted nude, she focused on creating “romantic” but, crucially, not “smoky” eyes. After drawing a line along the upper and lower lids with cream eye shadow, Rowe then loosely blended beneath the eye for a worn-in finish. Her advice for artlessly recreating this disheveled feel: “It should look as though its been done in a rush.”

headline: Grandmother, Surrogate Mother
text: In 2012, Sara Connel wrote “Woman Gives Birth to Own Grandson” here (we both laughed at the opportunity to accurately use such a tabloid-style headline in this august space). headline: Picking Up a Memoir of Madness
text: On an early summer night in 1944, on the wooded shoulder of a rural Massachusetts highway, a man in a rumpled brown suit wandered in the shadows. Whenever a car passed, he dropped to the ground and lay flat. His hair was matted, his face smeared with mud. He was a respectable Boston doctor on the lam, hungry, lost and ill.

headline: Schism Emerges in Bikram Yoga Empire Amid Rape Claims
text: LOS ANGELES — He is the yoga guru who built an empire on sweat and swagger. He has a stable of luxury cars and a Beverly Hills mansion. During trainings for hopeful yoga teachers, he paces a stage in a black Speedo and holds forth on life, sex and the transformative power of his brand of hot yoga. “I totally cure you,” he has told interviewers. “Whatever the problem you have.”

headline: Debbie Harry on Four Decades of Blondie
text: On March 5, Carnegie Hall will host Tibet House’s 25th Annual Benefit Concert, whose ongoing aim is to preserve the awareness of Tibetan culture around the world. This year’s event has a lineup bursting with talent to match the organization’s quarter-century existence, with performances from the composer Philip Glass and the rock band the Flaming Lips. Perhaps most exciting, however, will be the appearance of the legendary troika of rock goddesses Laurie Anderson, Patti Smith and the Blondie frontwoman Debbie Harry. The latter of the trio, still going strong at 69, also has an upcoming run at the posh Café Carlyle, dozens of blocks north of the lower Manhattan landscape she’s been synonymous with for the past 40 years. Harry talked with T about what we can expect from her uptown persona, how she braves the frigid New York winter and why she thinks she became a music and style icon.

headline: IBM Tries to Paint the Computing Cloud Blue
text: IBM hopes everything looks better in IBM blue.

headline: New Directors/New Films Picks Sundance Hit for Opening Night
text: “The Diary of a Teenage Girl,” about a 15-year-old, Minnie, who has an affair with her mother’s boyfriend, was a hit at the Sundance Film Festival last month, and now the organizers of the annual New Directors/New Films series in New York have chosen it as their opening-night selection.

headline: Shola Olatoye on Her Name
text: Ms. Olatoye, chairwoman of the New York City Housing Authority, discusses the pronunciation of her name and its origin.

headline: Oscars 2015: Dull, Witless, Unjust … and Irresistible
text: Frank Bruni: Ross, I begin this conversation with a sense of shame and the feeling that we’re feeding a bad habit, because there’s no annual event in American life more excessively and obsequiously chronicled by those of us in the media than the Oscars. From September, when studios start unveiling their award-season showboats, to late February, when the statuettes are handed out in a ceremony whose long-winded dullness never ceases to amaze, we’re Oscar slaves. Oscar suckers. We should be stronger. We should resist.

headline: Finding the Right Balance of Time and Money
text: One summer, a friend of mine planned a river trip. The closest public airport was a day and a half’s drive from the river. So my friend decided to hire a private plane to get his group to the destination in a few hours. I know this choice sounds extravagant, but it represents a choice we’ve probably all experienced at some point.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘The Absolute Brightness of Leonard Pelkey’
text: The artist Jerry Marsini didn’t need to travel far to research his poster design for “The Absolute Brightness of Leonard Pelkey.” Written by and starring James Lecesne, a co-founder of the L.G.B.T. youth organization the Trevor Project, the show is about the murder of a gay artistically-minded 14-year-old in a small town.

headline: The 10 Best Dressed at the 87th Academy Awards
text: Red and white gowns dominated the red carpet last night at the 87th Academy Awards — and the after party. As usual, the evening wasn’t short on outfit changes (Emma Stone notably took off the stunning gold number she wore to the show and put on a red-and-white look for a night out), but a majority of the leading ladies got it right the first, and only, time. As for Lady Gaga and her three custom Azzedine Alaïa dresses: the one she arrived in, complete with a pair of red leather gloves that blew up Twitter, was the most unforgettable look of the night. Here, a look back at the evening’s most glamorous Oscars style.

headline: Meet Project Phoenix, the new NYT Android App
text: The New York Times reaches more readers today than ever before in its 164-year history thanks to the rise of mobile. On Android specifically, user growth in recent years has been explosive.

headline: With Palestinian Debt Rising, Israeli Utility Briefly Reduces Power to West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s state-owned electricity company briefly reduced the power supply to two Palestinian districts in the northern West Bank on Monday because of a ballooning debt, according to company officials, in a measure that also reflected the growing political disconnect between the Israeli and Palestinian sides.

headline: Valeant’s Deal for Salix Continues Frenzied Deal-Making in Drug Sector
text: Valeant Pharmaceuticals, which has a penchant for deals, has taken on a $10 billion company in its latest deal to buy Salix. Valeant’s pledge last year to focus on organic growth and debt reduction didn’t last long. Cost cuts and tax savings from buying Salix Pharmaceuticals proved irresistible.

headline: Food Habits Getting Worse Around the World
text: People in some poor and middle-income countries have healthier diets than those in rich ones, but major Western snack and soft drink makers are targeting children in ways that will damage their health, according to a new series of studies on obesity.

headline: London Fashion Week: Thomas Tait Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: What Flying Was Like Before the Smoke Cleared
text: IF you think the air travel experience generally stinks now, consider what it was like before smoking was banned on domestic flights 25 years ago.

headline: Statement Earrings at the 87th Academy Awards
text: Although statement necklaces created predictable buzz at last night’s red carpet, the more interesting jewelry moments came via large, sculptural diamond earrings. At the 2015 Academy Awards, Julianne Moore and Marion Cotillard donned round, elegant pairs, both by Chopard, while the young starlet Chloe Grace Moretz opted for a single, edgier ear cuff by Forevermark, proving that sometimes, one is better than two.

headline: This Winter Has Gotten Old
text: “Then I’m laying out my winter clothes and wishing I was gone, going home, where the New York City winters aren’t bleeding me.” So goes the Simon and Garfunkel song, buried deep in the memory, an oldie that seems to have been around for as long as this old winter has.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Helping Boys Succeed
Time for New Antlers
text: Q. When deer lose their antlers each year, do they grow back in the same pattern?

headline: Mothers’ Sounds Are Building Block for Babies’ Brains
text: The sound of a mother’s voice plays a critical role in a baby’s early development, multiple studies have shown. Now, researchers have demonstrated that the brain itself may rely on a mother’s voice and heartbeat to grow.

headline: Obama Warns of Homeland Dept. Shutdown
text: While addressing the National Governors Association, the president warned of the effects of a Department of Homeland Security shutdown on states’ economies.

headline: Meditation for a Good Night’s Sleep
text: Do you have chronic sleep problems? You may be able to significantly improve your ability to get a restful night of sleep by practicing a popular form of meditation, a rigorous new study shows.

headline: Why Jeb Bush Has Only One Photo From His Wedding
text: Jeb Bush’s wife, Columba, is in the spotlight this week, with new profiles out about her wariness of the family business and her expensive taste.

headline: Brocade’s Renaissance at London Fashion Week
text: In London, opulence and regality have taken center stage at many a fall 2015 fashion show, from the historic venues in which they took place — the Tate Britain art gallery and the Victoria and Albert Museum — to certain decadent details in the collections. And over the past few days, beautiful brocade fabrics have been ushered into the 21st century with dramatic shapes (a voluptuous cape at Simone Rocha), bold hues (rich berry-and-black palettes at Mary Katrantzou) and interesting lines (sophisticated patchwork and cutouts at Erdem).

headline: Wall St. and Law Firms Plan Cooperative Body to Bolster Online Security
text: The threat of ever-larger online attacks is bringing together Wall Street banks and the big law firms that do work for them in an alliance that could result in some sharing of basic information about digital security issues.

headline: According to the Words, the News Is Actually Good
text: We journalists pride ourselves on a willingness to bring you bad news. The more death and destruction, the more words and pictures. If it bleeds, it leads.

headline: New York City Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Are Suspended on Tuesday
text: Because of snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Thomas Tait: Fall 2015 RTW
text: London

headline: Sunday Routine Made Graphic
text: Sunday Routine, a regular Metropolitan section feature, looks at the way newsworthy New Yorkers spend a typical Sunday.

headline: Reuters Bureau Chief Is Found Dead in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistan and Afghanistan bureau chief for Reuters, Maria Golovnina, was found dead at her office in Islamabad on Monday, according to a statement by Reuters and Pakistani officials.

headline: Hunter Original: Fall 2015 RTW
text: London

headline: Wim Wenders, Man of the World
text: Wim Wenders explores pristine landscapes in his new documentary, “The Salt of the Earth,” about the photojournalist Sebastião Salgado. Here, he recalls his own memorable brush with the great outdoors.

headline: An Overture by Winter, Then Warmth and Energy
text: “Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon. My name is Yannick.” A ripple of laughter went through the audience at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday when the conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin took the microphone at the beginning of his Great Performers concert with the Rotterdam Philharmonic Orchestra. To his adoring and vocal fans, he needed no introduction: As music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Mr. Nézet-Séguin is a frequent guest in New York. But the ensemble he was presenting on this occasion — and which he has led as music director since 2008 — is still unfamiliar to American audiences.

headline: Ukraine Rebels Celebrate Their Taking of Debaltseve
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Pro-Russian rebels celebrated their recent victory at Debaltseve with a festive rally on Monday in Donetsk, the main city they control, where soldiers received medals in Lenin Square and the crowd cheered and waved Soviet flags.

headline: France Seizes 6 Passports Under Antiterrorism Law
text: PARIS — The French authorities began to use new, sweeping counterterrorism powers on Monday to halt the stream of young people going to Syria, confiscating the passports of six people suspected of trying to go there to engage in terrorist activities.

headline: An Inimitable Western
text: Jim Krantz’s cinematic vision of the American West.

headline: General Electric Deal for Alstom Raises Concerns Among European Authorities
text: PARIS — General Electric expressed confidence on Monday that its $13.5 billion acquisition of Alstom’s energy business would be completed, even after European antitrust authorities raised concerns about how it would affect competition in the market for heavy-duty gas turbines.

headline: Seeing Spots on the Women’s Fall 2015 Runways
text: The virtues of leopard print as a neutral are undersung. It goes with everything and is almost always in fashion — decade after decade, the print continues to find relevance, from Bettie Page’s midcentury pin-up swimsuits to Kate Moss’s signature vintage leopard coat. For fall/winter 2015, designers are revisiting leopard in new ways. First, in New York, Marc Jacobs used the print as trim on the collar and pockets of a metallic belted jacket, as well as on a matching bag. Across the pond at Erdem, the designer showed a ladylike leopard skirt suit, in homage to his Hitchcockian muses. Lastly, at Burberry, a demure midcalf-length leopard coat was toughened up with a built-in harness — Page would approve.

headline: At Vanity Fair’s Oscars Party, Jay Z and Beyoncé Steal the Show
text: It may have been the most exclusive party of the year, but it didn’t matter: Jay Z and Beyoncé can stop any room.

headline: Andreja Pejic Transforms at Giles
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in London. Here, the model Andreja Pejic before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Sacha Mascolo.

headline: The Power of a Tease and a Bobby Pin at Erdem
text: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Egypt and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: In Performance | Patrick Mulryan
text: Mr. Mulryan sings “Giants in the Sky” from the Fiasco Theater’s production of the musical “Into the Woods,” with Matt Castle on piano. The show is at the Laura Pels Theater through April 12.

headline: Feb. 23, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Egypt, Bangladesh, Maldives and Ukraine.

headline: Strong Sales for Larry David’s ‘Fish in the Dark’ on Broadway
text: The new Broadway comedy “Fish in the Dark,” written by and starring Larry David, set a box-office record for the Cort Theater last week, grossing $1,177,593, according to ticket sales data published on Monday. The previous record was set by the 2010 revival of “Fences,” starring Denzel Washington, during its final week of performances, when the play grossed $1,175,626. “Fish in the Dark,” in which Mr. David plays the son of a dying family patriarch, is still in preview performances; the critics’ reviews will come out after opening night on March 5.

headline: Readers Respond: On ‘My Own Life’
text: The neurologist whose writing opened a popular window on a medical “awakening” of the human mind shared his personal awakening after receiving a terminal cancer diagnosis. Readers responded to Oliver Sacks’ “My Own Life” with gratitude.

headline: Oscars TV Ratings Fall 15 Percent
text: LOS ANGELES – Ratings tumbled 15 percent for this year’s Oscars ceremony on Sunday, delivering the least-watched show in six years, according to Nielsen data.

headline: Feeding Infants Peanut Products Could Prevent Allergies, Study Suggests
text: Turning what was once conventional wisdom on its head, a new study suggests that many, if not most peanut allergies can be prevented by feeding young children food containing peanuts beginning in infancy, rather than avoiding such foods.

headline: ‘Snow Snow Snow,’ and East Coast Skiers Rejoice
text: In early February, the outdoor sports website Teton Gravity Research posted a video of a skier plunging down an alpine chute in thigh-deep powder, slaloming through evergreens and yelping with joy as clumps of snow pelted his goggles.

headline: Christopher Kane’s Perfectly Pink Crocodile Booties
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Vice Media vs. Brooklyn Indie Music Clubs
text: When word spread eight months ago that Vice Media was moving into a complex of warehouses on the Williamsburg waterfront in Brooklyn, supporters of two indie-music clubs being displaced accused the company of violating the very spirit of hipness and authenticity that it had seemingly built its brand upon.

headline: Review: In ‘The Buried Giant,’ Ishiguro Revisits Memory and Denial
text: Kazuo Ishiguro’s latest novel, “The Buried Giant,” is an eccentric, ham-handed fairy tale with a jumble of story lines lifted from “Beowulf,” Arthurian legend and assorted folk traditions. It is recounted in stilted, formalistic language that’s presumably meant to evoke a bygone era, and set in a mythical Britain equally reminiscent of “The Lord of the Rings” and “Game of Thrones.” King Arthur’s knight Sir Gawain is a major character, and so is a she-dragon named Querig.

headline: As ‘Ida’ Wins an Oscar, Poland Ends a Losing Streak
text: WARSAW — The utter tenacity with which the director Pawel Pawlikowski talked and talked and refused to be shooed off stage by the Oscar orchestra has been matched only by the Polish film industry’s own persistent, decades-long pursuit of international recognition.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
text: Sometimes the anticipation for the game builds all week until Saturday’s kickoff. And sometimes you only have to wait a day. Here’s what you should watch this week.

headline: Stifel Financial to Acquire Sterne Agee
text: Stifel Financial, the financial services firm, said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire smaller rival Sterne Agee Group in a deal valued at about $150 million.

headline: Married Sex Gets Better in the Golden Years
text: Yes, there is sex after marriage. Particularly if you make it past your 50th wedding anniversary.

headline: Reviews: New Albums From Big Sean, Emile Haynie and DRKWAV
text: EMILE HAYNIE

headline: Funding Fight Over Homeland Security Poses Dangers for the G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — After promising an era of responsible governing and an end to federal shutdowns, congressional Republicans find themselves mired in an immigration fight that could cause funding for the Department of Homeland Security to run out on Friday.

headline: The Tangled Roots of English
text: The peoples of India, Iran and Europe speak a Babel of tongues, but most — English included — are descended from an ancient language known as proto-Indo-European. Scholars have argued for two centuries about the identity and homeland of those who spoke this parent language, but a surprisingly sudden resolution of this longstanding issue may be at hand.

headline: New York’s Fluoridation Fuss, 50 Years Later
text: In March 1957, as Elvis was buying Graceland and the Soviets were preparing to shock the world with Sputnik, Robert F. Wagner, the famously cautious mayor of New York, was having trouble taking a stand.

headline: Marine Life Study Suggests Bigger Is Better for Successful Evolution
text: Cope’s rule states that evolution favors larger bodies, suggesting that the average size of animals on the planet should always trend upward. The hypothesis has its proponents, but there has been scant evidence to support it.

headline: ‘Gangland Undercover’ and ‘Outlaw Country’ Examine Biker Life
text: It’s an interesting week in the ever-evolving relationship between television and crime. The History channel, no doubt hoping to fill the “Sons of Anarchy” void, puts motorcycle gangs back on the air with “Gangland Undercover,” based on a federal informant’s real story. And WGN tries to push the police ride-along show to the next dubious level by adding a potential-lawbreaker ride-along.

headline: Mouse Brain May Give Insight Into Diseases of Human Mind
text: When injected with bits of human DNA, mouse embryos grew brains that were 12 percent larger than those of embryos injected with the same genes from chimpanzees. Scientists at Duke University, writing in the journal Current Biology, say the experiment demonstrates the role that a particular gene sequence, HARE5, plays in the development of the human brain, which is far heavier and more complex than the brains of our closest animal cousins. The research also may help reveal why humans develop conditions like Alzheimer’s and autism, but chimpanzees do not.

headline: Formula for Headache-Free Flying: Pack Only a Phone and a Book
text: I’VE spent my career in the hospitality industry, and in 2008 started my own company, AJ Capital Partners. My business is investing in and restoring hotel properties to their glorious state, and right now we have about nine projects underway in cities across the United States.

headline: Review: Carmen de Lavallade’s One-Woman Show Comes to New York
text: What does it mean when an 83-year-old woman says, “Once I was beautiful”? Carmen de Lavallade is 83, and when she speaks those words in her autobiographical one-woman show, “As I Remember It,” their truth is unmistakable. You can see it in the projected photos and videos from her youth as a celebrated dancer and actress. But there is also the evidence of Ms. de Lavallade in the present, belying the verb tense. Her beauty is not a thing of the past.

text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

text: A collection of space program images, dating from 1946 to the end of NASA’s lunar missions in 1972.

headline: Oscars Show Growing Gap Between Moviegoers and Academy
text: LOS ANGELES — In the end, it was the audience that got snubbed.

text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: Disney Names Robert Chapek Chairman for Theme Parks
text: LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company on Monday handed the reins of its sprawling theme park operation to a fast-rising executive known for streamlining the entertainment giant’s merchandise division.

headline: Please Stop Making That Noise
text: I can’t stand it when someone behind me at a movie chews popcorn with his or her mouth open. I mean, I really can’t stand it.

headline: Rarely Seen Images From Space Including the ‘Best Selfie Ever’
text: Hundreds of photographs from the early years of the space age are for sale. That includes the first image taken from space — from an altitude of 65 miles by a camera on a V-2 rocket launched from the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico on Oct. 24, 1946. (The boundary to outer space is generally placed at 100 kilometers, or 62.1 miles.)

headline: Tiananmen Square ‘Negatives’: An Art Book or a Protest?
text: BEIJING — The latest book by the photographer Xu Yong is filled with the images of young Chinese idealists clamoring for democracy and denouncing the Communist Party, but he insists that there is nothing political about his decision to publish this trove of snapshots he had kept hidden for more than two decades.

headline: Former Chinese Premier Draws Praise for His Philanthropy
text: Since Zhu Rongji stepped down as premier of China in 2003, he has pursued interests including playing a type of fiddle called the huqin, writing best sellers and practicing philanthropy. It is this last activity, in particular, that returned Mr. Zhu to the spotlight, while also drawing attention to how unusual such charity is among former Chinese politicians.

headline: Christie Broke Law With Pension Move, New Jersey Judge Says
text: In a major blow to Gov. Chris Christie, a New Jersey judge ruled on Monday that he violated state law when he declined to make the full payment into the state’s pension system for public employees last year and ordered him to find a way to fund it now.

headline: The Next Big Military Civil Rights Issue: Transgender Service
text: Defense Secretary Ashton Carter got it right on Sunday when he said that nothing but “suitability for service” should “preclude” transgender people from serving openly in the military — in other words, ability to do the job.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Chegg Is Shifting Its Services to Focus on Digital Push
text: Chegg, the textbook rental service, is planning a big reinvention of its operations a little more than a year after going public.

headline: A New Lens on a Blurred History
text: Xu Yong’s “Negatives,” with images of the protests that convulsed Beijing in the spring of 1989, is likely to be viewed as a provocation by the hard-liners who govern China.

headline: She Runs S.E.C. He’s a Lawyer. Recusals and Headaches Ensue.
text: Their legal careers, and by extension their marriage, are the stuff of lore. Mary Jo White leads the Securities and Exchange Commission; her husband, John, practices law at an old-guard firm as elite as the corporations it represents. Together, they are a legal power couple that straddles Wall Street and Washington like few others.

headline: Justices Weigh Denial of Visa to Husband of U.S. Citizen
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday did not seem inclined to second-guess the denial of a visa on national security grounds to the Afghan husband of an American woman.

headline: London Fashion Week: Peter Pilotto Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: London Fashion Week: Peter Pilotto Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: For an Iraqi Expatriate, ‘American Sniper’ Both Draws and Repels
text: Like many others, I was intrigued by the attention the film “American Sniper” was getting. I knew I was treading murky waters, but I decided to follow the herd and see the movie. Unlike most people in the crowd, I had a very personal stake in the film. “American Sniper” takes place in Iraq, my homeland, which I left shortly after the American-led invasion that Chris Kyle took part in. So the film, powerful and sad, left me with mixed thoughts and reminiscences.

headline: London Fashion Week: Christopher Kane Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: London Fashion Week: Christopher Kane Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: ‘A Bronx Tale’ Musical to Debut at Paper Mill Playhouse in New Jersey
text: Chazz Palminteri’s semi-autobiographical story “A Bronx Tale” has been a movie (directed by and starring Robert De Niro) and a Broadway solo show (directed by the Tony Award winner Jerry Zaks). Now it’s coming back again as a musical – with Mr. De Niro and Mr. Zaks teaming up as directors. The Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., announced on Monday that the world premiere of “A Bronx Tale” musical will be one of five shows in its 2015-16 season, running Feb. 4-March 6, 2016. “A Bronx Tale” features music by the Tony winner Alan Menken (“Newsies”), lyrics by Glenn Slater, and a book by Mr. Palminteri (who will not be a member of the cast this time around); Sergio Trujillo is the choreographer.

headline: Jim Krantz’s Wild West
text: The Chicago-based commercial photographer Jim Krantz’s work has been famous in the art world for years. Krantz himself has been less so — a fact that perhaps requires some explanation. In the 1990s, Krantz, who had been documenting the cinematic vistas of the American West and its people with his camera for 20 years, went to Texas to photograph cowboys for a Marlboro advertising campaign. The final product caught the eye of Richard Prince, the “appropriation artist” who had achieved renown by photographing ads and presenting the resulting images in galleries and museums. Beginning in the 1980s, Prince reproduced images from Marlboro ads for his “Cowboys” series. One such print, at the time of its sale in 2005, was the most expensive photograph ever sold at auction.

headline: An Embedded Photographer Empowers the Poor
text: A Bangladeshi photographer who tired of seeing poverty portrayed in the usual ways had a brainstorm: He lived with his subjects and had them collaborate with him.

headline: Mary Jo White — From Prosecutor to Regulator
text: Before President Obama named Mary Jo White to run the Securities and Exchange Commission, she was the top federal prosecutor in New York City.

headline: Greece Delays Submittal of Its Overhaul Plans
text: ATHENS — Greece on Monday delayed the submission of the proposed reforms that European creditors have made a condition of the country’s financial aid.

headline: The Best Sellers: Filed Under Sports
text: The best-selling sports books in January 2015, according to the New York Times best-seller list.

headline: Google Guns for Apple in Mobile Payments Race
text: Technology companies have spent years trying to persuade people to put away their credit cards and pay with mobile phones instead, but consumers have mostly shrugged. Now, with the release of Apple’s Apple Pay application, the race to replace credit cards with mobile phones has turned into a brawl.

headline: Alan Howard, Actor With Royal Shakespeare Company, Dies at 77
text: Alan Howard, a celebrated English actor whose regal bearing and imposing voice gave life to a spate of Shakespearean kings, died on Feb. 14 in London. He was 77.

headline: Jeb Bush Looms Large for Marco Rubio in 2016
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, stood in front of reporters before a book signing here, pondering the question that has dogged him ever since Jeb Bush announced his plans to pursue a presidential bid: How does a Bush candidacy complicate Mr. Rubio’s own Oval Office aspirations, especially among donors?

headline: Defense Chief Vouches for U.S. Strategy on ISIS
text: CAMP ARIFJAN, Kuwait — The new defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter, said Monday after meeting with senior American military and diplomatic officials in Kuwait that the Obama administration had “the ingredients of the strategy” to defeat Islamic State militants in Iraq and Syria.

headline: A Photographic Memory
text: A collection of space program photographs, dating from 1946 to the end of NASA’s lunar mission in 1972.

headline: Chemicals Permitted in the U.S. but Banned in the E.U.
text: A sampling of pesticides and other chemicals used in the United States but prohibited in European Union countries.

headline: A Pesticide Banned, or Not, Underscores Trans-Atlantic Trade Sensitivities
text: LONDON — Syngenta, a Swiss chemicals company, produces one of America’s most popular herbicides. It is called atrazine, and 73.7 million pounds of the chemical compound were applied in the United States in 2013. It was used on more than half of all corn crops, two-thirds of sorghum and up to 90 percent of sugar cane.

headline: Columbia Hires Ex-Penn Coach Al Bagnoli, Surprising Its Ivy Peers
text: Three months after he retired with nine Ivy League titles in 23 seasons at the University of Pennsylvania, Al Bagnoli stunned the conference on Monday when he abruptly joined Columbia as its new football coach.

headline: Rebirth of the Cool: American Music Makes a Return to Iran
text: TEHRAN — The audience members in Tehran’s Vahdat concert hall rose from their seats, clapping wildly as the frontman Bob Belden, a fun-loving New Yorker with a predilection for loud shirts, rested his soprano saxophone on a nearby stand.

headline: 12 at Wesleyan University Are Hospitalized for Drug Overdoses
text: MIDDLETOWN, Conn. — Late on Sunday morning, students at Wesleyan University received an email from a university official: Three students had been taken to hospitals, apparently for drug overdoses, and one was in critical condition.

headline: Joey Logano’s Daytona Victory Fulfills Early Promise
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Jeff Gordon’s last Daytona 500 began as an ode to his legacy, but it might be best remembered as a harbinger of what is to come in Nascar.

headline: Jurors in Patz Case View Suspect’s First Confession
text: The tearful confession came after six and a half hours of interrogation, and yet, when it was over, the man now on trial in the murder of 6-year-old Etan Patz had left key questions unanswered.

headline: A Marine Is Convicted on Two Counts of Desertion
text: Wassef Ali Hassoun, a Marine corporal accused of faking his abduction in Iraq in 2004 and evading punishment for years by fleeing to Lebanon, was found guilty on Monday of two counts of desertion. He was sentenced to two years in prison by a military judge at Camp Lejeune, N.C., and given a dishonorable discharge.

headline: E.P.A. Issues Stiffer Rules on Vehicle Fuel Ratings
text: WASHINGTON — After two years of imposing increasingly stiff penalties on automakers that overstate their fuel economy ratings, federal regulators on Monday said they would tighten guidelines used in determining the mileage advertised to consumers.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 23, 2015
Refugees Are Pushed to Exits in Pakistan
text: TORKHAM, Afghanistan — First, the Afghan families’ homes were raided by Pakistani policemen wielding sticks. Then the men were hauled off to jail, released only after relatives paid bribes.

headline: Amex’s Loss in Court May Not Help Consumers
text: Last week, a federal judge handed down a major ruling against American Express, deciding that the brand-name card issuer had engaged in anticompetitive practices for more than a decade.

headline: Red Sox Place a Big Bet on the Latest Prospect From Cuba
text: Yoan Moncada sits at the intersection of dollars and dreams. He is a blank slate, completely unknown beyond the relatively few people who have watched him play. His potential, therefore, seems limitless.

headline: Metro-North Engineer Tried to Slow Train Before Crash With S.U.V., Report Says
text: Nearly three weeks after a fatal Metro-North Railroad crash, the National Transportation Safety Board released a summary of its preliminary findings on Monday, but official conclusions about the cause of the crash are months away.

headline: The Horrors Keep Coming at Rikers
text: Nearly a year has passed since Mayor Bill de Blasio installed Joseph Ponte as his correction commissioner and charged him with reforming the house-of-horrors city jail system at Rikers Island, where guards have routinely beaten inmates bloody as a matter of course. The mayor has since shaken up the jail system’s management team, committed new resources to the reform project and pledged to make cleaning up the jails a top priority.

headline: For Mets With Major Injuries, an Incentive and a Memento
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — When Matt Harvey went into the training room for his normal routine Monday morning, Dave Pearson, the Mets’ minor league rehabilitation coordinator, shook his hand, congratulated him for finishing the rehabilitation program and presented him with a small coin, a token of appreciation for his hard work.

headline: Rhode Island City May Lose Its Red Sox and, Mayor Says, Its Heart
text: For decades, the Pawtucket Red Sox have been a minor league team as familiar to baseball fans as the Toledo Mud Hens, the Memphis Redbirds, the Durham Bulls or the Birmingham Barons. Playing at McCoy Stadium, which opened during World War II, the Rhode Island team, commonly known as the PawSox, has sent future stars such as Jim Rice, Carlton Fisk, Nomar Garciaparra, Roger Clemens, Mo Vaughn and Jacoby Ellsbury to the big club in Boston.

headline: Review: In ‘Big Love,’ Fleeing Tradition Becomes a Messy Escape
text: They’re bouncing off the walls in Tina Landau’s frenzied revival of “Big Love,” Charles Mee’s 2000 play of things martial and marital according to Aeschylus. They’re also dangling from ropes and jumping on trampolines and rolling on the floor and fighting with tooth, claw, knives and slices of wedding cake. Well, as the song says, that’s amore.

headline: Review: ‘The Insurgents’ Stars Cassie Beck in a Lucy Thurber Drama
text: Beware, America! Sally Wright, a young woman who spends a lot of time with a shotgun in her hands, is having one whale of a nervous breakdown. It is, you might say, a breakdown as big as a whole country, and it’s been building for centuries.

headline: Shades of Grey
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Elizabeth Long’s puzzle is certainly timely. With the Feb. 13 release of the movie version of E. L. James’s novel, “50 Shades of Grey,” you might think that the theme of today’s puzzle ventures into non-standards-friendly territory, but it doesn’t. Today, Ms. Long is really thinking about shades that belong to people with the surname Grey.

headline: Bill Gates and Other Business Leaders Urge U.S. to Increase Energy Research
text: The government is spending far too little money on energy research, putting at risk the long-term goals of reducing carbon emissions and alleviating energy poverty, some of the country’s top business leaders found in a new report.

headline: ‘Sleepy Hollow’ Season 2 Finale Recap: Abbie Goes Back
text: Season 2, Episode 18: “Tempus Fugit”

headline: New York Attorney General Is Said to Review Casino Bidding Process
text: ALBANY — The state attorney general’s office has opened a preliminary inquiry into the process by which three projects were recently recommended for new casino licenses, according to two former bidders who were later contacted by investigators.

headline: Israeli Views on Iran Diverged, Reports Say
text: JERUSALEM — Shortly after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel’s dire warning at the United Nations in 2012 that Iran was a mere months away from being able to develop a nuclear bomb, Israel’s Mossad intelligence agency presented a more sober assessment that did not support Mr. Netanyahu’s timetable.

headline: Presumed Heir of Indian Party Requests Leave of Absence
text: NEW DELHI — Rahul Gandhi, long expected to be the next leader of India’s beleaguered Congress Party, threw political commentators into fits of baffled speculation on Monday when party officials announced that he had requested a leave of absence because he wants time to think.

headline: Ben Woolf, Actor in ‘American Horror Story,’ Dies at 34
text: Ben Woolf, a former teacher who took up acting and found success on the television show “American Horror Story,” died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 34.

headline: Bill O’Reilly and Fox News Redouble Defense of His Falklands Reporting
text: The Fox News host Bill O’Reilly on Monday stepped up his defense against reports that he embellished stories about his war reporting earlier in his career, while some former colleagues continued to say he had exaggerated his experiences.

headline: A Jarring Blast Arrives Without Warning
text: A man with a baby fled a cloud of heavy black smoke on Monday after a tanker truck carrying almost 9,000 gallons of fuel caught fire on a major southern New Jersey highway in Pennsauken.

headline: New York City Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Are Suspended on Tuesday
text: Because of snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Recap: Don’t Worry Saul, It’s All Good, Man
text: Season 1, Episode 4: “Hero”

headline: After Surge in Young Migrants on Long Island, Groups Team Up to Bolster Services
text: A partnership of New York groups and a state agency said Monday that it would invest about $500,000 to provide legal, mental health and educational support to children on Long Island who recently arrived as part of a surge in illegal migration from Central America.

headline: New Housing to Benefit as Citigroup Sells Queens Site
text: In 1989, Citigroup, the financial services giant, erected New York City’s tallest tower outside Manhattan in Queens, where city officials hoped to establish a new commercial district.

headline: A Melancholy — and Danceable — New Song from Brooklyn’s San Fermin
text: The Brooklyn-based baroque-pop octet San Fermin doesn’t approach new songs the way most bands in its zip code do — by assembling in a rehearsal space and jamming until something worth recording emerges. Instead, its songwriter and composer Ellis Ludwig-Leone writes preliminary versions of all eight parts for each new song himself, and then delivers them to his bandmates in the basement below his apartment, where they gather to practice. “The worst thing that I ever do with the band is rehearse a new song with them,” he says with a laugh. “Suddenly it’s like, ‘Oh, my God, I hope this is good, because we’re going to have to play this hundreds of times,’ and it’s terrifying.”

headline: A Winter Salad Recipe from Andrew Carmellini, in Honor of Bon Appétit’s New Kitchen
text: Bon Appétit magazine’s BA Kitchen was already home to some of the most exclusive culinary events in the city, having opened its doors to celebrated chefs such as Carlo Mirarchi (Roberta’s), David Kinch (Manresa) and Inaki Aizpitarte (Le Chateaubriand). But now, with Condé Nast an official tenant of One World Trade Center, the ad hoc dining club will have a setting worthy of its food. “As good as a job as we did before, you can’t compare it to being on the 35th floor of the World Trade Center overlooking the city with a view of the Empire State,” says the Bon Appétit editor in chief Adam Rapoport, who co-hosts the new space’s opening party this evening. And he’s tapped the James Beard Award-winning chef Andrew Carmellini to christen the place. “Adam’s an old friend, and we’re in the neighborhood already,” explains Carmellini, whose fashionable restaurants (Little Park, the Dutch, Locanda Verde) are, like the new Condé Nast headquarters, a Lower Manhattan fixture. “We’re going to have a party.”

headline: Accent on Singing in Coming Jazz at Lincoln Center Season
text: Jazz at Lincoln Center’s 2015-16 season, with the theme “Jazz and American Song,” will feature a sustained emphasis on vocal music in the blues, jazz and pop traditions.

First he squandered his initial strength in national polls — he holds 6 to 7 percent of the vote among Republican contenders, down from about 20 percent before the scandal involving the closing of lanes to the George Washington Bridge.

headline: An Embedded Photographer Empowers the Poor
text: Scenes of poverty are inescapable in a country like Bangladesh, where Western media and charities use them to generate outrage, sympathy and — sometimes — donations. That bothered Shehab Uddin, a former newspaper photographer in Bangladesh who knew there was more to the story than downtrodden people victimized by poverty, not to mention photojournalists.

headline: More New Jobs Are in City Centers, While Employment Growth Shrinks in the Suburbs
text: For decades, most Americans working in metropolitan areas have gone to work outside city centers – in suburban office parks, stores or plants, not downtown skyscrapers. But as people increasingly choose to live in cities instead of outside them, employers are following.

headline: V.A. Secretary Apologizes for Embellishing Military Record
text: Robert A. McDonald, the secretary of the Veterans Affairs Department, apologized on Monday for falsely claiming last month that he had served in the Special Forces.

headline: What’s On TV Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) A LITTLE ROMANCE (1979) Lauren (Diane Lane, above right), a 13-year-old American living in Paris with her stepfather (Arthur Hill) and mother (Sally Kellerman) — who is currently enamored of a pretentious filmmaker (George De Marco) — falls in love with Daniel (Thelonious Bernard, center). He is a French film buff, and together they arrange a rendezvous under the Bridge of Sighs in Venice with the help of an aging pickpocket (Laurence Olivier, left). “Lauren and Daniel are, I think, meant to be comic and appealing in their mixture of innocence and worldliness,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. Yet the film, directed by George Roy Hill, “recalls most vividly the arch manner in which the Our Gang comedies worked — by having their child actors ape not the behavior of children but of grown-ups.” Georges Delerue won an Oscar for best original score.

headline: Scientology’s Chilling Effect
text: When I was at Fortune magazine in the 1990s, one of my colleagues was a reporter named Richard Behar. He had a special lock on his door, and he wouldn’t even let the janitor in to empty his wastebasket. He used a secret phone, which he kept hidden in a desk drawer, so that calls made to sources couldn’t be traced back to him.

headline: Conspiracy Claims in Venezuela

headline: When the Best Sex Is Extramarital
text: I received a voice mail from a 40-something woman, Cynthia, who requested a late-evening session because she worked long hours at her law firm. She said that I was one of the few therapists she had Googled who seemed to have the expertise to help her. In recent years I have noticed that when potential patients Google me, they discover my university faculty profile, where I list as a research interest the psychology of infidelity. They also find a YouTube clip of an interview with me from a documentary on infidelity. Thanks to Google I am getting more patients looking for someone they think of as an infidelity expert.

headline: Morning Agenda: Power Couple Ties Up S.E.C.
text: POWER COUPLE TIES UP S.E.C. | Mary Jo White, who leads the Securities and Exchange Commission, and her husband, John, who practices law at an elite old-guard firm, are “a legal power couple that straddles Wall Street and Washington like few others,” DealBook’s Peter Eavis and Ben Protess write. But their careers can at times collide, creating headaches for the S.E.C. as it pursues wrongdoing in the nation’s financial markets, according to interviews with lawyers and a review of federal records.

headline: Rahm Emanuel Forced Into Runoff in Bid for Second Term as Chicago Mayor
text: CHICAGO — Rahm Emanuel, who was easily elected mayor of this city four years ago, was dealt a setback Tuesday. Though he came in first among five candidates, Mr. Emanuel failed to seal a second term by winning support from enough voters to avoid a riskier runoff election this spring.

headline: Twin Pole-Vaulters Reach the Height of Alikeness
text: BLACK SPRINGS, Ark. — Just off Highway 8, amid the cattle pastures, chicken houses and hog farms in these rolling hills, is Pole Vault Lane. Its short, gravelly path is decorated with pennants, and it leads to a metal building about half the length of a football field. It is a hangar of sorts, or, more accurately, an indoor runway designed to produce short but spectacular flight.

headline: Words We Love Too Much
text: Perhaps hoping to disprove the cliché that journalists hate math, we seem eager to sprinkle a couple of math-related terms as liberally as possible in our prose. Unfortunately, this casual usage is more likely to suggest fuzziness or even laziness than rigor and precision.

headline: Buffalo Embraces Winter’s Chill
text: At Buffalo’s newest outdoor rink, Canalside, teenage couples skated hand in hand, while a few stumbling toddlers nearly pulled their parents down. From a pedestrian bridge above the ice, spectators drank Flying Bison beer and bit into hot sandwiches from nearby food trucks. Stereos pumped Bob Marley, although the tropical beat belied the 20-degree temperatures. All around the double-sized rink, market vendors under striped awnings sold jewelry, hockey sticks and sweatshirts printed with “We Made Snow Famous” and “Buffalonians Never Say Die.”

headline: Restaurant Report: Green Street Smoked Meats in Chicago
text: Chicago does not want for meat in general, or the barbecued kind in particular. The city Carl Sandburg called the “hog butcher for the world" boils over with stellar kielbasas and, at least on the South Side, Delta-style vinegar-forward barbecue. There’s even a mash-up of traditional barbecue and Eastern European meats called boilbecue (not recommended by this meat-eater).

headline: An Outpouring of Love and Onesies
text: Possibly because I’m a guy, I never really thought too hard about giving people baby gifts. It was just something that did not often cross my mind. When one of my friends or family members said that they were having a baby, I might have halfheartedly found them something off their registry that wasn’t too cheap, or just sent them a gift card, figuring that they may need it for diapers. If I found myself cruising the baby aisles of Target, it tended to be so overwhelming that I found the first age-appropriate toy I could, whether I thought the child could use it or not. Let’s just say that gift receipts were key.

headline: 1890: Arizona’s Catastrophe
text: NEW YORK — The disaster at the dam on the Hassayampa River, near Prescott, Arizona, is the most fearful catastrophe in the history of the territory. The valley for miles below the dam was swept clean. The first intimation of the appalling disaster was a sound resembling thunder, and at the same instant a perpendicular wall of water, fully 50 feet high, came rushing down the narrow valley. The valley widens above Wickenburg, and much of the town lies upon lowlands close to the course of the stream, and it was almost certain that the vast body of water which rushed out of the reservoir had carried away many houses at that place. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 25, 1890

headline: Review: Robert Christgau Reflects on His Career as a Rock Critic
text: Here’s a cardinal rule of book criticism: Never blame someone for writing a book that’s different from the one you wanted him to write. But Robert Christgau’s memoir, “Going Into the City: Portrait of a Critic as a Young Man,” is so far from what I wanted that I can’t pretend I’m not crestfallen.

headline: James Baldwin Denounced Richard Wright’s ‘Native Son’ As a ‘Protest Novel.’ Was He Right?

headline: 1965: State of Siege Is Declared
text: GUATEMALA CITY — Col. Enrique Peralta Azurdia’s government suspended the constitution and decreed a state of siege throughout Guatemala today [Feb. 24] because of what was called an attempt to overthrow his regime. Col. Peralta said ‘‘several groups of armed men have attacked civilians and authorities as part of a widespread plan to spread terror.’’ The national radio broadcast the state of siege decree, saying that it would be in effect as long as necessary. There was no immediate information as to who the plotters Col. Peralta referred to might be. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 25, 1965

headline: Scores of Syrian Christians Kidnapped by Islamic State

headline: Smutty Books for Smart People
text: Trashy novels aren’t new, but thanks to a highbrow approach to Harlequin tropes, the people who buy them might be. This month, the online art magazine Triple Canopy is set to release “Headless,” a salacious murder mystery that reads like Dan Brown while name-checking Georges Bataille. Delving into full-on erotica, Badlands Unlimited — the book press established five years ago by the 2014 Hugo Boss Prize-winning artist Paul Chan — will publish a series of three novellas titled “We Love Lucy,” “How to Train Your Virgin” and “God, I Don’t Even Know Your Name,” the story of an artist who, fresh out of rehab, meets a Finnish curator through a dating app called Bangly. “Ideas about what sex is, and what pleasure can be, are changing, as they ought to,” says Chan. “We wanted to publish works that respond to this new spirit.”

headline: Pensions Haunt Christie 4 Years After Being ‘Fixed’
text: TRENTON — Four years ago, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey signed bipartisan legislation to overhaul public employee pensions and declared he had “fixed” the problem that was crushing state and local governments across the country with enormous debts. He held up New Jersey as a model.

headline: Private Equity Leaders Focusing on Returning Money to Investors
